DOC.HEAD: With AM-Soviet-Baltics, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Alexander Dubcek, ousted from power by the Soviet 22 years ago in Czechoslovakia, on Monday said Lithuanians should negotiate their independence with Moscow and that neither side should provoke the use of force. Dubcek, one of three senior officials in the Czechoslovak government, ended a four-day official visit, his first since 1968, with a meeting with President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. He told a news conference that time and patience were needed to resolve the impasse between the Kremlin and the breakaway Baltic republic, which declared independence March 11. Dubcek said the Lithuanian declaration was ``something that happened in such a way that solution is not possible today, but will be possible tomorrow.'' Although every nation has the right to self-determinaion, he said, Lithuania and the Soviet Union should look for ``optimum solutions and compromise to settle the issue and arrive at a transition period during which emotions die down.'' Both sides, Dubcek aid, ``should not lose patience, and avoid any possible conflict.'' As leader of the Czechoslovak Communist Party, he led the ``Prague Spring'' movement in 1968 and ran afoul of the Soviet hardliners who ordered Warsaw Pact forces to invade on Aug. 21 that year. Tass quoted Gorbachev as discussing the invasion with Dubcek. ``That action had a negative effect on the development of the Soviet Union itself, led to a freeze of planned reforms and slowed down the natural development of progressive processes and pushed the country to the blind alleys of stagnation,'' Gorbachev said.

DOC.HEAD: `Bird on a Wire' Opens Strongly, `Cadillac Man' Stalls
DOC.TEXT: The Mel Gibson-Goldie Hawn comedy ``Bird on a Wire'' soared at the box office, finishing on top with ticket sales of $15.3 million. The Univeral Pictures release averaged $7,890 per screen over the weekend, more than double that of the other new summer film, ``Cadillac Man,'' according to figures released Tuesday by Entertainment Data Inc. ``Cadillac Man,'' starring Robin Williams as a used car salesman dodging love gone bad, debuted in second place with $6.7 million. The poorly reviewed comedy should disappear soon as a wave of other holiday titles arrives. In third was the Richard Gere-Julia Roberts comedy ``Pretty Woman,'' with receipts of $6.3 million. Fourth were the pizza-eating ``Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles,'' with $3.3 million. ``Ninja Turtles'' has grossed more than $114 million. Here are the top movie ticket sales for Friday through Sunday as tallied by Entertainment Data, with distributor, weekend gross, number of theater screens, average per screen, total gross and number of weeks in release. Figures are based on a combination of actual box-office receipts and studio projections where actual figures are not immediately available. 1. ``Bird on a Wire,'' Universal, $15.3 million, 1,944 screens, $7,890 per screen, $15.3 million, one week. 2. ``Cadillac Man,'' Orion, $6.7 million, 1,826 screens, $3,675 per screen, $6.7 million, one week. 3. ``Pretty Woman,'' Disney, $6.3 million, 1,811 screens, $3,453 per screen, $109.6 million, nine weeks. 4. ``Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles,'' New Line, $3.3 million, 2,026 screens, $1,621 per screen, $114 million, eight weeks. 5. ``Tales From the Darkside,'' Paramount, $1.9 million, 1,535 screens, $1,256 per screen, $12.2 million, three weeks. 6. ``The Hunt for Red October,'' Paramount, $1.8 million, 1,241 screens, $1,413 per screen, $108 million, 12 weeks. 7. ``Spaced Invaders,'' Disney, $1.3 million, 1,426 screens, $934 per screen, $12.7 million, four weeks. 8. ``The Guardian,'' Universal, $857,460, 922 screens, $930 per screen, $14.3 million, four weeks. 9. ``Wild Orchid,'' Epic, $740,000, 757 screens, $977 per screen, $8.5 million, four weeks. 10. ``Q & A,'' Tri Star, $732,735, 857 screens, $855 per screen, $9.2 million, four weeks.

DOC.HEAD: User-Friendly Fast Food
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Tuesday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Fast food is getting faster with a computerized device introduced Monday that turns customers into order takers, isn't rude and _ like regular clerks _ even asks if they wouldn't like a soda with their fries. The ``8470'' computer would give customers more control over their orders and increased employee efficiency amid a troubling labor shortage, said officials at IBM, which developed the product, and a fast-food chain that recently began using it. If a customer orders a sandwich and salad, for example, but no soft drink, the screen illuminates a printed message saying, ``Would you like a refreshing soda?'' As the customer places the order, it appears on similar screens in the kitchen area, eliminating the need for clerks to shout or walk orders back to the cooks. The system is designed for one clerk to handle two terminals for two lines of customers. Bilingual versions are also available, IBM officials said in unveiling the system at the National Restaurant Association's international trade show. ``We think it's fantastic,'' said Mark Eagleton, vice president of a branch of The Bailey Co., which manages about 60 Arby's roast beef restaurants in five states. Bailey, based in Lakewood, Colo., is an independent Arby's franchisee and has installed eight of the devices in its stores. Eagleton said the system ``has improved service times by about 20 seconds (per order); it's improved the accuracy of the orders. It's increased our capacity for sales by allowing us to serve more customers with the same amount of employees.'' And, he said, ``customers buy more.'' ``We've seen our average check ... go up between 9 cents and 40 cents (an order) per store,'' he said. Arby's is IBM's first client, with about 20 restaurants around the country using the device. Eagleton says it's being used in eight of his Arby's and will be installed in all new or remodeled Arby's managed by his company. IBM also introduced a notebook-sized, radio-controlled order board for use by clerks at drive-ins. The clerk intercepts customers before they reach the pickup window and punches in the order. It then appears on a screen in the kitchen and is ready by the time the driver arrives at the window. It's being used in about 30 Wendy's hamburger restaurants nationwide but also could be used in sit-down restaurants, said IBM spokeswoman Cindy Beck. The devices come as the industry faces a shrinking work force, Eagleton said. ``We're having a shortage of workers thoughout the '90s and if we can automate more so that whatever workers we do have can be used more effectively, it's going to have a substantial impact,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev Presides Over Shrinking Soviet Domain
DOC.TEXT: From Africa to Latin America to Eastern Europe, Moscow's domain is crumbling. Soviet troops have left Afghanistan. The Marxist regime in Nicaragua is history. Ethiopia and Mozambique are veering from their rigid pro-Soviet ideologies. Not to mention the disintegration of the Iron Curtain. The speed of it all has taken Mikhail S. Gorbachev by surprise and dramatically altered his stance as he heads into next week's Washington summit meetings with President Bush. Soviet leaders and American presidents have met since Nikolai Bulganin and Dwight Eisenhower gathered with the leaders of Britain and France in 1955, 10 years after Josef Stalin won territorial concessions at Yalta that some said helped tighten the Soviet grip in Eastern Europe. For decades after Bulganin and Eisenhower met in Geneva, Moscow widened its circle of influence, becoming, to Ronald Reagan in 1983, the ``evil empire.'' How quickly things change. In less than a year: _ Poland and Hungary have held free elections, resoundingly defeating candidates who represented the status quo. _ Czechoslovakia's Parliament elected dissident playwright Vaclav Havel as president, replacing Communist Gustav Husak. _ Bulgaria's head of state, Todor Zhivkov, resigned. _ Nicolae Ceausescu was executed in Romania. _ East Germany dissolved its communist government and opened the Berlin Wall. It is headed toward reunification with West Germany. Within the Soviet Union, Gorbachev's power is threatened by ethnic and economic nationalists. He has been jeered by crowds in Red Square. He has been criticized within the Communist Party for being too fast, or too slow, in remaking the Soviet political and economic systems. He has dispatched troops to quell ethnic violence. He has beseeched Lithuania, unsuccessfully, not to declare itself independent. He is trying to cajole two other Baltic republics, Latvia and Estonia, not to follow the Lithuanians. Gorbachev has applied increasing economic pressure to Lithuania to rescind its declaration and President Bush has said the standoff between Moscow and the Baltic republics ``certainly puts some tension'' on the summit. In all, Gorbachev will go into the summit with less of a power base than any of his postwar predecessors. ``It puts Gorbachev in a weakened position in which he basically has to, in effect, ask the West for its indulgence as he tries to ride out the crises,'' said Michael J. Sodaro, a George Washington University political scientist and an expert on East Germany. ``On the other hand,'' Sodaro added, ``it puts the West in a position in which we don't really want to take excessive advantage of Gorbachev's internal problems for fear that there might be a conservative backlash and Gorbachev would be deposed. He recognizes that the West has an interest in his continuation in power.'' Observers said they are sure that Gorbachev, in introducing relative freedom of expression and political action to the Soviet domain, did not anticipate the results. ``He came to power dealing with not only the problems left to him by a Communist regime that has failed but by Russian history,'' said Arthur A. Hartman, U.S. amassador to Moscow from 1981 to 1987. ``I can't believe he didn't know he would have to deal with those problems. On the other hand, I don't think he predicted exactly the way things have gone.'' Janusz Bugajski, an Eastern European specialist at the Center for Strategic and International Studies, said, ``I don't think there was any preplanning for what happened in Eastern Europe. There was no blueprint. I think what happened was that Gorbachev became educated during the late '80's as far as the likelihood of some major revolution.'' Sodaro said, ``I think even the most farsighted advisers to Gorbachev were stunned by the rapidity of the dissolution of Communism in Eastern Europe and East Germany.'' The suddenness of those events, he added, is affecting the attitude of Kremlin leaders toward developments in the Baltic. ``I don't think they want as rapid a disintegration of the remaining part of the empire,'' Sodaro said. ``I think Gorbachev from the outset wanted to purge the Soviet system from the vestiges of Stalinism, and certainly the acquisition of the Baltic states can be chalked up to Stalin,'' said Sodaro. ``I think in the back of his mind he and his advisers would have to expect this would happen. But I don't really think that he intended from the outset to preside over the disintegration of the Soviet empire.''
DOC.HEAD: NEXT: Soviet Democracy
Taiwan President Launches Campaign of Pragmatism
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Tuesday AMs report.
DOC.HEAD: An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: On this island where fantasy has long dictated policy, reality is taking hold and may help improve relations with China and stimulate democratic change at home. The myth has long been that the ruling Nationalist Party, which retreated to Taiwan after losing a civil war to Communist forces in 1949, is still the legitimate government of China. That myth has long been used to justify the party's policy of no official contact with the rival government in Beijing. It also has long been used to justify the party's monopoly on political power. But events of the past week, culminating in the inaugural address of President Lee Teng-hui on Sunday, indicate the days of fantasy are drawing to a close. Lee was sworn in for a six-year term after being elected by the electoral college and stressed his commitment to democracy. The Nationalist government still calls itself the ``Republic of China'' and says reunification with the Chinese mainland is the ultimate goal. But on Wednesday, Hau said something no top official had previously acknowledged in public: The reality is that China today is ``one country with two governments.'' In his inauguration speech, Lee urged markedly improved relations with Beijing and ``channels of communication'' that could eventually lead to talks on reunification. In effect, Lee signaled a desire to end the 40-year-old hard-line policy toward the Chinese Communists known as the ``three nos'' _ no official contact, no negotiations and no compromise. There is a catch. The Nationalists want Beijing to renounce the threat of force against Taiwan, end its policy of isolating Taiwan diplomatically and scrap one-party Communist rule. China on Monday rejected such preconditions, saying Lee was ``ignoring the universally accepted fact that the People's Republic of China is the sole legitimate government representing all Chinese people.'' While Taiwan does not expect an immediate breakthrough, its leaders hope relations will improve as civilian and business contacts expand. Indirect trade across the Taiwan Straits was $4 billion last year, and Taiwan residents made 1 million visits to the Chinese mainland since such travel was first allowed in late 1987. ``We want gradually to expand our contact by peaceful ways,'' government spokesman Shaw Yu-ming recently told foreign journalists. ``We have to move in measured steps. ... It's not a very action-packed kind of approach.'' Lee also said he wanted to quickly scrap the 1947 ``Mobilization for the Supression of the Communist Rebellion.'' Not only would this mean Taiwan would no longer view the Beijing government as a rebel group, but it would also lift temporary legal provisions that have guaranteed the Nationalist Party a lock on power. Under the provisions, the Legislature and electoral college are dominated by Nationalists, elected on mainland China before the civil war defeat. The theory is they cannot be replaced until their constituencies are recaptured and new elections held. But the mainland-elected parliamentarians are dying fast and the island's 20 million people, 85 percent of whom are native Taiwanese, want a greater say in government. Lee on Sunday gave a two-year timetable for replacing the provisions with constitutional amendments that would establish ``a great model of political democracy for all times.'' He also stressed the importance of securing fair competition among political parties, indicating an understanding that future legitimacy must come from the people. Still, the promise of greater democracy is viewed skeptically by many students and opposition party members. They view Lee's decision to nominate the country's only four-star general as premier a step back toward the Nationalists' authoritarian past. But the nomination of Defense Minister Hau Pei-tsun also is viewed less sinisterly as an attempt by Lee to shore up his support among party elders and to crack down on rampant corruption and crime. Government spokesman Shaw said military rule or a return to authoritanism would be impossible. ``Nobody in this land, no party, no group ... no individuals, can turn the clock back,'' he said. ``Military rule, military dictatorship or even authoritarian-type of politics cannot ... be accepted by our people.''
DOC.NOTE: EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.TEXT: Dan Biers has been a news editor based in Hong Kong for The Associated Press since 1987.

DOC.HEAD: NBC and ABC Unveil Fall Lines; `Twin Peaks' Renewed
With PM-ABC-NBC Lineup
LaserPhoto NY5
DOC.TEXT: ``Twin Peaks'' returns to ABC's fall schedule despite slipping ratings in a ``bold experiment'' to lure viewers back to the tube on Saturday nights, the network's entertainment chief says. ``When you think about it, the idea grows on you,'' Robert A. Eiger told a gathering of network advertisers Monday. ``One, there are a lot of young adult viewers home on Saturday night with nothing to watch so they go out and rent videotapes. And two, we think this show can prosper when we move it away from that real tough `Cheers' competition on Thursday night.'' NBC, revealing its fall schedule later in the day, went for the laugh track with six situation comedies among nine new shows. That makes 17 sitcoms on NBC next fall, its most ever. ABC opens its Saturday night gamble with the Western ``Young Riders,'' followed by the critically praised Vietnam series ``China Beach'' and then ``Twin Peaks,'' the moody drama created by film director David Lynch. ``We're going for the gold with three special programs in an all-out attempt to change the perception of Saturday night television,'' Eiger said. ``Twin Peaks'' will debut with a two-hour movie and will take less of a serial approach, more akin to ``Hill Street Blues,'' he said. NBC's hourlong series are ``Signs of Life,'' a patient's-eye-view ``reality'' program about medicine; ``Law and Order,'' about criminal justice from arrest through trial, and the musical comedy ``Hull Street High.'' The network, which just won the prime time ratings for the fifth consecutive season, renewed ``Grand,'' ``Wings'' and ``Carol & Co,'' but axed 4-season-old ``ALF,'' ``227,'' ``Baywatch,'' ``My Two Dads'' and `Mancuso FBI.'' Two of NBC's new sitcoms are based on movies, ``Parenthood'' and ``Ferris Bueller.'' The others are rap-driven ``Fresh Prince of Bel Air,'' ``The Fanelli Boys'' and ``Working It Out,'' which co-stars Jane Curtin, formerly of CBS' ``Kate & Allie,'' playing a divorced person. ABC, with six new shows, also offers a musical hour in Steven Bochco's ``Cop Rock,'' an intriguing combination of police action and Randy Newman's music reminiscent of the PBS hit ``The Singing Detective.'' ABC dropped six low-rated series: ``Elvis,'' tales of the King when he was a youth, ``Brewster Place,'' with Oprah Winfrey, ``Capital News,'' ``The Marshall Chronicles,'' `H.E.L.P.'' and ``Sunset Beat.'' CBS' schedule may come out later this week or early next week, a spokesman said. Fox Broadcasting said it will release its lineup May 29. ``Twin Peaks,'' a tangled saga of sex, lies and death in the Northwest, was this season's most talked-about series. It started strong on April 8, winning with a 21.7 rating, but has lost more than 50 percent of its viewers. Its season finale Wednesday should have high ratings because it resolves the murder of high school beauty queen Laura Palmer, a mystery that prompted ``I Killed Laura Palmer'' T-shirts in California. Last Thursday's show gave the series its lowest Nielsens to date _ a 10.6 rating and a 17 percent audience share. Each ratings point represents 921,000 homes. Other ABC renewals include the high-rated ``Roseanne'' and ``thirtysomething,'' ``Life Goes On'' and ABC News' ``PrimeTime Live'' and ``20-20.'' Three of the new series on ABC's roster are sitcoms _ ``Baby Talk,'' based on the hit movie ``Look Who's Talking''; ``Going Places,'' about four young adults in Los Angeles working on their first TV show _ a ``candid videos'' series; and ``Married People,'' about three generations of couples sharing a brownstone in New York. Capitalizing on its top-rated ``America's Funniest Home Videos,'' ABC also will have ``America's Funniest ... Part II.'' James Earl Jones, whose ``Paris'' police series on CBS flopped a decade ago, will try again in a new hourlong ABC series, ``Gabriel's Fire,'' playing an ex-convict working as a private investigator for a defense attorney.

DOC.HEAD: `Looney Tunes' Shorts to Return After 20-Year Absence
DOC.TEXT: Daffy Duck, Porky Pig, Wile E. Coyote and 130 ``Looney Tunes'' short cartoons starring the animation heroes will return to movie theaters across the nation, it was announced Monday. The 5- to 7-minute cartoons will be shown for one year before most feature films in the 1,700 screens of AMC Theatres, said Ed Durwood, president of AMC Entertainment. ``Looney Tunes'' have not been shown in regular national screenings in 20 years. The shorts will debut in Los Angeles this week with additional theaters to be added Friday and throughout the summer, he said. ``We will take great pains to rotate the mix so that by the end of a year, all cities should have seen all 130 titles,'' Durwood said. ``We want to give people a reason to come to the theaters. We want the movie-going experience to be a little nicer.'' A few serious dramas and some animated films will be shown without the ``Looney Tunes'' trailers, Durwood said. The upcoming ``Dick Tracy,'' which Disney is distributing with a new ``Roger Rabbit'' animated trailer, will also be shown without a ``Looney Tune'' short.

DOC.HEAD: The Last `Newhart:' Well ... Not Really ...
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 2 grafs after 10th graf pvs, `Bob Hartley...,' to UPDATE with station cutting off part of episode and then replaying it on the news because of irate calls. Pick up 11th graf pvs, ` ``Newhart'' was...
DOC.TEXT: The last ``Newhart'' aired Monday night, the 184th episode of the long-running CBS situation comedy, and it closed with a surprise ending, of sorts. As innkeeper Dick Loudon, comedian Bob Newhart presided over the Stratford Inn for eight seasons, a frustrated pillar of reason among various rustics, zanies and spoiled yuppie brats afflicting the town of Stratford, Vt. In Monday's episode, the townspeople sold their town _ lock, stock and barrel _ to a Japanese businessman who erects ``the luxurious, 5,000-room Tagadachiville Hotel.'' Dick is the only holdout, of course. Flash forward five years: The inn is a hazard on the 14th fairway of the hotel's golf course, and, as golf balls batter the inn's clapboards, Dick's wife Joanna, (Mary Frann) scurries about in black wig and kimono. Their Japanese maid is thoroughly spoiled and their handyman always wears a suit and tie. Dick is depressed. Just when things look their worst, the townspeople return for their five-year reunion. The returnees include Larry (``Hi, I'm Larry and this is my brother Darryl and my other brother Darryl.'') and his perpetually silent brothers. They bring their talkative wives, Rhonda, Sada and Zora. Darryl and Darryl spoke! They told their wives to be quiet. Stehpanie and Michael Harris (Julia Duffy and Peter Scolari) returned with their spoiled daughter, as do Jim (Thomas Hill) and Chester (William Lanteau). As the townspeople settle in, Dick is hit on the head by a golf ball and wakes in the bedroom of Chicago psychotherapist Bob Hartley, the bemused hero of Newhart's 1972-78 first sitcom on CBS, ``The Bob Newhart Show.'' Bob Hartley wakes his wife, Emily, (Susanne Pleshette), and tells her of the terrible dream he had. A television station in Schenectady, N.Y., that cut off part of the last scene for a news update was so deluged with calls that it ran seven seconds of ``Newhart'' at the end of its newscast. WRGB-TV in upstate New York cut off the show because it ran overtime, said Gary Whitaker, the news director. The network had warned local stations the show would run two minutes overtime, he said. ``Newhart'' was the comedian's third incarnation on network TV. First there was ``The Bob Newhart Show'' on NBC in 1961-62, a variety show which won the Emmy and Peabody awards. Then there was ``The Bob Newhart Show'' sitcom on CBS. Then ``Newhart'' began in 1982. As the actor-comedian already has observed, they're thinking of calling his next CBS series ``The.''

DOC.HEAD: Names in the News
LaserPhoto NY14
DOC.TEXT: Paul Newman has developed five new varieties of salad dressing for Burger King and will be seen in the fast-food chain's TV commercials beginning today. The ads feature clips of Newman undressing in such films as ``The Sting,'' ``The Prize'' and ``Cat on a Hot Tin Roof,'' and advise viewers: ``For years, you've seen Paul Newman undressing. Now you can see Paul Newman dressing.'' Burger King will offer the new dressings alongside the actor's original Newman's Own Oil & Vinegar at its 6,000 restaurants. ``This all-natural product will help `shake up' awareness of our salad line,'' said Gary Langstaff, executive vice president of marketing for Burger King. Newman donates profits from his food company to charity.

Peter Yarrow of Peter, Paul and Mary says the folk group's sing-along ``Puff the Magic Dragon'' has two meanings, and neither is about drugs as once rumored. ``It's ostensibly a song about the moment of loss of innocence. When that moment occurs, it is sad indeed,'' the singer told 300 Augsburg College graduates. ``But it's about something else. It is about the loss of our ideals.'' In his commencement speech Sunday, Yarrow spliced folk songs with comments on the need for global thinking and the power of the individual to bring about change. Yarrow is affiliated with the college's Center for Global Education, which arranges for educational travel to the Third World. ``If you want to, we can make history together,'' he said. ``If you acknowledge there is suffering, think globally, act globally. If there is a single lesson from the '60s, it is the belief in our own capacities as individuals. We all matter.''

Music publisher Don Kirshner, best known for his TV rock show, hits the radio airwaves this weekend with the first installment of a 35-hour rock revue. His first radio project, ``DK-35,'' will air in 15 installments on more than 200 stations nationwide and will include conversations with music stars. Among them: Roy Orbison, who in an interview just before his death in 1988 spoke about meeting a then-unknown John Lennon. ``Basically, I'm doing firsthand experiences,'' said Kirshner, 56. His career in music began in 1955 when he met Bobby Darin, who later recorded ``Dream Lover'' and ``Queen of the Hop.'' ``Don Kirshner's Rock Concert'' came to television in 1972 and during the next decade gave national exposure to musicians from Billy Joel to the Police along with comics Billy Crystal, Arsenio Hall and David Letterman.

As it turned out, Bob Newhart's 184th and final appearance on ``Newhart'' revealed that the previous 183 episodes had all been, well, just a terrible dream. For eight seasons on the CBS comedy, Newhart has played innkeeper Dick Loudon, a pillar of reason among various eccentrics afflicting the town of Stratford, Vt. On Monday, the townspeople sell their town to the Japanese. Dick refuses to sell. Flash forward five years. The inn is a hazard on the 14th fairway of a golf course, and Dick's wife, played by Mary Frann, scurries about in black wig and kimono. Dick is depressed. Just when things look their worst, the townspeople return for a five-year reunion. Among them are Larry (``Hi, I'm Larry and this is my brother Darryl and my other brother Darryl.'') and his silent brothers. They bring their talkative wives. Then, Darryl and Darryl speak! They tell their wives to be quiet. As the townspeople settle in, Dick is hit in the head by a golf ball and wakes in the bedroom and character of Chicago psychotherapist Bob Hartley, the hero of Newhart's 1972-78 first sitcom on CBS, ``The Bob Newhart Show.'' Bob Hartley wakes his wife, Emily, (former co-star Susanne Pleshette), and tells her of the terrible dream he had.

DOC.HEAD: Police Arrest 38 Fans At Rolling Stones Concert
DOC.TEXT: Police arrested 38 fans at the Rolling Stones' concert here for rowdiness and other offenses, officials said. Six people were arrested when a group of fans pelted police with beer cans and tried to storm a fence at Feyenoord Stadium on Monday, Rotterdam police spokesman Coen van Maasloo said. Police charged with batons to disperse the fans, he added. He said another 32 people were arrested in other incidents and for hawking black-market tickets. Approximately 50,000 people attended the concert, part of the Rolling Stones' ``Urban Jungle'' tour of Europe. It was the band's final performance on the first leg of their European tour.

DOC.HEAD: Oyster Outlook Bleak For Galveston Bay Because of Flooding
DOC.TEXT: Rainwater funneling into salty Galveston Bay from the flooded Trinity River is muddying the outlook for the Texas oyster industry. In Louisiana and five other Texas bays on the Gulf of Mexico, the crop is expected to be good and retail prices could drop from the current level of $4.50 to $5 a pound, said Ben Nelson, an oyster harvester and exporter. But he said 90 percent of the crop in Galveston Bay will be killed _ 100 percent if the fresh water runs into the bay through July. ``There will be little to none,'' said sister-in-law Doris Nelson, who with her husband operates three boats on the bay and ships oysters as far as the East Coast. ``It was already kind of bleak and we're just struggling to come back from last year's flood. Now it looks like this year is going to be taken away too.'' Officials are expecting large releases of fresh water to continue down the Trinity well into the summer as the torrential rains of several weeks ago more than 200 miles to the north continue to drain into Galveston Bay. The high waters that have inundated thousands of acres of cropland and displaced hundreds of residents now threaten the livelihoods of the oyster harvesters. ``They have lots to fear, based on the amount of water that's projected to come,'' said Sammy Ray, former professor of marine biology at Texas A&M University in Galveston. ``With this coming down, probably a large number of oysters will be lost. When the water warms up and when they open, they lose whatever body salt content they have. ``And when they get completely fresh, they blow up like a balloon. They're dead.'' Last year, hurricanes and a tropical storm dumped fresh water into the bay and ruined last year's oyster crop. ``My guesstimate is that it's pretty much going to wipe out the oyster harvest this year,'' said Gil Moody, marketing specialist with the Texas Department of Agriculture. ``In the short term, it's a disaster for fishermen. There are 560 oyster dredges that work Galveston Bay, and it pretty much puts them out of business.'' Compared with the $600 million shrimp business in Texas, the oyster industry is small. ``But $12 million is not to be laughed at,'' said C.E. Bryan, regional director of the state Department of Parks and Wildlife. ``It's the livelihood of 1,100 people.'' The news is not all bleak if there is no serious flooding next year. Fresh water kills oyster predators like crabs, eels, starfish, stingrays, snails and fungus that thrive in highly salty water. ``The oyster population could come back and quite often they have bumper crops three or four years following,'' Ray said.

DOC.HEAD: Two-Term Law Produces Big, Diverse Primary
DOC.TEXT: The last time New Mexico tinkered with its election system, Democrat Bruce King in 1970 became the state's first governor in more than 50 years to be elected to a four-year term. Twenty years later, New Mexico again has changed the rules and King is among eight candidates hoping to become the state's first governor to be eligible to serve two consecutive four-year terms. The chance to serve eight straight years has attracted four Democrats and four Republicans to the June 5 gubernatorial primaries, the largest field in 16 years. Republican Gov. Garrey Carruthers was not eligible to run. ``I thought it would be a real opportunity to have an agenda and get something accomplished, because you'd be the first governor in a long, long time not to be a lame duck,'' said Democratic hopeful Paul Bardacke, an Albuquerque lawyer. ``One four-year term has been very bad for this state, because we haven't developed any continuity in government.'' New Mexico's governors were limited to two consecutive, two-year terms until 1970. For the next 20 years, they were elected to four-year terms but incumbents could not seek re-election. This year's Democratic primary has been largely a battle between Bardacke and King, a 66-year-old rancher and businessman who offers voters the experience he gained in eight years as governor. Four GOP contenders, meanwhile, are hoping to become the first Republican governor to succeed a GOP incumbent since 1920. King, who served longer than anyone else in the state's history, was elected to his first four-year term in 1970 and to his second in 1978. In the Democratic field, King led Bardacke in the most recent Albuquerque Journal poll by roughly 48 percent to 25 percent. But pollster Brian Sanderoff said the primary's outcome still could hinge on undecided Democrats who are unlikely to vote for King. Bardacke, 45, a former attorney general, is urging Democrats to seek new ideas and ``choose the future.'' He has attacked King's record, accusing him of cronyism, citing financial problems and questioning his ability to muster fresh ideas with a staff largely recycled from his 1979-82 term. King responded with a flurry of position papers outlining far-reaching programs in areas such as education, the environment and crime, but Bardacke has questioned how King would pay for scores of new initiatives. King says state revenues have nearly doubled since he was last governor, to almost $2 billion this year, and that ``what they need is someone to manage the amounts of money they have.'' The two other Democrats are former Supreme Court Chief Justice Tony Scarborough and lobbyist and former state economic development chief Bob Gold. The two top GOP contenders are Frank Bond, a former state legislator and former chairman of the Commission on Higher Education, and Les Houston, the state Senate Republican leader. The Journal's May poll showed the GOP race to be a virtual dead heat between the two, with each drawing about one-fourth of the Republican support and 40 percent undecided. Bond, 46, has drawn much of incumbent Carruthers' party support. He figures none of the other three Republicans candidates, all from Albuquerque, will claim a majority of that city's GOP vote, which accounts for nearly 40 percent of the state's Republicans. Houston, who was a Democrat until 1986, has formed a conservative coalition in the Senate and is counting on conservative Democrats to help him win in November. Also running in the GOP primary is former Albuquerque Mayor Harry Kinney, who has campaigned on a plan to establish mega-landfills for the nation's solid waste. The other Republican candidate is state Sen. James A. Caudell, who co-sponsored the 1986 two-term amendment in the Legislature.

DOC.HEAD: When in Washington, Don't Miss the Penguin Fountain
LaserPhoto WX6
DOC.TEXT: OK, tourists, you've seen the top of the Washington Monument and gotten foot blisters at the Smithsonian. It's time to get off the sightseeing bus and discover some obscure, quirky monuments that the guidebooks don't bother to mention. Here, free of charge, is a list of milestones on the road less traveled by visitors to the nation's capital:
DOC.HEAD: The Temperance Fountain
DOC.TEXT: A miniature temple supported by four granite columns and topped by a bronze water crane, symbolizing the purity of water over liquor, this unusual drinking fountain is situated across Pennsylvania Avenue from the National Archives. Ironically, it once stood outside a liquor store. The fountain was donated to the city in 1880 by Dr. Henry D. Cogswell, a San Francisco dentist who hoped passersby would quench their thirst with water instead of booze. Its canopy is inscribed with good Victorian virtues _ Faith, Hope, Charity, Temperance _ and its entwined dolphins still spout cooling water, but the horse trough is gone.
DOC.HEAD: The ``Air Mail'' Monument
DOC.TEXT: On the edge of the Potomac River, beside a jogging and cycling path midway between the Lincoln and Jefferson memorials, is a large boulder with a plaque marking the site of the landing strip where the world's first airmail flight began on May 15, 1918, carrying 150 pounds of mail to Philadelphia and New York.
DOC.HEAD: The Rawlins Statue
DOC.TEXT: This is probably the most-traveled statue in Washington. This memorial to Civil War Gen. John A. Rawlins moved four times around the city _ and was bumped to make room for a statue of Benjamin Franklin, a government building and a public toilet _ before it returned to its original site in a park near George Washington University. A proposal to move the statue to Rawlins, Wyo., one of the general's former campsites, was vetoed. Rawlins was aide-de-camp to Gen. Ulysses S. Grant. Historians say Rawlins distinguished himself by persuading the Union commander to quit drinking to excess during the war years.
DOC.HEAD: The Maine Lobsterman
DOC.TEXT: The Camp Fire Girls of Cundys Harbor, Maine, led the campaign to install this $30,000 statue, a replica of one that appeared at the 1939 New York World's Fair, in a small park on the Washington waterfront near Maine Avenue. It shows a dour-looking man kneeling to fondle his favorite crustacean.
DOC.HEAD: The Penguin Fountain
DOC.TEXT: In front of Walter Reed Army Hospital, off upper 16th Street N.W., is a huge urn guarded by four penguins spitting water into the air as they stand on pedestals decorated with cobras. The fountain is a widow's memorial to Col. John Van Rensselaer Hoff, a prominent figure in the Army Medical Corps. The penguins and cobras are believed to symbolize Hoff's service in the Arctic and the Philippines.
DOC.HEAD: Nuns of the Battlefield Monument
DOC.TEXT: Civil War nuns _ not fighting nuns but nursing nuns _ are honored by this large bronze relief panel erected in 1924 by the ladies' auxiliary of the Ancient Order of the Hibernians. After it was installed at a downtown intersection near Connecticut Avenue, the sculptor had a fight on his hands. He filed a $45,000 lawsuit against the ladies for alleged non-payment.
DOC.HEAD: Japanese Pagoda
DOC.TEXT: Nestled in a grove of Japanese cherry trees near the Tidal Basin, this 3,800-pound, nine-tiered sculpture from the mayor of Yokohama caused much consternation when it arrived in 1957. It was shipped in pieces in five wooden crates, without any instructions for assembling it. Experts from the Library of Congress helped solve the puzzle.

DOC.HEAD: Economic Seers Say No Recession But Weak Growth On The Way
DOC.TEXT: The nation's top economic forecasters, who just a year ago were predicting a recession this year, now say the economy will avoid a decline through 1991 and set a new record for business expansion. The latest survey of 68 professional forecasters by the National Association of Business Economists found 82 percent saying the economy would continue to advance slowly through the end of next year. That reversed the findings of a similar poll last May that found 63 percent of the economists believing a recession would occur this year. Ninety-six percent of those polled for the current survey now rule that out. If growth continues through 1991, the expansion will have lasted 109 months, topping the previous record when the economy grew 106 months during the Vietnam war years from February 1961 to December 1969. The current expansion began 90 months ago in November 1982 at the end of the last recession. The survey was conducted in April and May. But despite seeing no recession, the forecasters do not foresee strong economic growth either. ``The outlook for 1990 is for slower economic growth than in 1989,'' when the economy advanced 3.0 percent, the survey found. ``Weaker increases in real consumption and business spending on plant and equipment combine with a smaller improvement in the trade deficit to cause much of the slowdown.'' The economists also predict unemployment to rise from 5.2 percent in 1989 to 5.4 percent this year. Automobile sales will fall from 9.9 million last year to 9.6 million this year. Housing starts will remain unchanged at 1.39 million. Overall, the forecasters said the economy as measured by the gross national product would grow 2.0 percent this year and 2.4 percent in 1991. The GNP is the total output of goods and services. At the same time, the forecasters said inflation, which rose 8.1 percent in the first quarter, reflecting in part weather-related jumps in food and energy prices, will drop to an annual rate of 3.7 percent in the final nine months of the year. That would make the 1990 inflation rate 4.7 percent, down from 4.8 percent in 1989. On the twin deficits, the economists said trade would fall from a $53 billion imbalance in 1989 to $44 billion this year while the federal budget gap would continue to widen. The economists forecast a budget shortfall of $154 billion in the fiscal year ending Sept. 30 and $135 billion in fiscal 1991. The Gramm-Rudman balanced budget law sets deficit targets of $100 billion this year and $64 billion in 1991. The actual deficit for fiscal 1989 was $152 billion. Interest rates, which are blamed for the current economic sluggishness, are projected to remain near their current levels this year before declining slightly in 1991, the forecasters said. Rates for 90-day Treasury bills will edge down from 7.9 percent in June 1990 to 7.8 percent at year's end and 7.7 percent by the end of 1991, they predicted. Rates for 30-year Treasury bonds will fall from 8.7 percent next month to 8.6 percent in December and 8.4 percent at the end of 1991.

DOC.HEAD: Middle East Shooting Sprees Blamed On Lack Of Peace Plan
DOC.TEXT: The United States says the lack of a Middle East peace process played a role in the violence that flared in Israel after an allegedly deranged Israeli gunman killed seven Palestinian workers. State Department deputy spokesman Richard Boucher deplored the initial killings as ``a horrible senseless act of a madman.'' But he was critical of the force with which the Israeli army cracked down on subsequent Arab rioting, leaving an additional 10 Palestinians dead and at least 94 wounded. ``We see that as another sign that there must be a peace process,'' Boucher told reporters. ``In the absence of a peace process the potential for this kind of senseless violence and spiraling responses afterwards goes up,'' he said. ``We regret the violence that occurred after this incident,'' Boucher said and added: ``We're disturbed by the number of casualties inflicted by the Israeli army.'' The Bush administration has been striving for months to get talks underway in Cairo between Israel and representatives of Palestinian Arabs. But Israeli Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir, objecting to some of the provisions, refused to endorse the plan. The Israeli government collapsed in the midst of the controversy and neither Shamir nor Labor Party Leader Shimon Peres has been able to form a new government. The suspect in the slayings, Ami Popper, appeared in Israeli court on Monday and was ordered to undergo psychiatric evaluation. Police said Popper was suicidal after breaking up with his girlfriend. Although Boucher was critical of the apparent lack of restraint displayed by Israeli forces, he commended the actions of Jordanian authorities responding to the shooting of French tourists, an incident apparently triggered by the Israeli slayings. Eight French tourists and a Jordanian bystander were wounded in the attack. Jordanian police acted quickly to protect foreign tourists and to contain protest demonstrations at a Palestinian refugee camp, Boucher said. ``I think these were valuable steps,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Safety Board Recommending Mandatory Infant Seats
DOC.NOTE: Eds: NTSB meeting begins 9 a.m. EDT; prenoon lead expected
DOC.TEXT: Parents would have to get small children their own airline seats and use approved restraints rather than carry them free on their laps, under a recommendation being considered today by the National Transportation Safety Board. Whether all seats must be paid for would be up to airlines, which have indicated they would still give available seats to children under 2 years old. But a family traveling to see grandma and grandpa might not want to take the chance that a free seat will be there when they board. The NTSB scheduled a vote on the recommendation today. Even if approved by the safety board, the proposal would have to clear the Federal Aviation Administration before going into effect. The FAA has questioned the safety benefits of mandatory infant seats and proposes only to require that airlines allow their use when a passenger provides one. The agency has said, however, it would consider proposals for a stricter rule. The airline industry's Air Transport Association reversed its earlier opposition to mandatory seats in February, petitioning the FAA for a federal rule requiring them. The independent safety board's recommendation also adds to support by consumer safety groups, flight attendants and others for increased protection of children aboard commercial airliners. Some travel agents oppose the measure, saying it would add to the cost of flying for young families and possibly force them to travel by automobile on shorter routes. They say automobile travel poses greater risks per mile than flying. Most carriers already allow infant seats to be used, giving the child free passage if an empty seat is available for strapping in the restraint. But when there are no empty seats, babies may still be boarded without an assigned seat. Under a rule making infant seats mandatory, no child of any age would be allowed on the plane without an assigned seat. FAA officials have said they are concerned about the burden a mandatory rule would put on travelers when the number of children killed in airplane crashes is low. A Harvard Medical School statistical study in the early 1980s theorized that three infants might be saved over five years if all children used safety seats on airliners. Estimates of the number of infants flying range from 5,000 to 10,000 a day. ``We don't think there is any safety justification for either requiring the airlines to give up a seat for free or for requiring a parent to purchase a seat if they don't want to,'' said FAA spokesman Fred Farrar in February. Concern over infant safety aboard airliners increased with the death of 23-month-old Evan Tsao in the July 19 crash of United flight 232 in an Iowa corn field. The boy's mother, Sylvia Tsao, was among survivors of the crash that killed 112 people. Proponents of the seat rule say the boy, who died of smoke inhalation, might have lived if he had been strapped in next to his mother.

DOC.HEAD: Tailor-Made Antibodies Reverse Lethal Skin Cancer
DOC.TEXT: Tailor-made antibodies can dramatically reverse spreading melanoma, the deadliest form of skin cancer, when injected directly into the tumors, researchers say. The work, though still in its preliminary stages, suggests that it may be possible to stop the disease by harnessing the body's own built-in defenses. Antibodies are among the body's principal weapons for fighting off a variety of foreign invaders, including cancer. In this case, scientists crafted human antibodies in the test tube that were specifically targeted against the cancer. Then they injected them into cancerous growths on victims' skin. ``The lesions dry up and regress,'' said Dr. Donald Morton, director of the John Wayne Surgical Oncology Clinic at the University of California, Los Angeles. In initial studies, Morton and colleagues gave the injections to 28 people whose melanoma came back after initial surgery. In 18 of them, the shots caused partial or complete disappearance of the growths. The doctors injected three different kinds of antibodies. Each recognizes a different chemical structure that is unique to cancer cells. The antibodies latch onto these chemical structures, marking the cancer cells for destruction by other patrolling white blood cells. To the researchers' surprise, they found that the cancer patients began making more of these antibodies on their own. ``We are actually stimulating immunity with this treatment,'' said Morton. ``We don't know why, but it is happening.'' Morton presented his findings Monday at the annual meeting of the American Society of Clinical Oncology. ``I was quite impressed by the response rate,'' commented Dr. Carol Westbook of the University of Chicago. ``It appears to be a promising treatment that warrants further investigation.'' However, Dr. Bruce Cheson of the National Cancer Institute cautioned that melanoma is particularly hard to study. The course of the disease can be difficult to predict, and the cancer may go away for reasons that have nothing to do with the experimental treatment. Melanoma is curable in about 90 percent of cases when it is caught early. However, it is fatal if it progresses and spreads throughout the body. Melanoma, like other, less dangerous forms of skin cancer, can result from over-exposure to the sun, and people with light complexions or irregularly shaped moles are at highest risk. An estimated 27,000 new cases will be diagnosed in the United States this year, and the disease is believed to be increasing at a rate of 3 percent or 4 percent a year. Among other research presented at the meeting: _The acne drug Accutane appears to significantly reduce the risk of second cancers in people who undergo treatment for smoking-related tumors of the mouth and throat. In a comparison study on 100 people, Dr. Waun K. Hong of M.D. Anderson Cancer Center in Houston presented evidence that the drug, a synthetic form of vitamin A, suppresses abnormal growths from turning cancerous. Also on Monday, medical experts advising the Food and Drug Administration said stronger efforts are needed to make sure women do not use Accutane during pregnancy because it can cause birth defects. The advisory committees rejected the advice of some within FDA who want Accutane withheld from all women to eliminate any risk of birth defects from the drug. _Granulocyte colony stimulating factor, a genetically engineered substance that speeds up production of white blood cells, can offset a major side effect of cancer treatment. Often people receiving chemotherapy must stop their medication because the drugs lower their blood counts, leaving them open to infection. Dr. Jeffrey Crawford of Duke University Medical Center tested the growth factor on 126 lung cancer patients and found that it reduced low blood counts and infected-related fever by 44 percent. _A study by Dr. Charles G. Moertel and others from the Mayo Clinic helps doctors handle the dilemma of how to treat colon cancer patients whose tumors have spread through the bowel wall but have not visibly invaded the lymph nodes. Since three-quarters can be saved with surgery alone, doctors are reluctant to offer chemotherapy. The new study found ways of identifying the 25 percent whose tumors are highly likely to spread. Moertel found that those whose tumors have unusual genetic characteristics or have perforated the bowel would probably benefit from chemotherapy.

DOC.HEAD: Sheet Music Salesmen: No, But Hum a Few Bars and I'll Find It
LaserPhoto CX2
DOC.TEXT: If you want to learn the ``zucchini method'' of playing the piano or need sheet music to ``Furry Lice'' by Beethoven, the Carl Fischer store is the place to go. Customers who fracture the language and the lyrics don't deter the music-trained salesclerks _ but it helps if they can hum a few bars. ``It's better than when they tell you they're looking for a certain music book and all they know is that it's green,'' said Larry Heidel, floor manager at Carl Fischer, which stocks 610,000 titles and bills itself as the world's largest music store. Just before closing time Monday, Heidel and two salesmen stood at the counter as a young woman sang, ``I love you,'' then dropped off into a hum. She was the fourth hummer of the day at Fischer, where singing, whistling and tapping on the counter are an acceptable substitute for knowing the name of what you want. ``A lot of them are just like your average Joe who takes his first piano lesson and his teacher tells him to get something but he doesn't write it down,'' said salesman Tom Potter. ``Or people hear something on the radio and don't catch the title.'' Then there's that business about music being the universal language of mankind. ``A lot of times titles are in foreign languages _ and people somehow put them into English,'' Heidel said. A customer once asked for ``Christmas Intruder'' when he wanted ``Christmas Intrada.'' Another requested ``Furry Lice'' instead of ``Fuer Elise.'' ``Wash it Off'' was really ``Wachet Auf'' by Johann Sebastian Bach, and the ``zucchini method'' of piano playing is the Suzuki method. Once the goal is clear, salesclerks may have to search through an inventory that would stretch a mile high if stacked. It includes everything from classical to gospel to heavy metal. The business named after its founder was started in 1872 in New York. It opened its Chicago store in the 1920s when Wabash Avenue was the city's music row and was filled with piano stores, music publishers and other establishments that catered to musicians and music lovers. The Chicago store is the company's largest, Boston and New York have the others and headquarters is in New York. Printed music is Fischer's specialty. The department that sells guitars, metronomes and refrigerator magnets in the shape of clarinets is just a sideline. Fischer employees _ including Heidel the symphonic trombone player and Potter the tenor _ are one of the company's strengths. ``There's no way you could train people to do this. It couldn't replace the knowledge and devotion that these people have,'' said Gary Sigurdson, vice president and general manager and a former symphony musician. A sense of humor helps, too. ``Some people can't carry a tune,'' said Potter, a tenor with the Chicago Symphony Chorus who works part time at Fischer. ``If I worked part time as a waiter and heard people sing like that, I might have thrown a pie in their face,'' said Potter, who claims to have a 70 percent success rate at figuring out what a customer wants from the barest and bizarrest of clues. Potter said one of the most often requested songs in the past year has been ``Wind Beneath My Wings'' by Bette Midler. Or, as one customer called it, ``The Wind Beneath My Legs.''

DOC.HEAD: Agriculture Secretary Says Japan Trying To Have It Both Ways On Trade
DOC.TEXT: Japan can't have it both ways, defending a closed-door import policy while advocating liberalized global trade, says Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter. ``Japan cannot insist upon one set of rules for goods and services where it is internationally competitive, and another set of rules where it is uncompetitive,'' Yeutter said in a letter to Tomio Yamamoto, Japanese minister of agriculture, forestry and fisheries. Yeutter predicted April 9 that Japan would dismantle its rice import ban by the end of this year, when the Uruguay Round of trade talks is scheduled to conclude. The talks are being held under the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, with an objective of reducing or eliminating world trade barriers. Yeutter's May 18 letter to Yamamoto, which was released on Monday, was directed at the minister's recent remarks in Tokyo accusing Yeutter of meddling in Japan's internal affairs. Yamamoto was reported to have angrily reacted to Yeutter's flat-out prediction that Japan would open its door to rice imports. ``After working so hard over the past three years to manage this issue in a non-confrontational way, I am personally offended and deeply distressed to read that I am, nonetheless, accused of interfering in Japan's internal policy,'' Yeutter wrote. Yeutter recalled that as U.S. trade representative in the Reagan administration he twice rejected petitions from the U.S. rice industry for ``Section 301'' retaliation against Japan's restrictive import policies. ``Your comments seemingly indicate that Japan is not prepared to liberalize its rice market in the Uruguay Round,'' he told Yamamoto. ``If that is the position of your government, then I erred in rejecting those Section 301 petitions.'' Further, he said, Japanese government officials ``repeatedly assured me that Japan was prepared to negotiate on its agricultural import restrictions, including rice, if the United States and other nations were also prepared to negotiate on their agricultural import restrictions and other distortive trade practices.'' Yeutter said Japan ``agreed conceptually'' to do that when Yamamoto's government concurred in the launching of the Uruguay Round. At a 1989 midterm review in Montreal, Japan agreed to negotiate ``substantial progressive reductions in agricultural support and protection,'' he said. ``Recent comments by Japanese officials that Japan will never liberalize its rice market are contrary to all the commitments that have been made by your country during the Uruguay Round process,'' Yeutter said. Yeutter expressed hope that he and Yamamoto could get together soon to talk more about the rice issue.

An Agriculture Department report says a dramatic increase in wheat production this year will help rebuild U.S. stockpiles and probably will mean stiffer regional competition for some export markets. Total wheat output has been projected at more than 2.69 billion bushels, a rise of more than 650 million bushels from the weather-reduced 1989 harvest. It would be the biggest year-to-year increase on record, besides resulting in the nation's third-largest wheat harvest, the report said Monday. Winter wheat alone is forecast at 2.09 billion bushels, up 44 percent from 1989. As a result of the larger crop, lean stockpiles are expected to increase by June 1, 1991, to about 765 million bushels from an estimated 442 million bushels this June 1. Wheat prices received by farmers in 1990-91 are forecast at $2.90 to $3.30 per bushel, down from an average of $3.71 in 1989-90 and $3.72 in the 1988-89 marketing year. ``The 1990-91 price relationships and competition across classes (kinds) of wheat may change dramatically from 1989-90,'' the report said. ``Supplies of hard red winter wheat will be up sharply, resulting in more competition with hard red spring for the hard wheat market.'' Hard red winter wheat is concentrated in Kansas and other parts of the central and southern Great Plains, while hard red spring wheat is mostly in northern areas. White wheat is grown mainly in the Pacific Northwest, and soft red winter is raised in the eastern third of the country. ``Larger crops and reduced imports are expected in South Asia,'' the report said. ``This will mean that the larger U.S. white wheat crop will have to compete with soft red winter for export markets such as Egypt that take both classes of wheat.''

Pumpkin muffins, old-fashioned rice pudding, pork in peanut butter sauce, and stove-top tamale pie are some of the items in a new American Indian recipe book released by the Agriculture Department. About 70 traditional and non-traditional recipes are included in the 100-page, spiral-bound cookbook. Betty Jo Nelsen, administrator of the department's Food and Nutrition Service, said Monday the book was developed to help Indian families on reservations who get federal commodity donations. Indians and those working with them ``sent us some great recipes using USDA commodity foods,'' she said. ``From the recipes we received, we picked the ones for this book that taste good, use commodities for at least half the ingredients, use few pots and pans, and are quick and easy to make,'' Nelsen said. Although it is not a diet book, many of the recipes use less sugar, salt and fat than the original recipes called for, she said. State agencies and tribal organizations are responsible for distributing to Indian households participating in the commodity program.

DOC.HEAD: Tobacco Exports Threaten Health in Developing Nations: Koop
DOC.TEXT: U.S. tobacco sold overseas is often targeted at women and the young, carries no warning labels and threatens the health of people in developing countries, former Surgeon General C. Everett Koop says. ``Export of tobacco products is a moral outrage,'' Koop said at the World Conference on Lung Health meeting on Monday. While smoking in the United States dropped 5 percent last year, American tobacco exports rose 20 percent, Koop said. About 100 billion cigarettes were exported last year, he said. From 1971 to 1981, cigarette smoking increased in Asia and Latin America by 30 percent more than the population increase, Koop said. ``There is no sense in planning for the long-term economic health of a foreign society and providing that society with foreign aid on the one hand, if the physical health of the people of that society is fundamentally endangered during that same long term,'' Koop said. Koop's comments were bolstered by those of the health officials from developing countries. Dr. Judith MacKay, director of the Asian Consultancy on Tobacco Control in Hong Kong, said, ``For every smoker that stops in Boston, two more start in Beijing.'' The Bush administration is negotiating with Thailand to seek openings for the tobacco trade. Like other Asian countries, Thailand has a state monopoly on tobacco products. A recent General Accounting Office report said the negotiations were at odds with the administration's stated policy of promoting good health. Andy Copenhaver of the U.S. Cigarette Export Association in Washington said allowing American tobacco companies to market their products in Asia would not increase the number of smokers. Asian countries such as Japan, Korea and Taiwan have opened up to foreign tobacco companies only in recent years. Since then, smoking rates there have either declined or increased at the same rate as before, Copenhaver said. MacKay said estimates of how much smoking costs developing nations in health care, insurance and lost wages were not available. Dr. Carlos Alvarez Herrera, president of the Latin America Coordinating Committee on Smoking Control in Argentina, said tobacco companies are entrenched in Latin America. Tobacco advertising ``is everywhere, at all times, theaters, opera houses, many sporting events, popular concerts,'' Herrera said. ``We cannot compete with their public opinion.''

DOC.HEAD: Motorsports Fans: Potential Drunken Drivers or Respectable Citizens?
DOC.TEXT: A new study says that beer company sponsorship of motorsports races encourages drunken driving by fans, including young men with ``long shag haircuts'' and women with tight pants and braces. Beer industry supporters called the study elitist nonsense. Breweries spend $50 million a year to link beer and fast cars ``in a carefully crafted effort to promote beer, especially among working class youth and young adults who are part of the `car culture,''' said the American Automobile Association report released by a coalition of safety and health groups Monday. In dueling news conferences at the National Press Club, the coalition and the Beer Institute painted sharply differing images of the motorsports crowd. The fans at one beer-sponsored event at San Francisco's Cow Palace included ``teen-agers and young men with long shag haircuts, spotty complexions, work boots and denim pants; young women with tight pants, braces and hair-sprayed bouffant hairdos,'' said the study. ``Racing fans are overwhelmingly adult,'' said Less Richter of the National Association of Stock Car Auto Racing, who spoke at the beer industry event. ``They are employed, they are respectable citizens and they are too intelligent to believe any of the nonsense promoted in this booklet.'' The 92-page AAA report concluded that brewers target blue-collar youth by sponsoring motorsports racers and events across the country. Youth in that class are the most likely to drive drunk, said the report, which was based on previous studies, observation of 14 events and interviews with 60 high school students. The report offered no new scientific evidence of a link between drunken driving and beer ads or sponsorship of racing events. But researcher David Buchanan, coauthor, said it documents the way beer companies dangerously link beer and fast cars in the minds of racing fans. The Beer Institute said the research was faulty. One participant at the news conference, United Auto Workers union legislative director Dick Warden, characterized the coalition's view as ``elitist and condescending'' against blue-collar workers. Institute president James Sanders said 98 percent of racing enthusiasts are over 21 years old and the typical fan ``is an attractive customer for nearly any type of consumer product.'' At the coalition news conference, chairman Alexander Wagenaar was flanked by an ad showing a race car through a glass of Miller beer and a Coors T-shirt emblazoned with a picture of a big-wheeled ``monster truck.'' Wagenaar released copies of scolding letters to beer company executives and announced an effort to help drivers gain non-beer sponsors. The groups announced symbolic sponsorship of two relatively new race drivers: Michael Schriefer of Manhattan Beach, Calif., and Randi Lynn Hubbard of Aberdeen, Washington. In lieu of the several hundred thousand dollars sponsors often provide, both received stickers reading ``Drive Alcohol-Free'' to post on their vehicles. Ms. Hubbard said she has built her own ``monster truck'' but has been excluded from some competition sponsored by alcohol and tobacco companies because she uses her truck to campaign against the use of restricted substances by youth. ``I'm not going to change my mind,'' said the mother of three teen-age daughters. ``I'm going to continue to tell kids that drinking and driving is unsafe.'' Wagenaar said the coalition, formed in January to promote a nationwide campaign against drunken driving, includes 100 safety and health groups.

DOC.HEAD: De Klerk Trip Stirs Hopes Of End To South Africa's Isolation
An AP Extra
DOC.TEXT: President F.W. de Klerk's tour of Europe has thrilled whites here, who hope decades of international isolation may be ending. But it has dismayed blacks, who fear it may harm the anti-apartheid cause. ``It is wonderful to go to Europe with the knowledge that South Africa is busy taking its rightful place in the international community,'' de Klerk said before departing May 11 on his nine-nation trip, which runs through May 26. De Klerk's foreign tour is the most successful by a South African leader since World War II, and it has dominated the local media. TV and radio have followed every development, and newspaper front pages are filled with long accounts of the president's activities. ``The Iron Friendship,'' boomed a banner headline in The Sunday Times after de Klerk held talks with British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher. ``Red Carpet For F.W. In Paris,'' proclaimed The Citizen after de Klerk met French President Francois Mitterrand. For white South Africans, frustrated by decades of enforced international isolation, de Klerk's warm reception in Europe seems like a dream come true. Descended from Europeans, white South Africans value their ties with Western nations and fret over their country's poor reputation because of apartheid. De Klerk has raised hopes around the world that apartheid is about to end, and his cordial treatment in Europe has stirred hope among whites here that West European and other nations may ease or lift economic sanctions, and help boost the stagnant South African economy. ``My general impression is that Europe is ready to take specific steps, is really ready to do this re-evaluation,'' de Klerk said in London. Since assuming power last August, de Klerk has made major reforms. He released black leader Nelson Mandela and legalized black opposition groups. He has committed the government to ending white-minority rule and sharing power with the 28-million black majority. Those reforms and the South African leader's pragmatic style appear to have impressed European leaders. France, Britain and other nations have expressed cautious optimism that South Africa stands on the verge of historic change. British Foreign Secretary Douglas Hurd said the European Community was considering reductions in sanctions to help the reform process in South Africa. ``We need to consider how we pinpoint the signals ... so we can give encouragement,'' Hurd said. The 12 European Community countries have banned imports of iron, steel and gold coins from South Africa for more than three years, and also banned new investments in South Africa. But the prospect of a reduction in sanctions has alarmed the African National Congress, already concerned about the way de Klerk has been received. The ANC, the main black nationalist group, insists sanctions must be maintained to ensure the white minority government meets its commitment to end apartheid. ``The warmth of his (de Klerk's) reception here is not a good sign for us,'' said Sisa Ngombane, an ANC representative in Europe. The talk of easing sanctions ``is not a welcome development. This is a move by de Klerk to bust sanctions. I think the wrong signals are being given to him at this stage,'' he said. Mandela will attempt to offset some of de Klerk's triumph when he tours Europe next month. He is likely to urge leaders not to make any concessions on sanctions. South African newspapers have said Mandela also will be trying to diminish de Klerk's newfound prestige. De Klerk and Mandela are likely to be competing for attention on back-to-back visits to the United States in June. De Klerk's current journey offers a sharp contrast to the last major overseas tour by a South African president. Former President P.W. Botha was shunned by some heads of state when he toured seven West European nations in 1984. Yet de Klerk is under pressure to produce something more substantial from his trip than good feelings. South African officials say they need concrete economic and political concessions to help deflate right-wing white opposition to ending apartheid. De Klerk ``deserves something more tangible than kind words as a reward,'' said Foreign Minister Pik Botha.

DOC.HEAD: Israel Researching Ways to Build Supercomputer
DOC.TEXT: Disheartened by U.S. reluctance to allow the export of supercomputers to Israel, scientists in that country are researching a new system more powerful than anything the United States has, Israeli university officials say. Three Israeli institutions have applied for licenses to buy Cray and IBM supercomputers, but the permits have been delayed out of U.S. concern that Israel might use the fast-computing systems to develop nuclear weapons and ballistic missiles. U.S. government agencies have been considering the applications for almost two years but thus far have refused to grant the permits. ``The writing's on the wall,'' said Maia Hauser, the U.S. spokeswoman for Technion, Israel's leading high-tech university. ``We'll have to go it on our own.'' The university is asking supporters in the United States to raise funds for an alternative to the U.S. computers. Technion applied in 1988 for a Cray-2 computer for scientific and engineering research. The Weizman Institute of Science and Bar-Ilan University also have pending license requests. The Commerce Department, which has final say on the licensing, is banned by law from discussing supercomputer applications. Israel has set up a government committee to investigate the feasibility of researching so-called ``parallel processing,'' said Technion Vice President Brian Silver. In most computers, no matter how powerful, computation proceeds as one calculation at a time, known as ``serial processing.'' In some problems, multiple results might be calculable independently of each other, and a ``parallel processing'' machine is designed to save time by doing those independent calculations simultaneously. U.S. and West German scientists have developed some parallel processing computers, and some very specialized machines are available. Israel would have gone into such research anyway because that is the wave of the future in supercomputers, but the U.S. hold on the supercomputers has given the project a strong push, Silver said. ``There's not much difficulty in us producing them within several years if we decide to,'' said Silver. Technion scientists already have begun theoretical research into parallel computing and laboratories are being set up to conduct experiments, he said. Technion also has discussed buying a sophisticated West German computer, which uses applications of parallel computations, to serve as a basis for a future Israeli supercomputer, he said. Supporters of the sale of supercomputers to Israel note that Saudi Arabia, which is technically in a state of war with Israel, has been allowed to buy two Crays from the Minnesota-based CRAY Research Corp. But U.S. officials say those computers went to Saudi Arabia's oil company for use in seismic research, noting that the Saudis do not have an indigenous nuclear weapons program which could benefit from the machines. India, which is known to be developing nuclear weapons, has bought one supercomputer for weather predictions, and has a pending request for another. Israeli officials say that preventing Israel from buying supercomputers will not stop the development of nuclear weapons. Israel is known to have developed such arms on its own without supercomputers. Silver said Technion had agreed to submit to inspections on the Cray system to make sure it was not used for military purposes, but opponents of the sale say computer use is difficult to monitor.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Has Decided to Extend Favored Trade Status to China, Officials Say
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 12th graf, ``Sen. Pete Wilson to CORRECT party affiliation
DOC.TEXT: President Bush plans to renew China's most-favored nation trading status for another year, even though the decision is sure to provoke another round of criticism in Congress, administration officials said Monday night. The president is expected to tie the annual renewal to a provision giving him the option of withdrawing the privileged status quickly if he so choses, based on China's human-rights performance, said officials who spoke on the condition of anonymity. Bush's chief spokesman, Marlin Fitzwater, said Monday night no decision on the issue had been made. Bush must act by June 3. But sources said Bush would rather confront the issue _ sure to touch off another round of criticism in Congress _ now rather than wait until the deadline, which is only one day before the first aniversary of the Tiananmen Square massacre. The president would also like to clear the boards of the decision before the May 31-June 3 summit with Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the officials said, speaking on the condition of anonymity. Although Bush has recently voiced disappointment with China's performance in the aftermath of the crackdown, he decided that depriving China of most-favored-nation status would be too drastic a step, the officials said. Bush himself at a news conference last week expressed reservations about stripping China of the trade benefits for fear that it would harm the economy of Hong Kong. Some $8.5 billion worth of China-made goods are re-exported to the United States each year. Hong Kong officials have claimed that revocation of China's most-favored-nation status would make these goods subject to tariffs of up to 70 percent. Most-favored-nation status entitles nations to the lowest rate of tariffs and other trade benefits that are available to the United States' major trading partners. However, some nations, including the Soviet Union, have been denied most-favored-nation treatment because of their human-rights policies. Congress can act to block Bush's decision, but it seems unlikley that it could muster the two-third majorities needed to overturn his action. Sen. Pete Wilson, R-Calif., who returned to Washington with Bush Monday evening on Air Force One, said a decision to renew most-favored-nation status would likely be upheld by Congress, despite some grumbling. ``It's not as emotional an issue as the student visas one,'' Wilson said. He was referring to Bush's veto last winter of a bill to extent the visas of Chinese students in the United States. After a heavy lobbying campaign, the president won that battle in a close vote that sustained his veto. China's vice minister of trade has said his country could lose almost a fourth of its $43 billion worth of annual exports if the United States does not renew China's most-favored-nation trade status. The vice-minister, Shen Jueren, estimated the loss at $10 billion worth of exports, which would be the great bulk of China's $12 billion in shipments to the United States, from the effect of price increases caused by an increase in the average tariff from 9 percent to 50 percent. China's leading exports to the Untied States are clothing, shoes and toys. The United States ships China about $5.7 billion worth of goods each year, led by wheat, aircraft and fertilizer. China would revoke its most-favored-nation designation of the United States in retaliation, Shen said.

DOC.HEAD: Senate Fight Looms on Death Penalty
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Senate convenes 11 a.m. EDT; prenoon lead unlikely
DOC.TEXT: Senate Republicans are waging rhetorical warfare against a Democratic proposal they say would effectively rule out capital punishment in the United States. Sen. Orrin G. Hatch, R-Utah, assailed a Democratic provision in the crime bill that would permit those sentenced to death to use statistical evidence to argue they were the victims of race discrimination. Sen. Strom Thurmond, R-S.C., said the provision, sponsored by Sen. Edward M. Kennedy, D-Mass., ``is based upon the premise that the death penalty is currently imposed in a racially biased manner.'' In advance of Monday's opening of Senate floor debate on a wide-ranging crime bill, conservatives argued that Kennedy's proposal amounted to an indirect attempt to outlaw capital punishment. The overall package would authorize the death penalty for 30 federal crimes, including presidential assassination. But prosecutors seeking to carry out a sentence would have to show it wasn't being done in a racially discriminatory fashion. The Office of Management and Budget said Monday that, if enacted, the provision would have the effect of setting up ``an irrefutable presumption of `discrimination' based on a failure to achieve specific numerical proportions in the imposition of the death penalty.'' Thurmond said ``a majority of our nation's blacks support the death penalty.'' And he cited Justice Department statistics saying that 19 of every 1,000 whites convicted of murder are sentenced to death, compared with 12 of every 1,000 blacks convicted. Meanwhile, the chairman of the Senate Judiciary Committee, Sen. Joseph Biden, D-Del., accused the Bush administration of playing politics with the crime bill. Biden said he was disturbed about recent accusations by President Bush and Vice President Dan Quayle that the Senate has not moved aggressively in the law enforcement arena. ``We have heard, in my view too often, a lot of rhetoric suggesting that the president's crime bill has been languishing in the Senate since last May and I think it's time to set the record straight,'' Biden said. He noted that some elements of the Bush package already have been passed, including the 1988 bill allowing the death penalty for murders committed by drug kingpins. Bush, in a speech to a law enforcement audience in Portland, Ore., Sunday, accused Congress of spawning ``weak imitations'' of his proposals to attack crime after allowing them to languish for a year. ``We must reject those who soft-pedal the need to be hard on crime,'' Bush said.
