He accused lawmakers of sitting on key anti-crime proposals, although the president did acknowledge that Congress agreed to his request for more federal law enforcement officers, prosecutors and prisons. Biden maintained that Congress not only passed key elements of the original Bush package, but that lawmakers ``strengthened it, made it stronger.'' On the remaining issues such as capital punishment and the length of time prisoners have for filing federal appeals, he said, the administration seems to have no interest in negotiating with Democrats. ``Congress got to work on this proposal right away,'' Biden said. ``Just four months later, the full Senate had passed every single request in the second part of the president's crime package _ that is, the funding for law enforcement, the teeth _ the portion that will and has begun to make a difference in terms of making the streets safer for Americans.'' ``So I think we should kind of hopefully put aside this sort of partisan banter,'' the senator said, ``and hopefully not hear about how the president's crime bill has been left to languish on Capitol Hill.'' ``The time to play politics on this kind of issue is over,'' Biden said.

DOC.HEAD: Medical Experts Seek Stronger Warnings of Possible Birth Defects
With PM-Cancer-Antibodies
DOC.TEXT: Medical experts say stronger efforts are needed to make sure women do not use the acne drug Accutane during pregnancy because it can cause birth defects. The drug that offers hope to people suffering from a severe, disfiguring form of acne also can cause serious birth defects in one out of four cases where the mother used Accutane during pregnancy, officials say. Experts on two committees advising the Food and Drug Administration agreed Monday that the manufacturer, Hoffman-LaRoche, has alerted physicians and patients to the birth defect risk. But the committees recommended that more be done to get the word out. Hoffman-LaRoche officials said they were pleased with the recommendations, two of which were similar to additional warnings the company had announced earlier in the day. The FDA advisory committees rejected the advice of some within the agency who want Accutane withheld from all women to eliminate any risk of birth defects from the drug. The committee actions came as other physicians were reporting that Accutane can significantly block the growth of new tumors in people being treated for smoking-related cancer of the mouth and throat. Accutane has been on the market since 1982 to treat what is called severe recalcitrant cystic acne. In September 1988, Roche Dermatologics, a division of Hoffman-LaRoche, began a program aimed at educating physicians about the importance of having patients avoid pregnancy during Accutane treatment. Roche officials say 86 cases of birth defects have been reported to the company as being associated with Accutane since the drug was first marketed. But David Graham, an FDA medical epidemiologist, said that number represents only about 10 percent of the number that actually occur. He estimated that since 1982, nearly 1,000 babies have been born with birth defects associated with Accutane. Graham also estimated that 90 percent of the women using Accutane do not have the severe form of acne for which the drug is intended. They could be treated with other drugs without the kind of risk Accutane poses, he said. Accutane was prescribed last year for about 65,000 women of childbearing age. Graham said less than 4,000 women are estimated to have the severe form of acne that requires Accutane treatment. The overprescribing exposes tens of thousands of women to the possibility of a malformed child if they become pregnant while being treated, he said. Graham said one study found that women using Accutane underwent twice as many abortions as women not using the drug. Roche's pregnancy prevention program ``has failed to achieve its objective,'' he said. ``The only way to eliminate exposure is to eliminate use of this (drug) by women.'' However, Robert Armstrong, director of medical affairs for Roche Dermatologics, said Graham's estimates were based on shaky assumptions. He also said that no one is sure how many women have the severe acne. But he said he was sure the number of congenital malformations that result from Accutane are not as large as Graham believes. ``If there were that many out there, they would be noticed and reported,'' Armstrong said. The advisory committees recommended that the company emphasize the importance of a pregnancy test before a patient starts using Accutane. It also recommended a way for patients to return any unused Accutane at the end of treatment. The company said it was undertaking similar measures. The panels also said forms to record patient consent, now available in English and Spanish, should be available in more languages, and physicians should be encouraged to refer Accutane patients for contraception counseling.

DOC.HEAD: House Opens Debate on Clean Air Bill
LaserPhoto WX7
DOC.TEXT: Auto industry lobbyists are working to head off attempts to toughen smog controls in the House clean air bill, including a requirement to build 1 million non-gasoline powered cars a year. The proposal, being pushed by Rep. Henry Waxman, D-Calif., is expected to provide the most fireworks when the air pollution control bill comes up for floor votes on Thursday. The sweeping legislation is the first strengthening of federal clean air laws in 13 years and imposes new curbs on acid rain pollution, industrial toxic releases and smog-causing emissions from industry and automobiles. It is expected to cost more than $21 billion a year when fully implemented. The Senate approved a similar measure in April. The House began debate on the clean air bill Monday, while closed-door talks continued in an effort to work out compromises on some of more than a half-dozen proposed amendments. Agreements were reached on several amendments, including a measure aimed at curbing pollution over national parks and requiring a cleaner gasoline blend in smog-troubled urban areas, according to participants in the talks. But sources involved in the closed-door discussions said late Monday it was all but certain that Waxman's alternative fuel car amendment would be left for a showdown on the House floor. Waxman's amendment calls on automakers to produce non-gasoline powered automobiles for sale in the nine U.S. cities with the highest air pollution. The cities are Los Angeles, San Diego, Houston, Chicago, Milwaukee, Baltimore, New York, Philadelphia and Hartford, Conn. Rep. John Dingell, D-Mich., chairman of the Energy and Commerce Committee, who has been protective of auto interests, is strongly opposed to the production mandate. He said Monday he considered ``all the really important environmental issues'' to be already resolved and suggested those remaining in dispute represented little more than a difference of viewpoint among congressmen. Waxman said his measure differed little from a proposal offered by President Bush a year ago, which the White House later backed away from following strong auto industry opposition. The amendment calls for automakers to produce 500,000 alternative fuel cars for sale in the nine cities by 1994 and double that number by 1996. The cars would cut auto emissions in those cities by 75 percent by the end of the decade, according to Waxman. Auto industry lobbyists have argued for weeks that the mandate would push alterative fuel cars onto the road too quickly, saying they may be forced to make cars they can't sell. ``Until we know how to produce these vehicles in volume you run the risk of killing the program by forcing it onto (the public) too quickly,'' said William Ball, a lobbyist for General Motors Corp., in an interview Monday. Daniel Weiss, a lobbyist for the Sierra Club, scoffed at suggestions by the automakers that they might not be able to sell the vehicles. If required to do so, the automakers will find ways to market the vehicles, perhaps ``promote them as `Big Green Machines,''' he said. Democrats and Republicans in the House agree that the major components of the clean air bill that passed the Energy and Commerce Committee 42-1 in April are likely to stay intact on the House floor.

DOC.HEAD: Embargoed for release 10 a.m. EDT; time set by source
Many Elderly Skip Meals, Survey Shows
DOC.TEXT: Most elderly Americans know they need a sensible diet to stay healthy, but one in five say they skip at least one meal a day, according to a survey released today. The survey also found that 45 percent of senior citizens take multiple prescription drugs, which can affect appetite or absorption of nutrients. Also, one out of four surveyed had a household income under $10,000 a year. Yet, while about 85 percent said a healthy diet plays an important role in preventing and recovering from illness, only 18 percent said they worried a lot about a proper diet and more than a third said they don't worry at all. The survey was released by the Nutrition Screening Initiative, a five-year project launched by a coalition of medical, health care and aging groups. ``Nutrition is one of the important vital signs, just as blood pressure or pulse,'' said Dr. Gerald Keller, an official of the American Academy of Family Physicians, a leader of the coalition. ``The fact is, however, America has not effectively incorporated routine nutrition screening and care into the nation's system of health care delivery,'' he said. The initiative will focus first on the elderly, who face a disproportionate nutritional risk for a variety of reasons. Many live alone and tend not to cook, while others have reduced appetite and sense of taste, sometimes because of the medications they take, said Paul Kerschner, senior vice president of the National Council on the Aging. The initiative will include efforts to educate health care professionals, administrators and policy makers about the need for proper nutrition, plus media campaigns aimed at the elderly and those who care for them. The survey was conducted by Peter Hart Research Associates Inc. A sample of 802 people over age 65 was polled by telephone Feb. 7-16.

DOC.HEAD: Barry Wants Separate Trial On New Charges
DOC.TEXT: Mayor Marion Barry says he is ready to go to trial next month on drug charges, but is asking a judge to keep six new charges against him a separate matter. Barry ``is handicapped by the lateness of the new charges'' and by the government's refusal to disclose details of the charges, his lawyers said in court papers Monday. The mayor was indicted May 11 on a charge of conspiracy and five counts of cocaine possession. The six new charges were added to eight previous ones brought Feb. 15. The June 4 trial would include all 14 charges. Barry said he wanted to go to trial June 4 as scheduled on the eight earlier charges _ five misdemeanor counts of cocaine possession and three felony perjury charges _ while handling the six new charges as a separate matter. The government has refused to disclose names of alleged co-conspirators or to give the place, time and witnesses involved in the new charges, Barry's lawyers said. ``Given the government's reluctance to deliver the information and the shortness of the time until trial, it may be highly disadvantageous'' for Barry to proceed to trial on the new charges, the court papers said. Barry was charged in the February indictment with five counts of cocaine possession and three felony charges of lying to a federal grand jury in connection with his alleged involvement with drugs.

DOC.HEAD: Government Strips Communists of Property, Building Use
DOC.TEXT: The government has announced it will strip the Communist Party of all the property it was granted use of during the past four decades. The decision Monday followed a move three days earlier to freeze ownership of all buildings and other fixed assets owned by the Communists, who were ousted from power in a peaceful revolution last year. The moves were likely to be highly popular in Czechoslovakia, where up to 100,000 people have attended recent street rallies calling for the Communists to give up their property and urging a ban on the party in upcoming free elections. Kvestoslava Korinkova, head of the government's Inspection Commission, said all contracts for property used by the Communists will be declared null and void on June 1, a week before the country's first free elections in more than 40 years. ``Such contracts were very often made under strange circumstances,'' Ms. Korinkova said. She said the property would be turned over to educational, cultural, health and other institutions, or to other political parties. She did not say how many buildings would be affected, but she estimated the total value at $306 million. Last Friday, parliament froze $281 million in fixed assets of the Communist Party pending investigation of each acquisition. Korinkova said the acquisitions would be considered legal only if made before Nov. 17, 1989, the start of the popular revolt against Communist rule, and only if paid for from party dues.

DOC.HEAD: Government Agrees to Pay Noriega Attorneys
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto MH1
DOC.TEXT: U.S. taxpayers will foot Manuel Noriega's legal bills until $20 million of his frozen assets are confiscated or released, under a deal that averts disclosure of secret U.S. payments to the fallen dictator. Before the deal was reached Monday, Noriega's lawyers had threatened to quit the drug trafficking case because they hadn't been paid. Prosecutors froze the former Panamanian leader's assets, contending they were illegally obtained. In agreeing to cover Noriega's legal fees, the government headed off a confrontation over $11 million in U.S. intelligence agency payments he claims to have received over several decades. Noriega's lawyers had been trying to force the government to produce secret records of those payments to show Noriega had legitimate sources of income other than drugs. But on Monday, the defense agreed to drop the subpoenas when the deal involving Noriega's legal fees is formally approved. The U.S. government ``wanted to avoid litigation that would get into matters having to do, certainly, with classified information, with payments by our government and other governments to Noriega,'' defense attorney Jon May said. U.S. Attorney Dexter Lehtinen told U.S. District Judge William Hoeveler that the government agreed to cover the legal bills ``to assure Mr. Noriega receives a fair trial.'' The long and complex nature of the case made it possible for the prosecution to invoke a federal law allowing the unusual arrangement, he said. Noriega, who was in court in his general's uniform, agreed to sign affidavits declaring he was indigent and promising to repay the government if his assets are released. ``It can't be said that the American taxpayer is paying for this, because all the funding for the general's legal fees will come out of the seized assets,'' said chief defense attorney Frank Rubino. Defense attorney Steven Kollin has estimated Noriega would need $5 million to properly defend himself. The defense contends prosecutors have spent $12 million so far and are prepared to spend $25 million more to convict Noriega. Hoeveler gave his blessing to the agreement, but it is subject to approval by Chief U.S. District Judge James King. A hearing was set for Thursday. The U.S. government has frozen 27 Noriega accounts around the world valued at $20 million. Defense attorneys had subpoenaed records from the CIA, Drug Enforcement Administration and other agencies for evidence of payments to Noriega during the period he is said to have been a U.S. intelligence agent. Prosecutors acknowledge the United States paid Noriega. But ``the amount is substantially less than that offered by the defense counsel,'' said Diane Cossin, spokeswoman for the U.S. attorney's office. She would not elaborate. Prosecutors submitted a list of payments to the judge Monday but insisted it be kept secret. Noriega was indicted in 1988 on charges of taking $4.6 million in bribes from the Medellin cartel to protect cocaine smuggling into the United States. He turned himself in to U.S. authorities Jan. 4, two weeks after the invasion of Panama. He is being held at the federal Metropolitan Correctional Center outside Miami.

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev Planners Overwhelmed With Offers
LaserPhoto MP1
DOC.TEXT: The T-shirts are out, the vodka billboards are coming down and the bids to take Mikhail Gorbachev fishing or bear-watching don't seem to stop. ``Everybody's got an angle. No doubt about that,'' says Vern Freeh, vice president of international affairs for Minnesota-based Land 'O Lakes Inc., a food processing and farm supply cooperative. ``We all want to meet him.'' Since it was announced last week that Gorbachev will spend six hours in Minnesota on June 3, Gov. Rudy Perpich's office has been swamped with requests to meet the Soviet leader. Hundreds of people have offered gifts or tributes, and entrepreneurs quickly kicked in with T-shirts and a ``Tell it to Gorbachev'' hotline. Gorbachev wants to spend two hours talking with agricultural and business leaders to build on longstanding economic ties between the Soviet Union and Minnesota. Perpich said Monday that a final intinerary has not been determined but that Gorbachev's visit will probably include an address at a rally at the Capitol in St. Paul. The rest of his six-hour visit remained up for grabs. At least that's what the callers hoped. ``We've been receiving hundreds of phone calls every day,'' said Eileen Biernat, a Perpich aide. An Ely man who can call black bears out of the woods to meet with tourists offered to summon bears so Gorbachev can have his picture taken with them. And the Breezy Point City Council thinks Gorbachev would enjoy an hour or two of walleye fishing. Other suggestions: _In Minneapolis, Urban League President Gleason Glover wants Gorbachev to meet with Minnesota's minority leaders. Foreign dignitaries, Glover said, rarely make contact with U.S. minority groups. _Duluth officials plan to ship 173 old voting machines to Petrozavodsk, Duluth's Soviet sister city, to replace its paper ballots. Duluth replaced the machines last year with a computerized system. _For $10, Minnesotans can dial a 900 telephone number for updates on the Gorbachev visit and to tape messages for the Soviet leader. Among those hoping to profit on the hoopla in Minnesota are T-shirt makers. Morton Rykiss of Diversified Arts said his company has five designs, including one reading ``Hugs to the kids in Russia from the kids in Minnesota, with love.'' The distributor of Minnesota-made Karkov vodka announced Monday that it would remove billboards in the Twin Cities that show a likeness of Gorbachev holding a bottle of Karkov under the caption ``The Party's Over,'' a reference to the Communist Party's troubles. Some Minnesotans felt the billboards, which went up before Gorbachev's visit was announced, would insult the Soviet leader. ``We never imagined this much controversy and we certainly didn't imagine this much press,'' said Gerry Schmitt, a partner and creative director of Minneapolis ad agency Schmitt & Sloan. ``We set out to create a brand awareness for Karkov, and one way or another, it has.'' Out West, Gorbachev can expect a mixed reception when he arrives for a visit to Stanford University and the San Francisco Bay area June 3-4. The Soviet Jews Bay Area Council will hold protests at Stanford and in the city to complain about ``the unchecked rise of anti-Semitism'' in the Soviet Union, said spokesman Marshall Platt. Estonians, Latvians and Lithuanians are preparing protests to demand the independence of the Baltic states. Others are planning a warmer welcome. Opera singers want to serenade the Soviet leader, a school is eager to put on a play for him and businessmen hope to get close enough to whisper a few words about terrific deals. ``Some people are calling up asking to buy tickets, but there are no tickets for anything yet,'' said Mary Bartlett of Stanford's office of public affairs.

DOC.HEAD: Researchers See No Peace Dividend Yet
DOC.TEXT: Global military spending barely declined last year and the public has gleaned no ``disarmament dividend or peace prize'' from the thawing of the Cold War, arms researchers reported. In its annual yearbook, released Monday, the Stockholm International Peace Research Institute also reported that 26 developing countries have acquired ballistic missiles capable of delivering nuclear, chemical or biological warheads. The proliferation of these superlethal missiles ``has created a new fear of arms races among emerging regional powers,'' said the institute, commonly called SIPRI. The 700-page report said, however, that cash-strapped Third World countries bought fewer weapons and spent less money in 1989 _ about $16 billion _ than at any time since 1976. In 1989, ``the prospects for lasting peace have considerably improved, particularly in Europe. But peace has not yet broken out,'' said Walter Stuetzle, director of the 24-year-old research institute. SIPRI, which is financed by the Swedish government, tracks developments in global arms traffic, military conflicts and disarmament initiatives. Stuetzle, a former West German undersecretary of defense, told a news conference that the U.S.-Soviet strategic arms treaty under negotiation would not reduce nuclear arsenals enough to have an impact on military capabilities. U.S. Secretary of State James A. Baker III and Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze announced after talks in Moscow Saturday that major progress had been made that may allow a treaty to be initialed at a summit next week and signed before year's end. ``There is still room for drastic reductions,'' Stuetzle said. The treaty ``has no military relevance when you talk about deterrence or perception.'' In its report, SIPRI said $950 billion was spent worldwide on defense last year, a 2 percent drop from the previous years. ``After the dizzying heights of the 1980s, global defense spending began to fall in 1989. The decline was modest, however,'' and was due more to tight budgets and technology advances than to peaceful intentions, it said. The United States and the Soviet Union trimmed military spending by about 2 percent, but NATO's European members kept their defense budgets stable. In East Europe, cuts were announced, but won't be felt until next year. ``Neither the political will to pursue reductions beyond this level nor the reward in the form of a disarmament dividend or peace prize are forthcoming,'' it said. Though arms control prospects looked bright, ``performance did not match up to promises'' in reducing military spending, it said. The report also made these points: _ The number of wars and major regional conflicts fell last year to 32 from 35, the fewest in three years. In addition, about 75 lesser conflicts were waged, defined as involving fewer than 1,000 deaths. _ The Soviet Union led the world in arms exports last year, though the value shrank to $11.6 billion from $12.5 billion the previous year and from $14.7 billion in 1987. Nearly three-fourths were sold to Third World countries. U.S. arms exports totalled $10.7 billion, and about 76 percent went to industrial nations. _ India, for the third successive year, was the world's largest arms importer, spending $3.8 billion. Japan was second, spending $3.1 billion. _ The cost for destroying chemical weapons will be enormous, even for those countries like Belgium and Denmark still keeping 75-year-old stocks from World War I. The United States must spend $3 billion, while the Soviet Union still lacks the technology to safely demolish its arsenal.

DOC.HEAD: Budget Negotiators Hear Election-Year Clock Ticking
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Budget talks resume 3 p.m. EDT; may stand
DOC.TEXT: Rep. Bill Schuette said he was visiting his district town of Mount Pleasant, Mich., on Friday when a woman walked up to him. ``I have my `Keep the Pledge' button on,'' said the Republican, who is challenging Democratic Sen. Carl Levin in this fall's election. ``And she comes in, puts her finger on the button and says, `Way to go, Bill, keep it up.''' Schuette is one of many Capitol Hill Republicans sporting ``Keep the Pledge'' buttons these days. It's a plea to President Bush to not abandon his ``no new taxes'' campaign promise during budget negotiations with Congress. But the buttons _ and the voters' sentiments they elicit _ also are an example of a very real external pressure on the White House officials and congressional leaders who are trying to forge a fiscal 1991 budget deal. This is an election year. And the closer the talks drag to primaries and to Election Day, the more reluctant lawmakers will be to agree to tax increases or deep spending cuts. The third session is set for today. ``There's a serious problem with trying to do this in an election year,'' House Budget Committee Chairman Leon Panetta, D-Calif., one of the negotiators, said last week. ``Both parties have already begun to posture on the issues.'' Democratic feelings are still ruffled by White House Chief of Staff John Sununu's comments before the bargaining even began that Bush would never seriously consider raising taxes. Sununu's remarks were later disavowed by White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater, who reiterated that everything _ including new taxes _ was negotiable. But Democrats remain angry _ and poised to strike back. Last week, the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee sent six pages of ``talking points'' to Democratic House candidates listing arguments they could make against tax increases enacted during the Reagan-Bush years. Included was a full page entitled, ``The Sununu Tax Crunch,'' listing 10 tax boosts Sununu presided over while governor of New Hampshire. ``Sununu, who has spent the past week reiterating Bush's `no new taxes' lie, raised taxes 10 times while he was governor of New Hampshire,'' the paper said. Further adding to the political decibel level were three Democratic congressmen. They called a news conference last Thursday to criticize Bush for not making a nationally televised speech detailing the deficit problem and his proposal to address it. The president isn't about to do that now, before even having a chance to bargain with Democrats. But that didn't stop the lawmakers from using the opportunity to attack Bush. ``Sometimes one has to use that bully pulpit for leadership,'' said Rep. Charles Schumer, D-N.Y. Republicans are not sitting mute, either. Eighteen GOP senators sent a letter to Bush promising they would oppose any budget deal that includes new taxes. And Schuette has collected more than 40 signatures from House Republicans for a letter asking Bush to reject any package with tax increases. ``The Republican Party stands for the working men and women of this country and has consistently opposed efforts to raise taxes,'' the note says. None of this has made the work of the budget negotiators any easier. ``We're trying to walk through it, and you have the Hatfields and the McCoys firing shots over our heads,'' said Panetta last week. The negotiators have such a complicated task that their sessions are expected to last weeks and perhaps months. ``One conferee was heard suggesting we could get it done by December,'' said Rep. Bill Frenzel of Minnesota, ranking Republican on the House Budget Committee and a participant in the talks. In the end, the onset of the campaign season could actually end up speeding the negotiators' task. The bargainers know that the sooner they finish their job, the easier it will be to line up a majority of votes in the House and Senate to enact whatever budget pact emerges. But for now, the prospect of the upcoming elections does little but complicate the already problematic task of reaching a budget compromise.

DOC.HEAD: Top Salvadoran Military Commanders Linked to Human Rights Abuses
DOC.NOTE: EDS: House debate scheduled about 2 p.m.; lead unlikely
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto WX8
DOC.TEXT: Nearly all of El Salvador's top military commanders have been in charge of units linked to human rights abuses, according to a study released on the eve of a House battle over cutting U.S. military aid. Fourteen of the country's 15 senior military officials have commanded units documented to have killed civilians, tortured prisoners, kidnapped citizens or covered up such abuses, found a study by the Arms Control and Foreign Policy Caucus. The report did not seek to establish direct participation in human rights crimes by the officers, who include Chief of Staff Col. Rene Emilio Ponce. But it said the group's rise to power at least illustrates a striking lack of accountability in the country's military. Caucus chairman Rep. Howard Berman, D-Calif., said the results call into question a United States policy which has provided nearly $4 billion in aid to El Salvador over the past decade, one-fourth of that directly to the military. ``When we got involved in El Salvador, we gambled that we could reform the El Salvadoran military,'' Berman told a news conference. ``This report makes it tragically clear that this gamble failed.'' The caucus, a group of members of the House and Senate who have opposed U.S. policy toward El Salvador for years, issued its report a day before the House was to begin a battle over whether to cut the $85 million in annual U.S. military aid in half this year and next. The cut would include new conditions to pressure the government and leftist rebels to reach a negotiated peace. The amendment being considered today was part of a bill authorizing new economic aid for the new democratic governments in Panama and Nicaragua. Democratic proponents of the aid cut predicted they would narrowly win that vote, which they hope will be a strong signal to both the Salvadoran government and to the Bush administration that U.S. policy is headed for a sharp turn. Opinion on Capitol Hill has turned increasingly against the Salvadoran military since the murders last Nov. 16 of six Jesuit priests, their housekeeper and her daughter. Nine military personnel have been charged in the murders, but there is widespread skepticism about whether the killers will ever be brought to justice. Secretary of State James A. Baker III, in private meetings with congressional opponents of the administration's policy, has agreed some conditions should be imposed on new U.S. aid. But he has objected to linking the issue to the Panama-Nicaragua aid bill. In a speech Monday to corporate executives, Deputy Secretary of State Lawrence Eagleburger suggested the link could delay consolidation of the new democracies. ``I personally think it is outrageous,'' Eagleburger said. ``I am not here to bash the U.S. Congress, but there are some in that body that deserve it.'' The report also found that 12 of the 15 top-ranking officers were 1966 graduates of the country's military academy and part of a large class whose personal loyalties take precedence over the rule of law. ``Many officers have detailed knowledge of each others' questionable business practices,'' information which can be used to blackmail others into stonewalling human rights investigations, it said. One U.S. official told congressional investigators that after the Jesuit killings ``a lot of officers knew something was up and they didn't come forward ... They are a tight group.'' And a U.S. Embassy official interviewed in El Salvador told investigators that 5 to 15 percent of the military is made up of ``ghost soldiers'' who do not exist, but whose pay is funneled to commanders.

DOC.HEAD: Prom-Night Limos: Going in Style or Being Taken for a Ride?
DOC.TEXT: Anybody can roll around the capital in a dark-windowed limousine, but what it costs depends on who you are. A teen-ager on the way to the prom can end up paying six times more than an aging big shot. That's age discrimination, say three area high school students who filed complaints with local government consumer officials. Teenagers are charged the most, even though limousine service managers say they're often the best behaved _ they don't drink and they tip well because it's not their money. Adults pay roughly $60 an hour for a chauffeur-driven limousine and the customer determines how long the rental will last; teenaged prom-goers pay a lump sum of about $400 for a minimum of six hours. Kearney C. Francis, 16, said she called 30 area limousine services, wanting a chauffeur to drive her and her friends to a restaurant, then around the city for a quick tour, and then to the prom, where they would find their own way home _ all in all, a three-hour job. Francis says she discovered such an order was impossible to fill. The companies she contacted all asked her if she was renting the limousine for a prom. They then told her she must rent it for at least six hours and pay the lump sum up front. ``I asked them why it was different for a prom, and I never could get a straight answer,'' she said. ``During prom time, that's the way all the companies do it,'' said Senora Pyles of Ritz Limousine in Capitol Heights, Md., who told Francis she would be charged $375 for six hours and could not rent it for a shorter period. Asked if a couple wanting a sightseeing tour would be charged the same, Pyles said no. ``We'd go out of business if we charged you a six-hour minimum,'' she said. Andrea DelVillar, office administrator of Congressional Limousine in Bethesda, Md., says the students are paying for the ``motherly approach.'' For $432 _ and a six-hour minimum, all paid up front _ the students don't have to worry about paying the tax and the tip and have an evening of ``promptness and worry-free driving.'' Congressional Limousine, unlike many other services, however, includes sparkling wine and flowers in their prom packages. Francis says all customers, not just students, should be free from worrying about good service. ``Taking care of your patrons should be part of your service, not something you pay extra for.'' DelVillar says adults also are charged a six-hour minimum on weekend nights but acknowledged ``if it's a young voice on the phone, I'll say, `is this for a prom,' and then discuss the package with them.'' But Keith Shifrin, a classmate of Francis, said he called a few limousine services twice _ first, saying he was arranging a prom date, then again saying he wanted a limousine for a sightseeing tour with his wife. The prom calls received quotes of package deals; the tour calls received quotes of $59 to $65 an hour with no set minimum. Finally, Francis said her father, Leslie Francis, called Arrive in Style limousine service and negotiated a three-hour package for $180, no questions asked. Pat Bowie of Arrive in Style said, however, his company does ask teenagers if they are reserving a limousine for the prom, and ``we keep a list of all the prom nights in the area.'' Arrive in Style then charges $395 with a six-hour minimum. ``It's just a business decision, since most of your proms run five to 12 hours.'' Judy Doctor, manager of consumer education at the Montgomery County, Md., Office of Consumer Affairs, said she had received Francis's complaint, which she filed along with Stefanie Felrice and Miriam Plotkin, and the county would begin investigations for discrimination and possible violations of the county's Consumer Protection Law.

DOC.HEAD: Nikkei Closes Higher
DOC.TEXT: The Nikkei Stock Average closed at 31,938.30, up 173.25 points, or 0.55 percent on the Tokyo Stock Exchange Tuesday.

DOC.HEAD: Kentucky Town Preparing for Brass Band Revival
LaserPhoto LH1
DOC.TEXT: Band director George Foreman raised his hands and let them drop in a quick downbeat, summoning a brassy musical flourish from about two dozen trumpet, trombone and tuba players. The martial melody and its bouncy rhythm conjured a nostalgic picture from the turn of the century, when thousands of brass bands performed on weekends at community parks all across the country. But the fanfare being played at a recent rehearsal of The Advocate Brass Band was newly written. And some music observers say the 3-year-old group and its music are part of a slow but steady revival of brass bands. The band is preparing to play host for the Great American Brass Band Festival June 16-17. The festival will be held at the city park in this central Kentucky town known for its antique charm and Victorian-style homes. This night, however, the musicians were getting ready for the debut performance of the newly composed ``The Advocate-Messenger March.'' The song, in the tradition of newspaper anthems such as ``The Washington Post March,'' is named for the local daily paper, the band's sponsor. The group has a large collection of rarely heard marches named for a wide array of American papers. As many as 20,000 people are expected for the festival, which will include a balloon race, buggy rides and displays of antique cars and bicycles. ``We want to capture the nostalgia of a concert in the park,'' said Foreman, co-chairman of the festival and managing director of the Norton Center for the Arts at Centre. Through much of the 19th century and into the 1920s, the brass band was a familiar part of the American town. The bands played at political rallies, parades, parties and concerts. Harper's magazine in the 1880s reported that there were 10,000 brass bands in the United States, Foreman said. Brass bands began to decline, Foreman believes, because World War I took away many of the musicians and the advent of radio and phonographs ``gave people other entertainment opportunities.'' Paul Droste, president of the North American Brass Band Association, said there are about 60 brass bands in the country. The association was formed in 1983 when the bands began to rebound after nearly dying out in the 1950s. Droste, a music professor at Ohio State University, is also director of the Brass Band of Columbus, a British-style band that has been named champion of the association four times in the past five years. The Columbus band is expected to be among eight bands at the non-competitive Danville festival. Among the other groups will be Dejan's Olympia Brass Band of New Orleans. The seven-piece band has performed at Mardi Gras, jazz funerals, in movies and on television. ``It's a unique musical approach,'' Harry Mayronne, Olympia Brass Band business manager, said of the festival. ``We're excited about playing in it. It's exploring all areas of brass band music.'' Another is Mr. Jack Daniel's Original Silver Cornet Band of Lynchburg, Tenn., which has played at the White House, Lincoln Center and three public TV specials. The Advocate Brass Band started in 1987 when the Danville Advocate-Messenger asked Foreman if he would put together a band to play at an old-fashioned political stump rally it was sponsoring. ``When it was over nobody cared much about the speeches,'' said Mary Schurz, publisher of the newspaper. ``But they loved the band.'' The newspaper decided to sponsor the band. It purchased uniforms for the members to wear during its six public performances each year. There are several college and high school band directors, an optician, stockbroker and a space systems engineer in the 25-piece band. Vince DeMartino, a nationally known trumpeter, plays cornet. ``I think this is what communities are all about by providing music and entertainment and a musical experience for ourselves,'' said DeMartino. ``It's great enjoyment for me. It's great relaxation and a non-pressure situation.''

DOC.HEAD: Federal Appeals Court Upholds Judge's Age Discrimination Suit
DOC.TEXT: Justice Louis Peck says he feels like a condemned man who has won a reprieve _ the right not to be forced into retirement at 70. A federal appeals court in New York ruled Monday that the 71-year-old Vermont Supreme Court justice could remain on the bench. Peck had been placed on retirement status by the court's administrator, Thomas Lehner, and his last day on the job was marked in for June 30, 1989. Vermont's Constitution requires all judges to retire at age 70, but Peck would have none of it, and he filed an age discrimination complaint. ``I feel like a condemned man who has had a reprieve,'' Peck said after the 2nd U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals upheld a federal judge's ruling in his favor. ``Personally it is very satisfying.'' However, Peck said he may retire anyway. Lehner said he had no immediate comment. The ruling settles the Peck case but not the mandatory retirement issue. Two other federal appeals courts, the 8th Circuit based in St. Louis and the 1st Circuit in Boston, have ruled against judges wanting to stay in their jobs despite retirement provisions in their states. ``Obviously Congress has not made its intention clear if the courts disagree,'' said William Gray, who represented the state of Vermont against Peck. Gray said the state has not decided whether to appeal to the U.S. Supreme Court. At issue was whether the federal Age Discrimination and Employment Act applied to appointed state judges. Vermont argued that judges fit one of the exceptions _ ``appointees on the policymaking level'' _ and that Congress should not tell states how to set up their courts. On the first argument, the appeals court said appointed state judges do not fall under the exception. On the second argument, the judges said Vermont had failed to show the federal law trampled on the rights of the states. Peck was appointed to the five-member Supreme Court bench in 1981. His term expires in 1993.

DOC.HEAD: Drug Helps Transplant Patient
DOC.TEXT: An increase in Stormie Jones' medication quieted doctors' fears that the world's longest surviving heart-liver transplant patient was rejecting her second donor liver. ``Her condition's excellent. She just needed an adjustment in her medication,'' said Dr. Robert D. Gordon, transplant surgeon at Children's Hospital of Pittsburgh. The 12-year-old from White Settlement, Texas, returned to Pittsburgh on Sunday after tests showed high liver enzyme levels _ a sign of possible organ rejection. She had been taking the Japanese drug FK-506 since her last operation, on Feb. 20. Stormie will receive higher doses of FK-506 intravenously until she is discharged, probably within a few days, and will take the drug orally when she goes home, Gordon said Monday. ``When you're using a new drug you're a little sensitive to toxicity, over-sensitive perhaps. We now realize we lowered our dosages a little too much,'' he said. Modifications in dosages also will be made for many of the 400 transplant patients currently taking FK-506. The Food and Drug Administration approved the drug for use only at Children's and nearby Presbyterian-University Hospital. ``I think we've been making that error systematically over the last few months,'' Gordon said. In 1984, Stormie received the double transplant to control a congenital condition that left her cholesterol levels 10 times higher than normal. She received a new liver this year after hepatitis damaged her first donor liver. The surgeon said Stormie this time had a mild rejection episode, which he said is not uncommon the first few months after a transplant. ``We're not alarmed,'' he said. ``We don't think this liver is in jeopardy or that she's looking at another transplant.'' That's good news for Stormie, who has been awaiting a party for her 13th birthday on May 31, said her mother, Lois ``Suzie'' Purcell. ``Thirteen is a very special time in someone's life,'' she said. ``She's excited. She's running around all over the place.''

DOC.HEAD: Group Offers Communists A New Way Out of Past
With PM-Romania, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A group of revolutionaries who helped topple dictator Nicolae Ceausescu have come up with an unorthodox offer for Communist Party members to buy a way out of their political past. For just one leu (less than one cent), Communists can buy a certificate saying the holder no longer wants to be a member of the hated party or its youth branch. The anti-Communist group ``21 December,'' whose 2,200 members all fought in the December revolution, have decided to put aside the first 100 forms for the use of Romania's new leadership. ``We expect President (Ion) Iliescu to be on top of the list'' organization president Alexandru Nacu said Monday. Iliescu, the former Communist official who leads in early returns from Sunday's elections, fell out with Ceausescu in 1971 and was demoted. The Romanian Communist Party never formally dissolved, but nobody claims membership anymore. All party property has been assigned to different organizations. But the party still legally exists. Before the revolution, there were some 3.7 million Communist Party members and about 4 million young Communists. ``We fought against communism in University Square in December and we continue to do so. Therefore, we believe we are morally entitled to certify the dissolution of the Romanian Communist Party when it happens,'' said Lucian Mihai, the organization's legal expert. He referred to a downtown Bucharest square. The December 21 group wouldn't predict when that might happen. But the certificates could turn out to be quite lucrative for the group. It plans to declare the two organizations dissolved only when enough certificates have been issued to cover at least half of the Communist membership. At a news conference Monday launching the new plan, the group sold at least five certificates, including one to its leader, Nacu.

DOC.HEAD: Grievance Committee Suspends Lawyer in Brawley Case
DOC.TEXT: A lawyer has been suspended for refusing to appear before a grievance committee investigating his conduct in the Tawana Brawley case. Alton H. Maddox, 44, represented the black teen-ager, who was found by a grand jury to have concocted a tale of rape at the hands of a gang of whites. In 1988, Attorney General Robert Abrams filed complaints with a judicial panel accusing Maddox of making baseless allegations against officials and investigators. Robert H. Strauss, chief counsel for the committee, said the suspension imposed Monday will remain until Maddox agrees to cooperate. Maddox has repeatedly refused to respond to the complaints or testify, the panel said. Maddox charged that the suspension was an attempt by Abrams to punish him for his ``vigorous and zealous'' representation of Miss Brawley. The case raised racial tensions in New York City in 1987-88. ``This was expected. We knew that Mr. Abrams had to have his way. This is a prosecutorial vendetta,'' Maddox said. ``I will not be taking it lying down. This won't be lowering the racial temperature in his town.'' Abrams' office refused to comment on the suspension. Miss Brawley's advisers _ Maddox, lawyer C. Vernon Mason and the Rev. Al Sharpton _ had told her her not to cooperate with the investigation of her charges on the grounds it was part of a racist cover-up. They also accused some public officials of taking part in the alleged rape or covering up what happened.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Falls, Stock Gains
DOC.TEXT: The dollar fell against the Japanese yen Tuesday, while the key index on the Tokyo Stock Exchange gained moderately, the first advance in three trading days. The dollar closed at 152.40 yen, down 0.85 yen from Monday's close of 153.25 yen. After opening at 153.36 yen, the dollar ranged between 152.30 yen and 153.36 yen. The Nikkei Stock Average of 225 selected issues rose 173.25 points to close at 31,938.30 points. Tuesday's advance followed a 248.67-point decline on Monday and a 47.88 point-slip last Friday. In the bond market, the price of the benchmark No. 119 10-year Japanese government bonds inched down to 87.34 points as of 3 p.m. (2:00 a.m. EDT), down from Monday's close of 87.39. The yield stood at 7.095 percent, up from the previous day's 7.085 percent. Currency dealers said the dollar opened slightly higher following its overnight upswing in New York, where it finished at 153.73 yen, up from 153 yen Friday. ``The dollar weakened as it was affected by cross-trading'' between the yen and the West German mark, said Kozo Yoshida, a dealer with Mitsui Taiyo Kobe Bank. Yoshida said otherwise there was no major market-affecting news. The yen's rebound triggered an upswing in stocks, dealers said. ``Share prices as a whole dropped in early trading on index-related selling, but the yen's recovery against the dollar encouraged many investors,'' said Yu Yoshida, a stock analyst with Yamaichi Securities. In the bond market, the price of the benchmark No. 119 10-year Japanese government bond edged higher to 87.33 from Monday's close of 87.09. That lowered the yield to 7.10 percent from 7.15 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Thousands Attend Memorial for Muppet Creator
LaserPhoto NY7
DOC.TEXT: Jim Henson's admirers gave him the whimsical, colorful send-off he wanted, complete with songs, dance and, of course, the Muppets. ``We had such great silly fun together,'' said Frank Oz, who played Bert to Henson's Ernie, and Miss Piggy to his Kermit the Frog. ``The best thing is when you watched Jim laugh until he cried.'' Thousands took part in the tribute to the master puppeteer Monday at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine. Henson died Wednesday of pneumonia at 53. The happy songs, happy words and a Dixieland band were in accordance with wishes Henson expressed in letters to his family, written four years ago and opened after his death. Henson had asked that mourners not wear black. The funeral service program contained a quote from Henson: ``Please watch out for each other and love and forgive everybody. It's a good life, enjoy it.' An organist opened with a mournful rendition of the theme from ``Sesame Street,'' which used the Muppets to entertain and educate children worldwide. Then a band strolled in playing ``Please Release Me,'' followed by ministers, a red-and-white robed church choir and family members. ``There is no question about Jim Henson's great artistry and the extent to which we have all been touched by it,'' Harry Belafonte said. ``Greater than his artistry was his humanity.'' Mourners fluttered colorful butterflies atop metal stems as Belafonte and three back-up singers sang ``Turn the World Around,'' a song he wrote and Henson used. The mourners again fluttered their butterflies while listening to a recording of Henson as Kermit singing ``Rainbow Connection'' from ``The Muppet Movie.'' Big Bird, a character played by Caroll Spinney, sang, ``It's Not Easy Being Green,'' a number usually done by Kermit. Afterward, Big Bird looked heavenward, said, ``Thank you, Kermit,'' then slowly walked away, head hung low. The 5,000-seat cathedral was nearly full and lined with colorful floral arrangements, some with animal figures in them. At the entrance was a gallery of photos with Henson, his family and ``Sesame Street'' characters. ``He's stayed with us long enough to give us certainly all we need, if we're strong enough to carry on,'' said Henson's widow, Jane, who stood with their five children to address the congregation. Her advice to the mourners was, ``Enjoy life to the fullest. He always did, but always with a little pain, a little sorrow that gave it richness.'' Henson's son Brian read excerpts from his father's letters. ``Don't feel bad that I'm gone,'' Henson wrote to his children. ``It will be an interesting time for me. ... I look forward to seeing all of you when you come over.''

DOC.HEAD: Protesters Say Court Ruling Won't End Strife Outside Abortion Clinics
DOC.TEXT: Operation Rescue declared no court will deter its members from blocking abortion clinics in New York, Boston or Atlanta. The U.S. Supreme Court on Monday allowed a permanent ban on Operation Rescue demonstrations that blocked access to abortion clinics in the New York area. It was the third legal setback in two weeks for the anti-abortion group. The justices, without comment or any recorded dissenting vote, left intact a federal judge's order barring Operation Rescue members from interfering with women entering the clinics. ``Our sole purpose is to stop these women from taking their children in,'' said Operation Rescue spokesman Bob Jewitt. ``If we can save a child, we will do that, we will continue to do that. Injunctions won't stop us.'' Abortion rights advocates acknowledged the difficulty of stopping the protests. ``I know they will not go away,'' said Diana M. Gurieva, president of Planned Parenthood of New York City. ``But the decision will strengthen the resolve of law enforcement and the lower courts to at least punish these people appropriately.'' Last week, the high court voted 5-4 to leave intact a similar ban on Operation Rescue blockades at clinics in Atlanta. Also Monday, Massachusetts Attorney General James M. Shannon secured a court order barring anti-abortion groups from obstructing access to clinics in that state. The court's order in the Atlanta case was preliminary, in a dispute that reached the justices as a request for emergency help before Georgia courts had finished studying the controversy. Randall Terry, founder of Operation Rescue, said in a statement that ``no court can prohibit us from rescuing babies.'' ``These judges have joined the heritage of Nazi judges who sanctioned the murder of the innocent. The day of judgment will hold terrifying consequences for them,'' he said. Auxiliary Bishop Austin Vaughn, a suburban New York cleric who rebuked Gov. Mario Cuomo for supporting abortion rights, said he wondered how Martin Luther King Jr. ``would have reacted to an order that told him it was illegal to continue his civil disobedience.'' Bill Baird, who operates two Long Island abortion clinics, called the Supreme Court decision ``a tremendous victory that recognizes women have the right to go in a building.'' ``But I'd like to see the courts go further and assign federal marshals to escort women in, just as they escorted blacks into buildings in the 1960s,'' he said. He said he doubted the court's announcement would end harassment outside clinics. ``You're dealing with religious zealots here.'' Molly Yard, president of the National Organization for Women, said she ``couldn't be more pleased'' with the ruling, but she also warned abortion rights supporters not to get too optimistic. ``This is the only victory we've had since Webster,'' she said, referring to the Supreme Court ruling last summer that gave states more room to restrict abortion.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Asks Who Ordered Doctor's Kidnapping
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge has demanded prosecutors disclose who approved the alleged kidnapping of a Mexican doctor charged in the murder of U.S. drug agent Enrique Camarena. U.S. District Judge Edward Rafeedie asked for the information to be divulged at a hearing scheduled for Friday on the manner in which Dr. Humberto Alvarez Machain was brought to the United States for trial. Witnesses said the 42-year-old gynecologist was abducted April 2 from his office in Guadalajara at the behest of the Drug Enforcement Administration. The affair has strained relations between the United States and Mexico. President Carlos Salinas de Gortari said Mexico's sovereignty had been violated. At a conference Monday, the judge told prosecutors: ``I'd like to know the highest level of authority who authorized this.'' The judge has delayed the trial pending the outcome of the hearing. Camarena, 31, was kidnapped off a Guadalajara street in 1985. Testimony at the trial of three men in 1988 revealed that he was tortured and interrogated by drug lords before being slain along with his pilot. Their bodies were found on a ranch 65 miles outside Guadalajara. Prosecutors maintain that Alvarez administered drugs to revive Camarena so the agent could tortured further before he was slain. Three Mexicans and a Honduran are on trial for their alleged roles in the murders of Camarena, the pilot and two tourists who prosecutors said were mistaken for drug agents. Outside court, Alvarez' lawyer, Robert Steinberg, said he would call four or five witnesses at the hearing. Among them, he said, will be Antonio Garate Bustamante, a former Mexican police officer who has said he arranged the doctor's abduction at the behest of the DEA. DEA officials have vowed to capture and prosecute every person involved in the Camarena murder. Steinberg said he would argue that Rafeedie has no jurisdiction over the Alvarez matter and should either send it to the World Court for resolution or return the doctor to his native Mexico. ``Give it to the Mexican authorities and let them prosecute it, if they wish,'' the attorney said.

DOC.HEAD: Thunderstorms Strike Southeast
DOC.TEXT: Rain fell in the Northwest and Southeast early today, hours after tornadoes touched down in Georgia and Kentucky. Wet spring weather dampened Washington, Idaho and Oregon. Rain also fell in Tennessee, Virginia, Kentucky and northern New England. Tornadoes touched down Monday near Unadilla in central Georgia and southwest of Lexington, Ky. Thunderstorms rumbled over the Carolinas, Alabama, Mississippi and Louisiana. Golf ball-size hail fell near Uvalde in southern Texas, and baseball-size hail struck Austin. Showers and thunderstorms also extended over northern Florida, Tennessee, Illinois, Indiana, Ohio and Virginia. Rain dampened Vermont, Maine and the central New England coast. Temperatures rose to the 90s and higher in the South. Houston set a record for the day Monday at 94 degrees. The high temperature for the nation Monday was 102 degrees in Texas at Laredo, Lajitas and McAllen. Today's forecast called for showers in the Northwest and thunderstorms from southern Louisiana to South Carolina. Showers also were predicted for Minnesota and Wisconsin and much of the East Coast from Maine to Connecticut and from Virginia to South Carolina. DOC.HEAD: Trinity Reaches Record Levels in Texas; Floodwaters Recede in Louisiana
DOC.TEXT: The rain-swollen Trinity River hit its highest level here in 48 years, but the vast amounts of water being released into the river through the floodgates of Livingston Dam dropped. After four days of letting a record 100,800 cubic feet per second of water roar through the dam, engineers reduced the amount Monday to 98,400. The releases, dictated by the rising water, have flooded thousands of acres below the dam. Normally, 8,000 to 9,000 cfs pass through the dam, about 45 miles north of Liberty and 65 miles north of Houston. The Red Cross planned to open disaster centers today to help victims in the seven Texas counties flooded since the Trinity began rising. Elsewhere, tornadoes touched down in Kentucky, floodwaters receded in hard-hit Arkansas and Louisiana, and federal emergency workers were assessing storm damage today in Indiana. Heavy flooding since April 15 has been blamed for 13 deaths in Texas and one in Oklahoma. Flooding and storms elsewhere have killed two people in Illinois and one in Missouri, a woman who apparently was swept away by floodwaters at Jefferson City on Thursday. In northwestern and central Louisiana, the Red River continued to fall. Gov. Buddy Roemer said he would ask for federal aid for 11 parishes where crops were destroyed by flooding. In Texas, where 41 counties have been declared eligible for federal disaster funds, officials said the Trinity appeared to be stabilizing. Late Monday, the Trinity was at 29.83 feet in Liberty, surpassing the previous record depth of 29.51 feet in 1942, said Jim Mitchum, coordinator of the Liberty County emergency management office. Rising waters on Monday crested over a 6-foot dike built around the home of Howard Pipkins. In the past two weeks the home, which had been remodeled after it filled with two feet of water last summer, had become an island. ``I hate to see that happen,'' said Mitchum. ``He worked real hard to get that house from getting water. He was talking earlier about jacking up the house in case it broke.'' The Red Cross estimated 4,600 homes have been affected by flooding in the seven-county area. Spokesman Bill Barron said 500 people have stayed at Red Cross shelters since the Trinity began rising more than a week ago. The agency also has distributed more than 9,000 meals from shelters and mobile kitchens. Residents and merchants in Hot Springs, Ark., began cleaning up from a 24-hour deluge of 13 inches of rain over the weekend. City officials estimated damage to businesses and public works at $5.3 million. Not counted was damage to 136 homes in the town of 23 hot springs. Hot Springs National Park Superintendent Roger Giddings said pumps that distribute the thermal waters to seven bath houses and three hotels were knocked out by the flooding and would not be working for at least a week. But a rally was planned for Thursday to spread the message the resort is prepared to receive Memorial Day visitors as usual. Legislation was introduced Monday in Washington to provide emergency disaster payments to farmers hit by flooding in Louisiana, Arkansas and Texas. Twisters touched down Monday evening in seven Kentucky counties. The worst damage appeared to be at Richmond, where a bar, a storehouse and several other buildings were destroyed or heavily damaged. One person was reported injured.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Silences Town Bell at Night
DOC.TEXT: A dispute over the Hatfield town bell appears to have rung to a close with a judge's ruling that the hourly tolling must cease. The ruling was met with relief by a pair of newcomers living next door to the bell and with dismay by townsfolk who had argued the chiming was a treasured part of the New England character of the 320-year-old farm community. ``A certain part of the heritage of the town has been disrupted,'' Selectman Thomas Hurley said Monday after Superior Court Judge John F. Murphy ordered that the 92-year-old bell be stilled between 9 p.m. and 7 a.m. Selectman Chairman George Zgrodnick Jr. said the ruling would mean turning off the bell permanently because the town can't afford an automatic timer. The bell was sounded Monday night but was to be turned off this morning. Richard and Pamela Carnall, who had moved from nearby Northampton in 1988, had claimed the chiming was keeping them up at night. After selectmen refused to stop the chiming, the couple sued the town. A jury May 14 declared the bell a nuisance but decided that only Mrs. Carnall was injured by its ringing and that the couple was not entitled to damages. Based on the ruling, the Carnalls asked the judge to silence the bell at night W. Michael Ryan, the Carnalls' lawyer, said the ruling actually recalls an old tradition of ringing the bell at curfew. ``We've ended a 20th-century tradition and revived a colonial-Federalist era tradition,'' he said. The Carnalls had earlier offered to pay for a timer, but the offer has been withdrawn, Ryan said. The Carnalls were unavailable for comment Monday, Ryan said. When the Carnalls bought their 19th-century house across from the First Congregational Church, the bell was not working. But six months later it was fixed. The couple, who have a young daughter, complained the bell deprived them of sleep.

DOC.HEAD: Hancock, Loeb for Business Journalists Announced
DOC.TEXT: Business journalists from The Wall Street Journal, The Washington Post and The Associated Press were among those honored with prizes for excellence in two contests. Winners were announced Monday for both the John Hancock and Gerald Loeb awards for 1990. Both contests honor work that furthers public understanding of business issues. The prize-winning work ranged from the savings and loan scandal to personal finance to the workings of the Securities and Exchange Commission. Heading the list of seven Hancock winners was AP writer Vivian Marino, winner in the syndicated and news service category for a series on people and their finances. The stories covered topics ranging from selling a home to filing for personal bankruptcy. It was the third consecutive Hancock award and the 10th overall for the AP in the 23-year history of the contest. Also winning Hancocks were: _Dana Rubin of Texas Monthly magazine, in the general-interest magazine category, for ``The Day Leroy Died,'' a piece exploring the collapse of a small rural town's uninsured bank. _Johnnie L. Roberts of The Wall Street Journal, in the financial newspaper or magazine category, for articles on the reliability of Dun & Bradstreet credit reports. _Rick Atkinson and David Maraniss of The Washington Post, in the category for newspapers over 300,000 in circulation, for a series on the S&L crisis, titled ``The $150 Billion Calamity.'' _Rebecca Smith of The Tribune in Oakland, Calif., in the category for newspapers between 100,000 and 300,000 circulation, for a series on the thrift crisis, titled the ``S&L Debacle.'' _Bill Lazarus of the Star-Tribune in Caspar, Wyo., in the category for newspapers under 100,000 circulation, for articles examining the regulation of insurance in Wyoming. _Alex Beam of The Boston Globe, among financial columnists, for columns analyzing topics such as the decline of Massachusetts' Route 128 technology belt and the troubles of Wang Laboratories. Winners in each category receive $5,000 cash. Leading the Loeb winners in the large newspaper category (circulation over 400,000) were David Vise and Steve Coll of The Washington Post for ``The Man From Wall Street: John Shad's Reign at the SEC.'' Earlier this year, Vise and Coll also won a Pulitzer Prize for their reporting on the SEC. Other Loeb winners were: _In the medium-sized newspaper category (circulation over 150,000), Jerry Kammer, Andy Hall and a team from The Arizona Republic for coverage of the collapse of Lincoln Savings & Loan. _In the small newspapers category (circulation under 150,000), Gary Belsky and Phyllis Furman of Crain's New York Business for ``Calculated Madness: The Rise and Fall of Crazy Eddie Antar.'' _Among magazines, Peter Brimelow and Leslie Spencer of Forbes for ``The Best Paid Lawyers in America.'' _In the commentary category, L. Gordon Crovitz of The Wall Street Journal for his columns on alleged prosecutorial abuses of the racketeering law. _In the deadline reporting category, Kathryn Harris and Paul Richter of the Los Angeles Times for coverage of the Time-Warner merger. The judges also gave an award of special recognition, outside the established categories, to Richard McCord of The Green Bay (Wis.) News-Chronicle. McCord's series ``It's Now or Never'' told the story of the News-Chronicle's struggle to survive as an independent paper. A prize of $1,000 is given in each Loeb category. The awards were established in 1957 by the late Gerald Loeb. The Hancock prizes are awarded by John Hancock Financial Services of Boston. The Loeb contest is administered by the John E. Anderson Graduate School of Management at the University of California, Los Angeles.

DOC.HEAD: NBA Stats Get Poor Kids Hooked on Math
DOC.TEXT: Michael Jordan and other pro basketball players are getting inner-city youngsters hooked on math. Actually, it's free-lance writer Rich Share who uses Jordan's shooting percentages and other statistics to teach the basics to high school students struggling in math. Share, who holds a teaching degree from Northern Illinois University, tutors 20 to 30 students three days a week at Dunbar High School in a poor South Side neighborhood. ``You might say kids are getting too much sports, but you use whatever works _ and sports works,'' he said. ``This is 6th or 7th grade material, and I'm dealing with freshmen and sophomores. At first 70 or 80 didn't get it right. Now, I'd say 80 percent can. And they are attentive. There are no troublemakers.'' To really bring examples home, he marches his students outside to shoot baskets. ``The kids shoot free throws then figure out the percentages. They really enjoy it. If you shoot two of seven that's 29 percent. You'll remember that because that's what you shot,'' he said. Results have been so impressive Dunbar Principal Floyd Banks plans to use a manual Share wrote for all freshmen needing remedial help next year. ``This is a way to challenge these kids' interest into sports into something constructive, especially those who haven't been able to grasp the basics in elementary school,'' Banks said. Share uses basketball because ``it's my favorite sport and it's their favorite sport.'' ``They're always talking about basketball,'' he said. ``Also, unlike baseball or football, the basketball season starts at the start of the school year and ends at end of school year.''

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Backs Multinational NATO Forces, Cheney Says
DOC.TEXT: NATO should consider revamping its military structure by using multinational forces as U.S. troop levels in Europe are reduced, U.S. Defense Secretary Dick Cheney said today. Cheney, taking part in his second NATO defense ministers' meeting in two weeks, said the Western alliance must adapt if an East-West conventional arms pact is reached and the threat of war against the Warsaw Pact recedes. ``If all present, positive trends continue ... then we can contemplate new ways of doing business,'' Cheney told reporters aboard his plane en route to Brussels. ``I think, based on a first look, the notion of a multinational force has some appeal,'' Cheney said. ``I think it's worth pursuing.'' Cheney arrived in Brussels today for a two-day meeting of NATO defense ministers to discuss the alliance's future military posture. The ministers are holding a series of discussions in advance of a summit of NATO leaders in July. President Bush proposed the summit as a way to discuss changes in the role of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization in light of the upheaval sweeping Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union. The defense ministers' meeting comes at a time when German unification is advancing rapidly and pressure is growing in Washington for sharp cuts in military spending and reductions in the 300,000-strong U.S. force based in Europe. Using multinational forces in NATO could offer cost savings and ease nationalist sensitivities, particularly in West Germany where most NATO troops are stationed, said a senior defense official traveling with Cheney. Such forces could also help blunt any drive to take a unified Germany out of NATO. ``One way to emphasize the multilateral nature of the NATO alliance is to have units that are composed of troops of various nations,'' Cheney said. Such a plan would also ``emphasize the fact that (Germany) is not treated any differently than anyone else.'' As an example, Cheney said a multinational corps could be formed with three divisions each from a different nation. A U.S. division is made up of about 15,000 to 18,000 soldiers. At present, NATO land forces defend territory under a so-called ``layer cake'' formula by which an army from an allied nation defends a certain sector. U.S. forces, for example, are stationed primarily in southern and central West Germany, while French and British forces defend other regions. With the elimination of the border between East and West Germany, such a system would have to be revamped. Under a multinational system, U.S., German or British soldiers could be dispersed among several nations, said the senior defense official. He spoke on condition of anonymity. Soldiers of multinational units could be based in Britain or Canada for training exercises, the official said. Such an arrangement, for example, could help reduce complaints among the West German public. West Germans have grown increasingly irritated with NATO military exercises and accidents caused by low-flying aircraft. ``Today, there is the sense that Germany is singled out because the majority of troops are on their soil,'' the official said. But the official cautioned that setting up multinational forces poses many problems, including language barriers and varied weapons systems. He said he expected the defense ministers to propose a study of the multinational force concept during their two-day session. ``Mainly, they are trying to ask themselves, `How should NATO look in this new environment in Europe?''' the official said.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Mostly Firmer in Europe, Gold lower
DOC.TEXT: The dollar was mostly firmer this morning against the major currencies in busy trading in Europe. Gold prices were lower. Foreign exchange dealers said the West German mark weakened amid domestic political uncertainties and sentiment favored the strong British pound among European currencies. They said the mark was being hurt by the reluctance of the West German opposition Social Democrats to back rapid German unification, largely because of concern over the social and economic costs. In Tokyo, where trading ends before European markets open, the dollar fell by 0.85 yen to a closing 152.40 yen from Monday's close of 153.25. In London Tuesday morning the dollar was quoted lower at 152.05 yen. One British pound cost $1.6897 in London, cheaper for buyers than Monday's late $1.6917. Gold opened in London at a bid price of $372.50 a troy ounce. At mid-morning, the major bullion dealers fixed a recommended price of $372.40 down from $373.25 bid late Monday. In Zurich, the bid price was $372.60, down from $373.50 late Monday. Gold in Hong Kong closed at a bid $373.58, down from Monday's closing $374.08. Silver bullion was trading in London at a bid price of $5.12 a troy ounce, down from Monday's late 5.14.

DOC.HEAD: Workers, Visitors Mingle at New Studio Park
DOC.TEXT: Welders scrambled over a six-ton steel ape hanging onto a replica of a New York City bridge, sending sparks flying six stories down. And families with baby strollers sauntered by, seemingly unperturbed as technicians fine-tuned King Kong, Jaws and other attractions and builders hurried to complete Manhattan and San Francisco street facades. Universal Studios Florida opened its doors to the public for the first time Monday, giving about 10,000 visitors a preview of the latest entertainment park. The big attraction Monday was the E.T. Adventure, featuring the extra-terrestrial creature that starred in the Steven Spielberg movie. E.T. got the approval of 5-year-old Gemma John, of West Yorkshire, England. ``He's nice. He smiled,'' said Gemma, who waved and smiled back shyly. The $600 million park features acres of film-production sound stages along with gigantic high-tech rides and shows. It is easing into full operation with a break-in period before its official June 7 opening. ``It's painstaking work,'' says Jay Stein, Universal's top executive. ``We've got a lot of gnawing, aggravating things and problems to resolve, last-minute things that, no matter how well it all checks out in testing, have to be changed and fixed and fine-tuned.'' For instance, how much of a banana breath do you give the six-story-tall ape on New York's Queensboro Bridge that's manhandling an aerial tramway car filled with 50 terrified customers? Has the ``hydraulics guru'' got the right timing and tilt on the pontoon boat that the great white shark crunches his jaws into? Does the boat's stern lift up as soon as it should, or as far as it should, giving the wide-eyed passengers just the right amount of thrill? Less than half of the shows and rides are in operation at the 444-acre theme park and working studio. But Universal executives say everything is on schedule for the inaugural of the tourist rival to the Disney-MGM Studios. Attendance is being held to 10,000 to 12,000 people per day until the park officially opens.

DOC.HEAD: Fire Burns in Rocky Flats Laboratory
DOC.TEXT: A fire burned for 30 minutes at the Rocky Flats nuclear weapons plant, and officials said there was no release of radioactive materials. The fire late Monday was contained to one room of a plating laboratory and posed no threat to public health or safety, said Jeff Schwartz, a spokesman for EG&G, managers of the U.S. Department of Energy plant. One person who suffered minor eye irritation due to smoke was treated by the plant's occupational health department and released, Schwartz said. The fire appeared to be electrical in origin and involved plastic materials. It occurred in Building 444, a non-plutonium production building, he said. The fire was detected at about 8:50 p.m. Firefighters from the Rocky Flats fire department and the building's sprinkler system extinguished the fire by 9:20 p.m. As a precautionary measure, the plant's emergency operations center was activated and all employees in the building were evacuated until 11:45 p.m. Federal investigators searched the plant in June 1989 looking for evidence of illegal dumping and incineration of hazardous wastes. Plutonium operations at Rocky Flats are presently shut down. Officials have announced preliminary plans to resume productions in mid-June.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Vows to Protect Minority Teachers in Desegregation Case
DOC.TEXT: Boston's public school system must maintain court-ordered racial hiring guidelines and not base proposed teacher layoffs solely on seniority, a judge has ruled. U.S. District Court Judge Arthur W. Garrity said Monday the school system must still achieve a teaching and administrative staff of at least 25 percent blacks and minorities after the court ends its involvement in Boston school desegregation. Garrity made his remarks during a hearing on his plan for a final judgment that would end litigation in the long-running case. In 1974, Garrity ordered the citywide busing of black and white children to integrate the city's schools. The move sparked several years of busing-related violence. Garrity said his final order in the case, to be issued at an undetermined date, will ensure that the quota remains in effect until minority teachers have achieved enough seniority to protect them from immediate layoffs. Several hundred city teachers are expected to be laid off because of budget cutbacks. If minority quotas are eradicated, black teachers fear they will be among the first to go because they have little seniority. According to the Boston Teachers Union contract, layoffs are made solely on seniority. The union has fought the continuation of the minority quota system. Garrity told the hearing that he wanted to end the court's direct involvement in the case because of a new school assignment plan implemented last year. It goes into effect in September. ``The principle reason for ending the involvement is that we don't have a plan anymore,'' he said. ``The controlled choice plan is in effect. But it's not the court's plan and we shouldn't be involved.'' Garrity monitored the city's compliance with the desegregation order until 1987, when a federal appeals court ruled that the schools were finally desegregated and gave control over student assignment back to the School Committee.

DOC.HEAD: Police Advise Visitors to Stay Out of Georgetown on Weekend Nights
DOC.TEXT: Visitors should stay out of the city's Georgetown section on weekend nights because of growing crowds and the inability of police to provide special patrols, the police department's chief spokesman says. ``I advise people to avoid Georgetown if they can,'' Lt. Reginald Smith said Monday. ``A large number of people migrate to that area on weekends and that is an ongoing concern for us.'' Georgetown, which has one of the Washington area's most popular nighttime entertainment districts, has long been plagued by occasional street crime, primarily robberies. Gary Hankins, chairman of the labor committee of the Fraternal Order of Police, said Monday that five police officers were injured in confrontations with groups of young men last weekend. The weekend was supposed to mark the beginning of special anti-crime patrols in Georgetown, including the deployment of more than 40 additional officers and the use of a special mobile headquarters to expedite booking of those arrested.
