No additional officers were added to the usual deployment of six, and the mobile headquarters was not present because of cuts in the police budget. Police Chief Isaac Fulwood announced last week that the patrols would be curtailed, due to $4 million in cuts to the police overtime budget.

DOC.HEAD: Stuffed Animals Recalled Because of Choking Hazard
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 3rd item, on Indian museum, to change New Mexican to New Mexico in lead and fix typo in Cheyenne-Arapaho in 3rd graf.
DOC.TEXT: A California company is recalling six models of stuffed animals imported from China because their eyes can detach, posing a potentially fatal choking hazard. The Consumer Product Safety Commission said Monday there have been no known deaths or injuries caused by the toys, all of which contain music boxes. The CSPC said the toys have wind-up keys protruding from their backs and a small white tag sewed to the side or bottom that reads: ``The San Francisco Music Box Company, Emeryville, Ca., Reg. No. PA-2642 (RC) All New Materials Made In China.'' Approximately 2,866 of the stuffed animals were distributed nationwide from December 1988 through June 1989, the CSPC said. The names of the animals, their model numbers and the song played by the music box are: _White Jointed Bear, 55-0046, ``You Are My Sunshine.'' _Beige Jointed Bear, 55-0061, ``Don't Let Me Go.'' _Beige Small Jointed Bear, 55-0038, ``It's A Small World.'' _Pink Bear, 55-0079, ``A Baby's Lullabye.'' _Pink Monkey, 55-0095, ``Zip-a-dee-doo-daa.'' _Beige Articulated Santa Bear, 55-0368.
DOC.HEAD: Prison Population Grows 12 Percent in One Year
DOC.TEXT: The number of inmates in state and federal prisons grew a record 12 percent last year to 703,687 prisoners, according to a Justice Department study. The inmate population increased 76,099 last year from a 1988 prison population of 627,588 held in state and federal facilities, said the study by the Bureau of Justice Statistics released Sunday. The nation's prison population has more than doubled in the last decade, from 373,866 inmates in 1980 to 703,687 last year, said the study. Only three states _ Kansas, North Dakota and Alaska _ reported decreases in prison populations last year. The biggest proportional increase occurred in Rhode Island, where the number of inmates jumped 30.1 percent, followed by Colorado, with a 26.9 percent increase. South Dakota had the third highest percentage increase _ 25.2 percent _ and Utah ranked fourth with a 21.3 percent jump.
DOC.HEAD: New Indian Museum Director Hopes To Change Native American Image
DOC.TEXT: The National Museum of the American Indian will be a new type of institution that forever alters the image of native Americans, according to the New Mexico lawyer selected as the museum's first director. ``My highest aspiration for the National Museum of the American Indian is that it will reanalyze, redirect and, in many cases, reformulate entirely the concepts and presentations of the past concerning Indian culture,'' W. Richard West Jr. said Monday. West, of Albuquerque, N.M., and a member of the Cheyenne-Arapaho tribes, becomes the museum's director effective June 1, the Smithsonian Institution announced at a news conference Monday. West outlined his vision for the museum as a multi-cultural facility that will reach out, without paternalism or condescension, to native Americans throughout the hemisphere. West, 47, a partner and president of the Indian-owned law firm of Gover, Steton, Williams & West, has no direct experience running museums. However, a news release from the Smithsonian stressed his administrative and fund-raising abilities, and noted he was a founding member of the Smithsonian's Cultural Education Committee. West is also the son of American Indian artist Walter Richard West Sr. and from 1975 to 1980, was coordinator and treasurer of the Native American Council of Regents of the Institute of American Indian Arts in Santa Fe, N.M.
DOC.HEAD: Government Approves Bacteria Treatment for Bladder Cancer
DOC.TEXT: The Food and Drug Administration has approved use of a live but weakened bacteria to treat a type of bladder cancer. The product, Bacillus Calmette Guerin Live, or BCG Live, was approved Monday to treat bladder cancer referred to as ``carcinoma in situ.'' This type constitutes 20 percent to 30 percent of the 45,000 cases of bladder cancer detected in the United States each year, the FDA said. The treatment calls for the bacteria to be administered directly to the bladder through a catheter to attack the cancer cells on the lining of the organ. The inflammation that results eliminates many of the cancer cells. Studies sponsored by the National Cancer Institute found that 74 percent of patients with carcinoma in situ of the bladder responded to BCG treatment. Of those, the median time for recurrence of the cancer was four years, the FDA said. The product is made by Connaught Laboratories Ltd. of Willowdale, Ontario, Canada. It will be marketed under the trade name Theracys.

DOC.HEAD: New York To Be Host to Grammy Awards
DOC.TEXT: New York has won back next year's Grammy Awards from Los Angeles and plans four days of musical events surrounding the ceremony in February at Radio City Music Hall. ``You can be sure that we will roll out the red carpet, sound the trumpets and have the bands playing to welcome each and every member to the Big Apple,'' Mayor David Dinkins said Monday at a news conference at City Hall. ``New York City certainly knows how to put on a party,'' he said. The Grammys honor the top performers in the recording field. Los Angeles, which played host to the awards this year, was competing with New York for the 33rd annual ceremony, which Dinkins estimated will give a $30 million boost to New York's economy. Michael Greene, president of the National Academy of Recording Arts and Sciences, which sponsors the Grammys, said New York City ``feels like the place you would like to award excellence.''

DOC.HEAD: Radicals Vow More Protests; Eight Students Arrested
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New throughout to UPDATE with flag-burning in Kwangju, attack on police substation in Seoul, protest at Japanese Embassy, union workers rejecting Hyundai contract. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Hundreds of radical students yelling ``Drive out Yankees!'' clashed with police today at two universities in the southern city of Kwangju. Police in Kwangju also fired tear gas to disperse dozens of students who burned a U.S. flag. In Seoul, radicals vowed to stage a week of anti-American protests, and eight militant students were arrested after unfurling an anti-American banner in front of the U.S. Embassy. In another development, union workers at Hyundai Motor Co. rejected a proposed new labor contract today, dashing hopes for a quick end to a 7-day-old strike at South Korea's largest automaker. Recent labor unrest has compounded the troubles of President Roh Tae-woo's government, which has been beset by violent protests by radical students. At Kwangju's Chonnam University, about 500 students hurled rocks and firebombs at riot police, who responded by firing hundreds of volleys of tear gas during a two-hour clash. About 800 students at Chosun University lobbed rocks and firebombs as they fought police for hours on streets outside the campus. There were no immediate reports of injuries. Since Friday, Kwangju has been the scene of repeated clashes marking the 10th anniversary of a pro-democracy uprising that was brutally suppressed by troops. In Seoul, meanwhile, about 100 students attacked a police substation in the southern part of the capital with firebombs today, the South Korean news agency Yonhap reported. The police drove them off by firing blanks from automatic weapons. The National Council of Student Representatives sent the eight students to the U.S. Embassy to deliver a letter demanding that Washington apologize for allegedly condoning the military crackdown on the 1980 Kwangju uprising. The United States has repeatedly denied the allegations. By official count, 200 citizens were killed and at least 1,700 wounded in the 10-day uprising. Many Kwangju residents claim the toll was higher. After unfurling their banner, which also demanded a U.S. apology, the students scuffled with Korean riot police on guard outside the embassy and were taken away. Radical student leaders vowed at a news conference at Seoul's Hanyang University that they would stage anti-American protests until May 27. The student leaders said their open letter to the U.S. Embassy also demanded that the United States withdraw the 43,000 U.S. troops stationed in South Korea and stop pressuring Seoul to open its markets to American imports. National police ordered increased security at the embassy and other U.S. facilities. Radical students also said today they would stage protests while Roh is visiting Japan later this week. Roh's government has been holding talks with Japan over the wording of an apology it wants for Japan's treatment of Koreans during its colonial rule. The students said Roh should stop begging for an apology, and that his visit would deepen South Korea's economic dependence on Japan. In a separate protest, about 100 elderly Koreans tried to push their way through riot police guarding the Japanese Embassy in Seoul to press demands that Japan apologize and fully compensate for its actions during its 1910-1945 colonial rule. Elderly Koreans have staged daily protests near the embassy for the last week, asking Roh to cancel his visit, scheduled Thursday through Saturday.

DOC.HEAD: Priest Killed, Second Wounded In Congregation Brawl
DOC.TEXT: Armed worshipers clashed at a church service, stabbing one priest to death and wounding a second, a report said today. The independent South African Press Association said Rev. Tommy Velebhayi, 48, was killed Sunday at the Apostolic Church of Africa in Zwelitsha. Zwelitsha is in Siskei homeland, on the South Africa's southeastern coast. A second priest, the Rev. L. Nkcanka, was seriously wounded in the fight, the news agency said. Police said they arrested two people. The clash erupted when worshipers from one group tried to stop a rival group led by Velebhayi from entering the church, the report said. The news agency said the congregation had been split for about a month over a leadership disagreement. It said one faction was trying to break away and form a new church.

DOC.HEAD: Earthquake Jolts Southern Coast of Java
DOC.TEXT: A strong earthquake jolted parts of West and Central Java provinces, but there were no reports of damage or casualties, the Meteorology and Geophysical Agency said today. The quake, at 8:24 p.m. Monday, measured 5.6 on the Richter scale, it said. The epicenter was believed about 95 miles south of Cilacap, Central Java, 20 miles under the Indian Ocean. The temblor was felt in the West Java cities of Bogor, 40 miles south of Jakarta, and Tasikmalaya, 165 miles southeast of the capital. An officer at Cilacap police station said on condition of anonymity that many people fled their homes, but there were no reports of damage or casualties. The open-ended Richter scale measures the total energy released by an earthquake, as indicated by ground motion recorded on seismographs. An earthquake of 5 can cause considerable damage.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Ambassador to Italy Says Controversy is Behind Him
DOC.TEXT: Before his confirmation as U.S. ambassador to Italy last year, Peter Secchia's penchant for crude language earned him the nickname ``ambassador of dirty words'' in Italian newspapers. Now, they're calling him ``Cousin Pete.'' Secchia returned to his Grand Rapids home over the weekend with about 20 Italian business leaders for a four-day conference aimed at forging business partnerships between Michigan and Italy. Among the remarks for which Secchia was criticized: His August 1988 comment that he knows ``what sodomy is because that's what Democrats are always doing to me.'' On Monday, he recalled in a speech to about 600 members of the Economic Club of Grand Rapids the monthlong holdup in the U.S. Senate's confirmation of his appointment. ``One year ago today, our president went to Rome on an unofficial visit without me,'' he said. ``It hurt and it hurt deeply.'' But Secchia gave himself high marks for his work in Italy so far, saying in an interview after his speech that he ``was amazed at how fast (the controversy) went away. ... ``A few cuss words here, a few gestures there, in Italy, they don't care. I imagine I benefited from that philosophy.'' Secchia, 53, said he has devoted much of his time in Italy to promoting U.S. business interests. He encouraged local business leaders to explore potential partnerships in Europe. ``Italy isn't only gondolas and pizza, Roman ruins, leaning towers, music and wine. Italians are masters at applied technology and traditional industries,'' the former businessman said. ``Europe is our future market and Italians should be our business partners.'' Secchia also encouraged business leaders to learn the languages and cultures of the countries with which they would like to explore partnerships. He said he has had some problems himself in learning to speak Italian. ``I'm having trouble with the verbs and prepositions _ just like I did in English,'' he joked. ``But they haven't taught me any cuss words.''

DOC.HEAD: Switch in Names Sought in Dispute over Birthplace of Hamburger
DOC.TEXT: Residents who maintain that their Wisconsin community is the hamburger's birthplace are asking Hamburg, N.Y., to change names with their town. ``We just think it's appropriate that we become Hamburg,'' said Tom Duffey, honorary burgermeister of Seymour. Duffey and his Home of the Hamburger Inc. organization contend the first hamburger was developed at a local fair in 1885. He said Hamburg should accept the name change because he contends their claim to being the hamburger's birthplace is false. He said switching the name to Seymour would be fitting because a former New York governor was named Horatio Seymour. Home of the Hamburger Inc. grilled a 5,250-pound hamburger last year as part of its effort to promote the claim of Seymour, about 10 miles west of Green Bay. Hamburg Mayor Richard Hansen said he had not seen the letter from Duffey requesting the move, but would not agree to a change in names. ``We believe very strongly that we're the home of the hamburger,'' he said. ``We take great pride in that. I don't care what Seymour has to say.''

DOC.HEAD: North, South Yemen Merge Into Unified Republic Of Yemen
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 9th graf, `The 48-year-old ...' to DELETE incorrect reference to North Yemen and Marxism; SUBS 11th graf, `The council ...' to insert that South Yemen was formerly Marxist.
DOC.TEXT: North and South Yemen merged their impoverished nations of tribespeople into a unified Republic of Yemen today, and the new country stood on the brink of oil wealth. Gen Ali Abdullah Saleh, president of the unified state, raised the new country's red, white and black flag atop the portside presidential council building. The Aden Coast Guard fired several cannon shots, and ships hooted their horns as the flag went up. The united Republic of Yemen has newly discovered oil field reserves estimated unofficially at 2 billion barrels. At a later rally, attended by 2,000 people, Saleh said the united nation would remain committed to all treaties that either of the Yemens had concluded. ``The Republic of Yemen will be a factor for stability and security in the Arabian Peninsula and the Gulf region and a strong bastion for the Arab nations, the Arab League and joint Arab action,'' he said. Saleh said Yemen would work for development and progress, pledged to ``an opening up, economically, culturally and socially ... in line with the spirit of the age,'' Saleh said. Palestine Liberation Organization Chairman Yasser Arafat was the only Arab leader to attend the ceremony in Aden. The 48-year-old Saleh, president of North Yemen since 1978, was elected to head the five-man council that will rule the new state at a meeting of senior leaders from the two Yemens held before the flag-raising ceremony. Ali Salem al-Beidh, secretary-general of South Yemen's ruling Yemen Socialist Party, was elected vice-president. The council named Heider al-Attas, the president of formerly Marxist South Yemen, prime minister and asked him to form a Cabinet. On Monday, North Yemen's pro-Western Parliament approved a plan by Saleh to merge with Socialist South Yemen. North Yemen radio reports said the 159-member Shura Council, or parliament, had ``agreed with a sweeping majority'' to merge the Yemens, which are among the world's least developed states. San`a, the North Yemeni capital, is to serve as capital of the newly named Yemen Republic. South Yemen's parliament, the Supreme People's Council, also held a special session Monday to approve unification of the two Red Sea nations. It was the second such union between two Arab states in this century. In the 1950s, Egypt and Syria joined as the United Arab Republic, but the merger collapsed after three years because of internal squabbling. The new state binds 11 million people _ 9 million from the north and 2 million from the south. South Yemen became the Arab world's only avowedly Marxist state after it gained independence from Britain in 1971. But it began to reform as democratic changes swept through the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe. The two Yemens are poor and undeveloped; labor unrest in South Yemen has been aggravated in recent months as Western goods were transported from North Yemen to the south. Strikes mushroomed in most government offices and factories in South Yemen. The merger bid has been outwardly promoted by oil-rich nations on the Arabian Peninsula such as Saudi Arabia, which is eager to snuff out Soviet influence. Scores of Cuban and East German military experts are said to have left Aden, the capital of South Yemen, in recent months. A friendship pact entitles the Soviets to maintain as many as 18,000 troops in the port city, but the extent of their deployment is unknown. The merger was originally planned for Nov. 30. But in recent days there had been pressure to speed up the schedule so the two Yemens can attend an emergency Arab summit on May 28 in Baghdad, Iraq, as one state. The new flag is similar to the black, white and red one of North Yemen, but without the stars. A draft agreement on unification was agreed to by leaders of both nations on April 22 in the city of Taiz, halfway between Aden and North Yemen's capital of San`a. A planned transition period of 2{ years coincides with the remainder of the five-year terms for both legislatures.

DOC.HEAD: Deng Says Students Not Entirely to Blame For Pro-Democracy Protests
DOC.TEXT: Senior leader Deng Xiaoping blamed poor party leadership as the root cause for last year's pro-democracy demonstrations, West German sources said today. The new Communist Party chief, Jiang Zemin, says he cannot rule out more such demonstrations this year, the sources said, speaking on condition of anonymity. The comments came in talks with Monday with former West German Chancellor Helmut Schmidt, they said. The sources said Deng and Jiang took a generally conciliatory stance toward students who took part in the pro-democracy demonstrations, which were crushed by the military in June. Deng, China's 85-year-old patriarch, said poor party leadership was the root cause of the popular drive for democratic reform. Then-party chief Zhao Ziyang, Deng's protege, was purged in June for being sympathetic to the student movement. Since then, many of Zhao's followers have been jailed or lost their jobs in a sweep against the ideologically suspect. Schmidt told Deng that China suffered a serious loss of prestige when the military killed hundreds, perhaps thousands, in ending the democracy movement, and that the West had no other choice but to downgrade relations with China. The sources said Jiang told Schmidt the possibility of new demonstrations could not be excluded. He said ``hostile forces'' are trying to make use of anniversaries of events during the demonstrations last May and June. Jiang said China has built up its riot police, which is now better-equipped with non-lethal weapons. Luo Gan, secretary-general of the State Council, also told Schmidt that only police forces, not the military, would be used to put down any future political unrest. The sources also disclosed Schmidt had recently exchanged letters with Zhao, who has not been seen since an emotional meeting with student hunger strikers on Tiananmen Square on May 19, 1989. He is being held under virtual house arrest in Beijing. The contents of the exchange were not disclosed, but it was the first known incident of Zhao being able to communicate with the outside world. Deng's meeting with Schmidt was not mentioned by the Chinese press today, although the Jiang-Schmidt talks were reported on the front page of the party's official People's Daily. Deng retired from his last official post, as head of the state Central Military Commission, in March, and the absence of press coverage of the Schmidt meeting and a meeting on May 13 with Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak are an apparent attempt to emphasize he is now a private citizen. Deng, however, is still regarded as China's most powerful man, with final say over major policy decisions. The sources quoted Schmidt as saying Deng, who is frequently rumored to be seriously ill, appeared to be in better health than at their last meeting two years ago. Also today, a Chinese provincial newspaper's editor and Communist Party secretary, now in the United States, has been expelled from the party for ideological mistakes, his former paper reported Tuesday. The expulsion of Cheng Kai, former editor of the Hainan Daily, was the latest in a series of expulsions of reformists from party ranks since the student pro-democracy movement last year. The Hainan Daily's brief, front-page report on Cheng did not explain what ideological mistakes he made.

DOC.HEAD: Round-the-World Float-Plane Trip Stalls Without Soviet Approval
DOC.TEXT: A pilot trying to become the first aviator to fly around the world in a float plane got tangled in some Soviet red tape on the second day of his voyage. Tom Casey, 53, began the trip from his hometown of Seattle and reached Anchorage Monday, but he still hadn't received permission to fly over the Soviet Union. He won't leave for his next stop in Nome until he gets the go-ahead from Soviet authorities, he said. ``There seems to be some kind of problem _ I'm not sure what _ and I hope it's not going to be long,'' Casey said. ``They said it had to do with technical difficulties with the airplane.'' Casey is flying a single-engine Cessna equipped with pontoons that allow it to take off and land only on water. Casey had submitted a flight plan to Soviet officials ``from Nome to wherever they'd like me to go. I told them I wanted to go from Nome, Alaska to Helsinki.'' He suggested a route consisting of 500-mile legs between places where he can land his plane called ``Liberty II,'' on water near an airport. The voyage is timed to get Casey back to Seattle in time for the opening ceremonies of the Goodwill Games on July 21. His departure from Seattle on Sunday marked the 63rd anniversary of the beginning of Charles A. Lindbergh's first solo trans-Atlantic flight. Casey's proposed 27,000-mile route roughly retraces the 1924 path of the first globe-circling flight by a pair of Douglas World Cruisers, Casey said. ``I'm working out an alternate plan right now, through the Aleutian chain through Attu, towards Japan. But I still need one stop in the Soviet Union, in the Kuril Islands,'' he said. Casey and his project coordinator in Seattle, Dan Hood, planned to contact Soviet air traffic officials today. His flight so far through Alaska, Casey said, was ``the way it's always been _ beautiful.'' He said he spent years flying in Alaska as a bush pilot. ``One main reason I'm doing this is I'm trying to promote the safety and versatility of general aviation, especially in the Lower 48,'' he said. ``The only place that's left doing what aviation was originally designed for is Alaska. Up here, flying is almost like driving a car. You don't get all the problems that make flying difficult in the rest of the United States. Up here it's survival. It should be shown it's a very, very safe form of transportation.''

DOC.HEAD: Max Wall: From Music Hall Hoofer to Acclaimed Stage Actor
DOC.TEXT: Max Wall, whose stage talents took him from music hall comedy in the plays of Samuel Beckett to acclaim as a serious actor, died today after a fall. He was 82. Wall fell at Simpson's Restaurant in central London Monday afternoon, said his agent, Joan Prichard. He never regained consciousness and died early this morning at Westminster Hospital from a fractured skull. He became famous for his ``Professor Wallofsky'' character, a double-jointed eccentric whose bizarre walk was said to have inspired John Cleese of the Monty Python Flying Circus, the comedy troupe. Wall was born Maxwell George Lorimer in south London on March 12, 1908 into a family of entertainers, and made his first stage appearance as a baby in a kilt. At 14 he played Jack in Mother Goose, with a traveling pantomime, and in 1925 he landed his first London stage role, as a dancer. After appearing on Broadway in 1932, in Earl Carroll's Vanities, he brought his madcap humor and dancing skills to many musicals and stage comedies in Britain. He made his first radio show in 1940. Wall's career went into decline after the breakup of his first marriage, and he was reduced to working obscure north England nightclubs. He married and divorced twice more. His fortune dwindled to bankruptcy. But his career was resurrected when his comic talents and clown face, having reputedly attracted the attention of Beckett, landed him parts in the Irish playwright's ``Waiting for Godot,'' and ``Krapp's Last Tape.'' Wall played an unforgettable Archie Rice in a 1974 revival of John Osborne's ``The Entertainer,'' a role already immortalized by Laurence Olivier. Despite bouts of sciatica, Wall continued acting into his late 70s, including a role in John Arden's ``Sergeant Musgrave's Dance.'' He took occasional film parts, including the sinister Jeremiah Flintwich in the 1987 version of ``Little Dorrit.'' Wall and his first wife, Marion Pola, had five children.

DOC.HEAD: Sixteen Elephants Slaughtered in Sanctuary, Tamil Rebels Blamed
DOC.TEXT: The carcasses of 16 wild elephants killed by gunfire were found in a sanctuary in eastern Sri Lanka, the government said today, and it blamed Tamil rebels for the killings. The dead elephants were found in the first two weeks of May in Kumana jungle, a wildlife and bird sanctuary 130 miles east of Colombo. The eastern and northern regions of Sri Lanka, where most of the minority Tamil population lives, have been under the virtual control of the Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam rebel group since March. A statement by the Information Department said the Tamil Tigers were illegally chopping down trees, killing deer and wild buffaloes and setting up an explosives factory in Kumana. It said the elephant killings were under investigation but that the slaughter was ``probably an act done by the Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam to protect the laborers cutting trees.'' A rebel spokesman denied the allegation, saying it was made to ``tar our image.'' He spoke on condition of anonymity. Hunting wildlife in Sri Lanka is banned, and killing elephants can carry long prison sentences. The Kumana killings, the single largest slaughter of elephants in the island in recent years, has caused an uproar among conservationists and lawmakers. Sri Lanka's population of wild elephants has declined from 7,000 a decade ago to 2,000. The rebels moved into eastern and northern Sri Lanka after forcing the evacuation of Indian peacekeeping troops who arrived in 1987 under an India-Sri Lanka accord, intending to disarm the Tamil Tigers and smaller secessionist groups. The Tamil Tigers refused to disarm, however, and the Sri Lankan government eventually demanded that the Indian troops withdraw. The rebels began their independence campaign in 1983. The Tamils accuse the Sinhalese majority of discriminating in jobs, education and the use of Sinhala language. At least 11,000 people, including 1,100 Indian soldiers, have been killed in the rebellion. Tamils make up 18 percent of Sri Lanka's 16 million people. Sinhalese comprise 75 percent and control the government and the military.

DOC.HEAD: Pope Calls Gathering to Prepare for Synod
DOC.TEXT: Pope John Paul II has called a three-day meeting next month to help prepare for an unprecedented European-wide gathering of Roman Catholic bishops, the Vatican said today. The Vatican said the June 5-7 gathering would be to lay the groundwork for next year's synod, which is aimed at spreading the church's message across the continent. The pope announced plans for the European synod, or meeting of bishops, when he visited Czechoslovakia last month in his first papal trip to Eastern Europe outside his native Poland. The pope's visit to Prague was to underscore Vatican support for the emerging democracies of Eastern Europe, once dominated by communism. Today's brief announcement of the June preparatory meeting said invitations were made to the heads of Europe's national bishops conferences, bishops representing dioceses outside the conferences, Vatican officials and several Eastern Rite representatives. No exact date or site has been announced for the synod, though such gatherings are traditionally held at the Vatican. Shortly after the pope's return from Czechoslovakia, a senior Vatican official said he hoped prelates from all regions of Europe, including the Soviet Ukraine and Albania, will be able to participate in the synod next year. The Ukraine Catholic church, suppressed under Josef Stalin, is still not legal in the Soviet Union. In Albania, all religion has been outlawed.

DOC.HEAD: Idaho Primary To Nominate Hopefuls for U.S. Senate, Governor
DOC.TEXT: Idaho's attorney general hoped to garner votes in the southern and eastern parts of the state today in his underdog effort to win the Republican U.S. Senate nomination over a veteran congressman. The three-way Republican race for the right to a long-shot bid at stopping Democratic Gov. Cecil Andrus from claiming an unprecedented fourth term seemed to have narrowed to state Sen. Rachel Gilbert and former Majority Leader Roger Fairchild. Late campaign polls showed a large share of GOP primary voters still undecided. And stockbroker Milton Erhart, the only gubernatorial candidate with an abortion-rights position, needed a heavy turnout fueled by abortion backers to have any chance of overcoming limited statewide name recognition. Attorney General Jim Jones, who spent only a few thousand dollars in radio commercials, said: ``I think a small to average turnout would be helpful to me. A larger turnout would be a response to a mass-media campaign like (U.S. Rep. Larry) Craig has conducted.'' State election officials predicted an average turnout for a statewide primary of 30 percent to 35 percent. For his part, Craig, a solid favorite to succeed retiring Republican Sen. James McClure, took nothing for granted. He greeted voters in the Boise and Nampa-Caldwell areas before casting his own vote later in the day. ``I think it will be a good win, a strong win,'' said the five-term lawmaker, who hopes to become Idaho's third consecutive 1st District congressman to win a U.S. Senate seat. Craig benefited from the campaign organization that helped McClure win three Senate terms. He outspent Jones 10-1, forcing his opponent to concede defeat in the more Democratic 1st District of northern and western Idaho and concentrate on the conservative southern and eastern 2nd District where Craig had never run before. Boise businessman Ron Twilegar, the former state Senate Democratic leader, was the heavy favorite to win his party's nomination over political newcomer David Steed. In the campaign's final weeks, Steed has forced Twilegar to defend himself against charges of financial impropriety in a federally backed venture capital company he ran. The Senate seat, one of just three nationwide this year in which no incumbent is running, has been held by Republicans for all but eight years this century.

DOC.HEAD: Mandela Accuses Police of Massacre of Blacks
DOC.TEXT: Nelson Mandela today called the police killing of seven blacks a ``massacre'' and warned that efforts to end apartheid will collapse unless the government ends violence by the security forces. The African National Congress leader's comments came two days after police opened fire on protesters at Welkom in the Orange Free State. He said Sunday's killings cast doubt on the white government's commitment to its promises of major reform. ``The government must not talk of negotiations and peace and expect us to join in. The massacre of innocent people is inexcusable,'' Mandela said on his return from a visit to Zimbabwe. Police commanders said Welkom was tense but quiet today as armed police patrolled the area. Welkom has been the scene of several bloody confrontations between blacks and right-wing whites opposed to government plans to abolish apartheid and end white-minority rule. Extremists have formed paramilitary ``white defense'' groups in the area. Police said they were forced to open fire Sunday when hundreds of black protesters attempted to march from Welkom's black township to the white town. Mandela said the government must curb the security forces and end a growing wave of violence that has claimed hundreds of lives in recent months. ``The responsibility to end violence is that of the government,'' he said. The ANC and the government of President F.W. de Klerk are engaged in talks on ending white-minority rule and sharing political power with South Africa's black majority. Mandela threatened to call off the talks when police killed black protesters in March, but he later relented. Meanwhile, another black leader, Mangosuthu Buthelezi, urged Mandela today to meet with him to find ways to end violence in Natal Province, where several thousand blacks have died in fighting between Buthelezi's Inkatha group and ANC-backed groups. ``I can think of no two leaders who could make a greater impact in standing together to shame violence than Mr. Mandela and myself,'' Buthelezi said. A previous plan for talks in March between Buthelezi and Mandela collapsed after protests by some ANC leaders who did not want any dealings with Inkatha. The ANC and Inkatha have a number of leadership and political differences. Inkatha favors a more conservative plan for South Africa after white-minority rule ends.

DOC.HEAD: No Decision Made on Granting PLO Leader a Visa
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs graf 5, Arafat rejected, to restore Shamir's first name and title.
DOC.TEXT: Yasser Arafat, chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization, is seeking permission to attend an emergency U.N. Security Council session in New York, but U.S. officials said today no decision has been made on granting him a visa. Arafat made an indirect request for an entry visa in a letter to U.N. Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar, expecting it would be passed on to the State Department, which denied him a visa two years ago for a similar Mideast debate. U.S. officials, speaking on condition of anonymity, said no decision had been made. They said the situation is ``hypothetical'' because he has not made a formal request. It could remain so if the State Department passes word back to the PLO that the visa request would be denied. Arafat, speaking Monday in Baghdad, Iraq, appealed to President Bush to pressure Israel to stop what the PLO chairman described as ``atrocities'' against Palestinians. Arafat rejected Israeli claims that the lone Israeli gunman who shot and killed seven Palestinian workers near Tel Aviv Sunday was mentally unbalanced. He accused Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir of planning ``a criminal scheme against the Palestinians and the intefadeh.'' Intefadeh is the Arab name for the revolt against Israel's control of the West Bank and Gaza, which were surrendered by Jordan and Egypt in their war against Israel in 1967. ``We appeal to President Bush this time not to let the Palestinian people down and to refrain from protecting the Israeli crimes,'' Arafat said at a news conference. Arafat asked the United States not to use its veto to kill whatever resolution condmening Israel migh be adopted by the Security Council at the request of the PLO. If Arafat is allowed to attend the U.N. session in New York, it would elevate the PLO's stature at a time when Israel is under pressure for using force to try to stem a violent uprising by Palestinian Arabs on the West Bank and in Gaza. When the Reagan administration declined to permit Arafat to attend a U.N. General Assembly session in November 1988, the debate was shifted to Geneva. A month later, in a reversal of policy, the administration opened talks with the PLO. Arafat, acceding to U.S. instructions, had by then publicly renounced terrorism and said he recognized Israel's right to exist. However, the PLO covenant still calls for dismantling the Jewish state. If the visa is granted, Arafat would have an opportunity to take charge of PLO demands that the Security Council condemn Israel for its treatment of Palestinian Arabs. The State Department in March reported to Congress that the PLO was adhering to its commitment renouncing terrorism. Nearly 30 border and rocket attacks were launched by Palestinian groups against Israel since December 1988. But, the report said, ``we have no evidence in those cases or any others that the actions were authorized or approved by the PLO Executive Committee or by Arafat personnaly.'' In denying the PLO's application for a visa in 1988, then-Secreretary of State George P. Shultz said ``the U.S. government has convincing evidence that PLO elements have engaged in terrorism against Americans and other targets.'' Shultz said then that Arafat ``knows of, condones and lends support to such acts'' and is ``an accessory to such terrorism.'' A month later, Schultz took the lead in opening U.S. talks with the PLO, which are continuing in Tunis, the PLO headquarters.

DOC.HEAD: NATO Defense Ministers Gather to Review Strategy in Changing Times
DOC.NOTE: EDs: LEADS with 9 grafs to UPDATE with Cheney comment. Pick up 7th graf pvs, `Less than...'
DOC.TEXT: NATO defense ministers met today to take a hard look at the military strategy that guided the Western alliance during the Cold War years but now may be outdated. The North Atlantic Treaty Organization's key two-day meeting was to review what U.S. Defense Secretary Dick Cheney called ``new ways of doing business'' in an era of reduced East-West tensions. On Monday, West European defense ministers, meeting separately at the alliance headquarters in Brussels, urged NATO to ``adapt to the changing security environment.'' The ministers said it was ``of crucial importance'' to decide what level of defense was needed in a changing world. ``We consider that discussion in the alliance on these issues is timely,'' the ministers said in a statement at the end of their talks. They also said West European countries must prepare to pay more in common defense costs as the United States moves to substantially reduce its military presence in Europe. As an example of new NATO strategy in response to the impending unification of Germany, Cheney raised the idea of a NATO corps with divisions from different nations. Such a force would also ``emphasize the fact that (Germany) is not treated any differently than anyone else,'' he told reporters aboard his flight to Brussels. ``If all present, positive trends continue ... then we can contemplate new ways of doing business,'' Cheney said. Less than two weeks ago, the NATO defense ministers held a meeting of the alliance's Nuclear Planning Group in Kananaskis, Canada, and agreed that there was a ``diminishing need'' for battlefield nuclear weapons in Europe. Their current meeting, this time as the Defense Planning Committee, is part of a series of discussions among high-level NATO officials that will culminate in an early July summit between President Bush and the other alliance leaders. NATO is under pressure to move toward a political, rather than a military, role in an era of reduced East-West tensions. ``I think everybody accepts that business as usual is not possible,'' said a NATO diplomat, discussing the meeting on condition of anonymity. The defense officials were expected to take a look at the actual threat now posed by the Soviet-led Warsaw Pact; the status of conventional arms reduction negotiations in Vienna, Austria; shrinking military budgets, and the increased use of multinational forces. They also will likely discuss their strategy of forward defense, brought into question by the prospect of a united Germany. Forward defense refers to the stationing of troops to defend the front line during an attack. The idea is to defend territory at its border and not give up any land to invading soldiers. The border between East and West Germany, soon to be erased, is now considered part of the front line. The ministers will likely call for studies of some of these issues as they review their future strategy. ``There are many things which have been done for 40 years in a certain way which need to be revisited,'' said the NATO diplomat. The ministers were considered certain to scrap a guideline, in effect since the late 1970s, that called for increasing military spending by 3 percent annually. Many countries have failed to meet that goal in recent years. With easing tensions, even fewer will hit the target now. Some countries, like Greece and Turkey, may keep spending up because of regional problems rather than fears of Soviet aggression. The ministers also will be asked to endorse defense plans based on an assessment of the current military threat posed by the Soviet Union, said a senior NATO official, also on condition of anonymity. He said the alliance needs to adopt ``a degree of prudence'' because of the uncertainty of the political upheaval in the East bloc. But he said it also needs to be flexible to respond to future changes. All 16 NATO nations except France are represented at the meeting. France is not a member of the alliance's integrated military structure. Iceland, which has no armed forces, attends as an observer.

DOC.HEAD: Country Paralyzed By 24-Hour Nationwide Strike
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS thruout to UPDATE with nearly 2 million workers on strike, rallies being held, some service resuming at airport, comments by labor, government officials; no pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Nearly 2 million workers nationwide staged a 24-hour strike today to protest government economic austerity measures, shutting down transportation and businesses. Rallies were held throughout the country to denounce price increases and the abolition of inflation-linked wage increases for civil servants, measures that were adopted after Premier Constantine Mitsotakis took office in April 8. It was the second general strike this year, and labor officials said there could be more. Athens International Airport, the main gateway to Greece, was brought to a standstill when control tower and airline employees stayed off the job from 7:30 a.m. to 1:30 p.m. Only airlines with their own ground crews in Athens resumed flights after the air traffic controllers returned to work. Public transportation in major cities, banks and many businesses were closed down. Ferry service to the nearby islands was disrupted and Piraeus, the nation's key port, offered limited services. The strike was called by the General Confederation of Greek Workers, the civil servants union, ADEDY, and smaler labor groups across the country. The organizations claim a combined membership of 1.85 million workers. ``The strike was a great success,'' Dimitris Hadzisokratis, a member of the workers confederation, said in a telephone interview. ``We are totally satisfied.'' He said, however, that talks today with National Economy Minister George Souflias had been disappointing. ``The minister said that the government was not prepared to negotiate. ... More labor action will follow,'' he said. Labor Minister Aristides Kalatzakos said the strike would only hurt Greece's economy. ``With today's strike ... it is estimated that 16 million hours of precious work time, and over 14 billion drachmas ($86 million) are being sacrificed in the general attempt to overturn the government's economic policy,'' he said in a radio interview. Greece faces 20 percent inflation this year and a $2 billion budget deficit. Some economists say the deficit could reach $4 billion and prompt the International Monetary Fund to step in and force the country to take tougher measures. Premier Mitsotakis, who was elected April 8, has been visiting European capitals to win support and investments for Greece's recovery. He has said he would rather fall from office than tone down the austerity measures. Trade unions, spurred by gains during the eight-year socialist government that ended last June, say the austerity measures have seriously hurt the average worker's buying power. The measures include large increases in the basic costs of services and goods, ranging from 20 percent for bus fares to 300 percent for water. ``We do not care whether the government remains in power or falls,'' the secretary general of the worker's conference, Dimitris Kostopoulos, told a rally in Athens. ``Our concern is that the workers do not fall victim to capital and also that the law of the jungle does not prevail,'' he said. The last general strike was staged in January to pressure the coalition government in power at the time to uphold a promise that living standards would not be affected by austerity measures at the time. Those measures proved ineffective, however, and the economy deteriorated further.

DOC.HEAD: Britain Says `Nuclear Triggers' Sent To Embassy A Hoax
DOC.TEXT: A packet marked ``nuclear triggers'' sent to the Iraqi Embassy contained harmless electronic components used in home appliances, the Foreign Office said today. Iraqi diplomats said the packet, received in the embassy mail last week, was ``another campaign'' against their country and an attempt to strain British-Iraqi relations. But the Foreign Office said the episode appeared to be ``the work of a hoaxer.'' ``These devices are widely available in hardware shops and have a range of domestic appliance use,'' a spokesman said on condition of anonymity. ``They would not require an export license and do not have a nuclear weapons application.'' The spokesman said the Iraqis had not handed over the envelope in which they said the devices arrived and it was impossible to trace where the letter was mailed. The Foreign Office had the 28 small devices examined by Defense Ministry experts after the Iraqis handed them in. In March, British authorities working with the United States seized a consignment of U.S.-made capacitors at Heathrow Airport. U.S. prosecutors said the devices were powerful capacitors for detonating nuclear warheads. Iraq maintained they were destined for use on a non-nuclear university laser project. Britain subsequently expelled Iraqi Airways executive Omar Latif, arrested in connection with an alleged plot to smuggle the nuclear triggering devices.

DOC.HEAD: Teens Appear in Court in Graffiti-Painting at Jewish Cemetery
DOC.TEXT: Three teen-agers appeared in court here today for painting anti-Semitic graffiti on the walls of a Jewish cemetery in this community in eastern France. Two were paroled by the juvenile court after being formally charged with vandalism and racial injury, and the third was freed. The two charged were told not to meet withone another or carry weapons. The youths, who reportedly told police that they were inspired by hatred for ``foreigners,'' were accused of painting ``Long live Hitler and Dachau'' on the walls of a Jewish cemetery on May 4. That was a week before mourners discovered that 34 graves had been defiled and a corpse mutilated at the Jewish cemetery at Carpentras in southern France. The Carpentras incident outraged France and set off nationwide demonstrations against a perceived rise in racism and anti-Semitism. There has been a wave of incidents involving desecration of Jewish cemeteries or synagogues in other countries as well. In Hungary, the daily newspaper Nepszabadsag reported today that 14 tombstones were damaged at a small Jewish cemetery in the town of Sopron, 150 miles from Budapest. Interior Minister Pierre Joxe and other politicians have accused Jean-Marie Le Pen, leader of the far-right National Front, of creating an ``atmosphere of racial hatred'' that set the stage for the Carpentras desecration. Le Pen, in an interview today with the daily newspaper Le Quotidien de Paris, termed Joxe's behavior ``Stalinist,'' saying the minister was accusing him of crimes without conducting an investigation. Le Pen also responded angrily to a decision by authorities in his hometown of Trinite-sur-Mer, who decided Monday not to allow him to host a meeting of extreme-right European leaders there next month. Municipal councillors in the Atlantic coast town of 56,000 people said they were tired of being associated with Le Pen. ``This decision, made under pressure from the media and political parties, runs contrary to the fundamental principle of free assembly guaranteed by our constitution,'' Le Pen said today in a communique. Meanwhile, the weekly newsmagazine Le Meilleur posted a $43,000 reward for information leading to the arrest of whose who desecrated the cemetery at Carpentras. ``When honor and justice demand, it's normal to use all means to bring out the truth,'' said the magazine's editor, Alain Ayache. Police arrested six skinheads in connection with the crime shortly after the Carpentras desecration was discovered May 10, but they were released soon afterward. In another incident, prosecutors in Strasbourg, 300 miles east of Paris, ordered psychiatric care for two skinheads arrested Sunday for painting anti-Semitic slogans on a synagogue. A police patrol came upon the two in the process of daubing the slogans on the walls. A search of their residences turned up neo-Nazi literature, knives, clubs and other weapons, police said.

DOC.HEAD: Coup Leaders Arraigned; Powerful Bombs Defused
DOC.TEXT: Two generals and 19 other officers were arraigned today before a military court for their alleged roles in last December's abortive coup attempt against President Corazon Aquino. They were the first defendants to stand trial in the Dec. 1-9 uprising, the bloodiest attempt to oust Mrs. Aquino since she took office in the 1986 ``people power revolution'' against the late President Ferdinand Marcos. Also today, police defused powerful bombs outside the headquarters of two banks in the financial district and officials said the explosives, timed to explode during morning rush hour, could have destroyed both buildings. Brig. Gen. Marino Filart, chief of the police Capital Command, said the bombs could be part of an urban terror campaign to pave the way for a new coup attempt against Mrs. Aquino. No group claimed responsibility. Share prices tumbled 24.18 points today on The Manila Stock Exchange because of fears of political instability and the country's dim economic prospects. The defendants stood at attention as prosecutors read the indictments, and the session then was adjourned until next Tuesday. Defense lawyers had requested the time to allow their clients time to study their pleas. Each officer was charged with 21 counts of murder and 51 counts of frustrated murder, in addition to mutiny and rebellion. At least 113 people were killed and more than 600 others injured during the coup attempt, the sixth bid to unseat Mrs. Aquino. More than 2,200 of the estimated 3,000 mutineers are in military custory. If convicted on all charges, the officers face sentences of life imprisonment. Defendants included Brig. Gen. Marcelo Blando, former commander of the 7th Infantry Division, and Brig. Gen. Jose Commendador, former chief of the 2nd Air Division of the Philippine air force. The other defendants were two navy captains, one colonel, seven lieutenant colonels, three majors, five army captains and one air force lieutenant. Meanwhile, the commander of U.S. forces in the Pacific said today he is optimistic that U.S. and Philippine officials will reach a new agreement on continuing American military presence in the Philippines. Last Friday, American and Philippine negotiators agreed to continue talks at an unspecified date on whether to renew a lease that expires in September 1991 on Clark Air Base, Subic Bay naval base and four smaller installations. Rafael Alunan, spokesman for the Philippine panel, said the next round could begin in three to four weeks. ``I am very optimistic that we will reach an agreement with continued presence in the Philippines,'' Adm. Huntington Hardisty said. Opposition to the bases is growing because many Filipinos view them as an infringement on national sovereignty. There are 40,000 U.S.troops, Defense Department civilians and military dependents living in the Philippines. Philippine officials said today U.S. negotiators urged stepping up patrols by Philippine troops outside the bases, after suspected Communist rebels killed three Americans near the bases this month. Marine Gunnery Sgt. John Fredette was slain May 4 near Subic naval base, and two American airmen were shot dead on May 13 near Clark. Communist rebels took responsibility for the May 13 killing but not for Fredette's murder.

DOC.HEAD: Willie Nelson's Cowboy Channel Reflects Niche-Seeking in Cable TV
DOC.TEXT: Willie Nelson, the scruffy king of country music, is carrying a business card these days. And some who cherish his outlaw image may cringe because it lists him as a corporate chairman of the board. Nelson is heading up one of the latest entries in cable television's entertainment channel boom. His station is the Cowboy Channel and, yes, he really is chairman of the Cowboy Television Network Inc. ``Chief cook and bottle washer,'' was how Nelson described his duties during a brief interview Monday at the National Cable Television Association's annual convention. Nelson was just one of several celebrity attractions at the three-day convention. But unlike the athletes, movie stars and a Playboy Playmate of the Year signing autographs for the crowd, Nelson also was there on business. He's trying to drum up support among local cable systems for his new network, which will feature cowboy movies and country music when it begins telecasts in November. ``Traveling around the country and around the world, at 2 o'clock in the morning or 2 o'clock in the afternoon it's very difficult to find what I like to see, which is a good Western movie or some good music,'' Nelson said. ``That's exactly the reason I got into this.'' Like many cable TV newcomers, Nelson's channel probably won't appeal to everyone, and that's no mistake. Cable is narrowing its target audiences with an abundance of special interest stations, and that specialization will dictate how cable is sold and delivered in the future, experts say. Cable always has been an outlet for specialized programming like all-sports ESPN and all-news CNN, but newcomers are narrowing the approach even more, with these new stations on display at the show: _ In Court Television, for legal junkies, offers live coverage of noteworthy trials, from U.S. courtrooms as well as from abroad. _ The Golden American Network, ``for viewers that weren't born yesterday,'' features entertainment for an older audience, with such veteran stars as Steve Allen, Morey Amsterdam, Shirley Jones and Monty Hall. _The Sci-Fi Channel will show science fiction and fantasy programs. _ The Comedy Channel, launched in November, and its new competitor HA! have non-stop comedy. ``The challenge is to find large enough niches,'' said John Malone, president of Tele-Communications Inc. of Denver, at a panel discussion Monday on the future of cable.

DOC.HEAD: Hundreds of Thousands of Mourners Bury Top Moslem Clergyman
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 13 grafs with militants exploding bombs, firing guns at funeral, other details; pickup 11th graf pvs, `Some of...'
DOC.TEXT: Islamic militants set off 11 bombs and youths fired bullets in the air to honor Kashmir's top Moslem clergyman, who was buried today as 300,000 mourners wailed and screamed. Security forces kept their distance, apparently to avoid a recurrence of Monday's violence when paramilitary police shot and killed at least 58 mourners. Maulvi Mohammad Farooq, a recent convert to the Kashmir independence movement, was slain Monday by three unidentified gunmen. A few hours later, security forces fired on a huge crowd that defied a curfew and carried Farooq's body six miles to his office. Witnesses and official sources said 58 people were killed and 300 were wounded. The witnesses said the gunfire was unprovoked, but some officials said the security forces were returning fire from Moslem militants. As massive crowds, nearly one-third of Srinagar's population, gathered again today, the government withdrew all security forces along the route of the funeral procession, which wound its way from Islamia College to Martyrs Cemetery on the outskirts of Srinagar. Farooq's rose-covered coffin was in a truck at the head of the mile-long procession. It took four hours to travel the four miles to the cemetery. Thousands of men and women, weeping, beating their chests and waving at the crowd, lined the streets. Boys fired pistols and revolvers in the air. ``Farooq's blood will bear fruit. We will attain independence,'' they shouted. As the funeral cortege reached Martyrs Cemetery militants set off 11 bombs at the far end of the adjoining prayer ground. The crowd seemed to be expecting the blasts and bowed their heads. Then they screamed independence slogans. Farooq's son Umar announced over loudspeakers that his father's last wish was for ``Kashmiris to unite in the fight for independence.'' Forty to 50 militant youths fired Kalashnikov rifles and revolvers in the air after Umar Farooq's announcement. The firing continued for 10 minutes until the coffin was in the ground. The crowd dispersed after the burial. Some of Farooq's aides blamed his killing on right-wing Hindus, while government officials accused Moslem militants who thought Farooq was too moderate. Supporters or representatives of several militant groups, including the Jammu-Kashmir Liberation Front and the Hezbul Mujahedeen, took the microphone at Islamia College to tell mourners they were not responsible. ``This has not been done by any militant,'' one speaker said. Farooq's prominence in the troubled valley had been eclipsed by Moslems fighting for an independent nation. After the crackdown began on Jan. 20, he joined the demand for independence. Before that, however, Farooq had urged a political settlement of the problem. At the United Nations Monday, Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar said he was ``shocked and saddened'' by the assassination, and he appealed for restraint by all sides. Because the violence and independence drive have heightened tensions between India and neighboring Pakistan, and Perez de Cuellar has been careful in his statement not to take sides. Today, India's regular army troops were standing by in Srinagar but were not deployed on the streets, which were guarded by paramilitary police forces. ``We are keeping watch over the situation,'' said Hamidullah Khan, chief secretary of law and order for Jammu-Kashmir. He was contacted by telephone in Srinagar. Monday's shootings pushed the death toll in the Kashmir Valley to about 460 since Jan. 20, when the government began its harshest crackdown on a violent separatist campaign of bombings, kidnappings and assassinations. The majority of those killed have been Moslem militants or their supporters, shot during anti-Indian demonstrations or while defying the curfews that have become a way of life in Srinagar. The secession movement has flared on and off since 1947, when India and Pakistan were partitioned along religious lines upon independence from Britain. Both India and Pakistan claimed the territory. Initially, most secessionist groups sought to join Kashmir with Moslem Pakistan, but in recent years the most militant groups have demanded unconditional independence. Two Indian-Pakistani wars _ in 1948 and 1965 _ failed to resolve the Kashmir question. The region is split between the two nations along a contested frontier. The western part of Kashmir went to Pakistan, while the eastern part became part of India's Jammu-Kashmir state. It is the only Moslem majority state in India, where 82 percent of the population of 880 million is Hindu. In Jammu-Kashmir, Moslems comprise 64 percent of the 6 million inhabitants. Hindus, living mostly in the Jammu region, form 32 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Death Toll Rises to 68 in Ship Sinking
DOC.TEXT: The death toll reached 68 in the sinking of a passenger ship 1,000 miles northeast of Jakarta, a report said today. The official Antara news agency said it was unclear how many people had been aboard the vessel, the Macoli, which sank Sunday night in heavy seas off East Kalimantan province. The report said at least 141 people were rescued, including some infants. Originally it was thought that the ship was carrying 133 people. But Antara quoted a Tarakan Port Authority official as saying authorities believed the ship carried at least 209 people. Its capacity was 110 passengers. The ship was en route to Tarakan from Nunukan, both in East Kalimantan.

DOC.HEAD: Census Taker Suspended for Reporting Suspected Drug User
DOC.TEXT: A census worker has been suspended for violating the U.S. Census Bureau's tradition of confidentiality because he informed the police that a resident he questioned appeared to be using marijuana. The bureau's Cedar Rapids office said Stephen Larson should have informed his superiors and let them decide whether to inform the police. Larson said he was told Monday he was being suspended pending an investigation. Tom Moss, the district office's director, said census enumerators make assurances that ``nothing will come out of this to anybody other than the Census Bureau.'' Police, who took no action on Larson's complaint, said today that the census taker's only mistake was telling a reporter about his report. While on the job in early May, Larson said he was greeted with a cloud of marijuana smoke when a tenant opened his door. He said he completed the census form with the resident, who was cooperative, and later went home and reported him to police. ``I did what I thought was right at the time,'' Larson said. ``But according to them (his bosses), you can't even notify the police when you witness a murder going on if it occurs in a house you're doing for the census.'' Moss said confidentiality does not take precedence over criminality, or even suspected criminality. ``I am not saying there is a higher priority on confidentiality over anything, even a suspicion,'' said Moss. ``I'm simply saying that whatever our people can do we must keep the confidentiality we promised people. We promised the public that we won't tell.'' Sgt. Glenn Fox of the narcotics division in Cedar Rapids said Larson waited until late at night to make his report. ``By then, there was so little information, we couldn't have acted anyway. We added it to our intelligence file and that was it,'' Fox said. Fox said he can understand the Census Bureau's insistence on confidentiality, ``but I admire the guy for standing up for what is right.'' ``The mistake he made, and no offense, he should never have told the news media about it. We'd never have told anybody if he hadn't,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Three People Deliver Suspect to Police at Gunpoint
DOC.TEXT: Police have yet to decide whether to prosecute three people who forced a naked suspect at gunpoint into a car trunk for a 200-mile drive to Wichita. But they did charge the suspect, 24-year-old Darrel Hartley, on Monday with molesting his former girlfriend's teen-age daughter. Police say Hartley was delivered to them by the ex-girlfriend and two of her friends. Hartley was charged in Sedgwick County District Court with two counts of indecent liberties with a child and is being held in Sedgwick County Jail in lieu of $5,000 bond. Police Lt. Mike McKenna said Hartley was arrested early Sunday after the man's former girlfriend, 45, and two male companions drove to Sublette on Saturday night and confronted Hartley. McKenna said the woman told police that she and Hartley had been living together in Wichita when, in January, he had sexual intercourse with her 13-year-old daughter. ``They took him into custody at gunpoint, ordered him to undress, tied him up, put him in the trunk of the car and drove back to Wichita,'' McKenna said. He said the drive takes ``a ood four hours.'' When the trio got to Wichita at 1 a.m. Sunday, McKenna said, they took Hartley to the woman's house, gave him back his clothes and called police. Police interviewed Hartley, then took him downtown and booked him. McKenna said the woman and her friends were questioned and released, and the gun was turned in as evidence. ``They're not being charged at this time,'' he said. ``We'll discuss that with the district attorney.''

DOC.HEAD: Governor Starts Drug-Free Workplace Campaign with Urinalysis
DOC.TEXT: Gov. Bob Martinez jokingly described himself as a ``straight shooter'' today after submitting a urine sample to kick off his push for a drug-free workplace. Martinez was the first of about 45 people in the governor's office scheduled to submit to the drug tests. Under the mandatory program, opposed by some state workers, tests producing positive results will be followed by a more detailed confirmaton test. Employees in the governor's office were notified in January they would be subject to the $36 test, said press secretary Jon Peck. The governor's executive order March 26 served as a 60-day notice to workers. Results of his tests will be available by June 1, but won't be made public, his office said.

DOC.HEAD: Estonian, Latvian Presidents in Moscow for Talks With Kremlin Officials
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout with officials meeting with Gorbachev, strike spreading in Estonia, U.S. official urging end to embargo. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: The presidents of Estonia and Latvia met today with Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev to discuss moves they have taken toward independence, an Estonian spokesman said. In Lithuania, the parliament met to consider a new offer to the Kremlin aimed at breaking the republic's impasse with Moscow over its March 11 declaration of independence, a parliamentary spokesman said. A strike by pro-Moscow forces in Estonia went into its second day, with workers at two more plants joining the protest against the republic's independence drive, a strike committee spokesman said. The Tass news agency said the strike has spread to coal mines, shipyards and the Krengolmskaya manufacturing mills, the republic's largest light industry enterprise. Tass said 21 industrial businesses were on strike. Finnish radio reported a strike among members of Estonia's ethnic Russian minority had prompted the owners of the Baltic ferry boat ``Georg Ots'' to suspend service between the Finnish capital of Helsinki and Tallinn, the Estonian capital. The three Baltic republics _ Lithuania, Latvia and Estonia _ were forcibly annexed by the Soviet Union 50 years ago, and all are in varying stages of efforts to break free of Moscow's control. Presidents Arnold Ruutel of Estonia and Anatoly Gorbunov of Latvia met this morning with members of Gorbachev's Federation Council, an advisory body on the nation's republics and nationalities, said Andrei Birov, a spokesman for the Estonian mission in Moscow. The two Baltic officials met later with Gorbachev, another Estonian spokesman said. No details of either meeting were released. Last week, Lithuanian Prime Minister Kazimiera Prunskiene met with Gorbachev, who urged her to persuade the republic's parliament to suspend its declaration of independence. An assistant U.S. Commerce Department secretary said today the Bush administration ``hopes the Soviet Union will end its economic blockade of Lithuania and begin a productive dialogue with the Lithuanian people.'' The official, Thomas J. Duesterberg, was in Moscow for talks with Soviet trade officials. In Vilnius, the Lithuanian capital, legislators were debating measures on holding the economy together in the face of the Kremlin economic blockade as well as what approach to take toward Moscow regarding the independence declaration, a spokesman for the parliament's information bureau said. Debate continued through the afternoon, without any resolutions being passed, he said. So far, lawmakers have refused to suspend the independence decree, but have offered to consider rescinding other measures aimed at implementing the declaration. The Lithuanian economy is feeling squeezed by the cutoff of oil, natural gas and other raw materials imposed by Moscow more than a month ago. Lithuanian parliamentary spokeswoman Rita Dapkus said Monday that total industrial, construction and transportation layoffs have topped 12,100, not counting taxi and bus drivers who have been idled by the resulting shortage of gasoline. In the agricultural sector, the embargo has forced the shutdown of 712 enterprises, or 60 percent of the republic's total, Ms. Dapkus said. Lithuanian Vice President Ceslovas Stankevicius said townspeople may be evacuated to the countryside to conserve energy and food. ``I cannot say how long we can survive this situation, but the Lithuanian people are ready to suffer this anti-humanitarian act,'' he told a seminar on Baltic independence in Stockholm, Sweden. The economic embargo was imposed on Lithuania after it refused to rescind some of its pro-independence laws. On May 14, Gorbachev decreed that steps toward independence by Latvia and Estonia violated the Soviet constitution, but he has not taken any punitive action against those two republics. In Tallinn, the striking workers demanded that Ruutel resign and the parliament rescind laws challenging Soviet authority, said Viktor Tsunya, a member of the anti-independence Russian Strike Committee. Tass said the workers want pro-Moscow legislators to meet to consider setting up an alternate government. Estonian Prime Minister Edgar Savisaar told local radio that the strike ``will not do serious damage to the Estonian economy'' and that measures were being taken to solve any problems created by the work stoppage. The strike, which began Monday in the form of political meetings at plants and factories, is being carried out mostly by Russian-speaking workers who are against any break with Moscow. Sixty-five percent of the republic's 1.8 million population is Estonian. Russians comprise 28 percent, with Ukrainians and Byelorussians making up the rest. Russians and other ethnic minorities in all three Baltic republics complain that they are discriminated against as a result of the independence movements.

DOC.HEAD: Charges Pressed Against Former Communist Official
DOC.TEXT: Prague's former Communist Party boss was charged with abuse of power today, becoming the first Communist to face trial following last year's peaceful revolution, the official CTK news agency said. Miroslav Stepan is accused of using his position as the city's Communist Party chairman to suppress growing public dissent in 1988-89. If convicted, he could face up to 10 years in prison. According to the charges, at a meeting of the Prague security council on Oct. 28, 1988, Stepan told police chief Bohumil Carda to use water cannon and tear gas to stop demonstrations. ``These means were then indeed used, although the security council has authority only to take measures to protect the state,'' CTK quoted a statement by the prosecutor as saying. Stepan has been held in custody since Dec. 23, 1989, pending an investigation into whether he played a role in the bloody police crackdown on students last Nov. 17. The crackdown provoked a wave of protests that toppled the hard-line Communist regime of Milos Jakes. ``The result of our investigation so far does not indicate that the police ... intervention was based on the initative of Mr. Stepan,'' the prosecutor's statement said. It did not say when Stepan would be tried.

DOC.HEAD: Daily News Publisher To Head 1991 Pulitzer Board
DOC.TEXT: Daily News Publisher and President James Hoge has been elected chairman of the 1991 Pulitzer Prize board, Columbia University President Michael I. Sovern announced today. Hoge succeeds Eugene L. Roberts Jr., executive editor of The Philadelphia Inquirer and president of Philadelphia Newspapers Inc., who remains a Pulitzer board member. Hoge will serve as chairman for one year. In addition, scholar and critic Helen Vendler and Marilyn Yarbrough, dean of the University of Tennessee College of Law, have been elected to the board. Their election fills a vacancy left by Charlotte Saikowski, former Washington bureau chief of the Christian Science Monitor, and another created when the board voted to expand from 17 to 18 members in April. The Pulitzer board is responsible for recommending to Columbia University's trustees whom they should honor with annual awards for excellence in journalism and the arts.

DOC.HEAD: New Government Will Seek Talks On Withdrawal from Alliance
DOC.TEXT: Hungary's new premier said today his government will seek to negotiate the country's withdrawal from the Soviet-led Warsaw Pact. Jozsef Antall's elected government is to be sworn in next week, and he outlined his programs to Parliament today. The new government faces serious economic problems. Inflation is in double digits, unemployment is rising and Hungary has a $20 billion foreign debt, the highest per capita in Eastern Europe. Antall, who wants to restore free enterprise, promised anti-inflation measures and better social welfare and education, but did not explain how this would be financed. He said a more detailed program would be outlined soon. He also said he hoped Hungary could join the European Community in the next decade, and said his government intends to ``dismantle the system of repression'' and ``inaugurate the system of liberty.'' The Communist Party, which ruled Hungary for decades, revamped itself in advance of Hungary's free elections last March and April, but nonetheless was overwhelmingly defeated. On withdrawal from the Warsaw Pact, Antall said Hungary would take into account ``the international situation, our neighbors' positions, and the Hungarian armed forces' state of preparedness.'' Parliament's foreign affairs committee has urged swift talks with the Soviet Union and the five other Pact members on Hungary's possible withdrawal. Antall stressed, however, that withdrawal would come in the context of new security arrangements for all of Europe. The state news agency MTI earlier quoted Gyula Horn, the outgoing foreign minister, as warning that withdrawal from the pact would hinder ongoing talks on reducing conventional arms in Europe. The talks in Vienna by the Warsaw Pact and the North Atlantic Treaty Organization aim at an initial agreement on reducing conventional forces and weapons later this year. Horn was quoted as saying a Hungarian withdrawal from the alliance would force the Warsaw Pact to make unspecified ``new calculations.''

DOC.HEAD: Police Arrest Man Under Anti-Terrorist Law, Seize Automatic Weapons
DOC.TEXT: Police seized loaded automatic weapons from a car after a chase in north London early today and arrested the driver under an anti-terrorist law, police and witnesses said. The seizure, following Irish Republican Army bombings of two British army offices in London last week, raised speculation that police had intercepted an IRA unit shifting arms in the capital. A police statement said a patrol car began chasing the suspect car at about 3 a.m. in Tottenham in north London. The driver eventually pulled over and was caught as he tried to flee, police said. Scotland Yard, London's police headquarters, warned that another terrorist suspect was probably driving behind the arms car and had gotten away. They put out a general alert. Scotland Yard said only that ``weapons'' were seized and the driver was being held under the Prevention of Terrorism Act. It allows police to hold suspects for up to a week without charge. Witnesses said police hauled several loaded submachine guns from behind the driver's seat of the battered green Cortina. Police at the scene said at least two Soviet-made AK-47 rifles were seized. In Belfast, Northern Ireland, youths hurled a homemade bomb at a British army patrol in a Roman Catholic district on Monday night, wounding one soldier, the army reported. A bus driver was hurt in a separate attack with gasoline bomb, police said. The government says it believes the IRA bombings in London last week were the start of a summer offensive in Britain by the group. A sergeant was killed and another man wounded Wednesday when a bomb blew apart their vehicle at an army recruiting center in Wembley, north London, a few miles from Tottenham. Two days earlier, an IRA blast at an army education office at Eltham, southeast London, injured seven civilians. The IRA is fighting to end British rule in Northern Ireland and unite the Protestant-dominated province with the Republic of Ireland, which is overwhelmingly Roman Catholic. The organization is banned throughout Ireland and the United Kingdom.

DOC.HEAD: Senate Panel Approves Seafood Inspections
DOC.TEXT: The Senate Agriculture Committee voted Tuesday for a bill that would require that fish processed as food be inspected in much the same way as meat and poultry. ``Currently, less than 12 percent of American seafood undergoes some kind of inspection or grading,'' said Sen. Patrick Leahy, D-Vt., chairman of the committee. ``Only 7 percent of almost 2,000 seafood processors nationwide participate in these voluntary inspection programs.'' Meat and poultry undergo rigorous inspection by the Agriculture Department. A consumer advocate who has been campaigning since 1986 for similar standards for fish praised the bill, but said it was missing two essential features. Ellen Haas, founder of Public Voice for Food and Health Policy, said she hoped to see an amendment added on the Senate floor that would require fishing boats to be inspected. She also said she was disappointed the committee removed whistle-blower provisions in the bill that would have protected any employees of inspection programs who call attention to alleged misconduct or deficiencies. ``They are the insurance of a program with integrity,'' said Haas. ``Senator Leahy said he is committed to fight for it on the floor.'' Haas said the bill is strong as it stands, but gives a great deal of responsibility to the industry. Similar legislation is pending in the House, but has not yet been approved by the agriculture committee there. Under the Senate bill the Agriculture Department would: _set standards for processing fish. _determine sources of potential contamination. _require prevention and cleanup procedures for contaminated areas. _assure through inspections that fish and food made from fish are processed under sanitary conditions.
