The Food and Drug Administration, which administers the limited fish inspection program that exists, would continue to decide the level of contamination that is considered harmful. The commerce secretary would be authorized to close waters that are considered too contaminated for safe fishing. Imported fish would have to comply with all the standards set for fish harvested domestically. Grants totalling $2 million would be provided each year to educate fish processors on proper handling methods.

DOC.HEAD: American Held After Rushing Wall, Blocking Traffic
LaserPhoto BER1
DOC.TEXT: East German border soldiers apprehended a U.S. citizen Tuesday after he ran through a Berlin Wall border crossing and lay down in the street, blocking border traffic, an army spokesman said. The man bolted from the West Berlin side of the remains of the wall and through the passport control checkpoint known as Checkpoint Charlie, an East German army spokesman said. Foreigners are required to show their passports when crossing between the Germanys. The American then lay down in the street and blocked traffic until East German soldiers took him away and turned him over to the city's medical service, the army spokesman said. He was identified as John Runnings of Seattle. The spokesman referred to the man as a ``special personality'' who has done similar things in the past two years. He said the American apparently has been living in West Berlin.

DOC.HEAD: Newspaper Says Secret Police Tried to Eavesdrop on Pope
DOC.TEXT: Secret police under the previous Communist regime bugged the Jasna Gora monastery at Czestochowa just before Pope John Paul II's 1979 pilgrimage, a newspaper reported Tuesday. Vatican security officials discovered the eavesdropping devices and gave the pope another room, Solidarity's Gazeta Wyborcza newspaper said. The disclosure follows earlier reports by the Solidarity-led government that the now-dissolved Security Service eavesdropped on hotel rooms, foreign journalists and Solidarity offices. The Security Service was disbanded after Solidarity Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki took power in September. It once had an entire department devoted to monitoring the Catholic Church. The listening devices at the shrine in southern Poland, which shelters the revered Black Madonna icon, were installed during an expansion of the monastery's electrical system in preparation for the pope's visit, the paper said. Vatican officials inspecting the rooms tipped off the Rev. Jozef Platek, then head of the 600-year-old monastery, to the electronic listening devices. Platek assigned the pope to another room. According to the article, the monastery also mysteriously developed plumbing problems before the 1979 papal trip and a subsequent visit _ an apparent effort to allow a plumber to gain access to the papal quarters. When the monastery fired its plumber, the Interior Ministry pressed for his rehiring, the paper said. Gazeta Wyborcza writer Dariusz Fedor said the story was based mainly on interviews with confidential sources. The Polish-born pope's 1979 visit was the first by a Catholic primate to an East bloc country. It attracted huge crowds and is credited with inspiring the Solidarity movement born the next year. The Jasna Gora shrine became legendary in Poland after it withstood a determined Swedish siege in 1655.

DOC.HEAD: Three Killed In Accidental Grenade Blast
DOC.TEXT: A group of people began tossing a grenade around at a party Tuesday, and three were killed when it exploded, police said. Police said one of the guests apparently brought the grenade to the house in the city's Sampoloc district. In addition to the three deaths, four people were injured in the blast. It was not known how the guest obtained the grenade.

DOC.HEAD: Latest Wolf Study Shipped to Congress
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads throughout to recast; CORRECT and include party affiliations for congressman and senators. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: The superintendent of Yellowstone National Park says a new study that maintains the return of wolves to the park will have little impact on other wildlife is the most thorough look yet at the proposal. But U.S. Rep. Ron Marlenee, R-Mont., calls it ``poppycock,'' adding that the 586-page report shipped to Capitol Hill on Monday says exactly what the National Park Service and the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service _ proponents of the wolf recovery proposal _ wanted it to say. U.S. Sen. James McClure, R-Idaho, is expected this week to introduce legislation calling for wolves to be transplanted to Yellowstone as well as the Frank Church-River of No Return Wilderness in central Idaho. The study, put together with comments from wolf experts worldwide and researchers from three universities, predicts little impact on wildlife or livestock near Yellowstone if wolves are returned. However, it speculates that some wolves would head beyond Yellowstone's boundaries and have to be controlled by one means or another to protect livestock interests. Although some critics of the recovery plan fear wolves would decimate Yellowstone's big game herds, the study said the available prey was at least five times greater than that which 100 wolves _ the ideal recovery population _ would be expected to reduce or even limit. Bryce Dustman, press secretary for U.S. Sen. Conrad Burns, R-Mont., said he wasn't surprised by the report's claim that wolves would have little effect on wildlife or livestock. He said ``it jumped out at him'' that the Park Service and Fish and Wildlife Service wrote a study saying the wolf wouldn't have a detrimental effect on livestock or big game. Barbee acknowledged the Park Service supports the wolf's return, but said the two agencies didn't manipulate the report's contents. McClure's proposal is expected to call for three breeding pairs of wolves to be transplanted into the two core areas and protected within those areas. The wolves would not, however, be protected outside those areas and would be managed under state law rather than the federal Endangered Species Act.

DOC.HEAD: Thatcher Urges End to Sanctions
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher said Tuesday that economic sanctions against South Africa should be lifted because President F. W. de Klerk's reforms have made them ``almost irrelevant.'' Answering a question in Parliament from a pro-South African lawmaker, Mrs. Thatcher issued her most forthright call so far for waiving sanctions. It came four days after de Klerk met Mrs. Thatcher in England during the South African president's nine-nation tour of Europe. Praising de Klerk's ``integrity and courage,'' Mrs. Thatcher said he had made reforms ``which are irreversible, which will bring an end to apartheid'' and lead to a democratic government on a non-racial basis. ``I believe that there is no place now for sanctions and ... indeed they are almost irrelevant,'' she said. ``Those people who want South Africa to have a prosperous economy should not support sanctions in any way.'' Mrs. Thatcher has been consistently at odds with Britain's partners in the 49-nation Commonwealth and the 12-member European Community in opposing sanctions. In February, after de Klerk released black leader Nelson Mandela, Mrs. Thatcher acted alone and lifted some minor restrictions. Britain now appears determined to press the Community at meetings next month to ease sanctions. The main European Communisty embargoes are bans on the purchase of South African coal, steel and gold coins, and on new government investment. De Klerk was in Switzerland on Tuesday, where he voiced confidence that support for his reform policies will lead to the lifting of sanctions, perhaps before the end of the year. De Klerk spoke to reporters after meeting with members of the Swiss Cabinet. He warned that failure to recognize that his country is ``inexorably on the road to a new South Africa'' would ``play into the hands of the radicals, of those who do not want a peaceful solution.'' ``The time has come for the world to take off its apartheid glasses,'' he said. ``We are aiming at a situation where there won't be any underdogs in South Africa.''

DOC.HEAD: Radicals Battle Police, Begin Week of Anti-U.S. Protests
DOC.TEXT: Radicals armed with firebombs and rocks fought police and burned a U.S. flag in Kwangju on Tuesday, and students in the capital declared a week of protests against the U.S. presence in South Korea. Police tightened security at U.S. facilities and arrested eight radical students who tried to deliver a letter to the U.S. Embassy in Seoul. Shouting ``Drive out the Yankees!'' the protesters unfurled an anti-American banner that demanded the U.S. apologize for South Korea's bloody suppression of a 1980 civil uprising in Kwangju. Also in Seoul, police fired 23 blanks from an M-16 rifle at about 100 students who threw firebombs at a police station. At a news conference in Seoul, student leaders said they would stage anti-U.S. protests through Sunday. ``We are asking for a formal U.S. apology'' over the suppression of the Kwangju uprising, said a statement by radical students, who are a loud minority on South Korean campuses. It also accused the United States of supporting dictatorships in South Korea and demanded an apology for that. ``Unless our demands are met, the United States will be punished,'' the statement warned. The student leaders said they would ``seek the spread of anti-U.S. feeling among Koreans through various means during the period and unveil the true character of the United States.'' In Kwangju, 155 miles south, groups of 100 to 500 students staged violent anti-U.S. protests in the city center after burning a U.S. flag. Police firing tear gas chased the protesters into alleys and sidestreets. The scattered street protests in Kwangju died down after nightfall. Police did not say how many people were injured or arrested. The open letter to the U.S. Embassy demanded the United States withdraw its 43,000 troops stationed in South Korea, remove nuclear weapons positioned here, and stay out of Korean politics. Radicals have staged violent anti-government, anti-U.S. protests to mark the 10th anniversary of the Kwangju uprising, the bloodiest in modern Korean history. By official count, 200 citizens were killed in the 10-day revolt that began on May 18, 1980. Despite repeated denials by the United States, many citizens feel that Washington condoned the Korean military suppression. At a hospital morgue in Kwangju, about 500 militants brandishing metal pipes guarded the body of a student activist who suffered fatal head injuries when he jumped from a train to avoid police checkpoints. The 21-year-old student, Shin Jan-ho, died Saturday, as about 20,000 students from across the nation gathered for a rally marking the Kwangju anniversary. About 150 students staged an anti-U.S. sit-in Tuesday at Korea Aviation College, 18 miles north of Seoul, when 20 U.S. military helicopters landed on the college's airstrip. The protesters shouted ``Withdraw U.S. troops'' and marched around the helicopters, but there were no incidents, the Yonhap news agency said. U.S. helicopters occasionally use the airstrip for training.

DOC.HEAD: Torrential Rains Leave 23 Dead, Homes Destroyed
DOC.TEXT: Homes and streets have collapsed under torrential rains in this Central African capital, killing at least 23 people, official sources said Tuesday. Rescue workers continued to dig for bodies in the debris of homes and roads that were torn up and collapsed under the onslaught of tropical rain that hit Kinshasa early Monday. The government Tuesday announced it would pay for the funerals of victims. Entire suburbs have been cut off from the rest of the city by rivers of water. Heavy rain tends to be disastrous in the city of 3 million, where much housing is substandard and collapses in storms.

DOC.HEAD: Fugitive Marsupials Outmaneuver Police and Vet
DOC.TEXT: Police on Tuesday called off a two-month search for two wallabies that have been running wild on the outskirts of this Dutch town for two months. ``It can't do any harm to let them live up in the dunes,'' Deputy Commander J. N. Boer of the National Police told The Associated Press after abandoning the search. ``Besides, we have better things to do.'' The wallabies are relatives of the kangaroo and are also native to Australia. They were the pets of a local resident until they hopped over his fence. Police were concerned the sight of two 20-inch-high wallabies hopping down the highway might cause a traffic accident. They even called in a helicopter to ferret out the marsupials. The wallabies eluded searchers. ``Last Thursday I was called to a house on the edge of a meadow where a kangaroo was unassumingly eating grass in the backyard,'' veterinarian Erik van der Kamp told the AP. Attempts to tranquilize the animals with dart guns have failed because the animals draw crowds of local children wherever they appear. Police said the owner had refused to cooperate in capture attempts. Repeated telephone calls to his home were not answered. ``There's no law against letting your pet kangaroos roam free, but he will be responsible for whatever might happen,'' said Boer.

DOC.HEAD: New Security Measures in Medellin; President Cancels Trip to Peru
DOC.TEXT: Riding double on motorcycles was declared illegal Tuesday in the city of Medellin in an effort to stop drive-by killings that have become common in the drug-infested city. President Virgilio Barco, worried about a wave of violence prior to Sunday's presidential election, canceled a trip to Peru where he was to have attended a regional presidential summit Tuesday. The new law regarding motorcycle riders was imposed a day after the slaying of Sen. Federico Estrada Velez of the governing Liberal Party. Police in Medellin said two men on a motorcycle were responsible for the murder. Killers hired by drug traffickers often travel in pairs on motorcycles to carry out a job: one drives, one shoots, then both disappear rapidly into traffic. The 63-year-old politician and his driver were shot to death at a Medellin traffic light Monday. Condemning Estrada's assassination and a series of recent bomb attacks, Barco said he would not attend a presidential summit in Peru to discuss regional integration among Colombia, Venezuela, Peru, Ecuador and Bolivia. In a nationwide televised speech Monday night, the president called for national solidarity to fight violence. ``Violent people must be confronted by an invincible army of 30 million Colombians of good will,'' he said. In the last 10 days, five car bombs have exploded in three Colombian cities, killing 28 people and injuring about 300. On Monday, a powerful bomb was defused shortly before it was set to go off in front of a school where Barco's two granddaughters attend classes. One of the girl's bodyguards found the bomb. The Bogota daily El Tiempo said the fuse had 60 seconds left when it was defused. Colombia has been hit by a wave of bombings and assassinations since August, when Barco declared war on drug traffickers and resumed extraditions to the United States.

DOC.HEAD: Boys Digging For Worms Unearth Rare Baseball Card
DOC.TEXT: They were only digging for worms, but three boys came up with pay dirt instead when they found what appears to be a rare Honus Wagner baseball card dating back to the early 1900s. The card featuring the Pittsburgh Pirates' Hall of Fame shortstop, also known as ``The Flying Dutchman,'' was found dry and in good condition, with the colors still bright and corners neat and square, said Arlo Quint, 12. The boys raced to a collectors shop and compared the card against a reprint, and it appeared to be genuine, the boy said Tuesday. ``I can't believe it,'' said Quint, who found the card Monday. If proven authentic, it could be worth $10,000 or more, an expert said. The boy said he will probably sell the card and share the profits with his family and Chris Deck and Eric Love, both 13, who were looking for fishing worms with Quint when he unearthed a small, bent tooth-powder can that also contained three other cards. Quint said the boys can't make out whose pictures are depicted on the other cards. Wagner, a baseball legend who played for the Pittsburgh Pirates from 1897 to 1917, posted a .329 lifetime batting average. Quint has been collecting baseball cards since he was 5 and has about 5,000 cards in his collection. A Wagner card ``in real good shape'' is worth $100,000, said Brad Shaw of the Fuss-Budget Sportscards Center in Augusta. ``Even one in rough shape is worth $10,000 to $15,000,'' although it could fetch more at auction, Shaw said Tuesday. The card discovered by Quint was thought to have been distributed in 1909 by the Piedmont Tobacco Co. Wagner, a teetotaler who did not smoke, demanded that the tobacco company cease publishing his card because he said it implied an endorsement. Shaw said no more than 50 Wagner cards remain intact. Coincidentally, another Honus Wagner card was discovered about 30 miles away in Stockton Springs about a month ago.

DOC.HEAD: Artificial-Heart Pioneer Gets a Second Device
DOC.TEXT: The first person to successfully receive an artificial heart as a bridge to transplant of a human heart has received a second artificial heart implant, University Medical Center officials said today. Michael Drummond, 30, of Phoenix received the Symbion J-7-70 device during a five-hour, 15-minute operation Monday night, hospital officials said. Drummond was in critical but stable condition, normal for recovery from heart surgery, hospital spokeswoman Jan Howard said today. Drummond had been on a list for a heart transplant since Thursday, but doctors said the artificial device was decided upon Monday afternoon after an attempt to put Drummond on a ventilator critically lowered his blood pressure. Dr. Jack G. Copeland, head of the hospital's heart transplant and artificial heart programs, determined that an artificial heart support device was Drummond's only chance to survive to a new heart transplant, the hospital said. Copeland led the surgical team in the operation. Drummond was the first person to successfully undergo a bridge-to-transplant and recover from a subsequent heart transplant. He was also the youngest man to receive an artificial heart device when he had the Jarvik-7 artificial heart implanted Aug. 29, 1985. Drummond suffered a stroke, but recovered and received the heart of a 19-year-old Texas man nine days later. He went through several rejection episodes, but recovered and returned to work as a grocery store assistant manager until several recent illnesses. The Jarvik-7 Drummond received later was donated to the Smithsonian Institution in Washington, D.C.

DOC.HEAD: President Says US Should Encourage Free Markets
DOC.TEXT: President Bush said Tuesday the United States ``must do all we can'' to encourage free market development across Latin America to consolidate democratic gains in the region. Calling Cuba the hemisphere's lone holdout, Bush said, ``We are closer than ever before to the day when all the people of the Americas, North and South, will live in freedom.'' The events of the past year _ including the demise of dictatorships in Panama, Nicaragua, Chile and Paraguay _ have ``strengthened our desire to forge a new partnership with the growing forces of freedom in Latin America,'' he said. Bush, addressing a U.S. business group interested in promoting Latin trade, said, ``We in the U.S. must do all we can to ensure the future of free markets in the Americas, because our nation has a stake in the economic health of this hemisphere.'' Two-way trade between the United States and Latin America last year topped $100 billion for the first time, he said. ``Our challenge is to consolidate democracy and accelerate development,'' Bush told the Council of the Americas. On this anniversary of Cuban independence from Spain, Bush took a slap at Fidel Castro's ``isolated'' island, which he called ``out of step with the democratic tide.'' ``Let me say with certainty that even in Cuba, the dream of democracy can only be pushed back a little, only deferred. It will never be destroyed,'' Bush said. Many Latin nations have held free elections in the past year, including Nicaragua, where Sandinista President Daniel Ortega lost to opposition leader Violetta Chamorro, and Chile, where the military dictatorship of Augusto Pinochet ended after 17 years. ``All across the Americas, today more people live under freely elected governments than ever before,'' said Bush. ``The U.S. is engaged as never before in the future of this hemisphere,'' he said. Bush also made a pitch for his $720 million emergency aid package for Panama and Nicaragua. ``Finally, it appears the Congress may act this week on this vital measure,'' said Bush, who first sought the money in March. ``Let me say to the Congress: The fate of freedom rests in your hands. Do the work of democracy and pass this emergency aid package now.'' The Council of the Americas, founded by banker David Rockefeller in 1965, consists of nearly 200 U.S. companies with interests in Latin America and the Caribbean.

DOC.HEAD: Opposition Leader Says He'll Challenge Election Results
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 21 grafs to UPDATE with angry demonstrators chasing government official, police seeking those who called for demonstration over alleged fraud, new results, Ratiu saying he not approached about any coalition; other details. Pick up 15th graf pvs, `The official...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto BUC3
DOC.TEXT: Victorious presidential candidate Ion Iliescu today offered to form a coalition with losing parties, but one opposition leader ruled out the idea and another said he planned to challenge the vote. Hundreds of angry anti-goverment demonstrators camped out in downtown Bucharest today chased Sever Georgescu, a senior government official, and forced him to seek shelter in a hotel. The government sent Georgescu to speak to 24 hunger strikers, and as he left, protesters surrounded him, shouting: ``You thieves, you stole the revolution!'' and ``We want free elections!'' He escaped unharmed. State radio urged the public to help police find people who were circulating leaflets calling for a demonstration against voting fraud. In language reminiscent of former leader Nicolae Ceausescu's terms for opponents, the radio described the protest organizers as ``bad-intentioned elements.'' At least two Western European observer groups today questioned the legitimacy of Iliescu's victory in Romania's first democratic elections in a half-century, and the head of one group said Western governments should refrain from granting aid to Romania. With 12.6 million ballots counted by this afternoon, Iliescu of the National Salvation Front had about 86 percent of the vote in the three-way presidential contest, according to the Central Electoral Bureau. Radu Campeanu of the National Liberal Party had 10.2 percent and Ion Ratiu of the National Peasants Party had 3.8 percent. More than 85 percent of the 16 million eligible voters cast ballots. Iliescu, the interim president, had been heavily favored to win the election. The charismatic 60-year-old is credited with helping overthrow Ceausescu in December and implementing measures to help the large peasant and working classes. Iliescu and the Front are likely to become the first ex-Communists in Eastern Europe to triumph in the region's current multiparty elections. He told the French TV network TF-1 that he would support an investigation into the election. He said any examination would show the Front had won fairly. Iliescu said he would seek to form a coalition with the defeated opposition parties and would offer his opponents representation in the government based on their electoral showing. ``I would like to know what he's talking about,'' Ratiu told The Associated Press when asked about the possibility of a coalition. ``I haven't had any approach from anybody.'' Campeanu ruled out a coalition with the Front, saying minority views could not possibly be heard in a government overwhelmingly dominated by one party. Ratiu made the fraud charge as early results showed him lagging far behind Iliescu, a former Communist, in the voting for president. ``We will contest the election if this is the sort of result that we get,'' Ratiu told a news conference. ``We will ask for them to be considered null and void. We will ask for new elections.'' A National Liberal Party official also claimed the election was marred by fraud. ``We will demand the outcome of these elections be declared void,'' said Sorin Botez, the party's foreign relations secretary. ``The Front has won the elections but apparently it definitely alienated several million voters,'' the Romania Libera newspaper said in an editorial. It said the country had lost the chance to have ``a genuine political opposition in Parliament.'' In the race for seats in the two-chamber parliament, Electoral Bureau results based on 12.6 million votes gave the Front about 68 percent, the Liberals about 7.3 percent, the Peasants 2.2 percent, the Ecological Movement 2.5 percent. The Hungarian Democratic Union received about 7.3 percent, apparently winning broad allegiance from Romania's 2 million ethnic Hungarians. The other votes went to tiny parties. The official U.S. government observer, Gov. Garrey E. Carruthers of New Mexico, called the poll ``a good election'' and ``a very giant step toward democracy.'' But Austrian parliamentarian Andreas Khol, general secretary of the European Democratic Union, disagreed. ``These were a big step toward free and democratic elections, but they were no free and no democratic elections,'' said Khol, whose conservative political group also is supported by Britain and West Germany's governing parties. The European Parliament observer delegation said the results could be accepted but the contest could not be viewed as a normal election by Western standards. ``If the results are confirmed this doesn't seem to be the result of a pluralist system and this worries me,'' said Adelaide Aglietta, a lawmaker from Italy's Green Party. Various observer groups reported instances of ballots pre-stamped for Iliescu, Front members accompanying elderly voters into the booth, non-registered voters casting ballots and individuals voting several times.

DOC.HEAD: Protests Outside U.S. Consulate, Palestinian Killed in Gaza
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf to insert that Jordanian government official acknowledges only one Palestinian death.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto JRL2
DOC.TEXT: Police battled hundreds of protesters outside the U.S. Consulate today and troops killed a Palestinian in the Gaza Strip amid new rioting over the massacre of seven Arab laborers by an Israeli gunman. In Jordan, Palestinian protests broke out nationwide, and two people were reported killed and 23 injured. Demonstrations protesting the Israeli killing were held in the capital of Amman, the cities of Irbid and Zarqa and the Baqaa refugee camp. A Jordanian government official acknowledged only one death. At least 14 Palestinians were wounded by troops in clashes in the Israeli-occupied Gaza Strip, including a woman five months pregnant who was hit in the stomach with a plastic bullet, Arab hospital officials said. Another Palestinian died of wounds suffered in an earlier clash, bringing to 12 the number of Arabs killed since Sunday's massacre. The number of Palestinians injured by troops since Sunday reached at least 826. Throughout the West Bank and Gaza Strip, Palestinians closed shops and schools and stayed home from jobs in Israel for a third day to protest Sunday's slayings in which an Israeli gunman lined up 50 Arab laborers and opened fire, killing seven. The army extended a curfew on the Gaza Strip, home of the slain workers, and most of the West Bank to quell angry protests. About 1.5 million Palestinians were confined to their homes by the curfews. In Israeli-annexed Arab east Jerusalem, police fired tear gas today to break up a protest by about 200 Palestinians, mostly women, who carried black flags of mourning and chanted pro-PLO slogans as they marched to the U.S. consulate. The protesters were led by three Arab members of Parliament, Greek Catholic Archbishop of Jerusalem Lufti Laham and Sheik Hamad Jamal, a Moslem leader. Arab legislator Abdel Wahab Darousha complained police acted too quickly in firing tear gas. ``It was a brutal action by police. There was no need for it,'' he said. Sheik Jamal defended the violent protests throughout the occupied lands. ``In the name of the Palestinian nation, in the name of the stone throwers ... I say to the occupiers, get out of our land,'' the gray-robed preacher told reporters. In Jerusalem, Arab youths trapped a police jeep in a hail of rocks, but no one was hurt. In the Jewish quarter of the walled Old City, assailants hurled a firebomb into an apartment, gutting one room but causing no injuries. In Gaza City, troops firing on Palestinian stone throwers fatally shot 18-year-old Ahmed Musabeh in the chest, said officials at Shifa Hospital who examined the body. Musabeh's pregnant 23-year-old sister, Samira, was in stable condition after being shot in the stomach, the Shifa officials said. The fetus was unharmed, they said. Earlier today, Naji Moussa Abu Sabala, 22, died at Israel's Tel Hashomer Hospital after being shot twice in the head by troops in clashes late Monday in Gaza's Rafah refugee camp, Arab reporters said. The deaths today brought to 707 the number of Palestinians killed during the 29-month-old uprising. An additional 216 Palestinians have been slain by fellow Arabs, most on suspicion of helping Israel. Forty-three Israelis have also died in the violence. Many of the 800,000 Arabs living inside Israel returned to work and studies today after staging protests and a one-day solidarity strike Monday with their Palestinian brethren in the occupied lands. Israel army radio reported that Arab youths erected stone barricades and burned tires in northern Israeli towns and villages. Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir today rejected claims by Palestinian leaders that his hard-line policies encouraged attacks on Arabs by treating Jewish vigilantes leniently. ``Anyone wishing to see in this mad murder an expression of Israeli government policy and intentions is maliciously and viciously distorting the picture,'' Shamir told reporters after meeting with legislators of his right-wing Likud bloc. Shamir said his government would pursue peace efforts. ``We don't want to live by our sword, but we shall not be quick in throwing it out as long as it allows us to live in security.'' On Monday, deputy U.S. State Department spokesman Richard Boucher criticized Israel's role in the violence, saying that the absence of a peace process was to blame for the killings. He also complained about the number of casualties caused by the Israeli army. Meanwhile, the suspect in Sunday's massacre, 21-year-old Ami Popper, underwent psychiatric evaluation. Authorities have characterized him as ``deranged'' and upset by an unhappy love affair. The army said Popper had been dishonorably discharged from the military after completing 17 months of the mandatory three-year active duty service. He served four months in military lockups for disciplinary violations and being absent without leave.

DOC.HEAD: Safety Board Wants All Children Secured On Airliners
DOC.TEXT: The National Transportation Safety Board recommended Tuesday that children now flying free in parents' arms be required to sit in separate safety seats on airliners. ``All objects must be secured during takeoff and landing, including coffee pots and luggage,'' said board chairman James Kolstad. ``And yet infants, our precious children, are not.'' The proposal, approved 4-0 by the NTSB, does not deal with who will provide the seats or whether children will pay fares. But if such a regulation takes effect, airlines are expected to require that parents generally lug along an infant seat _ like the ones required in cars _ and buy a ticket if they want to be guaranteed passage for the child. When planes aren't full, the airlines are expected to continue to allow infants to fly at no charge. The recommendation now goes to the Federal Aviation Administration which has resisted a mandatory rule on the grounds that the 5,000 to 10,000 youngsters under 2 years old who fly in adults' laps each day are not at great risk. The FAA is not required to follow NTSB recommendations and sometimes doesn't. Under the NTSB proposal, parents who arrive at the gate of a fully booked flight with an unticketed baby would not be allowed to take the child aboard. They also could be denied passage with any small child, with or without ticket, if they are not carrying an approved car seat. The FAA has said it will consider mandatory restraints but has proposed only to require that airlines allow seats on board if passengers chose to use them _ a practice now followed by most airlines. The airline industry, flight attendants union, consumer safety groups and some members of Congress all have called for mandatory restraints. Some travel agents are among opponents of the measure who say it would add to the cost of flying for young families and possibly force them to travel by automobile on shorter routes. They say automobile travel poses greater risks per mile than flying. A Harvard Medical School statistical study in the early 1980s theorized that three infants might be saved over five years if all children used safety seats on airliners. But two recent crashes in which unrestrained infants were killed have led to more support for mandatory restraints. Two of the five unsecured children aboard United Flight 232 that crashed in Iowa last July died, and at least one unseated child was killed aboard the Avianca airliner that crashed in New York in January. The NTSB proposal would prevent children under 40 inches or 40 pounds from flying without car seats approved for airliner use. The safety board proposal, in keying on size and weight of the child rather than age, also could lead to required seats for small children older than 2 who now are allowed to use ordinary seat belts, said board senior investigator Nora Marshall. The board also called for a study to develop a more effective restraint for children just over 40 pounds or 40 inches tall who may not be fully protected by ordinary seat belts. ``It seems time to provide protection for those children who up until now have been unprotected,'' said Kolstad after the board vote. Asked if the possible increased cost for travelers could be justified, Kolstad said, ``I don't think the cost of protecting an infant's life is too much to ask.'' He said the practice of allowing infants to fly in parents' laps is ``a hole in the law ... an oversight we think needs to be corrected.''

DOC.HEAD: Two Killed in Nationwide Protests Over Israeli Killings
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 2 grafs to UPDATE with government acknowledging one death. Pickup 2nd pvs, `At least...' SUBS 5th pvs, `An official...' to elaborate.
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Israel, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Police trying to disperse demonstrations by tens of thousands of Palestinians today killed a 14-year-old boy in a northern city, witnesses said. A hospital said a man was killed at another rally. Government officials acknowledged only one death. At least 23 protesters were reported wounded in the nationwide demonstrations that protested the killing of seven Palestinian laborers Sunday by an Israeli gunman near Tel Aviv. In the Baqaa refugee camp northwest of Amman, about 7,000 Palestinians clashed with riot police, burned tires and blocked highways following a police crackdown on protesters the night before. One resident said at least 13 people were wounded and that at least eight armored vehicles entered the camp, firing live ammunition in the air in an attempt to disperse demonstrators. An official at Jordan University Hospital near Amman said Majed Hubeid, 19, died of gunshot wounds minutes after he was brought to the hospital from Baqaa. Relatives also reported he died, but the Interior Ministry did not acknowledge the death. Security officials in Irbid, 45 miles north of Amman, said police attempted to disperse 15,000 demonstrators who were trying to reach nearby Yarmouk University. Residents reached by telephone, speaking on condition of anonymity, said a 14-year-old boy was shot and killed by police. It was not immediately clear whether the boy was Palestinian. The demonstrators, mainly youths, marched through the city and tossed firebombs at police, who in turn fired back with live ammunition, witnesses said. The security officials, who cannot be named under police rules, said at least 10 people were injured and one said he saw several with ``blood on their bodies or their faces.'' Police sealed off all roads leading to Zarqa, 18 miles north of Amman, Zarqa, where at least 10,000 Palestinians staged protests. The six major Palestinian refugee camps around the country staged a day of mourning and all businesses and shops were closed in support of a Sunday call by the underground leadership of the Palestinian uprising in the Israeli-occupied territories. In Amman, at least 20,000 Jordanian students, including Islamic fundamentalists, demonstrated on the Jordan University campus protesting Israeli killings of Palestinians. Roughly half of Jordan's 3.1 million people come from Palestinian families who fled or were driven out of the homeland during the 1948 and 1967 Arab-Israeli wars. Hospital officials in Amman said four French tourists wounded in an attack by a Palestinian Monday were recovering and were likely to be discharged within days. The Palestinian boarded a tour bus with a dagger and pistol and shot or stabbed 10 people, police said. They said he was out to avenge the deaths of the seven Palestinians in Israel, but did not elaborate.

DOC.HEAD: COLA For Retirees a Hot Topic at UAW Meeting
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New throughout to UPDATE with delegates turning away initial effort to index retiree benefits to inflation. A version moved on financial wires.
DOC.TEXT: Members of the United Auto Workers won't ratify new contracts this fall unless they include cost-of-living protection for retirees' benefits, a local union leader warns. But about 2,000 delegates attending a three-day UAW bargaining convention today rejected an effort this morning to call for such inflation adjustments in a resolution. A procedural motion to introduce the resolution fell short of the needed 329 votes on a show of hands. Alex Wassell of Local 1776 in Willow Run, Mich., said he was disappointed that his move didn't work. He said he didn't believe UAW President Owen Bieber's statement that the issue would be carried to bargaining tables this summer anyway. In his opening speech Monday, Bieber outlined a five-point bargaining plan for contracts to be negotiated this summer with General Motors Corp., Ford Motor Co. and Chrysler Corp. It called for inflation protection for hundreds of thousands of retirees, but Bieber declined to say exactly how retiree benefits should be protected. He said: ``I can tell you absolutely that we will achieve the goals we all share of improving current benefit levels and ensuring that those gains are protected against inflation in future years.'' For the first time in 11 years, UAW contracts with the Big Three expire at the same moment _ midnight, Sept. 14. Contract talks begin after Independence Day. In the past, company executives and union officials have said cost-of-living adjustments, or COLAs, could be extremely expensive and could trigger benefit cuts for active workers. COLA backers say lump-sum payments have been eaten up by inflation. Jerry Melillo, a local president at Ford's Cleveland engine plant, warned, ``We have to come back with COLA in '90 to get ratification of the agreements.'' Inflation protection for retirees is attracting more attention in the union for several reasons. The average age of UAW members at the Big Three automakers is about 45, and many workers are approaching retirement. Also, there are nearly as many retirees as active workers. The UAW contracts with the Big Three cover about 500,000 workers. Bieber ticked off a list of priorities. Topping the list, as expected, is job and income security, followed by wage and benefit increases, maintenance of health care benefits, help for retirees and more responsible management.

DOC.HEAD: Army Used Secret, Barge-Based Chopper Unit
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf to CORRECT to Division sted Corps.
DOC.TEXT: The Army used an awards ceremony at Fort Bragg to take the wraps off a secret, barge-based helicopter unit that has been operating in the Persian Gulf for 2{ years. The unit, Task Force 118, will soon become part of the 82nd Airborne Division, said Lt. Col. Ed Hughes, the unit's commander. ``We're glad we can talk about it now,'' Hughes said. Twenty-five members were honored Monday for their roles in creating the unit, developing its equipment and for action in the Persian Gulf against Iranian gunboats. Chief Warrant Officer Gregory Hunter Odum was responsible for creating or finding much of the sophisticated equipment used by the unit in its secret missions, Hughes said. Odum said most of the equipment was modified from what is normally used by the military, although some was bought commercially. The commercial equipment included an underwater breathing bottle and 30-foot caving ladders, light aluminum roll-up wire ladders that can be suspended below a helocpter and used for picking up downed crews. ``The unit uses heavily modified OH-58D helicopters _ the most sophisticated and advanced helicopter in the Army today,'' Odum said. Originally designed as a light, unarmed scout helicopter, the OH-58 was upgraded in the mid-1980s with improved night observation equipment that gives the helicopter a distinctive ball on top of the rotor. The armed version of the helicopter was developed in less than four months when the Navy asked for help escorting tankers in the Persian Gulf. The Navy's shipboard helicopters do not have comparable night-fighting equipment. In addition to 2.75-inch rockets, the armed OH-58D can carry pods on pylons on each side the helicopter that are armed with Hellfire air-to-surface missiles, Stinger anti-aircraft missiles or .50-caliber machine guns, Odum said. The two-man flight crews fly almost exclusively at night with night-vision equipment and mostly over water _ the most difficult conditions to fly with night-vision equipment. ``We had to keep our guys rotated out regularly to reduce the stress,'' Odum said.

DOC.HEAD: Yemen at a Glance
With AM-Yemen
DOC.TEXT: Here are some facts and figures on the Republic of Yemen, which was created Tuesday by the merger of North Yemen and South Yemen:

THE LAND _ Yemen spans 203,645 square miles on the southwestern edge of the Arabian Peninsula and has borders with Saudi Arabia and Oman. The country controls the Bab al-Mandab strait, the strategic gateway to the Red Sea. The north is mainly mountainous, with a narow coastal strip on the Red Sea. The south has a sandy coastline along the Gulf of Aden backed by barren mountains.

THE PEOPLE _ Yemen has 11 million people. They are mainly tribal, and the main religion is Sunni Islam. A few hundred Jews live in the north, and there are small communities of Christians and Hindus in the south.

THE ECONOMY _ Yemen is among the poorest nations in the world, but newly discovered oil reserves could change that. Unofficial estimates say the reserves could amount to as much as 2 billion barrels. The south depended heavily on aid from the Soviet bloc, but the collapse of communism in eastern Europe apparently prompted the south to drop its Marxist policies and agreed to a merger. The major activities in the south are the refinery of Aden, the city's port and fishing. Money from millions of Yemenis working outside their country, mainly in the oil-rich gulf, and from foreign aid helped prop up the economy of the conservative pro-Western north for years. Farming is the main activity in the region, and crops include wheat, sorghum, coffee, tobacco and cotton.

HISTORY _ By merging, the north and south regained their former status as part of ancient Arabia Felix and the kingdom of Sheba that lasted for 800 years until the 2nd century B.C. For the next 800 years it was ruled by the Himyarites, one of the earliest Arab tribes, then by Ethiopians and Persians until Islam arrived in the 7th century. In 1517 South Yemen became part of the Ottoman Empire. Britain seized Aden in 1839 and the surrounding territory later became a British protectorate. Aden won independence in 1967 after a terrorist campaign, and South Yemen became the Arab world's only self-proclaimed Marxist state. The northern country, the Yemen Arab Republic, was established in 1962 after an Egyptian-backed revolution ousted the Saudi Arabian-backed imam.

DOC.HEAD: Lawyer Plans To Ask Judge To Drop Charges
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with court hearing.
DOC.TEXT: Prosecutors asked a judge today to change the wording of an indictment against an art gallery displaying Robert Mapplethorpe photographs so it would conform to obscenity standards set by the U.S. Supreme Court. Hamilton County Municipal Judge David Albanese said he would consider the request and would see the exhibit before it closes Saturday at the Contemporary Arts Center. Frank H. Prouty Jr., the senior assistant city prosecutor, said the city wants the indictment to specify that photographs in the exhibit include ``a lewd, graphic exhibition of the genitals.'' That wording would make the indictment conform to a Supreme Court decision establishing criteria for obscenity. The 175-photo exhibition includes five photos of sex acts and two photos of nude children. The indictment, issued on April 7, refers to the two children's genitals only as being exposed. H. Louis Sirkin, the art gallery's lawyer, said he will oppose the city's request because the judge should not have the power to alter a grand jury's indictment. Sirkin has asked the judge to dismiss the charges, arguing that Mapplethorpe's photographs are legitimate works of art. He also contends that authorities unfairly singled out the gallery and its director for prosecution. The gallery and director Dennis Barrie are charged with pandering obscenity and using children in material involving nudity, both misdemeanors. If convicted, both face $6,000 in fines, and Barrie faces six months in jail. More than 67,000 people have seen the exhibit since it opened April 6 with a showing to members only. It opened to the public the next day, when the indictment was returned. Sirkin raised his arguments against the charges in motions filed Friday. He called Ohio's obscenity statute vague, and said grand jurors may not have been told that the U.S. Supreme Court has ruled that pictures found to have artistic value can't be ruled obscene. ``For any one of the issues raised in the motions, I think the case should be dismissed,'' Sirkin said. ``I think the most important are the selective prosecution and the motion to dismiss based on lack of prior judicial determination of probable cause.'' Sirkin's motion notes that prosecutors took no action against Cincinnati's Taft Museum for earlier displaying some of the pictures mentioned in the indictment. The photographs also are available in books at the Hamilton County library and at the University of Cincinnati, the motion says. It also notes that the Tyler-Davidson Fountain, a downtown landmark, includes a statue of a nude boy.

DOC.HEAD: Sitting Bull's Pouch Returning To Montana
DOC.TEXT: Sitting Bull's buckskin tobacco pouch is being sent to Montana, the Sioux chief's home. Jackson resident George Turpin, who inherited the pouch from family members who lived in Montana in the late 19th century, has agreed to donate it to the Montana State Historical Society Museum in Helena. The 80-year-old man said he's happy to get the bag off his hands. ``I'm ready to stop thinking about Sitting Bull. I've started dreaming about that Indian,'' he said Tuesday. The pouch, decorated with tiny, colorful beads, was given by Sitting Bull to Molly Bailey, the wife of Turpin's great-great-uncle, Will Bailey. Sitting Bull was the victor of the Battle of the Little Bighorn in 1876. Museum curator Kirby Lambert said the pouch will be added to the Native American section of its permanent ``Montana Homeland'' collection.

DOC.HEAD: With AM-Clean Fuel
Congress Wrestles With Issue of Car Fuels
DOC.TEXT: Congress is going after the gasoline in your car's fuel tank as lawmakers try to clean up the nation's smog-clogged air. What the fuel of the future will be is unclear, but one thing seems certain: Something other than conventional gasoline will run the car of the late '90s. Tougher auto pollution controls that will be included in clear air legislation now before Congress for the first time not only requires new control technology on automobiles, but demands that oil companies change the chemistry of their gasoline so the fuel burns cleaner. Smog-causing pollutants will be reduced, as will toxic emissions. The bills also are being crafted to open the way for an array of gasoline alternatives, including alcohol fuel blends such as methanol and ethanol and in some cases pure methanol, compressed natural gas or propane. Proponents of the various fuels are lobbying intensely for provisions that might give them an edge. The oil industry has spent $1 million in recent months for a thus-far unsuccessful effort to thwart provisions that could require ethanol blended gasoline in some of the largest cities that account for more than a fifth of the nation's gasoline market. The legislation already approved by the Senate and a similar version coming to a vote this week in the House will require that gasoline meet tougher emission standards. The petroleum industry hopes to meet those requirements by reworking the gasoline's chemistry so that aromatics, the chemicals that boost octane, are replaced by cleaner additives. Some oil companies, including ARCO and Shell, already have begun selling reformulated gasoline in some limited markets. Some members of Congress say that doesn't go far enough. A compromise agreement announced in the House this week requires even cleaner fuels to be sold in areas with serious smog problems. The provisions, similar to one in the Senate bill, require reformulated gasoline to have a certain oxygen content _ likely to be achieved by adding ethanol _ if it is sold in nine cities with the greatest smog problems and in 44 cities with excessive levels of carbon monoxide during some months of the year. ``It will not ony clean up the nation's air but give credibility to the growing ethanol industry,'' said Rep. Bill Richardson, D-N.M., sponsor of the amendment. Some estimates say the provisions could more than double the demand for ethanol, which is made from grain. The oil industry argues the government should not impose a recipe for motor fuels and has vigorously fought not only efforts to require the use of ethanol, but also methanol, another alternative fuel derived from natural gas. Automakers say they are developing cars that run on methanol blends, a mixture of as much as 85 percent methanol and 15 percent gasoline. However, both the auto and oil industries are opposed to pushing too quickly the sale of vehicles that burn only fuels other than gasoline. The House this week will consider an amendment to the clean air bill by Rep. Henry Waxman, D-Calif., that would require automakers by 1997 to build 1 million cars a year powered by a fuel other than gasoline and sell them in the nine cities with the worst smog problems. Those cities are Los Angeles, Chicago, Houston, San Diego, Philadelphia, Baltimore, New York City, Hartford, Conn., and Milwaukee. President Bush made a similar suggestion a year ago, but the White House backed away from the production mandate under intense pressure from the auto industry. Attempts to impose such a mandate failed in the Senate, but both environmentalists and auto lobbyists say the House vote could be close. The aim is to cut total smog-causing emissions from those cars by 75 percent, a requirement the auto industry says can only be achieved by making cars that run either entirely on methanol or on compressed natural gas. The automakers have vigorously fought a production requirement for alternative fuel cars, fearful that consumers may not buy them because of concern about reliability and the availability of fuels. ``We're talking about 30 or 40 percent of the vehicles sold (in the nine cities). ... It's a preposterous notion,'' said Robert Liberatore, a lobbyist for the Chrysler Corp. Oil companies fear losing market share in a $100 billion annual gasoline business to the natural gas industry if the Congress requires production of cars that can't meet emission standards by burning even reformulated gasoline.

DOC.HEAD: House Approves Disability Legislation
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Combines pvs.
DOC.TEXT: The House voted 403-20 today for legislation prohibiting discrimination against disabled Americans. The Americans with Disabilities Act goes to House and Senate negotiators after the Memorial Day recess to work out the one major difference in the two versions. The difference is a House amendment, passed 199-187 last week, to let employers re-assign AIDS-infected workers to keep them from handling food. Opponents say the amendment would allow discrimination against one group of people despite overwhelming medical evidence that AIDS is not transmitted through such casual contact. President Bush has urged speedy passage of the bill, aimed at doing for disabled Americans what the Civil Rights Act of 1964 set out to do for blacks and other minorities: guarantee access to jobs, businesses, services, transportation and telecommunications. Supporters say at least one American in six _ 43 million _ is disabled. Prior to passage, the House 227-192 to defeat an amendment limiting the remedies disabled workers could seek from employers who willfully discriminate. The White House supported that amendment. Among key provisions of the bill: _Discrimination in hiring and on the job would be prohibited. The requirement would be phased in over two to four years, depending on the size of the company. Companies with fewer than 15 employees would be exempt. _Hotels, restaurants, shopping malls, drug stores, and business and professional offices, along with any other ``public accommodation,'' would have to make themselves accessible to disabled people. Accessibility includes structural adjustments, such as wheelchair ramps and widened doors, and services. _Transportation, public and private, would have to be made accessible. Fixed-route bus systems would have to be accessible for people with wheelchairs. Special facilities would be available for people with other disabilities who cannot use regular transit. Amtrak, Greyhound, and commuter rail systems are covered. Timetables for implementation vary according to system. _ People with speech and hearing impairments would have access to telephone service by means of relay services. These services would have to be provided by phone companies within three years.

DOC.HEAD: Firefighters Latest Group to Go on Strike
DOC.TEXT: Firefighters went on strike Tuesday afternoon for higher wages, briefly stopping cars and taxis trying to enter the city, witnesses said. The walkout followed similar strikes in the past week by soldiers and police, who returned to work only after being promised better pay. Salaries for state employees have been frozen for eight years as President Felix Houphouet-Boigny's government struggles to pay bills. In March, Houphouet-Boigny, Africa's longest-serving president, tried to impose wage cuts and new taxes. Violent protests forced the withdrawal of the measures, and the president had to give in to demands to permit opposition parties. Last week, mutinous soldiers occupied the nation's international airport for eight hours to demand better pay. Police demonstrated Monday, also demanding improved pay and working conditions. Other workers, including bus drivers and shipyard employees, have also gone on strike.

DOC.HEAD: Thompson Fight Against Sex, Drug, Explosives Charges Hinges on Search
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 12 grafs to UPDATE with morning testimony. Picks up 9th graf pvs, `Thompson claims...
DOC.TEXT: A woman who accused journalist Hunter S. Thompson of sexual assault leveled allegations of drug abuse against the writer during a court hearing today. The testimony from Gail Palmer-Slater, 35, came during a pretrial hearing for Thompson, who faces five felonies and three misdeamor charges. Ms. Palmer-Slater, of Port Huron, Mich., testified that she saw Thompson plunge his nose into a pile of white powder at his secluded mountain home and later boast of a ready supply of cocaine. She testified Thompson never offered her drugs and admitted under cross-examination that she had no proof the white powder actually was cocaine. Thompson was fidgety during the morning testimony and at times leaned over to one of his attorneys and whispered loudly, ``Bull, that's bull.'' Thompson, 53, was charged after the alleged sexual attack in February prompted a two-day search of his home that turned up narcotics and dynamite. His fight against the charges was expected to hinge on questions about the validity of the the extensive search. The writer whose chronicle of the Hell's Angels, accounts of political campaigns and shark hunts in Hawaii vaulted him to literary stardom in the 1960s and 1970s, pleaded innocent to the three misdemeanor charges April 9. At the hearing, Pitkin County District Judge Charles Buss was to evaluate evidence behind the five felony charges, including three drug possession counts, one charge of using cocaine and one charge of possessing explosives. Thompson's defense was expected to question the validity of the extensive search. The misdemeanors include third-degree sexual assault, third-degree simple assault, and possession of marijuana. The charges stem from a complaint by Ms. Palmer-Slater, a businesswoman and former X-rated movie actress, who claimed Thompson threw a drink at her, twisted her breast and shoved her during a visit to his home on Feb. 21. She contended that he became angry when she refused to conduct a business discussion in his hot tub. Thompson claims he never assaulted the woman. He told reporters the woman was drunk and allegedly was pressuring him to have sex with her when he pushed her away. Searches Feb. 26 and Feb. 27 resulted from her complaint. Police say they found a small amount of cocaine, more than an ounce of marijuana, 39 LSD tablets, the tranquilizer diazepam, four sticks of dynamite and several blasting caps. Thompson, who lives in nearby Woody Creek, could receive a maximum of 16 years if convicted of all eight charges, Deputy District Attorney Charles McCrory has said. The writer is free on $2,000 bond. ``I stand for everything they don't like,'' Thompson said as he left the courthouse April 9. ``It's a witch hunt.'' Supporters who created the Hunter S. Thompson Legal Defense Fund bought a full-page advertisement the same day in the Aspen Times Daily that reads: ``Beware. Today: the Doctor. Tomorrow: You.'' Thompson, whose lifestyle and exploits inspired the character Duke in the ``Doonesbury'' comic strip, ran unsuccessfully for Pitkin County sheriff in 1970. His news columns, magazine articles and books are written in a style dubbed ``gonzo journalism,'' because they include seemingly exaggerated accounts of his own rowdy behavior brought on by drug and alcohol abuse.

DOC.HEAD: Kashmiris Bury Senior Islamic Clergyman
DOC.TEXT: About 300,000 wailing mourners Tuesday buried Kashmir's senior Islamic cleric, whose assassination prompted some of the worst violence in the 40-year-old Moslem secessionist movement. Maulvi Mohammad Farooq, the most influential opponent to Indian rule of the mostly Moslem state, was slain Monday by three unidentified gunmen in the Kashmiri capital, Srinagar. A few hours later, security forces fired on mourners who defied a curfew to carry Farooq's body from the hospital. The gunfire killed 58 people and wounded 300. Gunbattles between security forces and militants, sniper fire and bomb blasts have become a way of life in Kashmir since India launched a crackdown on Moslem secessionists Jan. 20. About 460 psince then, including 49 people shot by security forces during eople have died a March 1 pro-independence march. All security forces were withdrawn along the route of the funeral procession, apparently to avoid a recurrence of Monday's violence. Massive crowds gathered at Islamia college, where Farooq's body was kept overnight. More joined en route and nearly one-third of Srinagar's population reached the Martyrs Cemetery on the city's outskirts. Farooq, 45, suffered 15 bullet wounds in the assassination. DOC.HEAD: Bush's Expected Renewal of China Benefits Draws Democratic Rebuke
DOC.TEXT: President Bush's expected call for renewal of major trade benefits for China brought sharp rebukes Tuesday from lawmakers objecting to China's human-rights policies. Republican leaders braced for a major new China-policy battle after Bush told them he planned to act within the next day or two. ``I'm not sure I'd like to have that vote come up this afternoon,'' House Minority Leader Bob Michel, R-Ill., said he told the president at a morning White House meeting. Bush narrowly won a bruising veto fight with Congress last winter over a bill extending visas for Chinese students. Michel, who supports extension of the most-favored-nation trade benefits, said he believed the administration could overcome any attempt by Congress to block such a move, since that would take two-thirds majorities of both the House and Senate. But, he added, ``We haven't really taken a good temperature of the House, yet, on that.'' Senior administration officials, who spoke on the condition of anonymity, said Bush would propose a one-year extension of the most-favored-nation preferential tariff treatment for Beijing within the next few days. The declaration would contain ``some conditions'' spellins Republic will ever be satisfied by anything he does.'' Not all Republicans supported Bush's apparent decision to renew trade benefits. Rep. Mickey Edwards, R-Okla., chairman of the Republican Policy Committee and one of the GOP members who met with Bush Tuesday, said he's opposed to extension of most-favored-nation status for China. ``I know the president thinks he has good reason ... but I'm bothered by the idea of granting special treatment'' to China, he said. Edwards said China has ``cracked down more, not less'' on human rights since Tiananmen Square. Administration officials and GOP leaders said that they did not think that a battle over the most-favored-nation issue would be as emotional as last winter's fight _ ultimately won by Bush _ over Chinese students. By a single vote, the Senate sustained Bush's veto of a bill to extend the visas of Chinese students in the United States. Bush argued that he was offering the Chinese students the same safe haven through administrative actions. On Tuesday, the Independent Federation of Chinese Students and Scholars asked Bush to suspend China's most-favored-nation status to demonstrate U.S. ``commitment to democracy and human rights in China.'' A letter signed by three students in the group said, ``We hope you will agree with us that the United States cannot continue `business as usual' relationships with the current regime.'' The federation says it represents some 40,000 students at more than 200 universities in the United States.

DOC.HEAD: Even If Fleet Cut, Shipbuilding Budget May Be Stable
DOC.TEXT: The Navy's shipbuilding budget would have to remain at its current level of about $11 billion annually for the service to maintain a pared-down fleet of 488 ships, congressional analysts said Tuesday. Members of the Congressional Budget Office told a Senate panel that the Navy's publicly stated goal for 1990 is 547 ships, including 14 aircraft carriers, four battleships and 34 ballistic missile submarines. But recent published reports said civilian and military leaders drafted spending plans that suggest 488 ships, including 12 aircraft carriers. Such a fleet ``would require a shipbuilding budget that, on average, stays constant at today's level in real terms,'' Robert Hale told the Senate Armed Services subcommittee on projection forces and regional defense. The shipbuilding budget for 1990 totals $11.4 billion, the CBO said. The Navy's proposed cut in its fleet comes in response to Defense Secretary Dick Cheney's orders to the service chiefs to cut spending by 2 percent below the rate of inflation in each year from 1992 to 1997. Reductions in the fleet creates a need for the Navy to reconsider its missions, the CBO said. ``If it has fewer ships, the Navy could reduce capability to perform each of its missions proportionately,'' Hale said. ``That might mean proportional reductions in submarines that provide strategic deterrence, ships that provide power projection by attacking targets on land and ships that provide sea control.'' Questioned by lawmakers about the Navy's priorities, Gerald Cann, an assistant secretary of the Navy, declined to provide specifics but noted Cheney's current review of the planned purchase of the Seawolf SSN-21 submarine and the DDG-51 guided-missile destroyer. Cann also said the negotiations on the services' spending plans, submitted to Cheney on May 1, will ``address the character and size of the Navy.'' ``When all is said and done, we are still a maritime nation,'' Cann said.

DOC.HEAD: Relocating an Embassy Proves Difficult for U.S. in Kuwait
DOC.TEXT: The United States wants a new, attack-proof embassy compound in Kuwait, but acquiring one is turning out to be a diplomatic headache. The present compound, bounded by a hotel and the waters of the Persian Gulf, has been deemed a security risk. Also, the landlord does not want to renew the lease. But replacing it could cost $32 million for the land alone _ a price tag that is raising eyebrows in Washington. Relocation efforts are further complicated by Kuwait's ban on real estate purchases by foreigners. The compound, which contains the ambassador's residence and the embassy, was fortified after Shiite Moslem terrorists rammed a bomb-laden truck into its gates in December l983. Despite safeguards including concrete blockades and a high barbed-wire fence that is electrified at some points, security is ``not exactly airtight,'' said an Arab diplomat, speaking on condition of anonymity. The site was rented in the early 1950s from a landlord who is a ruling emir of one of the gulf states, according to sources. Now a boom has driven the land's value up to an estimated $13 million, and the landlord has given notice that the lease will not be renewed when it expires in 1995. Some lawmakers say even if the lease weren't coming up, security concerns alone would justify a new mission. Rep. Mervyn Dymally, D-Calif., chairman of the House Foreign Affairs subcommittee on international operations, recently traveled to Kuwait. He told a congressional panel the compound is a ``ripe target for terrorist activities'' and that he would have had a clear shot at the No. 2 embassy official from his hotel room. Kuwait is significant to the United States on several counts, and the embassy's job reflects that. Its staff of 80 people _ about half of them military _ is the second-largest U.S. diplomatic mission in the Persian Gulf region, after Riyadh, Saudi Arabia. Kuwait is involved in an issue of key importance to the United States, that of Western hostages in Lebanon. The release of 15 pro-Iranian convicts held in Kuwaiti jails is one of the pro-Iranian kidnappers' demands. The 15 were jailed for their role in bombings of the U.S. and French embassies, along with the international airport and other public utilities in Kuwait, in 1983. In addition, five Kuwaiti oil tankers fly the American flag, a protection extended to 11 of Kuwait's 22 U.S.-registered tankers during the Iran-Iraq war, when attacks on gulf shipping were made by both sides. Kuwait is also a major oil supplier, and an importer of U.S.-build warplanes and military hardware. Whenever possible, the State Department prefers to own rather than rent embassy compounds. But technically, no foreigners are allowed to buy real estate in Kuwait, under laws that took effect after independence in 1961. Diplomats reached by telephone in Kuwait said it was not clear if the government would bend the rules and grant the Americans dispensation to buy land. Even if they do, the State Department says land costs in Kuwait are among the world's highest, and the necessary 14 acres would run about $32 million. Despite the obstacles, negotiations are apparently still in progress. State Department lawyers and other experts have been quietly traveling to Kuwait to check out prospective property and work on other details. Through it all, the embassy is maintaining a diplomatic silence. Embassy public affairs officer Alberto Fernandez declined to make any statement. ``We're not allowed to comment on these matters,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Minorities Underrepresented in Peace Corps, Congress Told
DOC.TEXT: The Peace Corps, nearly 30 years after its founding by President John F. Kennedy, suffers from lingering perceptions it is a white middle-class institution, Congress was told Tuesday. Only about 7 percent of the agency's roughly 6,300 volunteers are minorities, a congressional investigative agency found. And through 1988, no minorities held any of the top 20 management jobs at the agency. ``Efforts to improve the Peace Corps' minority profile in the past have been short-lived and costly,'' the General Accounting Office said. It called for a long-term strategy to correct the problem. The underrepresentation of minorities in the Peace Corps has made it difficult for the agency to teach foreign peoples about the racially diverse American culture, the study said. Congressional researchers acknowledged, however, that the Peace Corps ``has historically experienced great difficulty attracting sufficient number of minorities to serve as volunteers.'' Part of the problem stems from the lower economic status of blacks and other minorities, the study said, who ``believe that they cannot afford to volunteer two years of their lives to Peace Corps service.'' But it said that minorities also ``tend to see the Peace Corps as a white middle-class organization.'' Rep. John Conyers, D-Mich., chairman of a House Government Operations subcommittee examining the Peace Corps program, said the agency ``must work toward better portraying the United States to the people of the beneficiary countries by providing opportunities to ethnic and racial groups which would represent the amalgamation of our many rich cultures.'' The GAO report, released as the House panel held a public hearing, also said the agency was failing to meet a 1985 congressional mandate to build its volunteer force to 10,000. During its heyday, the Peace Corps in the mid-1960s had a volunteer force as high as 16,000 and a $114 million annual budget, but the agency was given less money and saw its volunteer force shrink to 5,000 at the start of the 1980s. By this fall, the GAO report said, the agency expects to have 6,700 volunteers in 76 countries. Several lawmakers noted that President Bush sought a 9 percent increase in the agency's fiscal 1991 budget. But they said more will be needed if the Peace Corps is to move people swiftly into Eastern Europe while continuing a heavy presence in Third World nations. ``If we expect the Peace Corps to meet the challenges and increasing responsibilities ahead, then we need to ensure that the appropriate resources are available for the agency to realize its goals,'' said Conyers. Sen. Christopher Dodd, D-Conn., a former Peace Corps volunteer who appeared as a witness before the subcommittee, said the agency has received requests for volunteers from Hungary, Poland, Czechoslovakia, Romania and East Germany. ``The Peace Corps needs the resources to respond to these requests from Eastern Europe,'' he said, ``but it cannot rob other parts of the world to accommodate an area of the world to which the Peace Corps has not previously been invited.''

DOC.HEAD: Spectators Weep at Tomb of Unknown Pets
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Pets cq 2nd graf
DOC.TEXT: Mary Nelson wept Tuesday at the grave of her best friend Casey, near the tombs of Miss Kitty, Snowball and nearly 20,000 other dear departed pets. Nelson and other animal lovers gathered at the Bonheur Memorial Park cemetery for the unveiling of the Tomb of the Unknown Pets, honoring the thousands of stray or abused pets that die every year. The tomb is marked by a fountain and a bronze plaque that reads: ``The Unknown Pets. For the Millions of Lost and Abandoned Pets A Final Resting Place.'' Jerry Rosenbaum, Bonheur's operator and caretaker, devised the idea of the tomb and planned the unveiling to coincide with Be Kind To Animals Month. Pets of all sorts have been buried in the 12-acre cemetery, including goldfish, police dogs, horses and Mary Ann, an elephant given to the city of Baltimore in 1925. The grounds are dotted with eternal flames lit in remembrance, as well as flowers, squeaky toys and statues of dogs and cats. At the unveiling of the tomb for the unknown, spectators also remembered their own. ``He was born in my hands and he died in my hands. He was truly my best friend,'' a tearful Nelson said of Casey, a champion boxer, who was buried in August under a rose-colored marble headstone. Joyce Williams, whose mutt Dixie was buried at Bonheur just a few weeks ago, took the day off from work to pay her respects. ``Our babies were all grown up. We didn't have anymore little children. He was our baby,'' Williams said, wiping away tears. Bonheur cemetery, 10 miles southeast of Baltimore, was named for Rosa Bonheur, a 19th century artist who painted and sculpted animals. Inscriptions on the gravestones remember well-loved pets with words like, ``Our precious baby'' and ``A gift from God. We will always miss you.'' ``Pets are strictly buried for love,'' said Rosenbaum, who took over the cemetery's lease six years ago and runs it with his wife, Winnette. ``The pets are here for the people to be happy, to live their memories.'' ``Pets give you an unconditional love, not because of what you have, but because you are you,'' he said. ``This is a quiet place where they can forget about their work and their problems and remember their pets.'' Human interments were first allowed at Bonheur in 1977, and about 100 plots have been reserved by people who want to rest close to their pets, Rosenbaum said. Elizabeth Kirk, president of the local chapter of the Animal Welfare League, has buried 18 of her pets at Bonheur, and reserved a place for herself. ``People just don't seem to realize that animals and children are alike,'' said Kirk, who brought along two dogs she adopted. ``They trust in the larger human to take care of them and not abuse them.''

DOC.HEAD: China Buys More Subsidized Wheat
With AM-Bush-China, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: China has bought an additional 399,350 metric tons of U.S. wheat under a price subsidy program, the Agriculture Department said Tuesday. Christopher E. Goldthwaite, acting general sales manager for the department's Foreign Agricultural Service, said seven private exporting companies made the deals under the department's Export Enhancement Program, or EEP. Delivery of the wheat is scheduled for July and August, he said. The sales were part of 2 million tons authorized China under EEP on May 2. Previous allocations had been exhausted except for 5,050 tons. A metric ton is about 2,205 pounds and is equal to 36.7 bushels of wheat. The latest sales would be about 14.7 million bushels. At current prices estimated by USDA at around $3.36 per bushel, the wheat would have a farm value of around $49 million. Under EEP arrangements, private exporters can sell U.S. commodities at reduced prices to meet foreign competition in selected overseas markets and then collect free government surpluses of grain or other commodities as bonuses, or subsidies. Goldthwaite said the latest subsidies averaged $11.20 per ton, or about 31 cents per bushel. The subsidized sales were handled by Louis Dreyfus Corp., 155,000 tons; Alfred C. Toepfer International Inc., 50,000; Tradigrain Inc., 49,750; J. Aron and Co., 45,000; Continental Grain Co., 39,600; Bunge Corp., 30,000; and Ferruzzi U.S.A. Inc., 30,000. With the latest sales, China has bought about 1.4 million tons of U.S. wheat for delivery in the 1990-91 wheat marketing year that will begin June 1, compared with 5.7 million tons in 1989-90.

DOC.HEAD: Union Makes Return-to-Work Offer
DOC.TEXT: Striking Greyhound drivers offered to return to work Tuesday in a legal maneuver that could make the company liable for $10 million a month in back pay. Greyhound called the offer ``part of the game'' in the 3-month-old strike and said it did not expect to immediately rehire striking union drivers. The union's return-to-work offer stems from a ruling last week by the chief investigator for the National Labor Relations Board, who authorized the filing of unfair labor practice charges against Greyhound. If upheld, the charges would mean that Greyhound would have to give union members back then workers with infectious diseases so they wouldn't be allowed to handled food. Opponents said the amendment was a setback for AIDS sufferers, who are protected under the Disabilities Act. The bill already exempts from protection anyone whose disease endangers others. AIDS is spread through intimate sexual contact or by contaminated hypodermic needles or by blood. Among key provisions of the bill: _discrimination against the disabled in hiring and on the job would be prohibited. The requirement would be phased in over two to four years, depending on the size of the company. Companies with fewer than 15 employers would be exempt. _Hotels, restaurants, shopping malls, drug stores, and business and professional offices, along with any other ``public accommodations,'' would have to be accessible to disabled people. Accessibility includes structural adjustments, such as wheelchair ramps and widened doors, and services. _Transportation, public and private, would have to be accessible. Fixed-route bus systems would have to be accessible for people with wheelchairs. Amtrak, Greyhound, and commuter rail systems are covered. Timetables for implementation vary according to system. _Speech- and hearing-impaired people would have access to telephone service by means of relay services. These services would have to be provided by phone companies within three years. Voting against the bill were: Reps. Bill Archer, R-Texas; Richard Armey, R-Texas; Joe Barton, R-Texas, Herb Bateman, R-Va.; Dan Burton, R-Ind.; Jim Cooper, D-Tenn.; Philip Crane, R-Ill.; William Dannemeyer, R-Calif.; Tom DeLay, R-Texas; Mel Hancock, R-Mo.; Wally Herger, R-Calif.; Jim Lightfoot, R-Iowa; Ron Marlenee, R-Mont.; Howard Nielson, R-Utah; Jim Olin, D-Va.; Ron Packard, R-Calif.; Norman Shumway, R-Calif.; Bud Shuster, R-Pa.; Charles Stenholm, D-Texas; Bob Stump, R-Ariz. Not voting were: Reps. Bill Alexander, D-Ark.; Larry Craig, R-Idaho; Ronnie Flippo, D-Ala.; Thomas Foley, D-Wash.
