(by tradition the speaker does not vote); Harold Ford, D-Tenn.; John Paul Hammerschmidt, R-Ark.; Donald Lukens, R-Ohio; Bill Nelson, D-Fla.; William Thomas, R-Calif.; Wes Watkins, D-Okla.

DOC.HEAD: Hezbollahis March to Denounce Palestinian Killings
With AM-Middle East Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Hundreds of Hezbollah members burned effigies of the Israeli prime minister as well as the U.S., Jordanian and Saudi Arabian leaders to protest the weekend slaying of Palestinian laborers by an Israeli. With shouts of ``the spiteful America is the cause of the world's misfortunes!'' the crowd wound its way past garbage piles in the dusty alleys of Beirut's southern suburbs. The pro-Iranian Hezbollah, or Party of God, is believed to be the umbrella group for extremist Shiite Moslem factions who hold most of the 16 foreign hostages in Lebanon. The march came three days after an Israeli gunman killed seven unarmed Palestinian workers near Tel Aviv. An Israeli judge ordered psychiatric tests for the suspect, Ami Popper. Israeli police said the gunman was ``deranged'' and upset over a breakup with his girlfriend, but Arabs accused the Israeli government of creating an atmosphere that led to the slayings. ``Both the Zionist entity and world arrogance committed the massacre in the name of a madman,'' said Hezbollah cleric Sheik Naim Kassem. The demonstration was led by a group of boys, aged eight to 13, carrying pictures of Iran's late Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini pasted on pieces of cardboard. They also carried colorful flags inscribed, ``We are at your disposal, oh Khomeini.'' Schools and businesses in the Palestinian refugee camps in the southern ports of Sidon and Tyre went on strike to protest the killings. About 125 Palestinians visited the International Committee of the Red Cross in Tyre and asked the organization to relay a message to U.N. Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar. The message demanded ``intervention by the ICRC and the U.N. to stop the massacres committed against our people in the Occupied Territories.'' In Beirut, the marchers burned cardboard effigies mounted on wooden poles depicting President Bush, Jordan's King Hussein, Saudi Arabia's King Fahd and Israeli Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir.

DOC.HEAD: Lithunian, Latvian Presidents Meet Gorbachev, No Progress Reported
DOC.TEXT: Mikhail S. Gorbachev took another step toward dialogue with the Baltics on Tuesday by meeting with the Estonian and Latvian presidents, but he stuck to his hard line against independence, reports said. Lithuania, struggling with an economic blockade the Kremlin imposed to weaken its independence campaign, said gasoline sales for private cars would be banned as of Wednesday. The Soviet president, who met last week with Lithuania's prime minister, sat down for 20 minutes with presidents Anatoly Gorbunov of Latvia and Arnold Ruutel of Estonia, the Estonian News Service reported. Gorbachev reportedly told the Latvian and Estonian leaders the same thing he told Lithuania's Kazimiera Prunskiene: the Baltic republics must either suspend or revoke their declarations of independence. The Estonian News Service, an independent information agency, quoted Ruutel as saying there was a common understanding of the need for dialogue, but he characterized the meeting as ``unpleasant'' for both sides. He did not elaborate but told Interfax, another independent news service, that each side stuck to its opinion and refused to budge. Lithuania, Latvia and Estonia are in varying stages of efforts to restore the independence they enjoyed before the Soviet Union forcibly annexed them 50 years ago. The Kremlin has declared the independence declarations illegal. It imposed a blockade of oil, gas, and other supplies on Lithuania, which led the independence movement with its March 11 declaration. At the Kremlin meeting Tuesday, Gorbachev repeated his view that the Baltics' independence declarations violate the Soviet Constitution, the Estonian report said. Elsewhere in the Kremlin, a Lithuanian legislator told one of the two chambers of the Supreme Soviet that the blockade against his republic is ``not only immoral but illegal.'' Eduardas Vilkas said the sanctions had cost Lithuania a quarter of a billion rubles in lost production but had also cost the Soviet Union several billion rubles in Lithuanian products it did not receive. He demanded the blockade be lifted and his republic be compensated. Legislators in Lithuania debated measures on holding the economy together during the blockade as well as an approach toward Moscow, the parliament's information bureau reported. No decisions were made. So far, Lithuanian lawmakers have refused to suspend the independence decree but have offered to consider rescinding other measures aimed at implementing the declaration. Starting Wednesday, gasoline will be sold in Lithuania only for ambulances, police cars, fire trucks, food trucks, armored cars, hearses and agricultural equipment, Algirdas Brazauskas, head of the government's anti-blockade committee, told parliament. Some gas will be available for limited public transport, Brazauskas said. Private cars had been limited to 2{ gallons a month. Brazauskas also announced what he called ``one of the most difficult decisions in these days,'' that small oil- and coal-fired power plants would be closed starting Thursday because of the fuel shortage. At a seminar in Stockholm on Baltic independence, Lithuanian Vice President Ceslovas Stankevicius said townspeople may be evacuated to the countryside to conserve energy and food. He said 22,000 people had lost their jobs because of the month-old embargo. A strike by pro-Moscow forces in Estonia was in its second day, with workers at two more plants joining the protest against the republic's independence drive, a strike committee spokesman said. The Tass news agency said the strike spread to coal mines, shipyards and the Krengolmskaya manufacturing mills, the republic's largest light industry enterprise. Tass said 21 businesses were on strike. The strikers demanded Ruutel resign and the parliament rescind laws challenging Soviet authority, said Viktor Tsunya, a member of the anti-independence Russian Strike Committee. Tass said the workers want pro-Moscow legislators to set up an alternate government. Finnish radio reported a strike among members of Estonia' ethnic Russian minority had prompted the owners of the Baltic ferry boat ``Georg Ots'' to suspend service between the Finnish capital of Helsinki and Tallinn, the Estonian capital. An assistant U.S. Commerce Department secretary said the Bush administration ``hopes the Soviet Union will end its economic blockade of Lithuania and begin a productive dialogue with the Lithuanian people.'' The official, Thomas J. Duesterberg, was in Moscow for talks with Soviet trade officials.

DOC.HEAD: Hard-Line Policies Blamed for Massacre, Riots
With AM-Middle East Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The hard-line policies of Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir have created an atmosphere of hatred that incites anti-Arab violence such as the slaying of seven Palestinian workers by an Israeli, Palestinians say. They charge that Israel's ``iron fist'' handling of the 29-month-old Palestinian uprising, and the government's failure to begin peace talks, have increased anti-Arab sentiment. In addition, Israelis who attack Palestinians face lenient punishment, Palestinian leaders said. ``There is no doubt that the Israeli government led by Shamir ... leads to such catastrophe,'' pro-PLO leader Faisal Husseini said after the slayings Sunday of seven unarmed Palestinian workers by an Israeli civilian. ``The atmosphere created by such a government is responsible.'' But Shamir and his supporters have said Sunday's violence was the act of a deranged man. They also accused Palestinian extremists of using the massacre to rekindle the flagging rebellion against Israeli rule of the West Bank and Gaza Strip. ``Anyone wishing to see in this mad murder an expression of Israeli government policy and intentions is maliciously and viciously distorting the picture,'' Shamir told Parliament members from his right-wing Likud bloc at a meeting Tuesday. He pledged that his government would pursue peace efforts in the Middle East but said: ``We don't want to live by our sword, but we shall not be quick in throwing it out as long as it allows us to live in security.'' Shamir has headed a caretaker government since the Likud-Labor Party coalition collapsed March 15 over Labor's insistance on negotiations with the Palestians. Benjamin Netanyahu, Israel's deputy foreign minister, said the U.S. State Department's call for restraint in handling the Palestinian riots that followed the massacre was ``understandable but unwarranted.'' ``I think the U.S. government and American people understand that this was a tragedy we had nothing to do with and that we are doing everything we can to restore tranquility,'' Netanyahu said. He accused the Palestine Liberation Organization and other Palestinian groups of ``fanning the flames and sustaining the violence.'' Thirteen Palestinians have been killed by Israeli troops in three days of rioting, most in the occupied Gaza Strip. More than 800 others have been injured. Their deaths raised to 708 the number of Palestinians killed by Israeli soldiers or civilians since the start of the uprising in December 1987. Forty-three Israelis have died in the violence. Ami Popper, 21, a cashiered Israeli army soldier has been arrested for Sunday's fatal shootings of seven Gaza workers in Rishon Lezion near Tel Aviv. An Israeli court ordered that he undergo psychiatric observation. Saeed Kanaan, a leading pro-PLO businessman from the West Bank, said the violence that followed the Rishon Lezion killings was not orchestrated by Palestinian leaders.

DOC.HEAD: Graduation Rehearsal Becomes Memorial Service for Grieving Seniors
DOC.TEXT: Graduation rehearsal should have been held Tuesday, but instead more than 180 high school seniors attended a memorial service for an assistant principal slain earlier in the week. ``We're all hurt by it, all disgusted by it, all angry,'' senior Marie Green said tearfully as she left the gathering. The students from this rural community of 2,800 gathered at Hickman County High School to mourn the death of Ron Wallace, 41, who will be buried Thursday. Wallace, whose daughter is among the 1990 graduates, also was the school's athletic director. Donald Givens, a 50-year-old science teacher at the school, was charged Sunday night with first-degree murder. He also was charged with aggravated arson for allegedly setting a fire to cover up the crime. Authorities said Wallace walked in on Givens on Sunday morning as Givens was preparing to blow up the school. Classes for the 850 students have been suspended for the rest of the year. An exam schedule remained posted Tuesday on a wall in a classroom near the school auditorium. The flag outside the school was at half-staff. The graduation rehearsal was reset for Friday prior to the formal exercise later that day. Reporters were barred from Tuesday's gathering in the auditorium, where a partition was set to hide a stage curtain burned when three fires were set Sunday. Afterward, students said school officials encouraged them to discuss their feelings with teachers and to get together to share their grief. Principal Rick Brewer addressed the group and ``ended up crying himself,'' senior Tina Barnes said. Before the service, Brewer met with teachers and urged them to carry on for the sake of the seniors despite the upheaval. ``What has to happen is that we make this work from here on,'' he told them. ``Everything that Ron was part of can not come to a stop.'' Givens remained in the Hickman County Jail where he is held without bond.

DOC.HEAD: Actress's Ranch To Be Part Of New National Park
DOC.TEXT: A ranch owned by actress Greer Garson would be combined with the 385-acre Pecos National Monument to make a new national park near Sante Fe, N.M., under legislation approved Tuesday by the House. The legislation, which passed 415-0, also would preserve about 15,000 ancient Indian rock carvings by creating the Petroglyph National Monument, near Albuquerque, N.M. Garson's 5,500-acre Forked Lightning Ranch went on sale after the death of her husband, Texas oilman E.E. Buddy Fogelson. Environmentalists and residents of the area became involved when she began transactions with a developer who wanted to commercialize the area. ``It's extremely important that we act quickly,'' said Rep. Bill Richardson, D-N.M., during debate on the bill. Garson, 77, won an Academy Award in 1943 for the film ``Mrs. Miniver'' during a career that spanned about 40 years on stage and in the movies. She and her husband, who died last year, made their home at the ranch and in Dallas, Texas. Richardson said one prospective buyer of the ranch wanted to build a huge commercial complex, including a resort, shopping mall, air strip, convention center and private hunting reserve, on the land. ``Although Mrs. Fogelson has decided against selling to these developers the land remains on the open market,'' said Richardson. ``Any development would pose a serious threat to the existing national monument.'' The monument was established in 1965 and preserves the ruins of the nearly 600-year-old Pueblo of Pecos and two Spanish missions from the 17th and 19th centuries. The legislation has the support of the Bush administration. It was attached by the House to a bill already passed by the Senate which would make a national monument of ancient Indian rock carvings, known as petroglyphs. The 15,000 petroglyphs are part of the Las Imagines National Archeological District on Abuquerque, N.M.'s West Mesa escarpment. Lawmakers say the drawings are threatened by urbanization and vandalism, and hundreds have already been destroyed. Aquisition of the land where the petroglyphs are located would cost about $90 million. State and local governments have pledged $30 million, said Rep. Robert Lagomarsino, R-Calif., a member of the House Interior Committee.

DOC.HEAD: Kathleen Turner to Reprise Broadway Role for ABC
DOC.TEXT: Kathleen Turner, nominated for a Tony for her Maggie in the Broadway revival of ``Cat on a Hot Tin Roof,'' will appear in an ABC version of the play next season, the network said Tuesday. No date has been set yet for the start of production. The video version of Tennessee Williams' play was among 11 new TV movie projects announced by ABC. Another will pair Vanessa Redgrave and her sister, Lynn, in a TV version of ``What Ever Happened to Baby Jane,'' a dark comedy whose 1962 film version co-starred Bette Davis and Joan Crawford as feuding sisters. Turner has starred in the films ``Body Heat,'' ``Peggy Sue Got Married'' and ``The Accidental Tourist.''

DOC.HEAD: Mandela Accuses South African Government of Massacring Protesters
DOC.TEXT: African National Congress leader Nelson Mandela accused the South African government Tuesday of massacring demonstrators and causing black-on-black violence. Mandela also charged the government with defaming his wife, Winnie, in a murder and assault trial involving one of her former bodyguards, and said the ANC is not satisfied with reforms introduced by President F.W. de Klerk. Mandela, speaking to reporters after returning from an eight-nation African tour, said de Klerk has no control over the police force. He accused police of ``slaughtering'' black people involved in political demonstrations. He alleged it was government policy to keep ANC supporters fighting members of the Inkatha political organization in Natal province, where more than 5,000 people have died in the past five years. ``It is quite clear that the government does not want this violence to end,'' Mandela said. ``If the government continues to massacre our people while they are talking of negotiations, that we cannot permit. We will have to address that question specifically in relation to whether these negotiations shall continue.'' De Klerk is hoping to begin formal talks with black leaders on constitutional changes that would give the black majority a voice in national affairs _ something denied them under the current system of apartheid. Since taking office in August, de Klerk has made a number of reforms, including legalizing the long-banned ANC; freeing Mandela from a life prison term; and ending segregation of beaches and hospitals. Mandela said the ANC is not satisfied. ``We have got basic demands,'' he said. ``The most basic of these is the demand for everybody to have the right to determine his own affairs.'' Mandela said the government has deliberately besmirched his wife's name by linking her to the alleged crimes of one of her former bodyguards, Jerry Richardson, but not charging her. Richardson is charged with murder, kidnapping, attempted murder and assault. Eight other bodyguards are facing lesser charges in separate trials. Three men have testified in court that Winnie Mandela whipped them, beat them allowed her bodyguards to keep them captive in her home and assault them in December 1988 and January 1989. One of the alleged victims, 14-year-old black activist Stompie Seipei Moeketsi, was found dead Jan. 6, 1989. Mrs. Mandela denies wrongdoing and has not been charged with a crime. ``When my wife is not charged and the whole case centers on her, she has no way of defending herself,'' Mandela said. But Mandela said he was not calling on the government to prosecute his wife. ``I am saying that the way the case has been conducted is intended to defame my wife without her having the opportunity to defend herself,'' he said. It was the first time Mandela had spoken publicly on the matter in South Africa since he was freed Feb. 12 from a life prison term for sabotage and plotting the overthrow of the white-minority government.

DOC.HEAD: Visitors, Workers Cross Paths as Movie Attraction Opens
DOC.TEXT: Visitors rode home with E.T. while technicians tinkered with King Kong and other exhibits Tuesday at the new Universal Studios Florida. A three-week break-in period got under way with a low-key public opening Monday, when about 10,000 people showed up. ``We're operating at roughly half-speed and half-price,'' said Universal's top executive, Jay Stein. The $600 million complex, featuring film production and large-scale, high-tech rides and shows, plans its official opening June 7. ``We knew that everything was not going to be ready, yet we desperately need the operating experience,'' Stein said after the first paying customers toured the 444-acre park. ``You've got to let these people perform in front of a paid _ as opposed to a free _ audience.'' Universal began testing its rides and shows with small crowds of invited guests early this month before throwing open its gates Monday. Some of the big attractions such as King Kong, Jaws and Ghostbusters are still being completed and checked. Families with baby strollers mingled with construction workers along some of the Manhattan and San Francisco street sets. Behind the scenes, welders scrambled over a six-ton steel ape hanging onto a replica of New York's Queensboro Bridge. Technicians fine-tuned the six-story-tall King Kong, the massive 1906 San Francisco Earthquake set and other attractions, while builders hurried to complete facades. Divers and workers in small boats tried to right a trawler used in stunt work that, to the bemused curiosity of many visitors, accidentally flipped over on its side in a lagoon. ``It's painstaking work,'' Stein said. ``We've got a lot of gnawing, aggravating things and problems to resolve, last-minute things that _ no matter how well it all checks out in testing _ have to be changed and fixed and fine-tuned.'' E.T., the extra-terrestrial creature that starred in the Steven Spielberg movie, is the star of the show so far. The ride sends guests on an intergalactic bike ride to E.T.'s endangered home planet. The creature got the approval of 5-year-old Gemma John of West Yorkshire, England, who was right up front when it ambled out during dedication ceremonies. ``He's nice. He smiled,'' said Gemma, who waved and smiled back shyly.

DOC.HEAD: Polish Railway Strike Widens, Government Sees Challenge to Reform
DOC.TEXT: A railroad strike in northwestern Poland spread Tuesday, and the government ordered the army to transport people and food. The strike began Sunday, and the Solidarity-led government of Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki continued to appeal to rail workers to return to work. The Solidarity leadership met in Gdansk to draft a response to the strike, organized without the union's endorsement. The government has rejected negotiations because the strikers are not operating through their unions. It also said that giving in to their pay raise demands could scuttle post-Communist Poland's economic reforms. Strikes were reported Tuesday at eight key depots, including Slupsk and Koszalin, near the Baltic coast. There were warning strikes and support actions in other provinces but precise numbers of those who walked off the job were not immediately available. The workers began striking Sunday night in support of more than three dozen colleagues on fasts. Some of the hunger strikers have been fasting since May 10. Three were reported to have been hospitalized, and others joined the protest Monday, PAP said. A team of doctors dispatched Tuesday by the Ministry of Health was under orders to hospitalize any other workers whose health was in danger. Only one rail route was open to Poland's busiest port in Szczecin, and mail lines were paralyzed. More than 160 local trains, 47 freight trains and 14 long-distance passenger trains were canceled Monday, the official PAP news agency reported. The government decided to use the military to transport goods, especially perishables, according to news reports. The army and the railway authority were also directed to organize alternative bus and truck transport for passengers and goods, PAP said. The strike was the most serious labor unrest since the pro-democratic reforms, which included unpopular austerity measures, went into effect on Jan. 1. The reforms have reduced buying power by 40 percent and cut subsidies to state-owned enterprises, including railroads. Labor Minister Jacek Kuron met late Monday with national railway authorities, and news reports said it was agreed that no government money was available to raise average pay of $79 per month. That is close to the national average but less than the pay in many industries, the news reports said. The strikers are demanding their salaries be raised to 110 percent of the national average, or another $8 this month, but these figures are adjusted monthly to keep up with inflation. The government, in trying to control inflation, has rejected pay or benefit increases that cannot be supported by the budgets of the enterprises or the government. The strike represents a challenge to Solidarity, which has been trying to define its role in society _ whether it should focus on serving as a trade union backing workers or a political party supporting the government. Solidarity leader Lech Walesa reiterated his contention that the government his movement created was moving too slowing with reforms and failing to win the understanding of working Poles. The Slupsk strike committee spokesman, Jerzy Sadka, said the workers support Mazowiecki and do not consider their action political. ``We are involved in purely worker, and thus trade union, issues and we protest against pulling us into political affairs,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Move Toward Drift-Net Ban Passes Senate Committee
DOC.TEXT: A proposed move toward a global ban on high seas drift-net fishing won approval Tuesday from the Senate Commerce Committee and the backing of the environmental group Greenpeace. ``This legislation sends a clear signal to those using drift nets that the senseless destruction of marine life for profit must end,'' said Sen. Slade Gorton, R-Wash., a member of the panel. Gorton and Sen. Ted Stevens, R-Alaska, cosponsored the amendment to the Magnuson Fishery Management and Conservation Act calling for an end to high seas drift-net fishing by June 1992. ``Today's action will increase pressure on the governments of Japan, Taiwan and South Korea to put an end to their high seas drift-net fleets,'' Stevens said. Gorton said the drift nets _ some stretching as long as 35 miles _ are ``environmentally devastating.'' Greenpeace spokesman Alan Reichman of Seattle said the nets cause large kills of dolphins, porpoise, northern fur seals and seabirds. The fleets also intercept North American salmon and threaten the viability of albacore tuna and red flying squid stocks, he said. ``The drift-net provisions would provide new leverage to gain a global ban on this destructive fishing technology which is threatening ocean environment,'' Reichman said. The measure establishes a congressional goal of gaining a global moratorium on high seas drift-net fishing through a resolution the United Nations General Assembly approved in December. That resolution calls for the moratorium on large-scale drift-net fishing to go into effect next year.

DOC.HEAD: Yeltsin Calls for Sovereignty for Republic of Russia
DOC.TEXT: Boris N. Yeltsin won applause from Russian congressional deputies on Tuesday with a call to wrest control of the republic _ the Soviet Union's largest _ from the Kremlin. Yeltsin, a rival of Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev, is seeking the presidency of the republic, which includes Moscow, 52 percent of the nation's population and three-quarters of its land. He told the Russian Congress the top-heavy Soviet political system ``continues to cling to life though its time has passed, and has hurt Russia most of all.'' Yeltsin's sovereignty proposal for the republic resembles measures passed by the three secessionist Baltic republics in the beginning of their independence drives. Under it, the republic would have final say over whether Soviet laws and decrees are valid on its territory, which stretches from the Baltic Sea to the Pacific Ocean. The Russian republic embraces 11 time zones and the vast oil, gas, mineral and gold reserves. Congress was expected to vote on various sovereignty proposals Wednesday or Thursday, then turn to nominations for president. The president is chosen by the Congress rather than in general elections. Yeltsin is running against Russia's premier Alexander Vlasov and several others. He has said he believes about one-third of the Congress' 1,059 deputies support him. A Yeltsin victory could mean a loss of face for Gorbachev, whose policies are frequently and stridently criticized by Yeltsin. Yeltsin is a leader of the Democratic Russia bloc that made major inroads into local and republic councils in March elections. The sovereignty plan outlined by Yeltsin would involve allowing republics and businesses to set trade contracts freely among themselves rather than having to go through the central government. Other deputies offered more extreme proposals. Irina Zalevskaya, a newspaper editor from the Ural Mountains city of Perm, declared that Russia must break from the Soviet Union if it wants true control over its own affairs. ``Full sovereignty requires the republic's secession from the Soviet Union,'' she said. Russia should eventually seek U.N. membership, form its own army and set up embassies in the other 14 republics, she said. Her vehement speech won hearty applause.

DOC.HEAD: Violence Troubling Once-Classy Georgetown
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates with reinstatement of patrols, subbing 3 grafs for grafs 4-5 pvs, Fifty officers
DOC.TEXT: Violent crime in Georgetown, the city's most exclusive neighborhood, has increased to the point where shopkeepers say they spend more time protecting their customers than selling them goods. District of Columbia police warned visitors Monday to stay away from Georgetown on weekend nights because, with reduced budgets, they could not promise to prevent the violence that rocked the trendy nightclub strip over the weekend. Police said there was one incident in which a crowd of men attacked an officer trying to make an arrest, and a police union spokesman said five officers in all were hurt in confrontations during the weekend. Fifty officers, instead of the usual six, were supposed to have been patrolling the area and a mobile headquarters was to have been set up as part of a special summer anti-crime effort. But police, citing budget cuts, said there wasn't enough money. Police Chief Isaac Fulwood on Tuesday reinstated the weekend summer anti-crime patrols. But shopkeepers said extra police will not repair the changing nature of Georgetown. ``It's not just police that are needed,'' one shoe store owner said. ``It's a whole different kind of person than the kind that used to shop here. It's too many young kids with nothing to do.'' Area residents say robberies and muggings have been on the increase for some time. And shopkeepers and residents said Tuesday they are mourning the loss of the neighborhood they sought out for its history, vibrancy and elegance. Georgetown, once a separate city, still has cobblestone streets, small row houses and sprawling mansions. It has been populated by Kennedys, Cabinet members and the city's most famed socialites and diplomats, and is home to the city's most prestigious university. But the old antique and rare book shops are gradually being replaced with national chain clothing stores, and the nightclub and restaurant strip is thriving. With those changes have come increasing numbers of youths either too young or too broke to shop or dine. Shopkeepers say those people have begun preying on the customers, who are beginning to stay away. ``We're definitely getting a security guard,'' said William Myers, manager of Hats in the Belfry, which stays open until 10:45 p.m. ``We get rowdy people and I'm getting tired of chasing shoplifters down the street.'' ``I'm beginning to second guess whether I want to stay,'' said the manager of a sports clothing store, who asked not to be named. ``I would have to see major changes. If I got an offer to get out, I'd take it.'' ``The last thing I want to hear is that the police are giving up on this area,'' he added. ``I spend more time being a policeman now, chasing riffraff and shoplifters out than I do selling. That hurts.'' Mehdi Mokhtari, owner of Shoe Inn, said he has chased out children with ``wads of cash crumpled in their hands.'' They came back later, he said, and sprayed his tiny store with a foul-smelling aerosol, which kept customers away for hours. David Friedman, a longtime resident who owns Susquehanna Antiques, says his store will be replaced this year with an ``upscale _ I hate that word _ clothing store.'' He said even the ``old Georgetown types'' no longer think of the neighborhood as a place to find fine furniture and head for New York or Boston instead. Others, however, say Georgetown has faced such phases periodically through its history, especially in the late 1960s and early 1970s with race riots and hippies and will survive this trend.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Welcomes Yemen Unification
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. government said Tuesday it hoped the unfication of North and South Yemen would contribute to Middle East stability. State Department spokeswoman Margaret Tutwiler said the department would also review its listing of South Yemen as a country that supports terrorism, but she wouldn't preduct what action the United States would take. ``We welcome this declaration as a measure that could improve stability and security in the region,'' she told reporters. The United States accused South Yemen of engaging in terrorism by allowing terrorist organizations to maintain facilities there and by providing refuge for airline hijackers. ``We were just notified of this at 5 a.m. this morning,'' Ms. Tutwiler said of the unification. ``Obviously it has not changed that South Yemen is on the terrorist list in the hours that this has taken place.'' North Yemen President Ali Abdullah Saleh met with President George Bush at the White House last January and discused his proposals for unity with the south. The United States resumed diplomatic relations with South Yemen last April 30 after a break of nearly 21 years.

DOC.HEAD: Baltic States Seek Diplomatic Recognition, Economic Aid
With AM-Soviet-Baltics, Bjt
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Stands for AM-Sweden-Lithuania on news digest.
DOC.TEXT: Leaders of the three Baltic states appealed Tuesday to the United States and Europe for diplomatic recognition and economic help for their independence-minded republics. With an apparent eye to the upcoming superpower summit, they also called on President Bush to suggest that the Kremlin begin negotiations with the three republics on independence. The call, which came at the end of a two-day seminar on Baltic independence, was signed by Estonian Foreign Minister Lennart Meri, Latvian Vice President Dainis Ivans and Lithuanian Vice President Ceslovas Stankevicius. The two-day seminar was arranged by Sweden's Institute of Foreign Affairs. A panel of representatives of the three Baltic republics and the Soviet Union were among about 150 participating diplomats, government officials and international law experts. Earlier, Lithuania's vice president said some city and town dwellers may be evacuated to the countryside to conserve energy and food. Moscow imposed a blockade of oil, natural gas and raw materials a month ago to force the republic to back down on its March 11 declaration of independence. Stankevicius said by the latest count, 22,000 people were out of work because of the embargo. ``I cannot say how long we can survive this situation,'' he told the seminar. ``It is a threat.'' He said Lithuania is establishing direct economic ties with other Soviet republics and towns outside Lithuania to get around the blockade. ``We are ready to supply food in exchange for raw materials,'' he said. Meri, of Estonia, said his republic ``has made arrangements to receive workers from Lithuania'' and that Latvia was taking similar steps. In Lithuania, legislators said gasoline sales to private cars would be banned as of Wednesday because of shortages caused by the Kremlin sanctions. Private cars had been limited to 2{ gallons of gasoline a month. The Baltic leaders in Stockholm appealed to the 35 countries in the Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe to include their republics in economic assistance programs. The United States, Canada and all European countries except Albania take part in the CSCE.

DOC.HEAD: EPA Reviewing Report On Link Between Cancer And Electrical Power Lines
DOC.TEXT: An Environmental Protection Agency study still under scientific review suggests that there is increasing scientific evidence of a link between heavy electrical currents and some types of cancer. The study, an EPA official said Tuesday, shows that research over the last decade has established at least a tentative connection between leukemia and some other cancers, and the slowly varying magnetic fields created by powerful alternating electric currents. Richard Guimond, director of EPA's Office of Radiation, said the report has no original research, but rather is a review of a variety of scientific studies of the human body effects of long-term exposure to magnetic fields created by power lines. At one time, he said, studies showed no link between electrical current and human cancer. The new report, however, said Guimond, ``suggests that there is in fact stronger and stronger evidence being developed as more and more of these studies are done.'' ``Over the past 10 years studies have been developed that show evidence of links'' between cancer and electrical current, he said. Guimond said the EPA review ``tries to analyze all of those studies to determine if there is a weak link, a strong link, no link.'' After the report is reviewed by a group of scientists, it will be available for public review sometime this summer, probably in July, he said. Until then, he said, ``We can't say that it is final and what the final conclusions are going to be.'' He said an independent panel will review work done by EPA staffers ``to assure that our methodology is correct ... and to give us some advice as to whether or not our evidence is strong enough to declare that this (long term exposure to magnetic fields) is a probable human carcinogen or not.'' There have been more than two dozen studies by various organizations and scientists on the possible link between illness and the electromagnetic fields created any time an electrical circuit is energized. Though there have been findings suggestive of a cancer effect, the link has not been universally accepted by scientists. A new understanding in recent years of how individual cells can be affected by even very low levels of electromagnetic radiation, however, has caused a closer look at a possible link between electrical currents and cancer. For instance, a 1987 study in Denver claimed that children living near electric power lines were 1.7 times more likely to develop leukemia than Denver children living away from power lines. Other studies in recent years have suggested there is a higher incidence of leukemia and brain tumors among people exposed to electrical fields on the job. These would include electrical power line and telephone line workers. Other studies have shown that even very low levels of electromagnetic radiation, such as from ordinary household applicances, can affect specific cells, but whether or not these cells are actually injured remains a controversial question. All households, and almost all power lines, use alternating current, changing direction 60 times a second and producing an electromagnetic field varying at the same frequency. Only a handful of very high power transmission lines use direct current, which produces a steady magnetic field.

DOC.HEAD: Red Cross Chairman: 1989 Donations, Expenses Set Records
DOC.TEXT: The American Red Cross received a record $165 million in donations in 1989 but spent $151 million, three times more than the record. ``It was a tremendous year for helping others,'' said Red Cross Chairman George Moody at the organization's annual convention in Orlando. Most of the money, $127 million, was spent on victims of Hurricane Hugo in the Southeast and the California earthquake, Moody said Tuesday. Last year was the most expensive year of disasters in the Red Cross' 109-year history, Moody said. Focusing on Hugo and the California earthquake, Moody said more than 21,000 volunteers helped serve 12.7 million meals, shelter almost 180,000 people and give financial assistance to 143,000 families. During the convention, the organization conducted a series of workshops for workers and volunteers on topics such as disaster-preparedness, blood donations, famines in Africa and AIDS-education programs. A new Spanish-language AIDS video was unveiled at the conference. It will be used along with other materials to help in AIDS education courses among Hispanics, Red Cross spokeswoman Diane Powers said.

DOC.HEAD: Israel To Spend $20.5 Million For Settlements In Territories
DOC.TEXT: Parliament's Finance Committee said Tuesday it approved spending $20.5 million to improve Jewish settlements in the occupied territories at the request of Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir. The decision came Monday after a plea from Shamir, who asked the committee in a letter to allocate the funds to the Housing Ministry. A copy of Shamir's letter was obtained by The Associated Press. Shamir asked that the money be used to develop settlements and roads beyond the Green Line, which divides Israel from the territories it captured in the 1967 Middle East War. A Shamir spokesman insisted the money would be used only to improve existing settlements, not build new ones. Two new settlements established by Shamir's caretaker government have sparked protests from the United States, which says settlements in the occupied areas are an obstacle to peacemaking. Shulamit Aloni, a Finance Committee member and left-wing legislator, condemned the decision to allocate the money. ``This decision was passed by a completely insane system at a time of political unrest,'' Aloni said. He said it could hurt U.S. aid to Israel and endanger Soviet Jewish emigration. Thousands of Soviet Jews are expected to immigrate to Israel this year, and there is concern in the Soviet Union and among Arab countries that some could settle in the occupied lands. Israel denies it has a policy of steering immigrants to the occupied territories. A report by an Israeli diplomat in Washington released Tuesday in the daily Haaretz supported Aloni's claims. Yoram Ettinger, aide to deputy Foreign Minister Benjamin Natanyahu, said the U.S. Congress appeared to be less motivated to maintain strategic cooperation with Israel and more inclined to support Palestinians in their struggle for statehood, Haaretz reported. The Arab states see any settlement move as an attempt to push out Palestinians from the occupied territories. Government officials insisted that the money approved by the Finance Committee would not be used to form a new Jewish presence in the occupied West Bank or Gaza Strip. ``We are talking about already existing settlements, not forming new ones,'' Shamir's spokesman Avi Pazner said. The allocated money included $2.5 million to ``strengthen'' new settlements and $3 million for developing and expanding existing settlements. A separate sum of $2.5 million was allocated to purchase prefabricated houses and strengthen settlements in the West Bank. Ariel Weinstein, who represents Shamir's Likud bloc on the Finance Committee, said the government decided on a policy of settling the occupied territories and they should be treated as any other Israeli town. ``They need new roads, schools. Nobody thinks the government can decide not to fulfill these needs,'' Weinstein said. In Egypt, President Hosni Mubarak warned Tuesday that settlement of Soviet Jewish immigrants in Israeli-occupied lands threatens ``new bloody confrontation'' in the Middle East. He spoke at the opening session of Socialist International, a non-governmental grouping of 89 socialist parties from 47 countries.

DOC.HEAD: Student Massacre Reported In Zaire
DOC.TEXT: A reliable Belgian newspaper reported Tuesday that more than 50 students opposing the Zairian government had been killed by soldiers in the southeastern Zairian city of Lubumbashi. A Belgian official, who requested anonymity, said there were deaths but declined to elaborate. Belgium, the former colonial power in Zaire, said its ambassador to Zaire had gone to Lubumbashi to get information. Official sources in Zaire said 14 students had been injured when soldiers were called to separate rival groups of students. Colette Braeckman, a reporter for Brussels daily Le Soir, quoted a Belgian professor from Lubumbashi University who was present at the time of the killing. The professor, who requested anonymity, was quoted as saying that a special commando unit of President Mobutu Sese Seko's personal guard flew to Lubumbashi May 11 and killed more than 50 students who had expressed their opposition to Mobutu's regime two days before. He was quoted as saying the opponents had seriously injured some alleged security agents. The source said the special commando attacked anti-Mobutu students while they slept in their campus dormitories, cutting their throats with knives or broken bottles, setting bedrooms afire and throwing bodies through windows. The professor added some bodies were removed by the soldiers. He added Belgian professors were asked to ignore the massacre. Some of them returned to Belgium, he was quoted as saying. On Saturday, Belgian Foreign Minister Mark Eyskens expressed concern about ``the serious incidents which took place on university campuses'' and called on Zaire authorities to respect human rights. The official Zaire news agency Azap criticized the Belgian foreign minister's statement, claiming soldiers had been called to separate rival groups of students. The U.S. State Department said in its annual human rights report that security organizations regularly harass, detain and physically mistreat opponents. Several leading House Democrats have urged the United States end aid to Mobutu, who has ruled since 1965.

DOC.HEAD: Democrats Call For Aid to International Ozone Effort
DOC.TEXT: A group of 11 Senate Democrats, challenging President Bush, introduced legislation Tuesday that would authorize money to help developing nation's phase out chemicals that damage the ozone layer. The Bush administration refused last month to go along with international efforts to help developing countries curtail the use of such chemicals as chlorofluorocarbons, or CFCs, that are damaging the ozone layer. The ozone layer protects the Earth from ultraviolet radiation. Under a plan floated by several European countries at a conference in Geneva, $100 million would be provided by industrial nations over three years. But the assistance plan reportedly was opposed by John Sununu, White House chief of staff, and Richard Darman, director of the Office of Management and Budget. Legislation introduced in the Senate on Tuesday would authorize the spending of $25 million annually for the assistance program over the next three years. It was not known Tuesday whether efforts would be made to specifically earmark money for such assistance in approprations legislation. ``We cannot accept the adminstration's preference for environmental negligence and we will not allow the United States to become an environmental outcast,'' said Sen. Al Gore, D-Tenn., one of the sponsors. The other co-sponsors of the legislation were Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell of Maine and Sens. Claiborne of Rhode Island, Patrick Leahy of Vermont, Timothy Wirth of Colorado, John Kerry, of Massachusetts, Max Baucus of Montana, Joseph Biden of Delaware, Brock Adams of Washington, Alan Cranston of California and Dale Bumpers of Arkansas.

DOC.HEAD: Big Iliescu Win Raises Fears About Romanian Democracy
LaserPhoto XBUC1
DOC.TEXT: Interim President Ion Iliescu defeated the opposition in Romania's election by such a large margin that fears were raised Tuesday in his own party about entrenching democracy in this former Communist bastion. Iliescu captured 85.9 percent of the vote in the three-way presidential race with nearly all ballots counted. His National Salvation Front party had more than two-thirds of the seats in the two-chamber Parliament. The 60-year-old former Communist Politburo member had been expected to win Romania's first multiparty election in 53 years last Sunday, but his overwhelming victory astonished many Romanians and foreign observers. Iliescu says he wants to turn Romania into a Swedish-style social democracy and that he will seek a coalition with the opposition. But his two opponents said they will seek to nullify the election on grounds of fraud and indicated it was unlikely they would join a national unity government. A monthlong protest by anti-Communist demonstrators in downtown Bucharest's University Square flared into what almost became a violent confrontation with government officials who tried to establish a dialogue. At least 4,000 protesters filled the square Tuesday night, shouting the election was a fraud. Silviu Brucan, the Front's power behind the scenes and one of its campaign organizers, said the turnout of more than 85 percent meant Romanians ``have passed magna cum laude the first class in democracy.'' But he said the Front's share of the vote was too high. ``This is no good for democracy because I stick to my statement that a strong opposition is essential in a democracy, particularly at a time when that democracy is in the making,'' he said. Iliescu, who announced Communist dictator Nicolae Ceausescu's execution at the climax of December's revolution, capitalized on his personality and his grassroots support from industrial workers and peasants. In an editorial, the outspoken independent daily Romania Libera said: ``The Front has won the elections but apparently it definitely alienated several million voters and the country has lost a chance, the chance to have a genuine political opposition in Parliament.'' Some foreign diplomats and observers monitoring the election said the Front's control of Parliament means it could overwhelm the process of writing a new constitution, which is to take place within 18 months. ``If the results are confirmed, this doesn't seem to be the result of a pluralist system and this worries me,'' said Adelaide Aglietta, a lawmaker from Italy's Green party, who was an observer for the European Parliament. ``I think people here were not helped to understand exactly what democracy means. They still think that other political parties are the enemies, and they haven't understood what a political dialogue in a democracy is,'' she told a news conference. Andreas Khol, leader of the European Democratic Union observer group, drawing together Western Europe's powerful conservative parties, said in Vienna the election did not give Iliescu or the Front the legitimacy of new governments in Hungary or Poland. He said it was an important step toward democracy but did not express ``the free will of the Romanian people.'' Khol said Western governments should refrain from granting Romanian aid and leave any help to private firms. But Robert Waring, a British lawmaker from the socialist Labor Party, called the election ``free and fair'' and said: ``When we get back we will tell the (British) government please, please help Romania with credits for investments to see that industries are re-equipped.'' With 13 million ballots counted Tuesday night, Iliescu had 85.9 percent of the vote, Radu Campeanu of the National Liberal Party had 10.3 percent and Ion Ratiu of the National Peasant Party 3.8 percent, according to the Central Electoral Bureau. More than 85 percent of the 16 eligible million voters cast ballots, authorities said. In the Senate race, the Front won 68.17 percent, the Liberals 6.46 percent, the Peasants 2.27 percent, the Ecological Movement 2.45 percent. In the lower Chamber of Deputies, the Front got 67.30 percent, the Liberals 6.0 percent, the Peasants 2.31, the Ecological Movement 2.69 percent. The Hungarian Democratic Union, apparently winning broad allegiance from Romania's 2 million ethnic Hungarians, emerged as the largest opposition party in Parliament, taking 7.41 percent in the Senate and 7.43 percent in the Chamber of Deputies. The other votes for the 506 parliamentary seats went to tiny parties. Justice Minister Teofil Pop was mobbed by protesters and government Secretary-General Sever Georgescu was grabbed by the collar when they visited 24 hunger strikers in University Square Tuesday night. Both had to flee. The hunger strikers want a ban on former Communist officials holding public office for 10 years.

DOC.HEAD: First Human Gene Transfer Opens New Cancer Treatment
DOC.NOTE: EDs: SUBS 4th graf pvs, Soon, however, to CORRECT spelling of factor; picks up 5th graf, This is
DOC.TEXT: Experiments have shown for the first time that human blood cells carrying foreign genes will zero in on tumors, opening a new strategy for treating cancer, researchers said Tuesday. The preliminary study, conducted on seven patients, is the first approved attempt at human gene therapy _ inserting potentially helpful genes inside the body in places where nature failed to put them. The experiment was intended to show that the approach was possible. Physicians introduced a bacterial gene that had no effect on the patients' cancer. Soon, however, they plan to equip patients' blood cells with a gene that delivers a powerful natural cancer-killing substance known as tumor necrosis factor. The researchers hope that will cure the disease by blitzing the tumor with extremely high levels of toxic proteins. ``This is the first study in which foreign genes have been introduced into humans with survival of those cells,'' said Dr. Steven A. Rosenberg. ``This is meant to pave the way to introducing genes that can improve the survival of cancer patients.'' His pilot study showed that not only did the cells survive, they homed in on tumors and produced a foreign protein there. Rosenberg outlined his results at the annual meeting of the American Society of Clinical Oncology. A more detailed report is scheduled to be published in the New England Journal of Medicine. Dr. Robert Young of Philadelphia's Fox Chase Cancer Center noted that while biologists have isolated genes that make potentially useful substances, transferring that knowledge from the petri dish to cancer patients has been difficult. ``The introduction of foreign genes and transferring them into human cells and putting them back into humans is an extremely important observation,'' Young said of Rosenberg's work. ``The potential of doing this and asking therapeutic questions is now possible.'' Rosenberg, a National Cancer Institute researcher, developed a cancer treatment known as adoptive immunotherapy intended to harness the body's own cancer-fighting chemicals to control the disease. His first results, using the protein interleukin-2, attracted wide attention when they were announced five years ago. Follow-up research showed only a small minority of patients, perhaps 5 percent to 10 percent, respond with complete reversal of the disease. The latest work is an attempt to boost the power of those natural chemicals by delivering them directly to the tumor. At Tuesday's meeting, Rosenberg described the results of experiments over the past year on his first five patients. First, doctors removed so-called tumor-infiltrating lymphocytes from each patient. Those are cancer-hunting white blood cells that had invaded the tumors of patients dying of melanoma, a form of skin cancer. Then, doctors isolated a gene that gives bacteria the ability to resist the antibiotic neomycin. They put that gene into a crippled virus, which in turn carried it into the patients' white blood cells. Finally, they multiplied the blood cells in test tubes with interleukin-2, a growth hormone, injecting 200 billion of those cells into each patient. Because the cells carried a bacterial gene, doctors could track them through the patients' bodies. They found that the manipulated cells persisted in the blood for up to 189 days. They performed biopsies on two patients and found the cells in the tumors, making the bacterial protein, 64 days after the injections. All of the patients treated were expected to die within three months. Two of them responded well to the boosted levels of tumor-infiltrating cells, and the melanoma has disappeared in one completely for 10 months. Rosenberg said the experiment worked just as his team had hoped. ``There were no suprises in this,'' he said. ``I am looking forward to trials that hopefully will help cancer patients.'' He said he and colleagues had already succeeded in inserting the gene that makes tumor necrosis factor into human blood cells. Those cells make 100 times higher levels of the protein than are ordinarily present. Rosenberg said he hoped to win approval within a few months from several regulating committees so he can try the next step on melanoma patients.

DOC.HEAD: Kuwait Professors Strike for Democracy
DOC.TEXT: About 70 Kuwaiti University professors staged a two-hour sit-in Tuesday at the Faculty of Law to protest what they said was an assault on the constitution. In a statement, they condemned as ``a violation of the Islamic principles and the rules of the constitution'' moves to replace the elected Parliament, dissolved in 1986, with a partially appointed body. The professors called the recently decreed interim Parliament, with 25 of its 75 members selected by the Emir of Kuwait, Sheik Jaber al-Ahmed al-Sabah, ``a bolt of lightning on the heads of those who uphold the constitution.'' They short of calling for a boycott of the June 10 parliamentary elections. Parliament was dissolved in 1976 and 1986 in the name of public interest after vitriolic attacks by the deputies against government ministers.

DOC.HEAD: Iraqi Official Claims Western Attack Behind Fears of `Super Gun'
DOC.TEXT: Iraq and the Palestine Liberation Organization claimed Tuesday that Western allegations about a ``super gun'' said to be able to launch nuclear weapons at Israel were a prelude to an attack against Iraqi installations. But Arab diplomatic sources, requesting anonymity, also said Tuesday that Iraq was behind a conciliatory message to be sent to the United States and Soviet Union at their summit May 30. Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz and the PLO's political department chief, Farouk Kaddoumi, linked Western charges about an Iraqi weapon to the influx of Soviet Jews into Israel, and the weekend killing of seven Arab laborers near Tel Aviv. An increase in Jewish immigrants in Israel is seen as a threat to Arab settlers in Israeli-occupied territories. The two officials said these were anti-Arab developments that could lead to an attack on Iraq. ``There's no doubt that this political and propaganda campaign ... is a prelude for a strike against our technological and scientific installations,'' Aziz told the Arab foreign ministers. They spoke at the inaugural session of an Arab foreign ministers meeting at the Al-Rashid Hotel. The meeting convened to prepare for a special summit of Arab leaders in Baghdad set for May 28. The summit was called by PLO chairman Yasser Arafat to discuss the emigration of hundreds of thousands of Soviet Jews to Israel. Iraq asked that its confrontation with the West be included on the agenda. ``Jerusalem is calling you, O leaders of the Arab world,'' said banners flying in the streets of the Iraqi capital. Others said, ``Arab unity is the shield against threats to our scientific development.'' But efforts to achieve the long-sought unity suffered a setback Tuesday when Syria and Lebanon failed to show up. Damascus had said it would not attend a summit in Iraq, its main Arab foe. Lebanon, two-thirds of its territory under control of 40,000 Syrian troops, had said it would participate if all other Arabs did. Iraqi President Saddam Hussein brushed aside the feud with Syria, ruled by a rival wing of the Arab Baath Socialist Party. He sent an envoy to Damascus on Monday to persuade President Hafez Assad to change his mind, but Assad refused. Arafat had insisted the Arab meeting be held before the May 30-June 3 superpower summit between President Bush and Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev in Washington. Arab diplomatic sources, insisting on anonymity, said the Arab leaders would send a message, drafted by Iraq, to Bush and Gorbachev. It urges Bush and Gorbachev to work for reviving Arab-Israeli peace initiatives and to curtail Jewish immigration to Israel. The letter requests that the United States and Europe open their borders to some immigrants. The message also reassures Washington and Moscow that Iraq's scientific and technological projects were for peaceful purposes. Britain said in March it confiscated a shipment of 40 electronic capacitors destined for Iraq. The devices can be used to trigger nuclear weapons. Shortly after, Britain impounded steel tubes it said was part of a giant gun. Greece, Turkey and Italy later said they seized shipments that may have been components of the gun.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Signs Biological Weapons Bill
DOC.TEXT: President Bush on Tuesday signed into law a bill making it illegal to develop and possess biological weapons. ``I call upon the leaders of all nations to join us in our drive to rid the world of biological and chemical weapons and to do everything in their power to stop the proliferation of these weapons of mass destruction,'' Bush said in a statement. Praising Congress for passing the legislation, Bush saluted the leadership for its commitment ``to our shared goal of destroying forever the evil shadow these weapons have cast around the world.'' The measure puts into effect a 1972 treaty against biological weapons. Biological weapons are harmful forms of bacteria, viruses, fungi or naturally occuring toxins that could be directed at an enemy. A biological weapon could be unleashed on an unsuspecting public by using it in a liquid to contaminate water or in an aerosol that is dropped by bomb. In 1925, the Geneva Protocol banned the first use in war of biological and chemical weapons, but did not address the development, production, possession or transfer of the weapons. Forty-four years later, President Nixon ordered the Defense Department to destroy its arsenal of biological weapons. The United States then spearheaded the fight for an international ban on production and possession of them. On April 10, 1972, in Washington, Moscow and London, 111 countries signed the Biological Weapons Convention, which prohibits production and possession of the weapons.

DOC.HEAD: Three Men Killed and One Seriously Injured By Falling Beams
DOC.TEXT: Falling beams killed three workers and seriously injured a fourth Tuesday at a construction site at Ohio State University, officials said. Richard T. Lombardi, vice president of Turner Construction, which managed the construction site, said the workers were erecting beams for the glass and granite four-story building when the accident occurred in the late morning. He said it hadn't been determined how many beams fell or what caused them to collapse. Work was halted at least for the day and federal investigators from the Occupational Safety and Health Administration were at the scene, Lombardi said.

DOC.HEAD: East Germany Brings 1st Criminal Charges Against Communist Official
DOC.TEXT: East Germany on Tuesday accused a former top Communist official of squandering government money, the first formal criminal charges to be brought against a member of the old regime. Also Tuesday, lawmakers from the ruling coalition called for the resignation of Interior Minister Peter-Michael Diestel for trying to use an ex-Communist spymaster as an adviser and for failing to fully dismantle the former government's system of police informers. Peter Przbylski, a spokesman for the federal prosecutor's office, said Werner Krolikowski, 61, a member of the former Communist Party's ruling Politburo and a deputy prime minister, faces trial in an East Berlin city court on charges of abuse of trust. No trial date has been set, he said. The charge carries a maximum penalty of five years in prison. Krolikowski has been under house arrest since authorities began investigating past abuses of the former regime early this year. He has been accused of using his powerful position to build homes with swimming pools for his son. Przbylski said the properties were worth in excess of $600,000. Although he is the first former top official to be charged with a crime, he may also be the last. Several members of the aging old guard are not expected to see the inside of a courtroom. Former Communist Party leader Erich Honecker, 88, and several other officials ousted in last October's pro-democracy revolt are under investigation for abuse of power, corruption and other charges, but many of the charges have been dropped. Honecker is in a Soviet sanitorium in East Germany and is reported seriously ill. Diestel, a member of the coalition government that replaced the Communists, has come under increased fire for what critics say is his unwillingness to purge his interior ministry of police linked with the old regime. On Tuesday, lawmakers from his own political party called for his resignation. ``He has not smashed the old structure of the Ministry for State Security,'' said Juergen Schwarz, a spokesman for the German Social Union delegation in Parliament. Schwarz said a majority of lawmakers believe that ``the mistrust is pronounced and his resignation is urged.'' Diestel said he was ``surprised and troubled'' by the call for his resignation. Members of Prime Minister Lothar de Maiziere's Christian Democratic Union have also called for Diestel's resignation. West German and East German lawmakers have joined in sharply criticizing Diestel for trying to bring in former Communist spymaster Markus Wolf, who is wanted in West Germany, to help with the dissolution of East Germany's notorious Communist secret police. Critics say Diestel still has hundreds of members of the former secret police on the payroll and has shown little enthusiasm for investigating past crimes of the much-feared security network.

DOC.BYLINE: Hopes For European Accord This Year Is Fading
DOC.TEXT: A treaty to sharply reduce U.S. and Soviet troops in Europe is unlikely to be concluded by the end of the year unless a half-dozen thorny issues are settled this summer, a senior Bush administration official said Tuesday. Soviet concerns about German unification and about the reliability of its Warsaw Pact allies are leading reasons for the setback, the official said at a White House briefing. President Bush predicted a year ago that the treaty would be completed within six to 12 months. It would be signed by 35 nations at a summit meeting in Paris. Since then, however, most of the Soviet allies in the Warsaw Pact have replaced hard-line governments with more moderate regimes. West Germany and East Germany are on track to unify this summer. Secretary of State James A. Baker III was unable to overcome the slump in troop negotiations during four days of talks last week in Moscow. But he reached agreement with President Mikhail S. Gorbachev and Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze to cut U.S. and Soviet nuclear-tipped cruise missiles and to end production of chemical weapons. Bush and Gorbachev are expected to act on both agreements at their summit meeting in Washington May 31-June 3. Before the slow-down, the United States and the Soviet Union agreed last December on new troop levels in Europe _ 195,000 for each in Central Europe and an additional 30,000 U.S. troops in Western Europe. To get down to that ceiling, the Soviets would have to pull some 400,000 troops back behind their borders; about 100,000 Americans would come home. The treaty also would set limits on battle tanks, artillery, armored combat vehicles, combat aircraft and combat helicopters, requiring cutbacks in all categories. The purpose of the treaty is to reduce East-West tensions across the vast expanse of Europe _ from the Atlantic in the West to the Ural Mountains in the Soviet Union. The negotiations technically are being conducted by the North Atlantic Treaty Organization and the Warsaw Pact. But the negotiators, in Vienna, take their cues from the United States and the Soviet Union. The official said there is disagreement over aircraft, tanks, troop limits, how weapons would be destroyed and over safeguards against cheating. He said the Soviets did not engage in ``serious'' negotiations with Baker on these issues in Moscow. But the official stressed the slow-down had deeper causes _ what he called ``the dissolution'' of the Warsaw Pact and concerns about German unification. ``If we don't have substantive agreement by this summer it will be hard to have a treaty by the end of the year,'' he said. That would mean postponing the Paris summit of NATO, Warsaw Pact and neutral nations, as well, the official said. Having lost some 20 million people _ some estimates are as high as 26 million _ in World War II, the Soviets are apprehensive about confronting a powerful German army while their own troops and tanks are being scaled back. Also, the Warsaw Pact countries that stood between Germany and the Soviet Union are drifting away.

DOC.HEAD: Lawmakers Ask Bush to Lift AIDS Immigration Restrictions
DOC.NOTE: EDS: SUBS grafs 4-9 pvs, bgng Robert Schmermund, to ADD HHS comment
DOC.TEXT: Two members of Congress called on the Bush administration on Tuesday to use its authority to lift immigration restrictions on people infected with the AIDS virus. The administration says only Congress can change the restrictions. But Reps. Henry Waxman, D-Calif., and J. Roy Rowland, D-Ga., said that according to a legal opinion from the General Accounting Office, the administration has the power to modify the AIDS exclusion policy. ``The policy should be changed now,'' Waxman said. A statement issued by the Department of Health and Human Services said that officials read ``with interest'' the GAO legal opinion, but still hold to the administration's view. The administration has maintained it lacks the authority to lift the restrictions because they were ordered by Congress. In 1987, Congress directed the president to add infection with the AIDS virus to a list of diseases used to bar entry to the United States. ``The administration continues to believe that the issue of amending or reversing this recent congressional mandate, imposed on the president by a vote of 96-0 (in the Senate), rests with the Congress,'' the statement said. Officials at the federal Centers for Disease Control in Atlanta in March recommended that infection with the AIDS virus be removed from the list. Rowland and Waxman introduced a bill last month that would give federal health officials authority over the list of contagious diseases. But in view of the GAO opinion, Waxman said, ``the question is now plainly before the president.'' The department's statement said the extent of the administration's power was that the attorney general could grant waivers to aliens infected with the AIDS virus for temporary visits. In that regard, the administration announced last month a new 10-day visa for foreigners attending certain White House-approved conferences in the United States. Travelers with the visa do not have to reveal whether they are infected with the AIDS virus. The action was taken in response to criticism from international organizations that have said they will boycott an international conference on AIDS in San Francisco next month.

DOC.HEAD: Bernstein Cancels Appearance At Spoleto Opening
DOC.TEXT: Leonard Bernstein canceled his appearance at Friday's opening gala at the Spoleto Festival U.S.A. because the composer is recovering from pneumonia, festival organizers announced Tuesday. ``We're all shocked. We only heard about it yesterday. He is a very sick man and he absolutely can't come,'' said Gian Carlo Menotti, the Pulitzer prize-winning composer who founded the American festival in 1977. Bernstein, 71, was to have conducted Beethoven's Symphony No. 7 in a concert opening the 14th festival and celebrating Charleston's recovery from the ravages of Hurricane Hugo. The event has been sold out for weeks. ``People who love music will come anyway,'' Menotti said. ``People who want to look at some rare star will probably want their money back.'' During the festival's second year, in 1978, the composer of ``West Side Story'' was scheduled to conduct three concerts. He withdrew because his wife, Felicia, was critically ill with cancer. She died in June of that year. ``This time it is the doctor's orders pure and simple,'' Bernstein wrote in a letter to Menotti, even offering to provide a written doctor's excuse. ``I am in the process of recovering from a brush with pneumonia and a complete week's rest has been imposed upon me,'' the conductor said in a statement issued in New York. More than 2,700 purchased tickets for the opening gala, paying as much as $150 for seats which includes a formal dinner following the concert. Festival officials said they would not refund tickets prior to the concert. Menotti, saying ``our specialty is miracles,'' announced the festival will instead stage a concert featuring mezzo-soprano Tatiana Troyanos, 18-year-old violinist Midori and conductor Julius Rudel.

DOC.HEAD: State Health Officials Try to Solve Mystery Disease.
DOC.TEXT: State health officials have no explanation for a mystery illness which has stricken at least seven children and possibly many others, prompting hundreds of calls from worried parents. ``We are in for the long haul,'' Dr. Dennis Perrotta, the Texas Department of Health's director of epidemiology in Austin, said Tuesday. ``This is going to be a tough one.'' The disease causes high fevers, debilitating joint pain, sore throats and rashes. It has been confirmed in seven children between the ages of 3 and 12. Some of the children have been hospitalized for up to a month. So far, none of the cases has been fatal and victims seem to make a full recovery, said Dr. Jeffrey W. Jundt, who has treated the seven confirmed cases. State health officials said Tuesday they have gotten 200 to 300 calls from concerned parents and others since word first surfaced in newspapers during the weekend. Investigators from the Centers for Disease Control in Atlanta have been called. Jundt, an arthritis specialist at Scott & White Memorial Hospital and Clinic in Temple, said the seven confirmed cases appeared in rural east and central Texas. The ailment has been dubbed ``Palestine Fever,'' after the East Texas town in which the three earliest cases surfaced starting in March. Palestine is about 100 miles southeast of Dallas. ``We traveled to Temple and Palestine and talked to the physicians and visited with the some of the families,'' Perrotta said. ``We have corroborated what Dr. Jundt has told us. We have not been able to come up with the answer. It does look like there are more cases.'' He said the department would probably complete an exposure questionnaire by Wednesday and begin collecting more followup information by the week's end. The treatment involves aspirin and antibiotics, Jundt said. He sees a similarity between this ailment and Lyme disease, a tick-borne illness. ``Lyme disease had been going on for a long time,'' Jundt said. But it wasn't recognized until a cluster of cases at Lyme, Conn., raised a question, he said. ``There's a possibility this disease has been around for a while,'' he said. One patient, 11-year-old Michael Sharp of Copperas Cove, lost 21 pounds in the seven weeks he suffered from the ailment.

DOC.HEAD: Former Laos Soldier Faces Deportation on Drug Charge
DOC.TEXT: A Laotian man who used opium to treat an 18-year-old war wound faces deportation proceedings under a federal law his attorney says wasn't intended for cases like his. Chao Yang, 38, says he began smoking opium as a painkiller in 1972 after his knee was shattered by a bullet during a battle with North Vietnamese soldiers in Laos. Still using crutches, Yang is in custody at Sherburne County Jail, waiting to see if the government wants to deport him because he shipped opium through the mail. He was admitted to the country seeking political asylum, and the decision on his application has yet to be made. Attorney Sam Myers said Yang faces deportation proceedings because of a 1988 law that Congress enacted to crack down on foreign drug kingpins. ``I think everyone was surprised, because I don't think anybody realized this would be the effect of the law,'' Myers said. Myers said the government agrees Yang is not a drug dealer. In Laos, ethnic Hmong people have cultivated opium for generations, and many used it the way Westerners use over-the-counter painkillers. When he emigrated to the United States in 1985, Yang, who is Hmong, tried legal medications. ``He went to St. Paul-Ramsey (Medical Center) and all they gave him was Tylenol. Geez, that didn't do any good,'' Myers said. Yang went back to opium. After his arrest in April 1989, Yang was convicted on drug charges and served six months in a federal medical prison in Rochester. When he finished his sentence last month, he planned to return to his wife and two teen-age daughters in St. Paul. But under the Omnibus Crime and Control Act of 1988, Yang was held without a court hearing by the Immigration and Naturalization Service. The law was designed to prevent foreign citizens convicted of drug offenses from fleeing automatic deportation efforts. Myers said Yang is not a flight risk. Complicating the case is a Washington order barring the immigration service from sending immigrants back to Vietnam, Cambodia or Laos because many fled political persecution and face prison or death if they return. Myers said he will challenge the constitutionality of the act's provision that allow detention without a bail hearing. Yang's deportation hearing was scheduled for July 25 in Minneapolis. ``If one is looking for a bad guy here, it's Congress,'' Myers said. ``Because Congress passed a law that allowed for no exceptions, and any time you pass a law with no exceptions, you're just begging for injustice.''

DOC.HEAD: Texas-Sized Thunderstorms and Record Northeast Cold
DOC.TEXT: Thunderstorms battered the Texas Gulf Coast with rain, hail and a tornado Tuesday, while the northeast was chilled with a record cold snap. In Arkansas, where torrential weekend rains produced serious flash flooding, the Ouachita River was significantly above flood stage early Tuesday and near crest at Arkadelphia in the south-central part of the state. The degree of flooding is expected to decrease significantly as the crest moves downstream. Snow fell across northern Maine at noon, and the morning was unseasonably cool in much of New England and eastern New York. Rainshowers extended over the central coast of New England. Showers also were scattered over northern Minnesota, eastern North Dakota, southeastern South Dakota and northeast Nebraska, and from southwest Washington across western Oregon and northern California. Showers and thunderstorms reached from central Virginia across West Virginia, northwestern North Carolina, northeast Tennessee and eastern Kentucky. There also were storms over the northern and central portion of the Florida peninsula and the Florida panhandle. And storms hit the lower and central Gulf Coast in Texas, where a tornado touched down west of Port O'Connor at about noon. Small hail and almost two inches of rain fell at nearby Palacios between 2 p.m. and 3 p.m. EDT. Heavier rainfall during the six hours ending at 2 p.m. EDT included 1.28 inches in Victoria, Tex., an dan inch at Cape Hatteras, N.C. A cold front moved across the Pacific northwest, south-central Oregon and the northern coast of California toward the Pacific Ocean. The colder temperatures were expected to bring snow to the mountains of northern California. The forecast for Wednesday included rain from northern California to the northwest, showers from the central to the northern Rockies and for New York, New England, Wisconsin and eastern Nebraska. The low temperature for the nation Tuesday morning was 31 degrees at Cutbank, Mt. Temperatures around the nation at 3 p.m. EDT ranged from 34 degrees at Houlton, Me., to 96 degrees at Phoenix, Ariz.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: For Release at 8:01 p.m. EDT. Time Set by Source.
DOC.HEAD: Amnesty Says Pakistan Human Rights Record Improving
DOC.TEXT: Amnesty International said Wednesday that Pakistan's human rights record has improved under Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto, but abuses reportedly persist, including torture, rape and whippings. The report by the worldwide human rights group said 2,029 death sentences were commuted after Mrs. Bhutto took office in October 1988, thousands of prisoners were freed, and compensation was promised for torture victims. But Amnesty said ``scores of people were reportedly tortured in police stations last year, including at least eight women who were allegedly raped. Torture in prisons has decreased but is still likely to recur as those responsible have not been brought to trial.'' The allegations appear in the summary of a memorandum submitted to the Bhutto government following an Amnesty visit to Pakistan last summer.
