It said ``whipping remains as a punishment for certain crimes; fetters are used in prisons; imprisonment on religious grounds continues.'' Also, special courts ``which do not conform to international standards for fair trials can impose the death penalty and try certain political offenses.'' ``The government has taken some steps to monitor police abuses by setting up a body to monitor police atrocities,'' the report says. But it calls for further safeguards including strict limits on incommunicado detention; prompt access to lawyers, doctors and relatives; prompt referrals to magistrates; independent investigations of torture allegations; and special measures to protect detained women and children. It said whipping, amputation and stoning to death, introduced by the previous government of the late President Mohammed Zia ul-Haq, remain on the law books and that two public floggings took place last year. ``Fetters are still used on prisoners, including children.'' While thousands of prisoners jailed under Zia's martial law were released, ``several hundred martial law convicts remain imprisoned, including possible political prisoners.'' The report says special anti-terrorism courts are increasingly used in Sind Province, where internal violence has left thousands dead in the past years. The courts fail to meet international standards for fair trial because they presume the defendant guilty in certain circumstances, it said.

DOC.HEAD: Senator Criticizes Romania Government's Election Behavior
DOC.TEXT: Romania's newly formed government tolerated violence and voter intimidation before last Sunday's national elections, the co-leader of an international observer team said Tuesday. Sen. Joseph Lieberman, D-Conn., just back from Bucharest after monitoring Romania's first free elections in 53 years, said the United States should supply humanitarian aid immediately. But he said further aid should be conditioned on the new government's ability to move toward democracy. ``There was a lot of unfairness in the pre-election process,'' Lieberman told reporters. ``Some of it was intentional by the government party and some of it was unintentional.'' A problem facing the opposition parties, he said, was a lack of time to organize a campaign against the governing party, which dominated media outlets. ``What happened on Sunday was a significant step forward toward democracy but there is a lot more to be done,'' Lieberman said. ``They've come a long way; they deserve some help. But they also need some pressure to continue to move toward more human rights, more political freedom, and greater recognition of the rights of minorities, particularly Hungarians.'' According to results reported Tuesday, interim President Ion Iliescu defeated the opposition in Romania's election with 85.9 percent of the vote. The victory was expected but the margin was large enough to worry some observers and even some in Iliescu's own party about the goal of establishing a true democracy with a strong opposition party. Iliescu's two opponents said they will seek to nullify the election on grounds of fraud and indicated it was unlikely they would join a national unity government. And at least 4,000 protesters filled Bucharest's University Square shouting that the election was a fraud. Lieberman, who said the Romanian capital was still riddled with bullet holes from the fighting that led to the overthrow of dictator Nicolae Ceausescu, said ``violence and intimidation'' were reported by members of the opposition parties. But he said the reports of telephone harassment and even some beatings could not be linked conclusively to the Iliescu government. ``While I could not conclude that the government party and the president himself had anything directly to do with that violence and intimidation, the president did not go out of his way to condemn it,'' Lieberman said, ``and I think that contributed to an unfortunate atmosphere there.'' Lieberman said the United States should provide training and emergency aid, particularly for babies in Romanian orphanages, many of whom have suffered from a lack of medical care. ``But we ought not to write a blank and permanent check to the government,'' he said. ``Long-term funding should be made contingent upon continued movement toward democracy.'' Lieberman was one of three co-leaders of a 60-member international delegation sponsored by the National Democratic Institute for International Affairs. The group is chaired by former Vice President Walter Mondale and includes many prominent Democrats among its senior advisers.

DOC.HEAD: People in the News
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4th item to CLARIFY that car wasn't sold.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto NY44
DOC.TEXT: Zsa Zsa Gabor's Rolls-Royce had no star appeal for bidders at the annual Bennett Investor Auction, who offered less than half the value. ``Perhaps the right-wing audience didn't respond to it,'' Terry Cooper, spokesman for the auction, said Monday. Auctioneers said the actress was driving the Rolls when she had her renowned run-in with a Beverly Hills motorcycle policeman. A California jury convicted her of charges alleging she slapped the officer after he stopped her. The Rolls drew a $23,000 bid, too low to bring a sale, Cooper said. Appraisers estimated the Rolls was worth more than twice that, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Doctors Release Transplant Patient
DOC.TEXT: Stormie Jones, the world's longest surviving heart-liver transplant patient, was released from a hospital Tuesday and doctors said a mild episode of liver rejection appeared to be under control. ``We're out of the hospital and are staying with friends,'' said Stormie's mother, Lois ``Suzie'' Purcell. ``She's doing better. ... They know she doesn't like to be in the hospital, so they are trying to make it as comfortable for her as possible.'' Stormie could return to her White Settlement, Texas, home within a few days, possibly by May 31, her 13th birthday, Mrs. Purcell said. Stormie returned to Children's Hospital of Pittsburgh on Sunday after routine tests showed high liver enzyme levels, a sign of possible organ rejection. Further tests revealed the rejection was moderate and could be controlled with increased doses of an experimental anti-rejection medication Stormie has taken since November, said hospital spokeswoman Sue Cardillo. Doctors do not think Stormie will need a third liver transplant. Stormie takes FK-506, which the Food and Drug Administration approved for use only at Children's and nearby Presbyterian-University Hospital. She received the drug intravenously in the hospital and will resume taking it orally. Dr. Robert D. Gordon, transplant surgeon at Children's, said Monday, ``When you're using a new drug you're a little sensitive to toxicity, over-sensitive perhaps. We now realize we lowered our dosages a little too much.'' Modifications in dosages also will be made for many of the 400 transplant patients currently taking FK-506. ``I think we've been making that error systematically over the last few months,'' Gordon said. In 1984, Stormie received the double transplant to control a congenital condition that left her cholesterol levels 10 times higher than normal. She returned to Pittsburgh for a second liver transplant, performed early this year, after hepatitis damaged her first donor liver.

DOC.HEAD: Democrat Wants Social Security Off-Limits to Budget Cuts
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Top 11 grafs new with meeting over, new figures; picks up 4th graf pvs, Sasser, in
DOC.TEXT: White House and congressional negotiators moved toward a consensus on Tuesday that they must find about $500 billion in new taxes and spending cuts over the next five years to balance the budget, participants said. At the third round of high-level deficit-reduction talks in the Capitol, the Bush administration also unveiled a new, higher estimate of the costs of rescuing the savings and loan industry. The administration now says the bailout could cost as much as $61 billion next year, participants said, about $11 billion higher than previous estimates. Democrats and Republicans remained divided over precisely how much savings would be needed to balance the budget within five years. Democrats said $500 billion or more was necessary, citing estimates by the non-partisan Congressional Budget Office. Republicans said the total necessary could be between $400 billion to $500 billion. They relied on projections by the White House's Office of Management and Budget, which until now has been saying that an improving economy will allow the budget to be balanced by 1995. OMB presented figures Tuesday showing that unless action is taken, the budget would still be $32 billion in the red in 1995. Nonetheless, both sides emerged from their meeting having narrowed their differences somewhat over the size of the deficit problem the government faces. They also spoke optimistically about their prospects for finding a solution. ``The future looks very good to me in terms of us being able to get it done,'' said Sen. Pete Domenici of New Mexico, ranking Republican on the Senate Budget Committee. ``There's no consensus yet, but I don't think we'd characterize the meetings as containing any sharp disagreements,'' said Senate Budget Committee Chairman James Sasser, D-Tenn. Negotiators did not discuss proposals for how budget savings would be achieved, a stage that participants say is weeks away. Tuesday's three-hour session was dominated by technical discussions by White House and congressional budget experts about how large the federal deficit appears to be. ``We're continuing to define the problem,'' Sasser said. Participants said the administration's new estimated costs of the savings and loan bailout remained uncertain. House Budget Committee Chairman Leon Panetta, D-Calif., called the $61 billion figure ``a real hit-and-miss number.'' Before Tuesday's meeting, Sasser said he believed Social Security benefits should be off-limits as negotiators search for ways to shrink next year's federal deficit. Sasser, in stating his opposition to paring Social Security payments, raised an issue nearly as politically sensitive as the question of new taxes. Members of both parties are reluctant to antagonize the nation's 39 million retirees who receive Social Security benefits. Republicans lawmakers in particular have been cautious on the issue ever since they backed an effort to limit benefits in 1985 from which then-President Reagan eventually backed away. Sasser conceded that negotiators would ``talk about everything, but said it would be unfair to turn to Social Security for deficit reduction. The payroll tax paid by workers and their employers has been boosted this year, he said, noting that the Social Security system is running an annual surplus of tens of billions of dollars. ``I don't see the equity in that,'' Sasser said of benefit cutbacks. Social Security is expected to cost the government about $265 billion next year, about one-fifth of the total budget. Advocates of trimming benefits as part of a deficit-reduction package argue that it comprises too large a portion of the budget to ignore. The retirement system is expected to run a $74 billion surplus next year as it builds up a cushion to pay for retiring baby boomers in the next century. The payroll tax rate edged up by 0.14 percent in January to 7.65 percent. It's likely to be several meetings before budget negotiators begin swapping proposals about cutting the deficit for the next fiscal year, which begins Oct. 1. The opening discussions have focused on technical issues. The goal of the talks is to find ways to reduce the 1991 shortfall to $64 billion, the target set by the Gramm-Rudman deficit-reduction law. If the budget gap exceeds that amount by $10 billion, the law triggers whatever spending cuts are necessary to lower the gap to $64 billion. The White House has been increasing its projection of the 1991 deficit since January, when it said a $100 billion shortfall was likely. Last week, the administration estimated the shortfall at between $123 billion and $138 billion. That excluded the costs of shoring up the savings and loan industry, which could have a $50 billion pricetag. The non-partisan Congressional Budget Office estimates a 1991 budget gap between $149 billion and $159 billion. With the thrift bailout, the gap could grow to as much as $246 billion, CBO said.

DOC.HEAD: North, South Yemen Unite to Form One Nation
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS three grafs after 11th graf pvs `Saudi foreign' to UPDATE with U.S. reaction. Pickup 12th graf pvs, `The merger...' ADDS final graf with background on mergers. EDITS to Trim
DOC.TEXT: North and South Yemen joined Tuesday to become one nation, the Republic of Yemen, an impoverised country sitting on newly discovered oil reserves. Gen. Ali Abdullah Saleh, the president of the unified state, raised the new country's red, white and black flag atop the portside Presidential Council building at noon. The Coast Guard fired several cannon shots, and anchored vessels blew their whistles. The republic is poor but has recently located oil reserves unofficially put at 2 billion barrels. The nation sits on the strategically located Bab al-Mandab, a strait at the southern outlet of the Red Sea into the Indian Ocean. Saleh said at a rally that the republic will honor all treaties either of the former countries concluded. About 2,000 people attended and interrupted Saleh's address several times with loud applause. ``The Republic of Yemen will be a factor for stability and security in the Arabian Peninsula and the gulf region and a strong bastion for the Arab nations, the Arab League and joint Arab action,'' Saleh said. ``The Republic of Yemen will extend its hand to all states for fruitful cooperation in fulfilling our national duties, led by those toward the Palestinian people,'' he added. Palestine Liberation Organization Chairman Yasser Arafat was the only Arab leader who attended the ceremony. He delivered a brief congratulatory message. Arab foreign ministers meeting in the Iraqi capital, Baghdad, to prepare for an Arab summit hailed the unification. Saudi Foreign Minister Prince Saud al-Faisal said it would improve ``the stability of the region.'' In Washington, State Department spokeswoman Margaret Tutwiler said the United States welcomed the union and will review its listing of South Yemen as a country that supports terrorism. ``We welcome this declaration as a measure that could improve stability and security in the region,'' she told reporters. ``Obviously it has not changed that South Yemen is on the terrorist list in the hours that this has taken place.'' Saleh met with President Bush at the White House last January and the United States resumed diplomatic relations with South Yemen last April 30 after a break of nearly 21 years. The merger was approved Monday by the parliaments of the former countries. It was pushed through several days earlier than planned so the Yemens could attend the Arab summit as one nation. The new nation has 11 million people _ 9 million from the north and 2 million from the south _ and is one of the poorest countries in the world. South Yemen became the Arab world's only Marxist state after it gained independence from Britain in 1967. Although it received aid from the Soviet Union, the south's economy had languished for 20 years, and there had been widespread labor unrest in recent months. Some Arab diplomatic sources said the south endorsed unity mainly because of the democratic reforms sweeping Eastern Europe. Scores of Cuban and East German military experts are said to have left the south in recent months. A friendship pact entitles the Soviets to maintain as many as 18,000 troops in Yemen, but the extent of their deployment is unknown. San`a will be the capital of the new state, and Aden the main commercial center. San`a was formerly the capital of the north and Aden the capital of the south. Saleh, 48, was elected president of the five-man Presidential Council that will rule Yemen. Ali Salem al-Beidh, the secretary-general of the socialist party that had ruled the south, was elected vice-president. The three others on the Presidential Council are Salem Saleh Mohammed, al-Beidh's deputy; Abdul-Aziz al-Arashi, a lawmaker from the north; and Abdul-Aziz Abdul-Ghani, the former prime minister of the north. A planned transition period of 2{ years coincides with the remainder of the five-year terms for the legislatures of the former nations. It was the second such union between two Arab states in this century. Egypt and Syria joined for three years as the United Arab Republic, but the merger collapsed in 1961 with Damascus accusing Cairo of betrayal and of wrecking its economy.

DOC.HEAD: Protesters Chase Romanian Official
With AM-Romania, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Hundreds of demonstrators chased a high-ranking government representative into a downtown hotel Tuesday evening, forcing him to abandon his attempt to hold a dialogue with hunger strikers. Anti-communist protesters have occupied University Square and blocked the capital's central intersection since April 22. On Tuesday, the government made its most determined effort to date to establish a dialogue with the demonstrators. Justice Minister Teofil Pop and Sever Georgescu, the government's secretary general, were sent to speak to 24 hunger strikers, some of whom have been without food for more than three weeks. Six of the hunger strikers passed out but were revived Monday. The demonstrators _ who numbered at least 4,000 Tuesday _ and hunger strikers have been demanding the exclusion from politics of former Communists, such as interim President Ion Iliescu. The protesters now also are charging that Sunday's election was fraudulent. They are demanding a televised dialogue with Iliescu and Prime Minister Petre Roman. Iliescu and his National Salvation Front won resounding victories in Sunday's elections. They have dominated political life here since dictator Nicolae Ceausescu was deposed and executed in the December revolution. The hunger strikers had not been informed of the delegation's impending arrival, but news media were notified and dozens of journalists converged on the crowded tent encampment in the square. ``We have had enough of the BBC and the Americans, who acknowledged the government,'' said Dumitru Dinca, a spokesman for the Anti-Totalitarian Front protest group. ``We shall do justice by ourselves, without either the Russians or the Americans.'' When Georgescu arrived he was surrounded menacingly by a fast-growing crowd of people who took him for Interior Minister Mihai Chitac, whose resignation has been demanded by the protesters. The crowd grew increasingly vocal and violent. Then one protester grabbed Georgescu by the collar, forcing him to flee into the Intercontinental Hotel. He left the hotel through a back door as hundreds of whistling, booing protesters berated him and shouted: ``You thieves stole the revolution!'' Pop continued talking with the hunger strikers without being disturbed. But as he tried to leave he, too, was surrounded by angry demonstrators and had to be protected by hunger strikers as he plowed his way to his official car. The government later released a statement saying its representatives ``were unable to hold a dialogue with the hunger strikers because of the aggressive intervention of some people .. . who, through their violence, gave their political demands a profoundly undemocratic character.'' ``These people are violating the laws of the country both in their political actions and in their physical aggression against the representatives of the government ... in violation of the elementary laws governing public peace and order.'' Iliescu called for the square to be ``cleaned out'' last week, but the goverment chose to tolerate the demonstration through the election.

DOC.HEAD: British Defense Chief Raises Possibility of Delayed Arms Talks
With AM-NATO
DOC.TEXT: British Defense Secretary Tom King on Tuesday raised the possibility that negotiators would fail to wrap up an accord this year to slash troops, tanks and other non-nuclear weapons in Europe. ``We haven't got (an) agreement yet and ... we aren't sure when we're going to get one,'' King told reporters at a meeting of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization. Western officials have complained in recent weeks that the Soviet Union has slowed progress in reaching a conventional arms treaty, although they have said they were optimistic a deal could be struck in the fall. The West has insisted an agreement must be reached before the holding of a summit of leaders of the 35 nations that form the Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe. The Soviets have urged the conference be held this year. The key two-day NATO meeting was to review what U.S. Defense Secretary Dick Cheney called ``new ways of doing business'' in an era of reduced East-West tensions. On Monday, West European defense ministers, meeting separately at the alliance headquarters in Brussels, urged NATO to ``adapt to the changing security environment.'' As an example of new strategy in response to the impending unification of Germany, Cheney said a NATO corps could be formed with divisions from different nations. Such a force would also ``emphasize the fact that (Germany) is not treated any differently than anyone else,'' he told reporters aboard his flight to Brussels. King, who met with high-level Soviet officials in Moscow last week, said there was ``certainly a risk'' that a conventional arms agreement would not be reached this year. ``We're not happy about it,'' he said. ``We want to see an early resolution. There's no change in our position.'' West German Defense Minister Gerhard Stoltenberg told reporters in a separate news conference that the arms talks have become more complicated. Negotiators for the 16 NATO nations and the seven members of the Soviet-led Warsaw Pact have been bargaining in Vienna to try to bring both sides to equal ceilings in main battle tanks, armored combat vehicles, artillery, troops, combat aircraft and combat helicopters. The two sides are still trying to agree on a ceiling for combat aircraft and on measures to verify compliance with the accord. King said the Kremlin was concerned about the talks in light of the political upheavals in its one-time staunch Warsaw Pact allies. ``There's no doubt there are worries,'' he said. He said it was unclear whether the Soviets were dragging their feet as a bargaining ploy or not. But he said they appeared to be placing more emphasis on the international talks on German unity. He said the Soviets appeared to feel there would not be ``any great embarrassment'' if there were a delay of a few months. A key clause of the proposed deal _ called the sufficiency rule _ would limit the holdings of any one country to a certain percentage of the overall number of tanks, artillery and other equipment. The Soviets, however, argue that countries like Czechoslovakia, Hungary and East Germany are not as tightly bound to the Kremlin as they once were and East Germany may soon be joining West Germany to form a united country.

DOC.HEAD: City Asks to Amend Charges Against Gallery
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 6th graf to restore first reference to Barrie.
DOC.TEXT: Prosecutors sought Tuesday to modify charges against an art gallery being prosecuted for obscenity for exhibiting photographs by the late Robert Mapplethorpe. At a hearing originally called on a request by the Contemporary Arts Center to dismiss the charges, Hamilton County authorities asked to reword an indictment to conform to wording in a U.S. Supreme Court ruling on obscenity. The wording is one of the grounds on which the art center is seeking to have the charges dismissed. Hamilton County Municipal Judge David Albanese set a hearing for Thursday to review the prosecution request. The judge said he planned to visit the 175-photograph exhibit, which closes Saturday, before ruling on the request to dismiss the charges. Such conservative lawmakers as Sen. Jesse Helms, R-N.C., and Rep. Dana Rohrabacher, R-Calif., have attacked the National Endowment for the Arts for supporting Mapplethorpe's exhibition. Gallery director Dennis Barrie and the gallery are charged with pandering obscenity and using children in material involving nudity. If convicted, they would face $6,000 in fines. Barrie also would face six months in jail. The charges concern seven photos, five of homoerotic acts and two with nude or nearly nude children. Senior assistant city Prosecutor Frank H. Prouty Jr. said the city wants the indictment to specify that photographs of two nude children in the exhibit include ``a lewd, graphic exhibition of the genitals.'' The indictment issued April 7 says the exhibition includes ``a photograph of a minor male child ... with his genitals exposed, and a photograph of a minor female child ... with her genitals exposed.'' Prouty also asked to add a phrase to the indictment to allege that five pictures of sex acts in the exhibit are obscene as defined by the Supreme Court's ruling in Miller vs. California. In the 1973 decision, the Supreme Court said that in order to be obscene, material must violate community standards, depict clearly offensive sexual conduct and lack artistic value. H. Louis Sirkin, a lawyer for the art gallery, said he will oppose the city's request, contending the judge should not have the power to alter a grand jury's indictment. ``It has to come from the grand jury,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Boesky Gives First Public Testimony in Wall Street Scandal
DOC.NOTE: Eds: A version moving on business wires.
DOC.TEXT: Ivan F. Boesky calmly admitted Tuesday that he paid for inside information with briefcases full of cash as Wall Street's most celebrated felon gave his first public testimony since his 1986 plea bargain. Testifying against former friend John A. Mulheren Jr. on securities fraud charges, Boesky recounted the crimes he committed with other players in Wall Street's insider trading scandal _ such as Dennis Levine, formerly with Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., and investment banker Martin Siegel. ``Did you understand you were committing a crime when you traded on inside information from Dennis Levine?,'' asked Assistant U.S. Attorney Scott Gilbert. ``Yes,'' Boesky said in a firm and loud voice. Boesky, center of the biggest insider trading crime scandal in Wall Street history, made his entrance through a back door of Manhattan federal court, where he faced Mulheren and a packed courtroom. It was Boesky's first public appearance since he was released early from a three-year prison term last month. Clean-shaven, white hair cropped short, Boesky wore a charcoal gray suit, white shirt and dark tie. Mulheren, a well-known and eccentric speculator who wears casual clothes, sat at the defense table several yards away. Boesky testified that he received inside information about proposed takeover attempts from Levine and Siegel, and that he had agreed to pay them up to five percent of his firm's profits for their help. He said he never gave Levine any money. Siegel, however, recieved a total of $800,000 in three cash deliveries, Boesky said. ``It was assembled by a colleague out of my personal accounts, put into a briefcase and handed by an intermediary to Mr. Siegel,'' Boesky said. A fourth cash delivery to Siegel was canceled when he recieved word about a Securities and Exchange Commission investigation into Levine's dealings, he said. Levine, the first to implicate Boesky, pleaded guilty to felony charges in June 1986 and agreed to cooperate with prosecutors. Seigel also pleaded guilty to securities fraud-related counts and is awaiting sentencing. Boesky is the government's main witness against Mulheren on charges of stock manipulation and other securities fraud violations. His testimony was expected to be the high point of the trial. The two once were close friends but Mulheren became enraged when he learned Boesky had implicated him in wrongdoing a few years ago. At one point Mulheren allegedly plotted to assassinate him with an assault rifle. Weapons charges against Mulheren were subsequently dropped. Boesky, who avoided eye contact with Mulheren, described Mulheren as a business associate and friend, who once helped save his trading company from collapse. He said Mulheren was one of his few friends with whom he shared the information he received from Levine and Seigel, although he never revealed its source. Mulheren, 40, is accused of manipulating one stock price and concealing ownership of other stocks to help Boesky cheat on his taxes and evade federal securities laws. For example, Boesky said that in July 1985, Mulheren's firm, Jamie Securities, bought 330,000 shares of Unocal Corp. stock that he held, with the understanding Boesky would compensate him for any losses in the stock's value. Boesky's testimony is expected to take days. He returns to the witness stand on Wednesday. When asked during the lunch break for his reaction to Boesky's testimony, Mulheren said, ``Not much excitement.'' Boesky paid $100 million in penalties and pleaded guilty to one felony to settle the biggest insider trading case ever. In exchange he gave government investigators incriminating information about a number of others. The biggest victims of Boesky's information were the now-defunct investment banking company Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. and its junk-bond trading specialist Michael Milken. Both have pleaded guilty to numerous fraud charges that include fines with a combined total exceeding $1 billion. Mulheren is charged with 41 counts of conspiracy, securities fraud, mail fraud and violating federal record-keeping laws. He faces a maximum five years in prison and $250,000 fine on each count.

DOC.HEAD: House Panel Approves Dairy Support Program
DOC.TEXT: The House Agriculture Committee voted Tuesday to establish a national dairy program that guarantees farmers $10.10 per hundred pounds of milk as long as surpluses stay below 5 billion pounds. The section of the 1990 farm bill differs from a plan approved earlier by the panel's subcommittee on livestock, dairy and poultry. That proposal included producer assessments and set up a two-tiered price support system that would have given farmers one price for the bulk of their milk and a lesser price for the amount considered excess by the government. Rep. Charles Stenholm, D-Texas, chairman of the subcommittee, said the bill brought before the full committee was changed because so many people in Congress and the industry disagreed with the original plan. ``This is an effort to allow everyone to have an opportunity to have their opinion heard,'' said Stenholm, who presented the new plan with Rep. Steve Gunderson of Wisconsin, the ranking Republican on the subcommittee. ``This is a dairy support program to provide stability to producers,'' said Gunderson. The two lawmakers successfully fought off amendments offered in committee that would have further redesigned the dairy program. The government traditionally has supported dairy farmers by setting a price it will pay for storable dairy products, such as cheese, butter and non-fat dry milk, that aren't bought by processors in the open market. However, overproduction has been an expensive problem for the government that lawmakers have been trying to correct. The plan adopted by the committee Tuesday would maintain for the next five years the current price of $10.10 per hundredweight of milk, if surpluses bought up by the government are between 3.5 billion and 5 billion pounds. If surpluses fall below 3.5 billion, the government would pay $10.55 per hundredweight. However, if dairy farmers produce between 5.01 billion and 7 billion pounds more than the market will bear, the government will pay only $9.85 to $9.60 per hundredweight. If more than 7 billion pounds of surpluses result in any one year of the five-year farm bill, the Agriculture Department would be authorized to establish an inventory management program. Stenholm emphasized that the price support system does not include assessments or a rigid quota system. These portions of the earlier version of the bill were considered its main problem.

DOC.HEAD: First Lady Zulema Menem to Judge: I Received Death Threats
DOC.TEXT: Argentine First Lady Zulema Menem told a federal judge Tuesday she has received telephoned threats warning that she would be killed unless she ``stopped talking.'' Judge Remigio Gonzalez Moreno interviewed Mrs. Menem at her private residence and told reporters she informed him regarding two threats allegedly made by an anonymous male caller who warned her ``not to make any more statements.'' Gonzalez Moreno was named to investigate after Mrs. Menem reported receiving the threats last month at the official presidential residence in the Buenos Aires suburb of Olivos. Mrs. Menem often has made public statements highly critical of political and economic policies by her husband, President Carlos Menem, who was inaugurated July 8. She also has charged her husband is surrounded by corrupt and untrustworthy aides and advisors. Menem, 59, a former provincial governor and member of the labor-based Peronist party, has surprised many Argentines by advocating replacement of the country's inefficient, state-controlled economy with a free-market economy in the hopes of ending four decades of inflation and economic stagnation. Mrs. Menem, 46, maintaining friendships with several of her husband's political foes, has adhered to a more traditional Peronist view, questioning in public her husband's policies and the effect they will have on workers, retirees and the poor in this nation of 32 million residents. She charged in January that the telephones at the presidential residence had been tapped and her outgoing calls blocked in what she described as an effort to ``isolate'' her. That charge also is under investigation by a federal judge. Argentine media reported last week that Menem had moved out of the residence and would seek a legal separation or divorce from his wife. The couple, married 24 years but reported for years to have been estranged, has two children, daughter Zulema Eva, 19, and son Carlos, 21. Menem and his wife have refused comment on the report.

DOC.HEAD: NATO Defense Chiefs Approve Use of Multinational Forces
DOC.TEXT: U.S. Defense Secretary Dick Cheney and other NATO defense chiefs on Tuesday backed using their soldiers to form multinational armies in Europe to keep NATO solidarity alive. The proposal, if enacted, would result in an overhaul of the 40-year-old pact's military structure. Supporters say it is aimed at producing renewed political support for the alliance among member nations as they face the evaporation of the Warsaw Pact and as they prepare to welcome a unified Germany into their ranks. ``Given the changing threat, there is no alternative,'' said Cmdr. Stefan Lang, a spokesman for the West German defense ministry. ``Existing forces will be hollowed out and we have to reconfigure them.'' Gen. Vigleik Eide, who serves as chairman of the alliance's Military Committee, formally declared NATO's primary military foe conquered at the morning session, telling reporters, ``It is our clear assessment that the threat from a united Warsaw Pact no longer exists.'' But the Norwegian general cautioned the Soviet Union, despite its economic and political turmoil, still wields forces that are ``very impressive'' and continues to modernize its forces. Given chances for reduced troop levels in Europe with the completion of a proposed East-West accord on conventional forces and prospects for sharp cuts in U.S. troops based in Europe, the idea of using multinational military units in NATO nations has garnered support among the defense ministers, Lang and other NATO officials said. The proposal was discussed as the ministers began a two-day session to review the pact's military strategy at this time of reduced East-West tension. During their conferences, the ministers also agreed to take a thorough look at their military strategy that has guided the alliance through the Cold War years. ``We reached agreement on that,'' said Britain's defense chief Tom King. ``We're keen to see (it) go ahead.'' Italian Defense Minister Mino Martinazzoli said the study must be ``daring.'' The officials said the study should take a look at the whole range of military practices that NATO has followed for many years, including exercises, conventional and nuclear weapons and the deployment of forces along the front line _ which has been put in question by prospects of a unified Germany. The ministers also agreed in their closed-door talks to scrap the defense spending guideline that calls for an annual 3 percent increase. NATO officials said they would also like to bring France _ which is outside the joint military structure _ into the alliance's defense planning. Cheney, speaking with reporters en route to Brussels, backed the idea of building multinational forces. At present, NATO land forces defend territory under a so-called ``layer cake'' formula by which an army from an allied nation defends a certain geographic sector. With the elimination of the border between East and West Germany, such a system would have to be revamped. ``If all present, positive trends continue ... then we can contemplate new ways of doing business,'' Cheney said. ``I think, based on a first look, the notion of a multinational force has some appeal,'' Cheney said. ``I think it's worth pursuing.'' Using multinational forces in NATO could offer cost savings and ease nationalist sensitivities, particularly in West Germany where most NATO troops are stationed, said a senior defense official traveling with Cheney. Such forces could also help blunt any drive to take a unified Germany out of NATO. ``One way to emphasize the multilateral nature of the NATO alliance is to have units that are composed of troops of various nations,'' Cheney said. Such a plan would also ``emphasize the fact that (Germany) is not treated any differently than anyone else.'' As an example, Cheney said a multinational corps could be formed with three divisions each from a different nation. A U.S. division is made up of about 15,000 to 18,000 soldiers. Soldiers of multinational units could be based in Britain or Canada for training exercises, the official said. Such an arrangement could help reduce complaints among West German citizens. West Germans have grown increasingly irritated with NATO military exercises and accidents caused by low-flying aircraft. But the official cautioned that setting up multinational forces poses many problems, including language barriers and varied weapons systems.

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev Advisers Approve Radical Plans for Economy
DOC.TEXT: Mikhail S. Gorbachev's presidential council of advisers approved a plan Tuesday that would double food prices next year and introduce other radical reforms to ease the Soviet Union into a market economy by 1995. The council stressed the need to help the poor survive the high prices by introducing compensation and indexing, the official news agency Tass reported. The government plan will be presented to the Supreme Soviet legislature on Thursday by Premier Nikolai I. Ryzhkov, Foreign Ministry spokesman Gennady I. Gerasimov told reporters. An accompanying resolution decrees that prices on bread, so cheap some of it is used to feed cattle, will be raised as early as July to offset higher grain prices. But it also calls for immediate compensation to help poor people buy bread, their main staple. The resolution also says new laws are needed on free enterprise, anti-trust, foreign investment, income indexing, employment, banking and customs. It requires the laws be ready for passage in September. The program is designed to rescue an economy plagued by huge shortages, strikes and ethnic conflicts. While outlining major price increases and other reforms, the report emphasized the need to control inflation, unemployment and other social ills. The government will continue to regulate the cost of basic foodstuffs, including meat, bread and cooking oil, a draft of the planned reforms said. The reforms would stagger the cumulative shock over five years instead of the two discussed earlier. Soviet officials are wary lest abrupt increases in food prices set off riots and strikes, like those that toppled Polish Communist governments in the 1970s and 1980s. The plan is far more radical than the government program presented in December to the Soviet Congress, the Supreme Soviet's parent parliament. But it falls short of the free-market measures in Poland that led to a spurt of rapid inflation the past six months. The earlier plan basically called for three more years of a centrally planned economy, but sentiment is growing that faster steps are needed to improve production and distribution. A report by Ryzhkov on the revised plan said, ``The negative effect of political instability, strikes and inter-ethnic conflicts is growing ever stronger.'' It asked workers to refrain from striking. A parliamentary opposition group attacked the proposed program and plans to present an alternative economic blueprint advocating a market economy. The independent news service Post-Factum quoted Siberian economist Gennady Filshin as saying, ``This is just another ploy to intimidate the people with the idea of a free market and consolidate its own positions.'' The Kremlin's new readiness to take harsh measures become more understandable in the light of disturbing figures on current economic performance. In the first quarter of 1990, cash incomes grew by 13.4 percent while the gross national product declined, the report says. Up to April, political strikes and inter-ethnic conflicts led to the loss of 9.5 million man-hours, compared to 7 million man-hours lost in all of 1989. Prices in state stores for many basic foods presently are low. Potatoes cost as little as 8 cents a pound and beef $1.80 a pound. But the Soviet economy is plagued by shortages, with commodities rationed in some regions and beef at about $16 a pound at free prices in farmers' markets and new potatoes at up to $8 a pound. About 290 million people live in the Soviet Union.

DOC.HEAD: Bored Soviet TV Viewers are Promised Better Fare
DOC.TEXT: U.S. and European television programs will be broadcast to the Soviet Union by the end of the decade to satisfy viewers who are tired of watching politics, a Soviet official said on Tuesday. The Western programs will be transmitted via satellite and the number of national televsion stations will be raised from two to five, said Mikhail Nenachev, president of the State Committee for Broadcasting. ``There is no political problem'' with Western programs, he told reporters at the Media Summit, a conference of broadcast specialists and policy makers from Europe and the United States. ``As far as European and U.S. programs are concerned, we are working very hard to receive them in the Soviet Union,'' he said. ``But because of technical difficulties, I do not think we will have it (on a large scale) in the near future.'' He said Soviets are bored of watching the often televised political debates and are hungry for European and American movies, television shows, music and youth programs. ``In these days of `glasnost' and `perestroika,' our television uses most of its time for political items. It's too much,'' he said. He was using the two Russian words for President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's system of political reforms. ``We forgot about culture, news and music. We want to make it more balanced,'' Nenachev said. He said Soviet television also wants to show a European music channel and will add three more national stations. Channels for ``alternative companies'' such as trade unions or youth groups are also under study, Nenachev said. But private stations are still out of the question. ``We are not ready for that,'' he said. To accommodate the increase in channels and broadcast time, the Soviet Union plans to launch 10 commercial satellites over the next three years.

DOC.HEAD: Thompson Faces Trial on Drug Charges
DOC.NOTE: Eds: CORRECTS spelling to Gail stad Gale in 6th graf, Doonesbury sted Doonsbury in 9th graf.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos ASPX1, ASPX3
DOC.TEXT: ``Gonzo'' journalist Hunter Thompson was ordered Tuesday to stand trial on drug and explosives charges after a hearing featuring some low-key antics by the celebrity defendant. Mesa County District Court Judge Charles Buss ruled there was sufficient evidence to try the author of such books as ``Fear and Loathing in Las Vegas'' on five felony charges of possessing drugs and possessing and storing explosives illegally. The judge threw out charges of cocaine use in the case, which stemmed from complaints by a woman who also alleged Thompson assaulted her in his home in February. Misdemeanor assault charges weren't considered Tuesday. Thompson, 53, figeted throughout the hearing and at times muttered under his breath, ``That's bull'' or ``Ah, come on,'' particularly during testimony by his accuser. She is Gail Palmer-Slater, 35, of Port Huron, Mich., a business entrepreneur and former porn film producer who had written Thompson several weeks earlier saying she wanted to meet him. The case began when she complained to Pitkin County authorities that she had been sexually assaulted while visiting Thompson. She said Thompson threw a drink at her, twisted her breast and shoved her during the visit. Her complaint led to a two-day search in which authorities found LSD, cocaine, Diazapam, and marijuana and four sticks of dynamite at Thompson's house. Thompson, father of so-called ``gonzo journalism,'' has written books on subjects as diverse as political campaigns and the Hell's Angels, dwelling as much on the drug-drenched antics of the writer as on the subject at hand. At the noon break Thompson, the inspiration for the Duke character in the ``Doonesbury'' comic strip, left the courthouse followed by photographers and reporters and at one point stopped to pose. ``Let me do a Nixon,'' he said, stopping to raise his arms and flash a V-for-victory signal with both hands. Later, asked to comment on the ruling, he growled, ``Today's pig is tomorrow's bacon.'' Protesters outside 99-year-old courthouse waved signs saying, ``When the going gets weird, the weird go to jail.'' Another read, ``Today the doctor, tomorrow you,'' in an apparent reference to a search of his home that Thompson has called excessively thorough. Thompson denies assaulting Palmer-Slater, maintaining she was drunk and pressuring him to have sex with her when he pushed her away. Hal Haddon, Thompson's attorney, argued the drugs couldn't be proven to belong to Thompson because he has so many visitors. He said the explosives didn't belong to Thompson, but to someone who used them to blow up beaver dams, stumps and other obstacles to irrigation water. Trial was tentatively set for June 25.

DOC.HEAD: Eleven Foreign Journalists Chosen As Nieman Fellows
DOC.TEXT: Eleven foreign journalists have been named Nieman Fellows, including Fernando Cano, editor of Colombia's second largest daily newspaper, which is under assault by the county's drug barons. Seven of El Espectador's employees have been killed in the past eight months, while more than a dozen have quit because of threats. The paper's publisher was killed by traffickers in 1986. Cano, whose family founded the paper in 1887, will join ten other journalists for the 1990-1991 academic year at Harvard University. U.S. Nieman fellows were announced last week. The other fellows are: _ Rui Araujo, a producer with the Portuguese Broadcasting Corporation. _ Kabral Blay-Amihere, a freelance journalist formerly with The Independent of Ghana. _ Raj Chengappa, a special correspondent with India Today. _ Maria Dunin-Wasowicz, deputy economic editor of Przeglad Tygodniowy of Poland. _ Tony Bluemenor, assistant editor of This Week of Lagos, Nigeria. _ Nanise Fifita, senior journalist with the Tonga Broadcasting Commission. _ Joseph Latakgomo, senior assistant editor of The Star, of Johannesburg, South Africa. _ Jennifer Lewington, Washington bureau chief of The Globe and Mail of Canada. _ Luis Alberto Moreno, director of Colombia's TV Hoy. _ Vladimir Vessenski, special correspondent for Literary Gazette of the Soviet Union.

DOC.HEAD: Mexican President Agrees to Seek Free-Trade Pact With U.S.
DOC.TEXT: President Carlos Salinas de Gortari accepted Senate recommendations Tuesday to seek a free-trade agreement with the United States, but economists and advisers said such a pact isn't likely to occur soon. The U.S.-Canada free-trade initiative, proposed in 1985 and begun in January, wasn't signed into law until last year. ``The recommendations will be the framework in which ... my administration will carry on Mexico's trade negotiations,'' Salinas told 55 senators at the presidential residence. Meanwhile in Washington, President Bush told a U.S. business group interested in promoting Latin American trade, ``We in the U.S. must do all we can to ensure the future of free markets in the Americas because our nation has a stake in the economic health of this hemisphere.'' Mexican Commerce Department adviser Jaime Zabludovsky denied reports that a partial free-trade agreement would be signed when Salinas and Bush meet June 10-12. Salinas said he would study Senate recommendations with an eye toward integrating Mexico, which has about 85 million residents, in the changing economic world. ``Mexico will not be left out of the new world configuration. The speed of the changes requires decisive answers on all fronts, in all markets,'' he said. The Senate recommendations also advise Salinas to take advantage of Mexico's strategic location next to the United States to expand trade with Pacific rim countries and Europe. ``We have given the president a broad mandate in all foreign trade relations,'' said Senate Foreign Relations Committee chairwoman Blanca Esponda. The 64-member Senate is the only authority that must approve presidential agreements with foreign countries. Its recommendations were based on trade strategies proposed by academics, entrepreneurs and politicians, sponsored by the Senate at Salinas' request. ``The majority of the participants said that one of the main advantages of free trade agreement between Mexico and the United States, would be a greater flow of foreign investment to Mexico due to the unbridled access to the U.S. market that Mexico would have,'' Senate president Maximiliano Silerio Esparza said in reading its recommendations to Salinas. The recommendations were based on hopes of permanent access to the U.S. market and lowering U.S. trade barriers on agricultural, textile and cement products, Silerio Esparza said. He said the recommendations include a transition period to let Mexican industry change to survive an onslaught of American goods onto the Mexican domestic market. Until recently high Mexican tariffs kept out many American goods or made them more expensive than similar Mexican products. Because of a lack of foreign competitition, the prices of Mexican products were in some cases artificially high. Mexican industry began feeling the pressure from lower-priced imports after Mexico joined the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade in 1988. Silerio Esparza noted some participants in the trade strategy forums opposed closer commercial ties with the United States on the grounds they would promote dependence, a topic of particular concern in Mexico. Salinas agreed to Senate recommendations that Mexico stop short of seeking an economic union with the United States of the type planned by Europe for 1992. He said such union ``is not compatible with the national objectives of sovereignty that we will always defend.'' In campaign speeches leading up to July 1988 presidential elections Salinas opposed a free-trade agreement with the United States. But the U.S.-Canada agreement and the pending European plan have posed new threats of competition to Mexico's export market.

DOC.HEAD: Anti-Apartheid Activists Surround Foreign Ministry
DOC.TEXT: About 500 anti-apartheid demonstrators formed a human chain around the foreign ministry on Tuesday to protest an upcoming visit by South African President F.W. de Klerk. The protesters formed a line from Madrid's main square to the foreign ministry and chanted slogans equating Socialist Prime Minister Felipe Gonzalez with de Klerk. The South African leader is scheduled to arrive Thursday as part of a nine-nation European tour and will meet with Gonzalez and King Juan Carlos before leaving the same day. Foreign Minister Francisco Fernandez Ordonez and other top diplomats said they do not plan to lift economic and cultural sanctions against South Africa during the visit. The sanctions were imposed to protest against South Africa's system of racial discrimination. One top diplomat said Spain would not change its sanctions ``until the normalization in that country was irreversible.'' The diplomat also said the leader of the African National Congress, Nelson Mandela, had accepted an invitation to visit Spain, but said a date has not yet been set. De Klerk's won cautious international approval for his February decision to release Mandela and other political prisoners. He also legalized many black political groups such as the ANC and reformed certain racial laws. De Klerk's European trip is the most extensive by any South African leader since the National Party took power in 1948 and instituted the system of apartheid.

Miramax Films said Tuesday it would sue the Motion Picture Association of America in hopes of getting the ``X'' rating rescinded for ``Tie Me Up! Tie Me Down!'' A statement issued by Miramax said the suit, to be filed Wednesday in New York, accuses the MPAA of being ``motivated by a prejudice toward foreign films and a prejudice toward independent distributors as well as a bias in favor of films released by major studios.'' Asked to comment on the announcement late Tuesday, MPAA officials in Los Angeles referred calls to the organization's New York office, which was closed. ``Tie Me Up! Tie Me Down!'', in which a lovesick man kidnaps a fading movie star, was directed by Spanish filmmaker Pedro Almodovar. The director also made the offbeat comedy ``Women on the Verge of a Nervous Breakdown,'' which in 1989 received an Academy Award nomination for best foreign film. The MPAA doesn't publicly announce a reason for giving the rating, which means no one under 17 is permitted to see the movie. But a passionate lovemaking scene is believed the reason. On April 24, Miramax appealed the decision to the MPAA's Rating Appeals Board, which upheld the rating on a 6-6 vote. The suit alleges the decision was arbitrary and capricious. In 1968, the MPAA and the National Association of Theater Owners devised the voluntary system under which filmmakers submit their movies to be rated. Filmmakers, have the option of releasing a film unrated, and that was done with ``Tie Me Up! Tie Me Down!'' Amanda Marashinky, a publicist at Miramax, noted that many theaters won't show X-rated or unrated pictures and that many newspapers won't accept advertising for them. ``I think a lot of people have brought up the fact that it isn't really voluntary,'' Marashinsky said. In the past few months, ``Wild Orchid,'' ``Henry: Portrait of a Serial Killer,'' and ``The Cook, the Thief, His Wife & Her Lover,'' another Miramax film, have also been rated ``X.'' Last year, the Miramax film ``Scandal'' was rated ``X'', but reduced to ``R'' after an orgy scene was recut. Marashinsky said the distributor is seeking an ``R'' rating for the film, meaning that no one under 17 would be permitted in the theater without being accompanied by an adult. ``Tie Me Up! Tie Me Down'' opened May 4 in New York and Los Angeles and is also being shown in theaters in Miami and Fort Lauderdale, Fla. Marashinsky says the film, which opens wide on Friday, has grossed $250,000.

DOC.HEAD: Cosby Angers Some Black Graduates of Notre Dame
DOC.TEXT: Bill Cosby, invited to address black graduates at the University of Notre Dame, drew anger and tears when he publicly criticized a football player for failing to attain a 3.0 grade-point average. ``I was in shock,'' Kenneth B. Durgans, director of minority student affairs, said Tuesday. ``I understood the underlying message, but he was really off-base.'' Cosby's remarks, made Sunday before about 300 people, mostly black graduates and their guests, went largely unnoticed beyond the room until those present voiced their anger this week. A spokesman for Cosby in Los Angeles, David Brokaw, couldn't immediately provide comment from the entertainer. Cosby delivered an upbeat and humorous speech at the university's commencement later Sunday. The earlier, smaller group had expected a message of challenge and congratulations. ``He said essentially that if you do not give 100 percent of your effort and attempt to exploit your potential each and every day, that you're compromising,'' said William P. Sexton, vice president of university relations, who attended the meeting. ``And when you do that, you get into a habit, and it's a habit that's hard to break.'' ``When we left there, he said, `I cannot be party to celebrating any result that has not been part of the very best effort to reach excellence,''' he said. ``The unfortunate thing was it became personal,'' Sexton said. ``I badly regret some of the folks there found it too tough.'' Robert Price, a 22-year-old architecture student and member of the campus Black Cultural Arts Council, said at first he thought Cosby was joking. ``I was saddened by the whole thing, really unimpressed,'' said Price. ``I was utterly insulted. The person sitting next to me was in tears.'' Durgans and Price said Cosby singled out football tackle Dean Brown. ``He asked him, `What's your (grade average),' and he said `2.5,''' said Price. ``(Cosby) said `that's nothing.''' During the exchange that followed, Brown began crying, and Cosby brought him onto the auditorium stage, Price said, adding that Brown tried to explain to the actor-comedian his difficulties in balancing studies and football. No one answered the telephone at Brown's dormitory Tuesday and college officials were unable to provide his whereabouts. Another student came to Brown's defense and began arguing with Cosby, then walked out, said Price. ``In all fairness to (Cosby), he had a rationale,'' said Durgans. ``I think a majority didn't agree with how he dealt with his rationale.'' In Los Angeles, Cosby spokesman Brokaw noted that Cosby has donated millions of dollars for black higher education, and has criticized alumni of black colleges for not helping more.

DOC.HEAD: Minister Who Resigned Says Quebec Moves toward Sovereignty
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with later comments by Bouchard, details, reaction. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: Lucien Bouchard followed up his resignation from the Cabinet by quitting Prime Minister Brian Mulroney's Conservatives on Tuesday and declaring that he thinks Quebec's best bet is sovereignty, in association with Canada. Mulroney, struggling to stem the damage to his government caused by the defection of his old friend and close political ally, admitted in the House of Commons that the future of the Meech Lake accord is in serious doubt. The proposed constitutional amendment would give all 10 provinces special powers and recognize Quebec as a ``distinct society'' within Canada. By law, all 10 provinces must ratify Meech by June 23 or the proposal will expire. Bouchard, the former environment minister, opposes any change to the 1987 accord. Recommendations for change are now before the government. Bouchard campaigned for an independent Quebec in 1980 before joining Mulroney and the Tories. The 1982 constitution instituted in Canada did not recognize the largely French-speaking province of Quebec as a ``distinct society.'' The Meech Lake proposal remedies that omission. About 6.7 million of Canada's 25 million people live in Quebec. The constitutional dispute over the accord has revived independence talk in Quebec. Bouchard, who was Mulroney's chief lieutenant in Quebec, told a news conference Tuesday he thinks Quebecers must act because the country isn't functioning well. ``I believe that the solution is sovereignty-association,'' he said. ``It's a term that's never been properly defined. English Canadians refer to separatists, this is a cold term. We have to remake the country.'' In the Commons, Mulroney fervently defended Meech, saying it was simply designed to welcome Quebec back into the Canadian family. Mulroney told Commons last-minute efforts to rescue the Meech Lake accord are not going well. ``I am advised that the progress has not been substantial,'' he said. In his speech to Commons later, Bouchard advised Quebec Premier Robert Bourassa not to attend any conference of Mulroney and the 10 provincial premiers to hear a committee report on changes. He said if Bourassa boycotts such a conference, ``he will have not just my support but that of all Quebecers.'' Bouchard told reporters if his resignation means stopping a compromise that dilutes Meech Lake, ``I will have done something very important. ``If my resignation helps some individuals to be realistic in what they are doing and to realize once again that it's Meech all or nothing, my resignation will have powerfully served the will of the people.'' Sen. Lowell Murray, Mulroney's personal Meech Lake emissary, said Bouchard's departure may have scuttled the idea of an 11th-hour meeting of Mulroney and the 10 premiers to save Mulroney's cherished constitutional agreement. ``Lucien Bouchard's letter of resignation raises the question of whether it's worthwhile to do this,'' Murray said. In his letter of resignation, Bouchard scoffed at ``those who would attempt, hopefully in vain, to convince Quebec to come to a conference that is booby-trapped in order to wrest from it ultimate concessions that could only be humiliating.'' The cracks in Meech and in Mulroney's party spread Tuesday. Gilbert Chartrand, Tory member of parliament for Verdun-Saint Paul, announced he was quitting the party, too, saying he was unable to toe the party line and would be ashamed if he didn't speak up against proposed changes to Meech. The Charest report, prepared by a special committee led by Quebec Tory Jean Charest, produced 23 recommendations last week in hopes of producing a Meech-saving compromise in the face of opposition by some provinces. It would have the federal prime minister and the provincial premiers state firmly that recognition of Quebec as a distinct society does not supersede the Charter of Rights. It says the federal government should be allowed to promote as well as protect linguistic duality. Bouchard vehemently opposes the report.

DOC.HEAD: Six Teens Indicted More Than a Year After Alleged Sexual Assault
DOC.NOTE: Eds: RECASTS lead. Note contents of third graf.
DOC.TEXT: Four teen-agers were indicted Tuesday on charges of sexually assaulting a mentally retarded girl more than a year ago. Charged were twins Kevin and Kyle Scherzer, 19, Peter Quigley and Richard Corcoran Jr. with aggravated sexual assault. Prosecutors allege that the Scherzers, co-captains of the high school football team, Quigley and Corcoran assaulted the girl with a broomstick and a miniature baseball bat, while nine others participated or watched. Defense lawyers don't contest what occurred, but say the girl consented. Lawyers for Quigley and Corcoran deny that their clients were actual participants. Essex County Prosecutor Herbert H. Tate Jr. has said the girl, now 19, is mentally retarded, with an IQ is between 49 and 67. The four were arrested last May, more than two months after the March 1, 1989, incident, which took place in the Scherzers' basement in Glen Ridge, an affluent suburb 15 miles west of New York City. They have been free on bail pending a grand jury investigation. The indictment also charges another teen-ager, John Maher, with conspiracy for allegedly asking the victim, identified as M.G., to return to the basement the next day. It charges Mari Carmen Ferraez, 19, with witness tampering for allegedly contacting the victim in an attempt to have her change her story. And it names, as unindicted co-conspirators, three juveniles under arrest in the case and a fourth who has not been charged, Tate said. Prosecutors have asked that the three juveniles charged be tried as adults; no ruling has yet been made on that request. Tate said the grand jury investigation took so long because of the large number of people involved and discovery of the taped conversation between Ms. Ferraez and M.G. Also slowing the indictment was a recent state appeals court ruling that the victim in a separate case is mentally defective only if she is unable to understand that others may not have sex with her without her consent. Tate said the investigation was continuing, but declined to elaborate. Defense lawyers say the girl was intelligent enough to have said no. But the grand jury found that, ``M.G. was one whom Kevin Scherzer and Kyle Scherzer and Peter Quigley and Richard Corcoran Jr. knew or should have known was physically helpless, mentally defective or mentally incapacitated.'' Those four are each charged with four counts of first-degree aggravated sexual assault, four counts of third-degree aggravated sexual contact and second-degree conspiracy to commit aggravated sexual assault and aggravated sexual contact. Maher is charged with one count of conspiracy, Ms. Ferraez with two counts of third-degree witness tampering and fourth-degree obstructing administration of law or other government function. If convicted, the Scherzers, Quigley and Corcoran face a maximum of about 20 years in prison, officials said. Maher faces 10 years, Ms. Ferraez five.

DOC.HEAD: Marlon Brando Sits Stone-Faced During Son' Bail Hearing
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhotos LA7, LA10
DOC.TEXT: Actor Marlon Brando sat stone-faced Tuesday as a judge refused to set bail for his son, who is charged with killing his sister's boyfriend, but later spoke emotionally of the suffering of both families. The white-haired Brando sat in the front row of the packed courtroom and stared straight ahead as his son, Christian, was brought in. The two did not acknowledge each other as cameras clicked and flashes went off. William Kunstler, the civil rights attorney summoned by the elder Brando to defend his son, said the shooting of Dag Drollet, 26, at the Brando estate last Wednesday was an accident and that Christian Brando was drunk at the time. Kunstler presented affidavits from friends and neighbors, including actor Jack Nicholson, who attested to the younger Brando's good character. ``His father is not going to help him (flee) in any way. He wants this process to go on,'' Kunstler said in requesting bail. But Municipal Court Judge Rosemary Shumsky denied bail. Christian Brando, 32, a welder and tree-trimmer, was arrested after police received an emergency call from his father and rushed to the hilltop estate to find the body of houseguest Drollet, 26, who had been shot. Drollet was the boyfriend of Cheyenne Brando, 20. Marlon Brando, who did not speak during Tuesday's hearing, later declared his son's innocence to reporters. ``We see on the television and read in newspapers things that are unpronounceably sad,'' said the reclusive actor. ``The messenger of misery has come to my house. He has also come to the house of Mr. Jack Drollet (the victim's father) in Tahiti and we must stand up to it.'' ``To those people who have known this kind of tragic circumstances in the world ... no explanation is necessary, and to those people who do not know the nature of this acute misery that both our families suffer, no explanation is possible.'' He added, ``My son has been denied bail. He has had his day in court and we will abide by that. The decision will be appealed.'' He also thanked the news media for what he called its mostly ``responsible and reasonable'' presentation of the case. As he left, he was asked to describe his feelings. ``There's no way to describe it to you unless you've gone through it in your life. We must just be strong, and the family, with love and supporting each other, will prevail.'' Christian Brando initially told police he shot Drollet during an argument involving alleged abuse of his pregnant sister. Kunstler the next day issued statements saying the killing was an accident in which a gun went off during a struggle. But in court Tuesday, Deputy District Attorney Steven Barshop said pictures of the body and other evidence indicate otherwise. ``There was a contact wound and decedent was shot while seated,'' Barshop said. ``The shot is at a 45-degree angle. Decedent is holding a TV changer and a Bic lighter, negating any struggle.'' Kunstler disputed Barshop's account of the evidence. Another Brando lawyer, Ronald Kuby, told the judge the younger Brando had an alcohol problem in the past, had been through a detoxification program and was willing to go through another if released. Kunstler said Christian Brando's blood-alcohol reading two hours after the shooting was 0.19 percent, which he called ``one of the highest blood-alcohol contents I've seen in a case of this kind.'' That is nearly double the state's threshhold for drunken driving. ``Christian Brando is not a famous person, not a public person,'' Kuby told the judge. ``He happens to have a famous father. I beg you to treat him as you would any other person without the Brando name.'' The judge set the next hearing in the case for June 11.

DOC.HEAD: Violence Spreads into Gaza, West Bank, Jordan
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 17 grafs to UPDATE with Bush condolences, Israeli retort to U.S. criticism. Picks up 15th graf, `Residents reached;' edits thereafter to trim
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos JRL2,4; LaserColor JRL104
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of Palestinians protesting the murder of seven Arabs in Israel demonstrated Tuesday in the occupied lands and in neighboring Jordan. Four people were reported killed and at least 47 injured. Escalating protests included a rally by hundreds of people outside the U.S. Consulate in Arab east Jerusalem. Striking Palestinians shut down schools and shops in the occupied Gaza Strip and the West Bank. Hundreds of members of the pro-Iranian Hezbollah organization burned effigies of Israeli Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir and of U.S., Jordanian and Saudi leaders during a march in Beirut, Lebanon. Israeli troops killed two Palestinians and wounded 22 Tuesday, raising the toll since Sunday to 13 Palestinians slain and more than 800 injured. That does not include seven Palestinians killed Sunday by an Israeli civilian _ an incident that touched off widespread riots. Israel said he was deranged. President Bush extended personal condolences Tuesday to the families of the seven slain Palestinians and those killed later by security forces and asked the Israeli army ``to act with maximum restraint.'' Bush said the political problems at the heart of the Arab-Israeli conflict must be urgently addressed and a peace process opened that involves all parties. In Jordan, at least two people were killed and 25 wounded as police fired to disperse demonstrations in two cities and Baqaa refugee camp near Amman, the capital, Jordan's official Petra news agency said. Prime Minister Mudar Badran pledged to take ``all necessary measures to guarantee safety and order.'' Nearly half of Jordan's 3.1 million people are Palestinians who fled Israel in the 1948 or 1967 Middle East wars. Shamir defended his government against criticism by Arabs and the U.S. State Department over Sunday's slayings and the heavy casualties caused by army gunfire. ``Anyone wishing to see in this mad murder an expression of Israeli government policy and intentions is maliciously and viciously distorting the picture,'' Shamir told legislators from his right-wing Likud bloc. State Department spokesman Richard Boucher complained about the number of casualties caused by the Israeli army, and Department spokeswoman Margaret Tutwiler told reporters it is the United States' ``deeply held belief that absence of a peace process contributes to violence in the Middle East.'' Motti Amichai, a spokesman for Israel's Foreign Ministry, replied, ``The main obstacle to peace in the Middle East is the refusal of Arab states to start direct dialogue with Israel.'' ``We are suprised vis-a-vis the attempt to link the actions of one lunatic to the peace process and the policy of the government of Israel,'' he said. The protests in Israel started soon after an Israeli man lined up 50 Palestinian day laborers in a Tel Aviv suburb Sunday and opened fire with an assault rifle. Seven people were killed and 11 injured. Authorities say the suspect, 21-year-old Ami Popper, was deranged and also upset by an unhappy love affair. But Arabs have said anti-Israeli policies by Shamir's government encourage such attacks. Israeli officials in turn have accused the Arabs of trying to use the slayings to revive the flagging, 29-month Palestinian uprising against Israel's occupation of the West Bank and Gaza Strip. About 7,000 Palestinians clashed with police Tuesday in Jordan's Baqaa camp, and security officials said 15,000 protested in Irbid, 45 miles north of Amman. Residents reached by telephone in Irbid said a 14-year-old boy was killed by police. It was not immediately clear whether the victim was Palestinian. An official at Jordan University Hospital near Amman said a 19-year-old man died of gunshot wounds suffered at Baqaa. Police sealed off all roads leading to Zarqa, 18 miles north of Amman, where at least 10,000 Palestinians staged protests. In Israel and the occupied territories, violence persisted for a third day. The army imposed curfews keeping 1.5 million Palestinians in their homes. Troops firing on Palestinians in Gaza City fatally shot 18-year-old Ahmed Musabeh in the chest, hospital officials said. The army confirmed the death and said it was investigating the circumstances. Seventeen Palestinians were shot and wounded in clashes with soldiers in Gaza and five others were injured by army gunfire in the West Bank, Arab hospital officials said. Among the wounded in Gaza was Musabeh's 23-year-old sister, Samira, who was five months pregnant, the officials said. They said she was shot in the stomach with a plastic bullet but that the fetus was unharmed. An army statement said a Palestinian also was killed by soldiers after he set off a roadside explosive device in Bani Suhelia in the Gaza Strip. Palestinians identified the victim as Ata Ali Abu Shaed, 20. Tuesday's deaths brought to 708 the number of Palestinians killed by Israelis in the Palestinian uprising. At least 216 other Palestinians have been slain by fellow Arabs, most on suspicion of collaboration with Israel. Forty-three Israelis have been slain in the revolt.

DOC.HEAD: Five Held in Threats Against Rushdie
DOC.TEXT: Police are questioning five men under the Prevention of Terrorism Act over threats to kill author Salman Rushdie, the Daily Mail newspaper reported in Wednesday's editions. Scotland Yard refused to confirm if the men were being held in connection with threats made against Rushdie, saying only that, ``A number of persons have been arrested today under the Prevention of Terrorism Act and are being interviewed at a central London police station.'' The Daily Mail newspaper reported the five were arrested by police in raids at four locations in London and one in Scarborough, 155 miles northeast of London. Rushdie has been in hiding since Feb. 14, 1989, when the late Iranian leader, Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, condemned him to death for allegedly blaspheming Islam in his novel, ``The Satanic Verses.'' Iran reaffirmed the death threat earlier this year. The Daily Mail reported Scotland Yard has intensified its operations after warnings that Iranian hit squads were sent to Britain. A Scotland Yard spokeswoman, who was not identified in keeping with British custom, refused comment. In another development, a publisher scrapped plans for bringing out a limited collectors' edition of two of Rushdie's short stories, saying he feared it could endanger the author's life, the Independent newspaper reported on Wednesday. Two previously published short stories by the Indian-born author were to be reissued in an illustrated, limited edition that would sell for $250 a copy, the Independent quoted the publisher as saying. The publisher decided a dozen copies of the stories ``The Prophet's Hair'' and ``The Free Radio'' would be bound and privately distributed to friends of the author, the illustrator, and the publisher, the newspaper reported. The publisher said Rushdie agreed to withdraw the book from wider sale and circulation, the newspaper reported.

DOC.HEAD: Suspected Rebels Kill Five, Wound Nine on Manila Thoroughfare
DOC.TEXT: Suspected Communist rebels firing from a van killed a Filipino colonel and four others Wednesday in an ambush along a thoroughfare jammed with rush-hour commuters, police said. Nine others were injured, most of them passengers in a bus that was riddled with stray bullets. Col. Reynaldo Dino, deputy personnel officer of the Philippine Constabulary and former chief of staff of the police Capital Command died of head and body wounds a short while later in a hospital. Dino's 23-year-old daughter, Lolita Halili, and three of his bodyguards were also killed, police said. Police said six assailants led by a woman sprayed gunfire at Dino's car as it traveled along the thoroughfare, sending the vehicle swerving into a bus. Three of the assailants, including the woman, then jumped from their van and began firing at point-blank range, police said. Witnesses said the woman spat toward bystanders after she finished firing. The assailants escaped but their van was recovered, police Lt. Rogelio Bilang said. Police Col. Victor Tiangco, operations chief of the Capital Command, blamed the killing on the Marxist New People's Army. Tiangco said Dino had been receiving death threats from the insurgents and one suspected guerrilla was arrested last month near Dino's home. Tiangco said the Alex Boncayao Brigade, the Manila wing of the New People's Army, was responsible for killing about 60 police, soldiers and civilians in Manila this year. Wedsnesday is the sixth anniversary of the Alex Boncayao Brigade. The attack was the latest sign of the deteriorating security situation in this turbulent capital. On Tuesday, police defused powerful bombs outside the headquarters of two banks in the financial district and officials said the explosives, timed to explode during morning rush hour, could have destroyed both buildings. Brig. Gen. Marino Filart, chief of the police Capital Command, said the bombs could be part of an urban terror campaign to pave the way for a new coup attempt against President Corazon Aquino.

DOC.HEAD: Boxer Rocky Graziano Dies, Briefly Held Middleweight Title
DOC.NOTE: Eds: DELETES grafs 2-3, redundant material.
DOC.TEXT: Rocky Graziano, who briefly held the middleweight boxing crown but was better known as the subject of a movie and a pitchman for products from yogurt to auto mufflers, died Tuesday. He was 71. Graziano died of cardio-pulmonary failure at New York Hospital, said hospital spokeswoman Diana Goldin. He was hospitalized April 8 after suffering a stroke. In his 11-year pro career, Graziano managed a 67-16 record with 52 knockouts. He is best remembered for three fights with Tony Zale and it was the middle one of those which gave Graziano his only title. In retirement, Graziano became as popular as he had been as a fighter.
