His life story, ``Somebody Up There Likes Me,'' was a best-selling book that was made into the 1956 movie of the same name, starring Paul Newman. Graziano was frequently seen on television as a sidekick to comedienne Martha Raye and on commercials for all manner of products from yogurt and foot powder to dog food and auto mufflers. He was elected to the Boxing Hall of Fame in 1971. Graziano turned pro in 1942 and by 1946, he was a contender. On Sept. 16 in Yankee Stadium, he fought Zale for the middleweight title and they staged a small war with Graziano going down in the first round and then being knocked out in the sixth. He recalled the knockout punch. ``It was a big left hook and I see it coming, but I can't stop it. It was like the ground exploded up and hit me in the stomach. The lights spin in a circle then dim down to a tiny little spot,'' he said. ``I try to yell but I can't make a sound. I am deaf and I can't talk and I can't lift my arms and I am falling. For the first time in my life, I know what it's like to be KO'd.'' The fight was such a crowd-pleaser that 10 months later, on July 16, 1947, Graziano and Zale had a rematch, this time in Chicago. Graziano returned the favor, knocking Zale out in the sixth round to capture the championship. Graziano held the title for 11 months but in his first defense, Zale took the crown back on June 10, 1948 with a third-round knockout in another bloody battle. Graziano got one more chance at the championship, but was knocked out in the third round by Sugar Ray Robinson on April 16, 1952. He would fight just once more, losing a 10-round decision to Chuck Davey before announcing his retirement. Twenty-five years after his last fight, Graziano chortled about his post-boxing popularity. ``This author stuff, TV and the movies _ it's a piece of cake, better than ripping off stores. Pays better, too.'' Graziano often made himself and his delinquent childhood the butt of jokes. ``I quit school in the sixth grade because of pneumonia,'' he once said. ``Not because I had it _ but because I couldn't spell it. We stole everything that began with an `a' _ a piece of fruit, a bicycle, a watch, anything that was not nailed down. ``It took me nine years to get through the fourth grade. When I got into television commercials, I had to take a crash course in reading. I was 32 years old and I couldn't read the cue cards.'' Graziano was treated last year for physical and mental exhaustion, and had a heart attack last February, Ms. Goldin said. Funeral arrangements were pending. Graziano was born Thomas Rocco Barbella on New York's lower East Side. The son of a former boxer who used the name ``Fighting Nick Bob,'' Graziano grew up as a street brawler who learned to steal before he learned to read. He ran with a tough crowd and recalling those days later in life, he called himself ``the world's champion punk.'' At age 12, he was arrested for the first time, caught breaking into a subway gum machine. While on probation, he stole a bicycle and was sent for the first of three trips to reform school. In 1939 a friend, Jack Healy, took him to New York's famous Stillman's Gym to see if he could put his street fighting instincts to use in the ring. When a seasoned pro named Antonio Fernandez beat up the callow 17-year-old, the kid swore he'd never box again. Two months later, however, he was back in the ring, this time fighting under the name of his sister's boyfriend, Rocky Graziano. He won the the Metropolitan AAU welterweight championship. ``The AAU gave me a medal which I hocked for $15,'' Graziano recalled years later. ``Maybe this is not so bad a racket after all, I think. I will give this a shake.''

DOC.HEAD: Dinkins Calls Again for Racial Unity
DOC.TEXT: Mayor David Dinkins on Tuesday urged New Yorkers to put aside racial antagonism and rededicate themselves to the ``values of justice, opportunity and caring.'' The public condemnation of racism, the second in 12 days by the city's first black mayor, follows a series of events that have heightened racial tensions in the city. ``We will never get ahead if we are fighting each other for crumbs falling from the table of opportunity,'' Dinkins told a rally of 6,000. ``The powerless are trying to prove their power by hurting those who are just as powerless. It must stop and it must stop now.'' The most recent irritant to race relations was a pair of verdicts in the so-called Bensonhurst case, the killing of a black teen-ager by a mob of white youths. One white teen-ager was convicted of killing a black youth during a gang attack in a predominantly white section of Brooklyn in August. A co-defendant was acquitted of murder in the case but convicted of lesser charges. A black boycott of a Korean-American owned grocery store in Brooklyn and a speech by a City University professor who espouses white supremacy also have brought recent front-page headlines. Dinkins, in announcing the city-sponsored Unity Rally on Monday, said ``a silent majority'' needed to be heard above the voices of some activists who have been fueling instead of soothing tensions. ``Wherever you come from or what's been done to you, you have no right to lash out against others,'' Dinkins told the rally Tuesday night at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine. ``I'm tired of hatred. I've seen too much of it. Too much pain and too much suffering and I'm sick of it. So let me be blunt _ I need your help.'' Gov. Mario Cuomo urged New Yorkers to turn crisis into opportunity. ``We need to refocus our hostility away from one another and onto the government's policies that neglect people in need,'' Cuomo said. ``Mr. President, read our lips: We need your help and we are entitled to it.'' Cardinal John O'Connor, head of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York, told the rally, ``I will unite every single day with the religious, political leaders of this city. I will spend every waking moment and as much as possible of every night to try to help achieve unity.'' The speeches, regularly interrupted by standing ovations and cheers, were broadcast live on local television. Inside the cathedral 2,800 people were seated and at least 2,000 more stood, while another 1,000 listened to the speeches outside via loudspeakers, said Paul Gorman, a cathedral spokesman. The mood inside was jubilant among a crowd that was about one-third black, one-third white and one-third Hispanic and Asian and crossed all lines of age and occupation. About a dozen black demonstrators picketed outside, refusing to talk to reporters and holding signs that read: ``Let's take our peace, justice and unity rally to Bensonhurst.'' That is the mostly white neighborhood where the August gang attack occurred and where blacks marching last weekend were pelted with obscenities and pieces of watermelon. Keith Mondello, 19, was acquitted of murder and manslaughter Friday but convicted of lesser charges in the Aug. 23 attack on 16-year-old Yusuf Hawkins. On Thursday, Joseph Fama, also white and also 19, was convicted of murder in the Hawkins slaying.

DOC.HEAD: Arab League Envoy says U.N. Council to Meet Friday in Geneva
With AM-Middle East Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: UNITED NATIONS _ The U.N. Security Council will meet Friday in Geneva to hear PLO chairman Yasser Arafat because the U.S. government has not granted him a visa to speak in New York, the Arab League announced late Tuesday. ``Yes, we definitely will go to Geneva,'' said Clovis Maksoud, permanent observer of the 22-nation League of Arab States. He made the statement to reporters as the Security Council held informal consultations on an emergency meeting to discuss violence in Israel and the occupied territories. The council was expected to make a formal statement later. The U.S. government had not accepted or rejected the request for a visa for the Palestine Liberation Organization leader. But Arab diplomats indicated the United States did not oppose a move to Geneva. The PLO requested an immediate U.S. visa for Arafat, who is considered the head of the Palestine state, to address the Security Council in New York. Arab envoys said they decided on the Geneva move in order to consider the pressing issue of how the council can help safeguard the rights of Palestinians. ``We do not seek confrontation, we are seeking protective measures for the Palestinian people,'' Maksoud told reporters. ``We did not back down. No deal has been done with the United States (on not forcing the visa issue).'' Arafat last visited the United States in 1974 when he addressed the General Assembly on Palestine. Two years ago the United States refused to grant him a visa to address the assembly about the Palestine problem, on grounds his was a terrorist organization. The assembly in defiance shifted the 159-nation assembly to Geneva to hear him. There, in December 1988, Arafat delivered a speech that opened a new chapter in Middle East diplomacy. He renounced terrorism and implicitly recognized Israel's right to exist within secure borders. As a result of his statement, the United States opened a dialogue with the PLO in Tunis. The Security Council has met outside New York only twice: in January 1972 in Addis Ababa, Ethiopia, to discuss African matters, and March 1973 in Panama City to discuss the Panama Canal.

DOC.HEAD: Record Company Mogul Morris Levy Faced Prison for Conspiracy Conviction
DOC.TEXT: When record company mogul Morris Levy died, he left a legacy of shady dealing in a career that spanned more than 40 years. Levy, who died Monday of cancer at age 62, was facing a $250,000 fine and 10 years in prison for a May 1988 conviction on two federal counts of conspiring to extort $1.25 million from a Pennsylvania record wholesaler. Free on bail, Levy tried to have his sentence reduced to zero in January because of his failing health. Although that was denied, he eventually was granted a 90-day stay and would have reported to jail on July 16. Levy owned several nightclubs in the 1940s and 50s, including the world famous jazz mecca Birdland in New York. He became active as a music publisher and record company owner in the 1950s. His company, Roulette Records, produced such hits in the 1950s as ``Why Do Fools Fall in Love'' and ``Peppermint Twist'' and helped develop such stars as Tommy James. In the 1970s, Levy entered the record retail business and opened a chain of Strawberries record shops in the Northeast. Eventually, he became linked to organized crime. In a case authorities called an example of how the mob was trying to infiltrate the recording industry, Levy, Roulette comptroller Howard Fisher, and reputed Genovese crime family member Dominick Canterino were charged with the attempted shakedown of record wholesaler John LaMonte of Darby, Pa. Levy denied the allegations, but after a three-week trial in federal court in Camden, N.J., a jury convicted Levy, Fisher and Canterino. Levy appealed but a federal appeals court upheld the conviction in October. Prosecutors had presented hours of taped conversations obtained by government wiretaps at Levy's office and other locations. FBI documents filed in the case said government agencies believed Levy, a self-made millionaire, had been involved with organized crime for 20 years. Levy had been the principal shareholder of BeckZack Corp., which owned the 81-store Strawberries chain. He sold the chain last year.

DOC.HEAD: PLO Chief Asks to Enter U.S. For U.N. Session
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS lede with two grafs to note Arab League announcement from a0774; editing to conform
DOC.TEXT: Yasser Arafat, chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization, wanted the Bush administration to allow him to attend a U.N. Security Council session in New York City, U.S. officials said Tuesday. But the question apparently became moot during the evening. The Arab League said in New York the Security Council would meet in Geneva to hear Arafat, as it did once before, and an announcement was expected from U.N. officials. Arafat made an indirect request for an entry visa in a letter to U.N. Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar with the expectation it would be passed on to the State Department. The United States denied Arafat a visa two years ago for a similar Mideast debate at the United Nations. U.S. officials, speaking on condition of anonymity, said no decision had been made because the situation was ``hypothetical.'' It would remain hypothetical if the department passed word back to the PLO that the visa request would be denied. ``We're hearing reports a formal application will be made, but as of this briefing we have not received anything,'' Margaret D. Tutwiler, the State Department spokeswoman, told reporters at mid-day. If Arafat had gone to the United Nations, the PLO's stature would have been elevated dramatically. That would come at a time when Israel is being pressured, even by friends such as the United States, because of the force it has used to try to stem a violent uprising by Palestinian Arabs on the West Bank and in Gaza. When the Reagan administration refused to allow Arafat to attend a U.N. General Assembly session in November 1988, the debate was shifted to Geneva. A month later, in an electrifying reversal of policy, the administration opened talks with the PLO. Arafat, following U.S. instructions, had publicly renounced terrorism and said he recognized Israel's right to exist. However, the PLO covenant still calls for dismantling the Jewish state. The State Department told Congress in March that the PLO was adhering to its commitment renouncing terrorism. In denying the PLO's application for a visa in 1988 despite overwhelming pressure from many other U.N. members, then-Secretary of State George P. Shultz said ``the U.S. government has convincing evidence that PLO elements have engaged in terrorism against Americans and other targets.'' Shultz also said that Arafat ``knows of, condones and lends support to such acts'' and is ``an accessory to such terrorism.'' A month later, Shultz took the lead in opening U.S. talks with the PLO. Those talks are continuing in Tunis, the PLO headquarters. Through Egypt, the PLO has registered its terms for talks between Palestinians and Israel in Cairo. Secretary of State James A. Baker III has been unable to persuade Israel to adopt the terms _ participation by exiled Palestinians and by residents of East Jerusalem. Israeli Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir is trying to shut the PLO out of the elections he has proposed for the West Bank and Gaza. Arafat, speaking Monday in Baghdad, Iraq, appealed to President Bush to pressure Israel to stop what the PLO chairman described as atrocities against Palestinians. Arafat rejected Israeli claims that the lone Israeli gunman who shot and killed seven Palestinian workers near Tel Aviv on Sunday was mentally unbalanced. He accused Shamir of planning ``a criminal scheme against the Palestinians and the intefadeh.'' Intefadeh is the Arab name for the revolt against Israel's control of the West Bank and Gaza, which were surrendered by Jordan and Egypt in their 1967 war against Israel.

U.S. taxpayers will foot Manuel Noriega's legal bills until $20 million of his frozen assets are confiscated or released, under a deal that averts disclosure of secret U.S. payments to the fallen dictator. Before the deal was reached Monday, Noriega's lawyers had threatened to quit the drug trafficking case because they hadn't been paid. Prosecutors froze the former Panamanian leader's assets, contending they were illegally obtained. In agreeing to cover Noriega's legal fees, the government headed off a confrontation over $11 million in U.S. intelligence agency payments he claims to have received over several decades. Noriega's lawyers had been trying to force the government to produce secret records of those payments to show Noriega had legitimate sources of income other than drugs. But on Monday, the defense agreed to drop the subpoenas when the deal involving Noriega's legal fees is formally approved.

In a move that could delay plans to merge the two German economies, the opposition Social Democrats have demanded alterations in the newly signed economic treaty with East Germany. Hans-Jochen Vogel, the Social Democrats' national chairman, told reporters Monday his party wants to negotiate with Chancellor Helmut Kohl's government over improving the treaty's terms for East Germans. The Social Democrats' position could spell trouble for the economic merger treaty, which was signed Friday at a ceremony in Bonn. According to the treaty the two Germanys are to be one economic entity by July 2. The treaty must still be approved by the parliaments of both countries. The Social Democrats recently won control of the upper house in West Germany's parliament by defeating Kohl's Christian Democrats in two key state elections.

Tailor-made antibodies can dramatically reverse spreading melanoma, the deadliest form of skin cancer, when injected directly into the tumors, researchers say. The work, though still in its preliminary stages, suggests that it may be possible to stop the disease by harnessing the body's own built-in defenses. Antibodies are among the body's principal weapons for fighting off a variety of foreign invaders, including cancer. In this case, scientists crafted human antibodies in the test tube that were specifically targeted against the cancer. Then they injected them into cancerous growths on victims' skin. ``The lesions dry up and regress,'' said Dr. Donald Morton, director of the John Wayne Surgical Oncology Clinic at the University of California, Los Angeles.

Auto industry lobbyists are working to head off attempts to toughen smog controls in the House clean air bill, including a requirement to build 1 million non-gasoline powered cars a year. The proposal, being pushed by Rep. Henry Waxman, D-Calif., is expected to provide the most fireworks when the air pollution control bill comes up for floor votes on Thursday. The sweeping legislation is the first strengthening of federal clean air laws in 13 years and imposes new curbs on acid rain pollution, industrial toxic releases and smog-causing emissions from industry and automobiles. It is expected to cost more than $21 billion a year when fully implemented. The Senate approved a similar measure in April.

Disheartened by U.S. reluctance to allow the export of supercomputers to Israel, scientists in that country are researching a new system more powerful than anything the United States has, Israeli university officials say. Three Israeli institutions have applied for licenses to buy Cray and IBM supercomputers, but the permits have been delayed out of U.S. concern that Israel might use the fast-computing systems to develop nuclear weapons and ballistic missiles. U.S. government agencies have been considering the applications for almost two years but thus far have refused to grant the permits. ``The writing's on the wall,'' said Maia Hauser, the U.S. spokeswoman for Technion, Israel's leading high-tech university. ``We'll have to go it on our own.'' The university is asking supporters in the United States to raise funds for an alternative to the U.S. computers.

DOC.HEAD: `Twin Peaks' Star Doesn't Even Know Who Killed Laura
DOC.TEXT: Peggy Lipton co-stars on ``Twin Peaks,'' yet even she doesn't know who killed Laura Palmer. ``I don't know if anyone on the cast knows,'' she says. Hard to believe, given that someone on the show must have done it. Unless it was the bird. And the bird was killed off in last week's episode. Or maybe it was the dancing dwarf who spoke in reverse. Who knows. But ABC promises that if you watch tonight's season finale, you'll know. And the murder of 17-year-old Laura, the driving force behind the new show with more twists than a road through the Cascades, will finally be resolved. ``I don't think there is a plot line,'' says Miss Lipton, asked to explain the disjointed maneuvers of ``Twin Peaks,'' one of the most publicized programs in television history. ``It's like life. Sometimes it doesn't make sense.'' Miss Lipton plays world-weary Norma Jennings, owner of the town's Double R diner, who is torn between two men, one of them named ``Big Ed.'' It's a long way from the smoky-voiced, bell-bottomed Julie Barnes of TV's ``The Mod Squad.'' You remember that show. Miss Lipton, Michael Cole and Clarence Williams III running down an alley in the program's title sequence. From 1968 to 1973, they played hip, anti-establishment cops while Williams spent much time uttering the word ``solid'' whenever confronted with something totally cool. Miss Lipton's role consisted mostly of looking sullen behind stringy blond hair and misting up every now and then. She faded from view with the show's demise, appearing on television only in ``Mod Squad'' reruns and a dismal 1979 television movie dubbed ``Return of the Mod Squad.'' After more than a decade of self-imposed exile, Miss Lipton has returned. Her children more than half grown, her marriage to legendary record producer Quincy Jones long over, the actress who was 18 years old when she filmed the Mod Squad pilot is grown up, secure and finally ready to stand on her own. ``When I was doing `Mod Squad,' I was really very insecure,'' says Miss Lipton, sitting in a Hollywood office where she has just finished a photo shoot that had her lounging seductively on a Porsche. ``I really didn't like myself very much.'' For more than 10 years after ``Mod Squad'' left the airwaves, Miss Lipton devoted herself to her husband and her two daughters. ``My mother was a career woman who wasn't home enough,'' she says. ``I never wanted my children to have that yearning.'' With the exception of ``Return of the Mod Squad,'' Miss Lipton did not pursue acting again until 1985. She made a couple of forgettable movies, divorced Jones and did a lot of auditions. ``People were usually very curious,'' she said of reactions to her re-emergence in Hollywood as something other than Jones' wife. But it was not until the actress met David Lynch, the quirky and decidedly different director who made ``Blue Velvet,'' ``Eraserhead,'' and ``Elephant Man,'' that she felt something click. Lynch and former ``Hill Street Blues'' writer Mark Frost were about to film the pilot for ``Twin Peaks,'' and somehow Miss Lipton was called to audition. ``I don't even know if David knew who I was,'' she says. ``Mark Frost brought up my name. Someone told me later that I read for the part, but I was so nervous I didn't remember.'' She got the part, as did other actors who had vanished from the public viewing eye for awhile. Michael Ontkean from ``The Rookies'' television show of the 1970s was cast as doughnut-loving sheriff Harry S. Truman. Richard Beymer of ``West Side Story'' became hotelier Benjamin Horne. And on the set of ``Twin Peaks,'' the cast that also includes Piper Laurie, Joan Chen from the Oscar-winning ``The Last Emperor'' and Kyle MacLachlan of ``Blue Velvet'' found themselves in a surreal environment. ``While we were shooting, it was like a film within a film,'' says Miss Lipton, who is now 42. ``I'd never seen a crew like that _ so quiet, so tuned in to David that they watched his every move. ``There was not a lot of set talk. All these people were quite mysterious.'' Not to mention the characters they portray, from a log-toting woman called simply ``The Log Lady,'' to pie-fixated FBI man Dale Cooper, to the one-armed man, that dancing midget and Laura's mom, who has psychic visions. Take a Dramamine, watch the final episode tonight and get ready for more. ABC announced this week that ``Twin Peaks,'' despite its mediocre ratings, has been picked up for the fall season.

Elsewhere in television ... TWIN PEAKS REDUX: More ``Twin Peaks'' bizarreness. Playwright Stan Barr claims his two-act comedy titled ``Twin Peaks,'' produced in 1985 about the San Francisco community of the same name, was lynched for television. Barr claims he has no choice but to change his play's name. ``It's like asking the author of `April in Paris' to change the title to `April in Bucharest,''' he says.

DOC.BYLINE: What Happened With Tax Reform? ^By JOHN CUNNIFF
DOC.TEXT: In the 1980s the American people learned the wonderful uses of debt _ government, business and personal, the underlying urge in all three being the ability to buy things now, not later. They also learned the penalties, especially as high interest rates denied them the opportunity not just to buy for the future but to finance the present and the past as well. The Gramm-Rudman Act forced government to at least attempt scaling back, and the phasing out of tax deductions on installment debt has made individuals more conscious of saving rather than spending. But business debt is another matter. It is still encouraged, at least by the tax system. At a time when concerns about corporate debt make news every day, U.S. tax policy continues to encourage borrowing over the old-fashioned way, which is to finance through equities, or the sale of ownership shares to the public. Consider the ways: _For corporations, interest payments on borrowed money is a tax-deductible expense, but payment of dividends to shareholders is not. _Owners of common stock are taxed twice, first when corporations pay taxes on profits and again when shareholders pay taxes on dividends and capital gains. But interest on bonds is taxed only once, as income to the bondholder. _The 1986 tax act raised the maximum capital gains tax rate to 33 percent from 20 percent, while lowering the maximum rate on ordinary income, including income from interest, to 33 percent from 50 percent. The situation causes Wright Investors' Service, among others, to warn that changes should be considered in corporate taxation, if not specifically for the good of corporations then for the good of the entire economy. It argues that while the high corporate debt doesn't assure a recession, ``it certainly increases the risk and potential severity of the consequences, in terms of bankruptcies and job losses.'' In addition, the first defense against inflation is greater productivity, which means capital investment in new techniques, new plants, new equipment. But capital investment is hardly encouraged by the tax law. This is the direction of corporate debt: _Non-financial corporate borrowing as a percentage of gross national product rose to 67 percent last year from 47 percent 20 years earlier, and 39 percent 30 years ago. _In the 20 years through 1989, the ratio of interest expense to corporate earnings more than doubled to 40 percent. _In the late 1980s, half of all funds raised by non-financial corporations came from debt issues, with the other 50 percent from equity offerings. But as recently as the 1960s and 1970s, the average was only 24 percent debt. Why debt was encouraged by the tax law in corporate matters while discouraged elsewhere in the economy is one of the mysteries of so-called tax reform. Junk bonds and their collapse can be traced directly to it. Not just junk bonds, but other techniques for overleveraging that preceded the savings and loan crisis, have their roots in tax law. That, in turn, has led to a self-imposed tight money policy by banks, relatively high interest rates and a sluggish economy. Could this be what the tax reformers had in mind?

DOC.HEAD: Reports Scanty on Protesters Still Imprisoned
DOC.NOTE: Eds: In b0460, moved May 21, SUB 20th graf `He acknowledged' to CORRECT spelling to Columbia
DOC.TEXT: Ren Wanding, a veteran of Chinese jails, was mentally prepared for arrest several weeks before police arrived at his apartment door last June 10. Even before soldiers and tanks rolled into central Beijing on June 3 to end popular protests for democracy, Ren's name had been raised in private official meetings as one of the ``very few counterrevolutionaries'' who eventually would be blamed for the whole movement. Friends alerted him, but Ren said May 27, after a last meeting with foreign journalists, that he wasn't running. ``This is my freedom of speech,'' said the skinny, bespectacled accountant, who for six months had been writing and distributing essays calling for human rights and the rule of law. ``I must speak. It is my fate to do these things.'' Nine months after his arrest, Ren, now 45, was charged with counterrevolutionary incitement. With his prison record, four years served for participating in a 1978 democracy movement, he is likely to get more than the minimum five years. ``I keep having this vision, that Ren comes home and I'm not there and he can't get in,'' his wife, Zhang Fengying, said soon after his arrest. Now, with hope of an early release gone, friends say she has become deeply depressed. She has not been allowed to see him, only to deliver clothes and books. Ren is believed held in Qincheng Prison, western Beijing, where many of last year's protesters were sent, but it has not been confirmed. There have been no reports on his condition, but before his arrest Ren predicted he would manage. ``I'm experienced,'' he said. A little more is known about the fate of Wang Dan, a Beijing University sophomore who was at the forefront of many marches and was arrested in July. Reports from others jailed with him and later released, and from friends who received a postcard from jail, indicate he has enough to eat but little exercise, and is allowed to read newspapers and approved books. His parents, Beijing intellectuals, were allowed to visit in January, a rare exception to the usual rule of no visits before sentencing. Some reports say Wang has shown what authorities call ``a good attitude'' and may be released, but two large prisoner releases _ 573 people last winter and 211 in May _ did not include him. Just before martial law was declared in May 1989, Wang, then 20, was impatient when asked if he feared arrest. Didn't he remember Wei Jingsheng, another youth who led a democracy movement and has been in jail for 11 years? ``How can we worry about one person's safety?'' Wang replied, standing in his dormitory hall with a dinner bowl in his hand. ``Besides, I'm too busy. What can we do, anyway? If they want to arrest us, they will.'' Gao Xin, a hunger striker released from prison in December, believes his friend and fellow hunger striker, Liu Xiaobo, also will be freed. ``It's as if the government is sifting sand,'' said Gao, who used to edit a university newspaper but has been unemployed since his release. ``The little pieces will fall through the sieve _ I fell out early _ and only the big ones will be charged.'' He acknowledged that Liu, a teacher of Chinese literature with a passion for politics, might be a ``big piece.'' Liu returned from New York, where he planned to lecture at Columbia University, to take part in the spring democracy movement. Official media have singled him out frequently. The government even compiled a slim paperback volume of criticism of the ``crazy turmoil inciter.'' Liu, 34, has not been charged with anything so far, even though he has been held since early June. His wife and in-laws were allowed to visit him in January at Qincheng Prison _ a good sign, Gao said _ and found he had put on weight from lack of exercise. He is allowed to read books sent from home. Reports are that he, like most of the other intellectuals, receives better treatment from guards than common criminals and is not physically abused. Despite the releases, arrests continue. Chinese sources said police went to the home of a college teacher last month and told him to come for a walk. He never returned. A few dissidents still write political tracts and plant them cautiously in bicycle racks and public places, but they meet only in very small groups of trusted friends and have no immediate plans for protests or acts of sabotage. Some would-be activists make pilgrimages to Beijing, seeking leadership. Recently, a 20-year-old worker got off a train from the south and began looking for ``an armed rebel group,'' without success. None is known to exist. ``In our country, there aren't many people willing to sacrifice themselves,'' he said disconsolately. ``I am willing.'' Sacrifice is more prosaic for the wife of one jailed protester. Without his income, she faces financial difficulty. She has had to send their child to her parents and fears losing their apartment. She said she is willing to deal with those problems because, ``while he is in jail, I should sacrifice.'' When he comes out, she said, ``I'll dance up a storm.''

DOC.HEAD: Daunting Odds for Candidates Who Take on House Members
DOC.TEXT: The odds are daunting for the 400 or so candidates who will challenge incumbent congressmen this November. Chances are, fewer than a dozen will win. Discontent over the pay raise that House members voted themselves, talk of a tax increase and ethical lapses could spell trouble for some members of Congress. But over the years few bets have been safer than a House incumbent's re-election. The success rate has been as high as 98 percent in recent years and many believe the re-election rate will approach that figure this time around. The two parties are jostling over about 30 ``open'' seats, where no incumbent is running. But otherwise this fall generally is viewed as a warm-up for 1992. That's when the pattern should break. The redrawing of congressional districts and a surge in retirements will reshape the House, giving Republicans a rare chance to regain a House majority, or to come close. Currently, the House is controlled by Democrats by a 257-176 margin, with two vacancies. ``Basically the parties have written off the House in 1990 and are putting all their energies into '92,'' said Thomas Mann of the Brookings Institution, a liberal think tank. With all the advantages available to members of Congress, high re-election rates have become the norm for House races, much more so than for senators. Members of Congress have an arsenal of weapons to keep their names in front of voters: taxpayer-financed mail privileges, a staff to help solve constituents' problems, ready access to news coverage and an overwhelming advantage in raising money. ``Let's face it,'' said Rep. John G. Rowland, R-Conn. ``You have to be a bozo to lose this job.'' Some call this the ``permanent Congress.'' It is at the heart of political debates over campaign finance reform, redistricting, even proposals to limit House and Senate members to 12 years in office. Rowland, who is running for governor, is among the handful bypassing likely re-election. Republicans, stymied by 36 years in the minority, are more frequently departing the House for other offices. Eight are running for the Senate this year. For those who choose to remain, the odds are good. The rate of re-election has been 98 percent or better in the last two election years, and it was 96 percent in the face of the 1984 Republican presidential landslide. The rate hasn't dipped below 90 percent since 1974, the Watergate year that swept Republicans out of Congress. Over the last two election years, only 15 out of more than 800 candidates who challenged incumbents were successful. A challenger's best chance to overcome the odds comes when scandal befalls the incumbent. Of the seven incumbents who were defeated in 1988, four had been implicated in scandal. Scandal already has claimed one seat this year. Republican Donald E. ``Buz'' Lukens of Ohio lost renomination after he was convicted on misdemeanor charges for having sex with a 16-year-old girl. But even a sex scandal doesn't necessarily end a House career. Democratic Rep. Barney Frank of Massachusetts, who admitted he had a relationship with a male prostitute, is given a good chance of winning re-election this year. Both parties' congressional campaign committees have targeted some incumbents for defeat, based on scandal or other vulnerability. Among those considered vulnerable are the 22 Democrats and 20 Republicans who were elected with 55 percent or less of the vote in 1988. Democrats, for example, hope to oust Rep. Denny Smith, R-Ore., who won re-election by just 707 votes last time, is on the hit list of a national abortion-rights group and has become enmeshed in the savings and loan problems. Republicans see an opportunity to oust some potentially vulnerable Democrats but also must defend the seats vacated by their Senate candidates.Most of their best opportunities are for vacant Democratic seats. Their other targets include three North Carolina Democrats whose districts always produce squeakers. The pay raise Congress voted itself late last year could emerge as an issue for challengers, even though Republican and Democratic leaders agreed to a non-aggression pact to win its passage. Some challengers are using the issue anyway. It is blamed for the surprisingly close scrape veteran Rep. John Murtha, D-Pa., had in his recent primary. President Bush's apparent willingness to consider tax increases as part of a budget solution could confound some Republican candidates' plans to attack Democrats as tax raisers. Ed Rollins, head of the Republican Congressional Campaign Committee, called the tax talk ``a disaster'' for his candidates. Charles Cook, who publishes a political newsletter, argues that a surprise may be in store for incumbents of both parties this year. Congress, he figures, has taken a beating over the pay raise, savings-and-loan scandals, sex scandals, and attention on speech fees and campaign money since Speaker Jim Wright was forced to resign. ``A potentially explosive combination of unrelated events and news stories with a single common thread are all extremely unflattering to Congress,'' Cook said. ``The result may well be a re-election rate closer to the normal 94 percent to 96 percent range.'' Both parties need skillful challengers to exploit any possibilities, and recruiting good candidates has been a problem. Republicans in particular have had trouble, and their longtime minority status in the House is only one reason. ``It's much easier for Democrats to recruit a candidate than for the Republicans,'' said Rep. Mickey Edwards, D-Okla. ``Republicans tend to be people who want government out of their lives. ... They're just not inclined.'' Money is the big obstacle for any challenger. Special-interest political action committees, or PACs, tend to direct their money to the candidate most likely to win. ``Political campaigns today are determined by money, media and personal influence,'' said Harold Coker, a Republican who lost a 1988 challenge in Tennessee. ``If you are `in' you have access to it all, but if you are `out,' you're just out of luck.'' The high success rate for incumbents who seek re-election doesn't mean there isn't turnover in Congress, since some members opt to run for other office or retire. The median number of terms served by House members in the current Congress is just five, or 10 years, said the Brookings Institution's Mann. The changes expected in 1992 may bring as many as 80 to 100 new members. Redistricting will encourage retirements and could pit some incumbents against one another. Other incumbents may decide to take the money and run, since 1992 is the last year they can pocket their unspent campaign treasuries upon retirement.

DOC.HEAD: Noted Black Crime-Fighter Sought By Two Old-South Cities
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: One of the nation's top cops, Reuben M. Greenberg, is on the ``Most Wanted'' list of two historic Southern port cities eager to keep him fighting crime on their streets. The innovative officer is the once-and-future police chief of Charleston, S.C. He's also midway through a six-month contract as public safety director in this bustling coastal city. Charleston expects him back in July. Mobile's leaders want him to stay. ``People have got to stop zeroing in on me as the magic man,'' said Greenberg, the author of ``Let's Take Back Our Streets,'' which details the law enforcement philosophy that has made him so popular on the lecture circuit. His methods have worked like magic in Charleston. The murder rate is half what it was when he arrived in 1982; the overall crime rate has dropped more than 35 percent. Will his methods work in Mobile, a city with 2{ times as many people and almost six times as much crime as Charleston? That's what Greenberg is here to find out. If his street-level assault is effective here, it might work in New York or Los Angeles, too. Greenberg does it by putting cops where the crime is _ in housing projects, on street corners, in front of crack houses and outside hotels where prostitutes take their customers. He works to win the trust and cooperation of inner-city residents who have lost faith in the system and have come to expect crime as part of their daily lives. ``They've given up whole sections of the city to the criminal element,'' said Greenberg, 47, who arrived in Mobile on Feb. 1 with the blessing of Charleston Mayor Joseph Riley Jr. ``It's bad, but it wasn't worse than what I expected,'' he said. ``What is worse than I expected is the willingness of the people to accept criminal activity. I'd like to push down those expectations.'' Greenberg himself is somewhat unexpected: black, balding, the grandson of a Russian Jew who emigrated to Houston and married a black woman. The family shortened its name to Green and were practicing Methodists, but Greenberg changed his name back again and converted to Judaism. The chief, who holds master's degrees in public administration and city planning, began his law enforcement career 22 years ago, the last eight of which he has spent in Charleston. ``He's as energetic as hell,'' Charleston Police Major Edward Hethington said of Greenberg, who has taken some of his Charleston officers to Mobile to help train some of this city's force. Mobile is Alabama's second-largest city, and Greenberg is the first black to be placed at the helm of any of the state's major municipal police forces. Birmingham, the state's largest city, has a black majority and a black mayor, but it never has had a black police chief or public safety commissioner. Mobile's crime problem mainly involves black perpetrators and black victims. ``If we could have an impact on crime in the black areas, you'd have a tremendous impact on crime in the city, because that's where the crime victims are,'' Greenberg said. ``Half of the rape victims in this town are black women. Almost all of the robbers are blacks, and their victims are about 70 percent black as well.'' Early indications are that police in Mobile have made headway in driving drug dealers out of two housing projects and prostitutes off the streets. Two recent sweeps snared 39 people seeking to buy sex in downtown areas long known for illicit sexual activity. If a drug dealer is controlling a street corner, Greenberg puts an officer on the same corner every day until the dealer goes away. The result: public confidence is restored, and the dealer and drug-related crime disappear. In the Charleston projects, there were only 18 drug-dealing arrests last year. ``The key to the thing is at the retail level,'' Greenberg said. ``That's where you have to hit them.'' Public Housing Director James Alexander said the two housing projects targeted by Greenberg were ``clean as a whistle'' after the public safety commissioner opened police stations inside the projects and started chasing drug dealers on scooters. ``You'll see crime being reduced dramatically in the areas in which we control,'' Greenberg predicted. ``Eventually, that will be the city as a whole. I would want to see it for a six-month period. I wouldn't want to see a month or two months _ that's flash-in-the-pan. ``Even after a year, I wouldn't be satisified, until you really turn the corner. You're going to have two or three years of decreasing crime in areas that you're impacting. You better hope it's not increasing in the areas you're not impacting.'' Part of Greenberg's crime-fighting strategy is to convince ghetto residents that the police will respond to them. Common courtesy on his officers' part is one way to do it, and Greenberg sets the example. ``He missed his first meeting with me in Charleston by 20 minutes because he stopped to help a woman get her car started,'' Mobile Mayor Mike Dow said, noting that Greenberg has his officers carry jumper cables in their patrol cars, something they didn't do before. ``He's just very conscious of the public.''
