DOC.HEAD: Thumbnail Sketches of Protest Leaders
With BC-China One Year Later
DOC.NOTE: Eds: In b0764, which moved May 21, SUBS 7th graf, Liu Xiaobo sketch, to CORRECT spelling to Columbia
DOC.TEXT: Here are brief profiles of leaders of the Chinese pro-democracy movement crushed a year ago:

IN EXILE Wu'er Kaixi _ 22, a freshman education major at Beijing Normal University who grabbed a megaphone during one of the first sit-down protsts and persuaded the crowd to hold its ground against police. He became one of the movement's most prominent leaders and boldly challenged Premier Li Peng during a televised meeting. Wu'er went into hiding June 4, 1989, and turned up in Hong Kong three weeks later. He now lives in the United States.

Chai Ling _ 24, sometimes called La Pasionaria of Tiananmen Square for her emotional, tearful speeches. She was a graduate psychology student at Beijing Normal University and emerged as a spokeswoman early in the pro-democracy movement. Some other students said she was too unstable and fond of notoriety. She was among the 21 most-wanted students after the June 4 army attack. After months in hiding, Chai and her husband, Feng Congde, also on the wanted list, arrived in Paris in April. She has been nominated for the 1990 Nobel Peace Prize.

IN JAIL Wang Dan _ 21, sophomore history student at Beijing University, arrested in July 1989 after being named the most-wanted student leader in China. He became prominent on campus in 1988 by organizing unofficial lectures. Guest speakers included physicist and political dissident Fang Lizhi, whom Wang greatly admired. Later, he helped lead the spring marches. Wang's parents, both Beijing intellectuals, were allowed to visit him in prison in January. He has not been charged.

Liu Gang _ 29, No. 3 on the government list of most-wanted protest leaders after Wang Dan and Wu'er Kaixi. Liu took part in 1986-87 student marches for democracy while a graduate physics student at Beijing University. When last year's movement began, he was working at a research institute and joined the students. On June 19, state television announced his arrest in Baoding, south of Beijing, where he was posing as a worker. There has been no word of him since.

Chen Xiaoping, 29, a teacher at the Politics and Law University in Beijing, who was arrested last summer. Friends say Chen was a Communist Party member who believed the system could be reformed from within. His first act of protest came as a graduate student at Beijing University in 1985, when he criticized officials for banning a student pro-democracy demonstration in Tiananmen Square. Last spring, he helped organize Beijing citizens behind the latest protest. A recent unconfirmed report said he was sentenced to 15 years in prison.

Ren Wanding _ 45, arrested at home June 10. An accountant with thick glasses and an intense manner, Ren took part in the 1978-79 democracy movement, which also was put down by senior leader Deng Xiaoping. He spent four years in jail. In November 1988, Ren began writing essays commemorating the earlier movement and calling for democratic change. When students began marching in the spring of 1989, he made speeches on campuses and at Tiananmen Square. He was charged in March with counterrevolutionary incitement, but there has been no word of a trial. His sentence could range from five years in prison to death.

Liu Xiaobo _ 34, a lecturer in Chinese literature at Beijing Normal, arrested the first week of June 1989 while bicycling from a friend's home. He was an outspoken critic of what he considered repressive aspects of traditional culture. When the protests began, he returned from the United States, where he was to teach at Columbia University, and joined in. He and three friends began a hunger strike June 2 in support of the students. When soldiers reached Tiananmen Square the morning of June 4, the four negotiated a peaceful retreat for the students. His wife and in-laws visited Liu at Qincheng Prison in January. He has not been charged.

Zhang Zhiyong _ About 24, a graduate student in international relations at Beijing University, arrested in July in Nanjing. He was one of three students who knelt for hours on the steps of the Great Hall of the People on April 22, 1989. They sought to deliver a student petition to China's top leaders, who were at a funeral service inside for former Communist Party chief Hu Yaobang. Friends said Zhang was optimistic to the end that the party would grant democratic reforms. He favored compromise rather than confrontation, a course other students rejected. Sources say he shares a cell with several other students. He has not been allowed visitors, but was permitted to write his family a letter.

Zhang Weiping _ A senior at the Zhejiang Fine Arts Institute in Hangzhou, sentenced in August to nine years in prison for having told the Voice of America that Hangzhou students forced local authorities to fly the flag at half-mast in honor of protesters slain June 3-4 in Beijing. The report was not true and Zhang was accused of spreading counterrevolutionary propaganda.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Sunday, May 27

DOC.TEXT: A surge in income tax payments helped the government set a record $42.52 billion budget surplus in April, one month after a record monthly deficit. April receipts reduced the deficit so far for the fiscal year that started last Oct. 1 to $108.34 billion, down from $150.85 billion in March but still 23.3 percent more than the deficit at this time last year, the Treasury Department reported Monday. The deficit still was more than the $100 billion target set by the Gramm-Rudman balanced budget law with five more months remaining in fiscal 1990.

Greyhound Lines Inc., acknowledging the heavy cost of a strike by its bus drivers, has asked holders of $225 million of its junk bonds to sell them back at steep discounts to keep the company out of bankruptcy. The company also said Monday it was changing its pay scale for drivers and withdrawing proposed bonus and pension schemes to save money. The announcements marked a dramatic change in tone from just two weeks ago, when Greyhound's chairman confidently declared victory in the strike after contract talks failed.

Microsoft Corp. stock strengthened, reflecting optimism about the formal unveiling of its computer software designed to give IBM computers and their clones the easy-to-use features of Apple Computer Inc.'s Macintosh. The leading software designer's Windows product was widely praised prior to its nationwide debut Tuesday in what was regarded as major event in personal computer advancements. Microsoft rose $2 to $70.25 in over-the-counter trading Monday. Apple fell 25 cents to $39.50.

United Auto Workers President Owen Bieber outlined a five-point bargaining plan for this summer's Big Three contract negotiations, including inflation protection for hundreds of thousands of retirees. Delivering the opening speech Monday at a three-day UAW bargaining convention, Bieber ticked off a list of bargaining priorities for when the union sits down with the Big Three shortly after Independence Day. For the first time in 11 years, UAW contracts with GM, Ford and Chrysler expire at the same moment: midnight, Sept. 14.

The Kremlin plans to double food prices as part of desperately needed economic reforms that will begin next year and not bring a turnaround until 1995. A preliminary draft of the economic program, released to Supreme Soviet deputies and obtained Monday by The Associated Press, ended weeks of speculation over whether the government would introduce Polish-style ``shock therapy'' or opt for a more gradual transition to a market economy.

Rupert Murdoch denied an Advertising Age story that said he was peddling TV Guide, only a few weeks after the media executive agreed to sell the Star supermarket tabloid. Murdoch said Monday he would give Ad Age's parent $1 million if it could prove the account, which said his News Corp. empire of publications was ``sounding out prospective buyers'' for TV Guide. Ad Age stood by the story.

The government slashed prices on everything from blue jeans to television sets in a bid to lure back consumers enamored with Western goods. The price cuts announced Monday were part of a broader strategy to smooth the transition to economic and political unity with West Germany. Meanwhile in Bonn, the main opposition party demanded changes in a newly signed economic treaty with the East that could delay reunification.

Motorola Inc. will begin universal drug testing of its 60,000 U.S. employees this year, apparently becoming the only major corporation besides Texas Instruments to test all workers for substance abuse. The giant electronics company has been testing job applicants since 1987, said spokeswoman Margot Brown. Under the expanded policy announced Monday, all employees will be tested within the next three years.

Convicted speculator Ivan F. Boesky bought stocks so voraciously that worried underlings curbed his appetite by telling him he had less money to spend than actually was available, a former aide said. The disclosure by Reid Nagle, one-time senior vice president for Ivan Boesky & Co., came his testimony Monday at the securities fraud trial of John Mulheren, a former Boesky associate. Boesky also was expected to testify.

The stock market reached a new high for the fourth time in the past six sessions Monday. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials climbed 24.77 points to 2,844.68, surpassing the previous peak of 2,831.71 established last Thursday. Bond prices rose slightly. The dollar gained ground against foreign currencies while gold fell in New York after rising in Europe. Soybean futures prices fell sharply in a continued reaction to bountiful harvest forecasts and greater supplies from South America. Grain futures also retreated; energy futures tumbled; precious metals were mixed, and livestock and meat futures were mixed.

DOC.HEAD: Rates Inch Up In Latest T-Bill Auction
DOC.TEXT: Interest rates on short-term Treasury securities rose at the latest auction to their highest level in two weeks. The Treasury Department sold $8.4 billion in three-month bills at an average discount rate of 7.74 percent on Monday, up from 7.67 percent last week. Another $8.4 billion was sold in six-month bills at an average discount rate of 7.79 percent, up from 7.68 percent last week. The rates were the highest since May 7 when three-month bills sold for 7.79 percent and six-month bills averaged 7.84 percent. The new discount rates understate the actual return to investors _ 8.00 percent for three-month bills with a $10,000 bill selling for $9,804.40 and 8.22 percent for a six-month bill selling for $9,604.00. In a separate report, the Federal Reserve said the average yield for one-year Treasury bills, the most popular index for making changes in adjustable rate mortgages, fell to 8.24 percent last week from 8.36 percent the previous week.

DOC.HEAD: Japanese Companies Introduce New Generation of Brainy Camcorders
DOC.TEXT: Fuzzy may not seem like a good feature for a camcorder, but Japanese electronics companies say ``fuzzy logic'' allows their new hand-held video cameras to produce sharper, jitter-free pictures. The camcorders are the latest in a growing number of Japanese consumer appliances to incorporate fuzzy logic, which uses high-powered semiconductors to enable computers to reason more like humans and recognize the nuances of the real world. The trend is yet another example of Japanese manufacturers taking an innovation developed in the United States and incorporating it more rapidly in consumer goods. Most computers can process information only in ``yes-no'' form, such as ``black or white'' or ``near or far.'' But fuzzy logic allows computers to think in degrees such as ``medium gray'' or ``rather close.'' To make such distinctions, the camcorders are packed with technology _ so much so that analysts say they're in the same league as hardware used in military guidance systems or reconnaissance satellites. In fact, the devices share many of the same technologies _ CCD sensors that convert light images to digital signals, digital pattern recognition circuits, sophisticated semiconductors and computers, all in super-miniature size. A camcorder's microcomputer uses fuzzy logic to give more accurate auto-focusing and auto-exposure by responding more smoothly and quickly to changing conditions, Itaru Ishizawa of Sanyo Electric Co. said. Sanyo's VM-ES88, the first camcorder to use fuzzy logic, sets the lens' exposure by dividing the image into 64 parts. By measuring the relative brightness of each part, the camera can calculate the best exposure and compensate automatically for strong lighting in front or back of the subject, he said. Most camcorders focus on whatever is in the middle of their field of view, but the VM-ES88's fuzzy logic helps it stay focused when a subject moves away from the center, Ishizawa said. The 8mm format camcorder weighs 1.7 pounds and is being sold in Japan for the equivalent of $1,060. Sanyo plans to begin marketing it in the United States in July and in Europe in the fall, Ishizawa said. Pentax is selling in Japan under its own brand name a similar camcorder made by Sanyo. It has the additional feature of time-lapse recording, such as one frame every 10 seconds, Toshihiro Tanaka of Pentax said. The company plans to begin sales in both the United States and Europe in the fall, he said. Matsushita Electric Industrial's new camcorder takes a different hi-tech tack for sharpening images with an electronic image stabilizer. The stabilizer reduces picture jitter caused by unsteady hands by digitally analyzing the camera's images and storing them in a memory. It detects brief shifts from previous images resulting from camera shakes and recalls the earlier image from the memory to smooth out the picture, Matsushita said. Matsushita, which uses the Panasonic brand name overseas, said it will begin selling the camcorder, called NV-S1, in Japan next month for the equivalent of $1,075. The unit, which uses VHS-C tapes, weighs 1.6 pounds. Sony, meanwhile, has announced a Video Walkman component set with a separate camera, deck, monitor and tuner that can be used in any combination. The 8mm format set, featuring the world's smallest and lightest video deck at 1.1 pounds and stereo sound, will begin selling in Japan in July for $1,070, the company said. Fuzzy logic was first developed in the 1960s by Lofti Zadeh, a professor at the University of California at Berkeley, but has won greater popularity in recent years in Japan. It guides elevators and subway trains to smooth starts and stops, and helps Sony's new keyboardless computer recognize thousands of hand-written Japanese characters. In recent months it even has appeared in the controls of washing machines, where it measures the degree of dirt in the clothes and amount of laundry, and in vacuum cleaners, where it calculates the quantity of dust and type of floor. Fuzzy logic's rapid rise in popularity among Japanese manufacturers illustrates the fierce technological competition in Japan's marketplace. It also shows how Japanese companies struggle to develop a market for new technologies. ``Fuzzy logic is a difficult concept to explain to customers,'' Sanyo's Ishizawa said. ``We generally explain that it's a more human way of analyzing information.'' The company has produced a videotape, he said, to explain the idea at stores selling the product.

DOC.HEAD: Microsoft Unveils Software That Makes IBM Computers Look Like Macintoshes
DOC.NOTE: Eds: News conference set for 3 p.m. EDT; No pms lead planned.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto, Graphic
DOC.TEXT: The popular Macintosh computer may be facing its strongest challenge yet as Microsoft Corp. unveils software that gives IBM computers and their clones the same easy-to-use features as the Apple Computer Inc. machine. Experts say the newest version of Microsoft's Windows product successfully replaces the arcane technical commands of most IBM computers with friendly on-screen graphics and a ``mouse,'' or hand-held control device. The development is being hailed by many computer experts as a watershed event for the Redmond, Wash.-based software company led by multibillionaire Bill Gates. Microsoft was scheduled to present its latest Windows at news conferences today in New York and several other cities in the United States and abroad. In addition to generating a publicity deluge, the introduction of the new software has grabbed the attention of Microsoft's competitors and pushed the price of Microsoft shares to a new 52-week high. Windows could spell trouble for Apple by ending the dilemma of many computer buyers: Whether to buy a user-friendly Macintosh, or an IBM or clone, which are harder to use but generally cheaper and compatible with many office systems. For Apple, ``it means they have seen their innovation lead in the market diminished,'' said Rick Sherlund, a computer analyst at Goldman, Sachs & Co. PaineWebber Inc. analyst Stephen K. Smith last week downgraded his rating of Apple stock from ``neutral'' to ``unattractive'' due to Windows. Smith hailed the new product as the biggest software development since the advent of 1-2-3, the spreadsheet program from Lotus Development Corp. that is among the most popular computer applications. Those opinions helped send Apple stock down $1.75 a share Friday in national over-the-counter trading to close at $39.75, while Microsoft shares, also traded over the counter, rose $3.50 to close at $68.25. On Monday, Microsoft rose $2 more to $70.25; Apple fell 25 cents to $39.50 after adjusting for a dividend. Coincidentally, Lotus announced late Friday it had called off its plan to merge with software maker Novell Inc. The merger was seen as providing a viable competitor to Microsoft in the personal computer software market. Apple, meanwhile, isn't standing still. The Cupertino, Calif.-based company is expected later this year to introduce a low-price version of the Macintosh. Apple also filed a lawsuit against Microsoft in 1988 contending earlier versions of Windows _ and, by implication, the new version _ infringe on Macintosh patents. The case is pending. Many experts say the Macintosh still is tops for graphics-intensive uses, such as desktop publishing. Microsoft also denies it is trying to edge out the Macintosh. Russ Warner, who headed the Windows development unit, says it would be crazy for the company to target the 7 percent of the computer market that uses the Macintosh, instead of the estimated 85 percent that uses IBM computers and their clones. ``We're talking about getting those 85 percent to understand the benefits of graphics,'' Warner said. Most IBM machines and compatibles use an operating system call MS-DOS, developed by Microsoft. Operating systems allow a computer to perform such basic functions as opening files and responding to keyboard commands. But MS-DOS is notorious for its complex series of typed commands. Windows, a type of program called a graphical user interface, shields users from these commands by replacing them with on-screen pictures called icons and a mouse. For example, instead of having to type a command telling the computer to print a file, Windows provides a representation of a printer. The user moves the cursor on the screen to the printer and pushes a button on the mouse to print the file. Windows software was introduced in 1985, later followed by a second version. But computer experts said neither provided a true competitor to the Macintosh. The new version, which will sell for $149, is vastly better, they say. In addition to providing a graphics-based way to operate computer functions, it can run several applications programs at once in different sections of the computer screen, called ``windows.'' It also greatly expands the amount of computer memory. Microsoft is expected to get a major boost from Windows. The company says the potential market for the software is about 30 million personal computers already in use. Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. projects Windows and related products will reap nearly $500 million in revenues for Microsoft in the fiscal year that starts July 1. Windows also is expected to help companies that make applications programs, such as word processing and spreadsheets, because computer users must buy specially tailored versions of these programs to gain the advantages of Windows. Microsoft is among the major makers of these programs. Windows also is expected to have an impact on an alternative operating system for personal computers developed by Microsoft and International Business Machines Corp., called Operating System 2, or OS-2. OS-2 was promoted as a graphics-based system for IBM personal computers when it was introduced in 1987, but it failed to catch on.

DOC.HEAD: Is Pattern Bargaining Dead?
With PM-UAW Convention
DOC.TEXT: Tougher competition in the automotive industry threatens the United Auto Workers' attempt to force a common contract on the nation's Big Three automakers, some analysts say. For the first time in 11 years, contracts between the UAW and General Motors Corp., Ford Motor Co. and Chrysler Corp. will expire at the same time _ midnight, Sept. 14. But the so-called pattern bargaining that characterized labor relations until 1979 may not be feasible in the hotly competitive 1990s. In the past decade U.S. automakers have lost market share, faced financial crises, slashed costs, joined with Japanese companies in joint ventures, closed factories and trimmed salaried and hourly work forces. The moves were inspired, at least in part, by competition from Japanese automakers, first with cars imported from overseas and later with vehicles made in the United States. As a result, negotiating strategies have changed. Twenty years ago, when the Big Three completely dominated the U.S. market, the UAW would pick one company as a target, settle on a contract and then impose the terms the other two. In turn, that contract would serve as a model for other large industrial unions, including steel and rubber workers. But Dale Brickner of Michigan State University says those days are over. ``These firms have different cost factors, they have different abilities to pay,'' he said Monday. ``If a pattern means that you are going back to the years of Xerox contracts, those days are dead and gone.'' UAW President Owen Bieber, speaking after the first day of a three-day union bargaining convention in Kansas City, disagreed. ``We're not going to end pattern bargaining,'' he said. ``I just moved Chrysler last time (in 1988) to a common expiration date. We're not going to get off pattern.'' In 1979, when Chrysler was on the brink of financial ruin, the No. 3 automaker broke from the pattern. Chrysler today faces fresh financial problems and industry observers have said it again is the mostly likely company to break the newly revived pattern. Chrysler's labor vice president, Anthony St. John, recently sounded an ominous tone when he said if the current contract is continued with no changes, it would boost the struggling automaker's labor costs by 16 percent. That hinted at the possibility of Chrysler seeking concessions from the UAW, something the union reluctantly swallowed in the early 1980s. Chrysler workers returned to near pay parity with their counterparts at Ford and GM in 1988. This year's negotiations, Brickner said, ``will determine whether an old econmic pattern will continue at all. With the Japanese in there, it ain't the same game any more.''

DOC.HEAD: Greyhound Offers To Buy Back Notes In Attempt To Avoid Bankruptcy
DOC.TEXT: Greyhound Lines Inc., acknowledging the heavy cost of a strike by its bus drivers, has asked holders of $225 million of its junk bonds to sell them back at steep discounts to keep the company out of bankruptcy. The company also said Monday it was changing its pay scale for drivers and withdrawing proposed bonus and pension schemes to save money. ``The ability to restructure the balance sheet in some way is very important to avoid bankruptcy,'' said Michael Doyle, the company's chief financial officer. The comment marked a dramatic change in tone from just two weeks ago, when Greyhound's chairman confidently declared victory in the strike after contract talks failed. ``The cost of the strike has been pretty expensive,'' Doyle said, and cash is ``very tight.'' Nevertheless, he said the only nationwide bus company is able to meet its payroll and buy fuel. Greyhound issued a variety of junk bonds to refinance debt taken on in a leveraged buyout three years ago. The bonds include $150 million due in 1995 that pay interest of 13 percent and $75 million of 12.5 percent bonds due in 1997. The two issues represented more than half of the company's total debt of $359 million at the end of 1989. The company is technically in default on the first issue after missing a recent interest payment, and noteholders could force the company into bankruptcy. As a result, Greyhound said it was making a cash tender offer to redeem the 13 percent notes at 54 percent of their face value and the 12.5 percent notes at 27.5 percent. Doyle said both offers are higher than prices currently quoted for the bonds in secondary markets. The offer is conditional on its acceptance by a majority of noteholders, plus their agreement of a change in some terms on the notes, especially those that restrict Greyhound's indebtedness and call for certain levels of net worth. The offer also is conditional on Greyhound being able to find financing to buy the bonds. The company's total debt stood at $359 million at the end of 1989. Most of Greyhound's 6,300 bus drivers walked out March 2 in a dispute over wages and job security. Greyhound immediately began operating a reduced schedule with newly hired drivers. After attempts to reopen negotiations collapsed, Chairman Fred G. Currey said May 7 the strike had become ``irrelevant'' because the carrier had enough drivers to operate. Union officials say their strike will continue to hobble Greyhound and the company will have to return to the bargaining table. Last week, a National Labor Relations official suggested the company had engaged in an unfair labor practice by instituting its contract offer on March 2. Such a finding, if upheld, could force the company to rehire union drivers. Greyhound said the strike caused it to lose $56 million in the first three months of the year. The company missed a $9.75 million interest payment due May 15 on the 13 percent notes and did not pay about $5 million in leases due at the end of April. Those missed payments left the door open for creditors to begin proceedings that could force the company into bankruptcy. ``This is a way of starting a dialogue with noteholders,'' Doyle said of the tender offer. The company put no time limit on the offer, although Doyle said regulations require it to be open for at least 20 business days. ``If they were to get this exchange offer off successfully, I would assume that they would avoid Chapter 11,'' said analyst Ken Frankel with Drake Capital Securities Inc. in Santa Monica, Calif. ``If they don't get it off, all bets are off.'' Under Chapter 11 of the federal Bankruptcy Code, companies are protected from creditors while they reorganize. Greyhound has hired Goldman, Sachs & Co. as a financial advisor to help in the debt restructuring. In another effort to save money, Greyhound said it would implement an hourly wage scale on Sept. 1, replacing its mileage-based scale for drivers. Spokesman George Gravley said the change from 30 cents a mile to $12.79 an hour effectively would increase pay for drivers on the East and West Coasts, but ``flatten or depress'' wages in the middle of the country. The company also withdrew bonus and pension provisions it had proposed but not implemented. In a letter to all employees, Vice President P. Anthony Lannie said, ``We simply can no longer afford to continue these programs.''

DOC.HEAD: Ad Age Reports Murdoch Shops ``TV Guide,'' Murdoch Denies It
DOC.TEXT: Rupert Murdoch angrily denied a trade publication report that he is ``sounding out prospective buyers'' for TV Guide and said he offered $1 million to the publication's parent if it could prove for its story. Advertising Age said Monday that the head of News Corp. Ltd. was shopping TV Guide around. Rance Crain, the editor in chief of Ad Age, said he turned down the offer ``to bet me $1 million'' because it would have required revealing the magazine's sources. ``We stand by the story completely,'' Crain said in a telephone interview. News Corp. acquired TV Guide as part of a $3 billion buyout of Triangle Publications Inc. nearly two years ago. That deal also included Seventeen magazine and the Daily Racing Form. The report in Ad Age comes a few weeks after News Corp. agreed to sell Star magazine, a supermarket tabloid, for $400 million in cash and securities. Murdoch confirmed in a recent interview that he had no plans for additional major acquisitions over the next few years and would focus on improving profits at existing operations, which include magazines, book publishing, newspapers, television stations and the Fox TV network. His company has an estimated $6 billion in debt and has lost more than $400 million in its effort to launch a satellite-TV service in Great Britain. The Ad Age story said unidentified publishing industry sources have met with a number of major publishers in recent weeks to gauge interest in TV Guide, a weekly magazine that the report said ``has been in an ad page and circulation slump'' since it was acquired in 1988. The story said the asking price is an estimated $2.6 billion, but it said informal bids have been in the $1.5 billion to $2 billion range. In a statement which described him as incensed, Murdoch said he ``has $1 million that says TV Guide is not for sale.'' Murdoch said he had told Crain he would pay $1 million to Crain Publications ``if the story could be verified and if Crain's could bring forth anyone with whom News Corp. has had discussions.'' The statement said Murdoch would expect Crain Publications to write News Corp. a ``check for a similar amount'' if support for the story could not be provided. It said Crain declined the offer. In the statement, Murdoch said the story ``had no basis in fact.'' It said Murdoch also said ``there had been no discussions of a sale between either he or any News Corp. executives with anyone _ either in the publishing or financial community.'' Crain said Ad Age had been working on the story for three weeks. ``We did not rush into print,'' he said. He said he had received a letter from a lawyer for News Corp. that demanded the ``identity of the sources who supplied your reporter with this scurrilous gossip.'' ``I think Mr. Murdoch wants me to reveal our sources,'' Crain said. ``I think if he were in the same boat, I don't think he would either.''

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Falls Against Yen, Stock Gains
DOC.TEXT: The dollar fell against the Japanese yen today after a four-day climb, while the Tokyo Stock Exchange's key index gained moderately. The dollar closed at 152.40 yen, down 0.85 yen from Monday's close of 153.25 yen. After opening at 153.36 yen, it ranged between 152.30 yen and 153.36 yen. In the previous four trading days, the dollar had gained a total of 1.95 yen. It declined in Tuesday's trading after a reported remark by U.S. Treasury Undersecretary David Mulford welcoming the yen's recent rise against the dollar, said a senior dealer with Mitsubishi Bank, speaking on condition of anonymity. The dollar fell 6.75 yen in five trading days before its latest rebound. Mulford is in Tokyo for two days of meetings of the Japan-U.S. working group on Japan's financial markets, which ended Tuesday. On the stock market, the Nikkei Stock Average of 225 selected issues gained 173.25 points, closing at 31,938.30 points. Tuesday's advance followed a 248.67-point decline on Monday and a 47.88-point drop last Friday. A total of 500 million shares changed hands, up from 369 million shares on Monday. ``The index rebounded for the first time in three trading days, encouraged by the yen's appreciation and firmness in the bond market,'' said Yoshiro Inoue of Nomura Securities. Inoue said large-capital issues such as steel and shipbuilding shares were among gainers. The price of the benchmark No. 119 10-year Japanese government bonds rose to 87.45 points as of 5 p.m. (4 a.m. EDT) from Monday's close of 87.09. The yield fell to 7.075 percent from 7.150 percent the previous day.

DOC.HEAD: West German Finance Minister Criticizes Opposition for Treaty Objections
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 12 grafs to UPDATE with West German finance minister's speech to parliament on economic treaty; pickup 6th graf pvs: Volker Ruehe ...
DOC.TEXT: The finance minister today rejected opposition leaders' demands for changes in the new economic treaty with East Germany and warned that delaying unification could cause trigger unrest among East Germans. West German Finance Minister Theodor Waigel made his remarks in a speech to the upper house of parliament, the Bundesrat, which began examining the treaty today. Waigel appealed to the opposition Social Democrats not to attempt to delay the July 2 target date on which the two Germanys are to be merged into one economic entity. His comments came a day after Hans-Jochen Vogel, the Social Democrats' national chairman, told reporters his party wants to negotiate with Chancellor Helmut Kohl's government over improving the treaty's terms for East Germans. The Social Democrats favor the economic merger, but maintain the treaty as written is unfair to East Germans. But Waigel told the Bundesrat that rejection of the treaty could result in worsened social and economic conditions in East Germany. ``A new entrance into the basic discussions (on the treaty's terms) could seriously place East Germany's economic health in question,'' Waigel said. It could also ``heap up ... social problems and social explosives'' because of East German hopes for a better standard of living after economic union, he said. ``Whoever rejects this treaty must assume the moral, political and historic responsibiity if German unity is gambled away for a limitless time,'' Waigel said. The Social Democrats' position could spell trouble for the economic merger treaty, which was signed Friday at a ceremony in Bonn. The treaty must still be approved by the parliaments of both countries. The Social Democrats recently won control of the upper house in West Germany's parliament by defeating Kohl's Christian Democrats in two key state elections. The Bundesrat is expected to vote on the treaty June 22. The lower house, or Bundestag, is scheduled to vote on ratifying the treaty on June 21. Volker Ruehe, the head of Kohl's Christian Democrats, accused the Social Democrats of displaying an ``alarming amount of irresponsibility.'' He appealed to the opposition party ``not to let in a dangerous risk for the future of all Germans and not to reject the state treaty'' on economic merger. Vogel told reporters the Social Democrats cannot accept the proposed treaty in its present form because it falls short in helping create ``modern and qualified jobs'' for East Germans and guarding against the collapse of East German businesses. According to Vogel, the Social Democrats are demanding ``changes or amendments either within or outside the treaty text.'' That seemed to leave open the possibility the treaty could be approved as is, with additions to be worked out later. Vogel said the Social Democrats would determine their final position on the proposed treaty ``in light of answers to our demands.'' The Social Democrats could use their majority in the upper house to slow approval of the treaty. However, they could also decide it is not in their best political interests to actually block the merger, since that could cost them votes when joint German elections are held, possibly at the end of this year. East Germany's own Social Democrats _ the sister party of the West German group _ say they will not try to block the treaty. The East German Social Democrats are part of their country's coalition government, and participated in the treaty negotiations. Under the merger treaty, West Germany's mark will become East Germany's own legal tender as of July 2. East Germany will also start scrapping its centrally planned economy for one that mirrors West Germany's. Thousands of East Germans are already worried they could be hit hard by their nation's economic overhaul. Many East German state-run factories are expected to shut down when they are forced to compete in a free market, and hundreds of thousands of workers are likely to lose their jobs. The East German government slashed prices on everything from blue jeans to television sets Monday in a bid to lure back consumers enamored with Western goods. Hans Klein, Kohl's chief spokesman, said the government is ``determined to hold to the timetable'' of putting the treaty into effect July 2. Klein also rejected Vogel's charges the treaty does too little to protect East Germans from joblessness and other economic shocks. He said delaying ratification of the treaty could result in disappointment among East Germans, who are eager to get the West's powerful mark as their own legal currency.

DOC.HEAD: British Airways Reverses Quarterly Loss, Posts Annual Profit Gain
DOC.TEXT: British Airways PLC said Tuesday it reversed a loss in its traditionally weak fiscal fourth quarter, and increased profits by 40 percent for the full year. The airline said the results were helped by strong growth in routes to Japan, South America and the United States. British Airways said its profit for the three months ended March 31 was 31 million pounds, or $52 million, compared with a loss of 2 million pounds, or $3.4 million, in the same period a year ago. The airline's earnings translated to 3.8 pence, or 6 cents, a share. Sales rose 13 percent to 1.12 billion pounds, or $1.9 billion, from 991 million pounds, or $1.7 billion. For the full year, earnings totaled 245 million pounds, or $414 million, compared with 175 million pounds, or $296 million, a year earlier. Earnings per share jumped to 31.2 pence, or 53 cents, from 23.3 pence, or 39 cents. Sales increased 14 percent to 4.84 billion pounds, or $8.2 billion, from 4.26 billion pounds, or $7.2 billion. The company said its results were boosted by the sale of 11 aircraft during the year. Staffing costs rose 12 percent, while fuel costs soared 30 percent because of higher world oil prices, the airline said. Despite the buoyant earnings, British Airways chairman Lord King sounded a note of caution for the year ahead. ``We are aware that our costs require constant scrutiny, particularly in view of the increasingly competitive nature of the market we serve, and the softening of Western economies,'' he said. The figures were converted at the current exchange rate of $1.69 to the pound.

DOC.HEAD: Polly Peck Plans to Increase Stake in Sansui
DOC.TEXT: Polly Peck International PLC said Tuesday it plans to increase its stake in Sansui Electric Co. Ltd. to 70 percent from 51 percent after merging two of its electronics subsidiaries into the Japanese group. The move is part of a larger planned restructuring under which Polly Peck intends to develop its electronics, foods and leisure businesses as three, largely independent companies. Polly Peck, which bought a controlling interest in money-losing Sansui last October, said it intends to sell its Asian-based Capetronic Group and Italian-based Imperial Group electronics divisions to Sansui for the equivalent of $524 million. Sansui, which specializes in audio electronics but also is licensed to manufacture video equipment, plans to finance the purchase through the sale of shares, most of which will be bought by Polly Peck, the company said. Polly Peck had said at the time of its purchase of the controlling stake that it intended to broaden Sansui's product range to include video equipment. Its plans also included putting Sansui at the head of its own electronics operations. Capetronic is a consumer electronics manufacturer with operations in Taiwan, Hong Kong, Malaysia, China and the U.S. Imperial is an Italian maker of large-screen color televisions and distributor of televisions, audio products and video cassette recorders.

DOC.HEAD: Kremlin Plans To Double Food Prices in Shift to Market
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 5 grafs to UPDATE with advisers approving plan. Pickup 5th pvs, `Soviet officials...'
DOC.TEXT: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's advisers decided today to introduce radical reforms next year to try to salvage an economy plagued by massive shortages, strikes and ethnic conflicts. Food prices would double, but the government would continue to regulate the cost of staple items, a draft of the planned reforms says. The reforms would not start until next year and would take place over five years, instead of the two years discussed earlier. Foreign Ministry spokesman Gennady I. Gerasimov told a news briefing the Presidential Council approved the draft report today and that Premier Nikolai I. Ryzhkov would present it to the Supreme Soviet parliament on Thursday. Gerasimov did not say whether the council had made any changes in the 70-page plan, obtained by The Associated Press. The plan falls short of the free market measures in Poland that led to a spurt of rapid inflation over the past six months. Soviet officials fear that sudden rises in food prices could touch off riots and strikes, like those that toppled Polish Communist governments in the 1970's and 1980's. Nevertheless, the plan is far more radical than the government program presented in December to the Soviet Congress, the Supreme Soviet's parent parliament. That plan essentially proposed three more years of a centrally planned economy, but sentiment is growing that faster steps are needed to improve production and distribution. ``The negative effect of political instability, strikes and inter-ethnic conflicts is growing ever stronger,'' Ryzhkov's report says. It appeals to all workers not to strike. Ryzhkov's draft came under immediate fire from a parliamentary opposition group, which plans to present an alternative economic blueprint advocating a market economy. ``This is just another ploy to intimidate the people with the idea of a free market and consolidate its own positions,'' said Siberian economist Gennady Filshin, who developed the alternative plan for the Inter-Regional Group. He was interviewed by the independent news service Post-Factum. The government report emphasizes the need to control inflation, unemployment and other social ills, but also outlines major price increases and other reforms beginning in 1991. ``The retail prices on food should, on the average, double, increasing by 112 billion rubles ($187 million),'' says the report. However, the prices of basic foodstuffs _ including bread, meat and oil _ will remain under government regulation and not be allowed to spiral out of control, the plan says. It also provides for wage indexing to cushion the effect on the country's poor. Frightening figures on current economic performance explain the government's new readiness to take harsh measures. In the first three months of this year, cash incomes swelled by 13.4 percent while the gross national product declined, the report says. From January to April, political strikes and inter-ethnic conflicts led to the loss of 9.5 million man-hours, compared to 7 million man-hours lost during all of last year. The government plan foresees passage of all the laws needed for the transition to a market economy by the end of this fall. It says ``predictions show that in 1995 the country will be in a position to accumulate the real financial means and resources'' to let the economy leap ahead. Current prices in state stores for many basic foods are extremely low, with potatoes costing as little as 8 cents a pound and beef $1.80 a pound. The Soviet economy is plagued with shortages, and free prices at farmer's markets have rocketed to $16 a pound for beef and up to about $8 a pound for new potatoes. Commodities are rationed in some regions.

DOC.HEAD: Japan-U.S. Officials Clash on Interest Rate Deregulation
DOC.TEXT: U.S. Treasury officials and their Japanese counterparts ended two days of talks today sharply divided over a U.S. request that Japan move quicker to lift interest rate controls. U.S. Undersecretary of the Treasury David C. Mulford said the Japanese refusal to provide a timetable for deregulating interest rates on bank deposits within one year could push U.S. regulators toward imposing limits on Japanese financial activities in the United States. Japan's reluctance to promise faster liberalization could aid passage of a legislation being considered in Congress that calls for retaliatory action against foreign financial firms in the United States if their own governments do not give U.S. companies reciprocal treatment, he said. ``Rapid action to complete the deregulation process in Japan would avoid what otherwise will become an area of serious political conflict,'' Mulford said. ``The Treasury is in the process of preparing a national treatment study for the U.S. Congress on the status of U.S. financial firms in foreign financial markets,'' he said. ``As of today, it will not be possible for the U.S. Treasury to give a positive report on the Japanese market.'' Vice Minister of Finance Makoto Utsumi said the two sides agreed on the goals for complete liberalization of Japan's once strictly controlled financial markets, but clearly disagreed on the timing. He likened the process of reform to mountain biking: ``The problem is we are now facing the final stage of liberalization, and the slope is steeper, the problems become more serious. We have to complete the process without causing a heart attack,'' he said. Utsumi declined to elaborate on the reasons why Japan could not provide a timetable for lifting interest rates, but said the ministry planned to eventually lift all controls on rates for bank deposits. The Finance Ministry is reportedly considering proposals that would stretch the process of lifting interest ceilings to 1993 or later _ far beyond the U.S. proposal for a one-year deadline. ``We believe it is important to complete the process as quickly as possible. But this `mountain bike' is like a bicycle built for two, and whenever we get some speed up ... the Ministry of Finance puts on the brakes,'' Mulford said. Analysts say the ministry faces strong opposition to interest rate deregulation from small- and medium-size banks that are already facing difficulties due to higher interest rates and limited liberalization. Japan's central bank has raised its key rate for loans to commercial banks from 2.5 percent to 5.25 percent in the past year. In turn, commercial banks' prime lending rates jumped from about 5.5 percent to 7.2 percent. The higher rates banks must pay to depositors make it more expensive for them to acquire funds for lending and investment. Moreover, a reduction in the minimum purchase for money market certificates from $62,500 to $6,250 means banks now must pay 5.8 percent interest to a growing pool of depositors, compared with the 0.75 percent paid on ordinary bank accounts. Utsumi bluntly disagreed with Mulford's assertion that interest rate controls were in effect subsidizing Japanese banks, giving them a source of artificially cheap capital for loans and other investments and enabling them to expand their presence overseas. ``To avoid foreign exchange exposure ... loans overseas are made with funds in the same currency the loans are denominated in,'' Utsumi said. Mulford said some progress had been made in Japanese moves to expand ceilings on individuals' overseas accounts and to allow their use for portfolio investment. He said Finance Ministry officials had promised to approve new foreign exchange-related and securitized financial products and allow foreign securities firms to establish banking facilities to handle foreign exchange services. Mulford said the U.S. was pleased by a pledge to approve the use of the GLOBEX trading system by the end of June. GLOBEX is a global electronic automated transaction system for the trading of futures and futures options jointly operated by the Chicago Mercantile Exchange and Reuters Holdings PLC.

DOC.HEAD: Crop Futures Gain On Strong Exports, Rain Forecasts
DOC.TEXT: Grain and soybean futures prices edged higher in early trading today on the Chicago Board of Trade amid signs of stronger export sales and forecasts for more rain in the Midwest next week. The slightly stronger opening represented a modest rebound from moderate to sharp losses in Monday's session. Analysts attributed the early strength in part to new wheat export prospects, including a government offer to subsidize sales of 2 million metric tons of U.S. wheat to Algeria. The Agriculture Department also said it had accepted bids from private exporters to cover a sale of nearly 400,000 metric tons of wheat to China at subsidized prices. Monday's weekly USDA export-inspections report showed a larger-than-expected amount of corn earmarked for export last week. Wheat inspections were about as expected while soybean inspections were below expectations. Corn and soybean planting is progressing at a slower-than-normal pace, according to another USDA report released Monday. And the National Weather Service's latest six-to-10-day forecast predicts wetter-than-normal conditions in the Midwest early next week, which could further delay planting. In early trading, wheat futures were \ cent lower to \ cent higher with the contract for delivery in July at $3.36} a bushel; corn futures were } cent to 2\ cents higher with July at $2.77} a bushel; oats were 1 cent to 2 cents higher with July at $1.53\ a bushel; soybeans were 3 cents to 5\ cents higher with July at $6.14 a bushel. Livestock and meat futures were mostly lower in early trading on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. Live cattle were .57 cent lower to .05 cent higher with June at 74.40 cents a pound; feeder cattle were unchanged to .42 cent lower with May at 85.50 cents a pound; live hogs were unchanged to .68 cent lower with June at 66.55 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were .40 cent lower to .23 cent higher with May at 67.85 cents a pound. DOC.HEAD: Congressional Panel Opens Hearings on Collapse of Colorado Thrift
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Combines pvs, with editing.
DOC.TEXT: A Colorado savings and loan that counted one of President Bush's sons as a director made inflated loans to developers who had to reinvest part of the money in the thrift, federal regulators said today. The House Banking Committee opened two days of hearings on the $1 billion collapse of the Silverado Banking, Savings and Loan Association of Denver. Bush's son, Neil, and other former board members are to testify on Wednesday. A panel of thrift regulators told the committee they found a ``quid pro quo'' lending program at Silverado, under which developers received loans to buy buildings at inflated values set by outside appraisers. The properties' values had been inflated $270 million to $300 million, they said. The regulators told the banking committee that Silverado's board of directors operated as a ``rubber stamp'' for management. They also said insider abuse occurred at the thrift. ``Because management of Silverado took excessive risks, engaged in abusive or questionable practices to generate short-term gains, and undertook innovative manipulations to avoid recording losses, the role of the directors was even more crucial,'' the regulators' statement said. ``Throughout Silverado's history, the board did little beyond rubber-stamping the activities of its sophisticated, bright and manipulative management team.'' The panel of regulators testifying today included Stephen P. Hershkowitz, deputy director of enforcement at the Office of Thrift Supervision, and Brian C. McCormally, Terry Sandefur and Dorothy Van Cleave of the OTS district office in Topeka, Kan. Kermit Mowbray, former president of the Federal Home Loan Bank of Topeka, did not appear and Gonzalez said he would ask the committee to subpoena Mowbray, who is in Greece. In exchange for receiving loans bigger than the market price of the buildings, the developers were required to use the surplus part of the loan money to buy preferred stock in Silverado's holding company or to purchase an interest in a ``loan pool'' set up by the thrift. The pool, which contained both good and bad loans, totaled around $1 billion or roughly 60 percent of Silverado's total loan portfolio. The developers who bought shares in the loan pool received interest generated by the performing loans in the pool. Examiners said Monday they believed this arrangement was unique in the S&L industry. Federal regulators declined to say Monday whether the appraisers, who included accounting firms Coopers & Lybrand and Ernst & Young, also were under investigation. Government investigators said Monday they believe Robert M. Lewis, former vice chairman and chief financial officer of Silverado, was the ``financial guru'' who probably invented the concept of the loan pool. The December 1988 collapse of Silverado, now operating as part of Columbia Savings, the largest thrift in Colorado, is expected to cost U.S. taxpayers as much as $1 billion. Total losses from the nationwide savings and loan crisis, which has forced the government to take over more than 400 failed institutions, are estimated at around $250 billion. The connections among Silverado and other insolvent S&Ls are being examined. The others include Charles H. Keating Jr.'s Lincoln Savings and Loan Association and the junk bond operation of former Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. financier Michael Milken. OTS has alleged that loans by Silverado to Neil Bush's business partners, developers Kenneth Good and Bill Walters, represented a conflict of interest for Bush, 34, who was a director of Silverado from 1985 to August 1988. He resigned two weeks after his father received the Republican presidential nomination. In January, regulators began disciplinary procedures against Bush that could result in a lifetime ban from the financial institutions industry. Bush, who has denied any wrongdoing, said early this month he will cooperate with Congress, the OTS and any other agencies involved. Examiners at the OTS have expressed concern about Silverado's heavy investments in Colorado's ailing commercial real estate market. They also have focused on what they said was ``an exceptionally large number of problem transactions'' between Silverado insiders and borrowers. Bush, who was a partner in an oil exploration firm, JNB Exploration, had business deals with two of Silverado's major borrowers, Good and Walters. Bush has said he did not benefit directly or indirectly from any loan or transaction between Silverado and businesses controlled by Walters, who had a 6.25 percent limited partnership interest in JNB Exploration. Bush has said he voted in 1986 with the other directors in unanimously approving the Walters loans brought to them by management, because there was no conflict of interest under federal banking laws or Colorado regulations. Good and Walters are scheduled to testify at Wednesday's hearing along with Michael R. Wise, the former chairman of Silverado. Richard K. Vanderpool, Silverado's former vice chairman and chief operating officer, also is expected to appear Wednesday, along with Lewis and other former directors besides Bush.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Hints He's Ready to Grant China Extension of Trade Benefits
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Combines pvs.
DOC.TEXT: President Bush hinted to Republican leaders today that he is ready to grant China a one-year extension of trade benefits. Administration sources said announcement of such a move would come this week. The expected decision to renew Beijing's most-favored-nation status drew advance criticism from Democrats. Republican lawmakers who met with Bush at the White House said the president left the clear impression he was ready to grant China the extension. ``He indicated he would present that while Congress is still in session this week,'' said Sen. Alan Simpson, R-Wyo. Simpson and other GOP leaders said Bush made a strong case for extending most-favored-nation treatment, arguing that to withdraw preferential trade status would severely damage the free-market economy of Hong Kong. Although he did not say exactly what he planned to do, Bush demonstrated ``a tilt toward granting it. But he was seeking our views,'' said Sen. John Chafee, R-R.I. Sen. William Armstrong, R-Colo., said: ``He gave us the impression he would do it.'' Bush was to meet with Democratic leaders on the subject on Wednesday. White House spokesman Roman Popadiuk said a decision on the issue would not be announced today. ``As far as I know, no decison has been taken'' on whether to continue most-favored-nation trading status for China, he said. The spokesman said Bush might bring up the topic at today's meeting with congressional Republicans. It is unlikely the White House would announce such a move before Bush conferred with congressional leaders. However, other officials, speaking on the condition of anonymity, said the president was expected to notify Congress formally of the move before the end of the week. In advance of a White House announcement, Senate Majority Leader George Michell, D-Maine, today strongly criticized renewal of trade benefits to China. ``Should we, by now giving the Chinese government what it wants, passively adopt the Chinese government's casual dismissal of our concerns?'' Mitchell said. ``I say we should not ... because it is contrary to our principles, contrary to American interests and wrong.'' Mitchell said the Bush administration, by its actions, is ``sowing the seeds of disaster with respect to the next generation of leaders in China.'' House Speaker Thomas S. Foley, D-Wash., said he would withhold comment on Bush's decision until one is actually announced. Foley said he understood there were conditions attached to the status, and he wanted to find out what those conditions are. ``I think it's better to see what he recommends,'' he said. Bush was planning to make the extension provisional, based on China's human-rights performance over the coming months, said the officials. Sen. Pete Wilson, R-Calif., who accompanied Bush on the flight, said he did not expect Congress to react as negatively to the move as it had last winter when Bush vetoed legislation extending the visas of Chinese students. ``It's not as emotional an issue,'' Wilson said. ``Most people in the nation don't even know what MFN is.'' Most-favored-nation (MFN) trading status guarantees China the same treatment as this nation's best trading partners, including the lowest possible tariffs. This benefit has provided preferential tariffs for about $12 billion in Chinese products shipped to the United States each year, mostly textiles and toys. Bush is required under law to act one way or another by June 3. But sources said he would rather deal with the issue now than wait until the deadline, one day before the first anniversary of China's bloody repression of pro-democracy demonstrators in Beijing's Tiananmen Square. The president also would like to clear the boards of the decision before the May 30-June 3 summit with Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the officials said. Although Bush has recently voiced disappointment with China's failure to ease restrictions on dissidents, he considers depriving China of most-favored-nation status a drastic step that could have widespread trade implications, the officials said. Bush himself expressed reservations at a news conference last week about stripping China of the trade benefits, in part out of fear it would harm the economy of Hong Kong. Some $8.5 billion worth of China-made goods are re-exported to the United States each year, passing through Hong Kong. Officials of the enclave on the South coast of China claim revocation of China's most-favored-nation status would make these goods subject to tariffs of up to 70 percent. Some nations, including the Soviet Union, have been denied most-favored-nation treatment because of their restrictive human-rights policies. Congress can block Bush's decision, but it seems unlikely it could muster the two-third majorities needed to do so. Bush, a former U.S. envoy to China, won a bruising veto battle with Congress last winter on a bill that would have extended the visas of Chinese students in the United States. Bush argued that he was offering the Chinese students the same safe haven though administrative actions. Previously, the Bush administration waived restrictions on U.S. Export-Import Bank financing of business with China and granted permission for Chinese rockets to launch three U.S.-built satellites.

DOC.HEAD: Southmark Says San Jacinto Insolvent
DOC.TEXT: Southmark Corp. says its San Jacinto Savings Association unit is insolvent and won't be able to meet required minimum capital levels despite plans to pump more than $100 million in assets into the Houston savings and loan. The disclosure Monday in a federal Securities and Exchange Commission filing raises new questions about Southmark's ability to keep control of San Jacinto after Southmark emerges from Chapter 11 bankruptcy. The real estate and financial services company has proposed selling all its remaining holdings except for San Jacinto, which would be the centerpiece of a reorganized Southmark. Thrift president and chief executive Lawrence Connell said the thrift is seeking to increase its capital, in part through the sale of $200 million in real estate that is in negotiation or under contract. The thrift also has asked regulators for a temporary reprieve from the minimum capital standards and to delay any actions until it can put its business plan into effect. San Jacinto, under regulatory oversight since 1988, is one of the largest thrift institutions in the state that hasn't been sold or seized by federal regulators. In the third quarter ended March 31, San Jacinto reported a loss of $67.2 million, causing its shareholders' equity to fall to a negative $50.8 million and making the institution insolvent for the first time. ``It is expected that San Jacinto will experience further increases in its capital deficit due to continuing operating losses,'' Southmark noted. The parent company posted a loss of $58.5 million for the quarter. It already had taken a $28.6 million charge in the quarter ended Dec. 31 for possible loan losses at the thrift. In the third quarter of 1989, Southmark reported a record $1 billion loss caused by huge write-downs in the value of Southmark-held real estate an by provisions for loan losses at San Jacinto. That loss led to the company's filing for protection under Chapter 11 of the federal Bankruptcy Code in July. Before the filing, Southmark reached an agreement with the Office of Thrift Supervision, which regulates the savings and loan industry, permitting the company to continue to own the thrift while in bankruptcy proceedings as long as it maintained minimum capital levels.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar, Gold Up
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Rewrites thruout to UPDATE with closing numbers in Europe. An AMs version planned by 5:30 p.m. EDT
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. dollar rose modestly Tuesday against other major currencies, except for the Japanese yen and Swiss franc, in European trading. Gold prices also were slightly higher. Currency dealers said the dollar got a boost from a combination of technical factors and the weakness of the West German mark. The market is feeling some jitters over a potential political row that could develop in Bonn before the planned German unification, they said. The dollar slid against the yen after a senior U.S. Treasury official indicated a further weakening of the dollar would be acceptable, although not necessarily a remedy to the U.S. trade deficit. The dollar also was hit by comments earlier Tuesday by Swiss National Bank Vice President Hans Meyer, who said the Swiss will not loosen its monetary policy during the next six months. In Tokyo, where the global trading day begins, the dollar fell to a closing 152.40 Japanese yen from 153.25 yen Monday. It closed at 151.55 yen in London, and traded at 151.30 yen by midday in New York. In London, the British pound fell to $1.6915 from $1.6917 late Monday. By midday it was up to $1.69325. DOC.HEAD: Asea Brown Boveri to Sell Its C-E Minerals Business for $150 Million
DOC.TEXT: Asea Brown Boveri Inc. said it has reached an agreement to sell its C-E Minerals business to Imetal SA for approximately $150 million. ABB had previously announced its plan to sell C-E Minerals, a supplier of alumina silica calcines and fused silica. Imetal, based in Paris, is active in building materials, industrial minerals, metal fabricating and international trading. Asea Brown Boveri, with sales of approximately $7 billion and 35,000 employees in the United States, provides products and services for the power, automation, environmental control, transit and other markets. It is part of the ABB Group, Zurich, an electrical engineering company with total annual sales of about $25 billion and 215,000 employees in 140 countries. The proposed acquisition is subject to approval by U.S. regulatory authorities.

DOC.HEAD: Deere Reports Records Earnings as Sales Soar
DOC.TEXT: Deere & Co. reported Tuesday its second-quarter earnings rose 10 percent as the tractor and farm equipment manufacturer's sales increased and expenses were cut. Deere said it earned $144 million, or $1.90 a share, on revenue of $2.12 billion, in the quarter ended April 30, compared with earnings of $130.5 million, or $1.74 a share, on revenue of $1.92 billion in the same period a year earlier. ``The second quarter and year-to-date improvements are attributable to our North American operations, resulting primarily from increased sales, higher production volumes and improved operating efficiency,'' retiring Deere Chairman Robert A. Hanson said in a joint statement with Hans W. Becherer, chief executive officer. Becherer is expected to succeed Hanson as chairman. Tractor and machinery sales accounted for $1.8 billion of Deere's revenue in the second quarter while income from the company's credit, insurance and health care operations was $237 million. For the first six months of the fiscal year, Deere's earnings totaled $222.5 million, or $2.94 per share, on revenue of $3.76 billion, up 24 percent from $178.9 million, or $2.39 per share, on revenue of $3.29 billion, in the first half of 1989. Deere is building on momentum that began in 1988 as the company piled up record earnings of $315.4 million after suffering $637 million in operating losses in 1982-87.

DOC.HEAD: Sock Shop Closes Half Its British Stores
DOC.TEXT: Sock Shop International PLC will close 58 stores, more than half its British outlets, to try to save the business, its administrators announced Tuesday. The company closed its 17 U.S. stores in December. The closure of 58 British stores out of 109 will mean 150 job losses, the administrators said. ``It has been a tough time for the employees of Sock Shop,'' said administrator Peter DuBuisson. ``I believe the steps we are now taking to rationalize the company will improve its profitability and reward everyone's efforts to save Sock Shop,'' he said. DuBuisson and Phillip Sykes, accountants with the firm BDO Binder Hamlyn, were called in three months ago. Last week, a court gave them another three months to find a solution to propose to the company's creditors. The administrators are looking for new investors to bail out the company, which was founded in 1982 by a former typist, Sophie Mirman, and her husband Richard Ross. The company has blamed its problems on last year's hot summer and transport strikes, which discouraged sales. Many Sock Shops are at train and subway stations. Heavy debts incurred through rapid expansion also took their toll as interest rates climbed. Miss Mirman opened her first Sock Shop at London's Knightsbridge subway station near the Harrods department store. The company prospered during the free-spending 1980s with passers-by dropping in on a whim for a handful of tights or socks. Sock Shop's expansion to the United States failed, because of high rents and security costs. In February, the company posted a six-month loss of 2.9 million pounds, or $4.9 million.
