DOC.HEAD: Government Panel Adopts New Economic Policy Guideline
With AM-Japan-Interest Rates, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The government and the ruling party on Tuesday adopted a new economic policy guideline aimed at meeting promises made in recent trade talks with the United States. The new guideline calls for opening Japan's markets to more foreign goods, making fiscal and budgetary policy changes to conform with other trading partners, and increasing foreign aid. ``We must push forward the adjustment of Japan's economic structure in order to improve the nation's standard of living and promote consumer benefits in accordance with world economic growth,'' said a government statement. The policy was adopted by the Government-LDP Economic Structural Adjustment Board, which consists of bureaucrats and lawmakers from the governing Liberal Democratic Party. It marks a major revision in the direction suggested for Japan's economy. A 1986 guideline, known as the Maekawa Report, urged a drastic shift from heavy reliance on exports to increased domestic demand to reduce the country's trade surpluses. In recent months, however, a number of government and LDP panels have called for less emphasis on expanding domestic demand and more on international cooperation and benefits for Japanese consumers, who now pay some of the world's highest prices. The new guideline suggests that Japan's economy already has been transformed to a domestic orientation and notes that its trade surplus has been decreasing. ``For us to assume a role and responsibilities compatible with our position in the international community, ... it is an extremely important theme for Japan to promote the adjustment of our economy to a more internationally cooperative style,'' it said. In addition to improved living standards, the guideline calls for shorter working hours and longer vacations. In its interim report on the U.S.-Japan Structural Impediment Initiative talks, released in April, Tokyo promised to streamline its complicated distribution system, tighten the anti-monopoly law and increase government spending on public works to help improve the nation's standard of living. The report said such measures would lead to a reduction of Japan's $49 billion surplus in trade with the United States. The new guideline, like the trade report, calls for easing the Large Scale Store Law, which U.S. trade negotiators say makes it hard for foreign stores to open outlets in Japan.

DOC.HEAD: Interest Rates Next Spat Between U.S., Japan
DOC.TEXT: By ELAINE KURTENBACH=

A dispute over how fast Japan will liberalize interest rates on deposits could make banking the next area of trade tensions in coming months, a senior U.S. official said Tuesday. After two days of talks with Japanese officials on financial reforms, U.S. Undersecretary of the Treasury David C. Mulford said Japan's refusal to finish deregulating interest rates within one year was beginning to ``look more and more like a trade problem.'' ``The deregulation process for interest rates is the key to all other liberalization and it is necessary for developing a money market policy,'' Mulford said. He said that after seven years of step-by-step transition, U.S. officials would like the process of deregulation to be wrapped up within a year. The talks led by Mulford and his Japanese counterpart, Vice Minister of Finance Makoto Utsumi, were the eighth in a series of discussions on reforming the two countries' financial markets. Separately, the Japanese government and ruling party on Tuesday adopted a new economic policy guideline aimed at meeting other promises made in recent trade talks with the United States. The new guideline calls for opening Japan's markets to more foreign goods, making fiscal and budgetary policy changes to conform with other trading partners, and increasing foreign aid. On the interest-rate front, U.S. officials charge that Japanese financial firms take advantage of open markets overseas while receiving government protection from foreign competition at home. While interest rates for money market certificates and large-lot time deposits have been partially liberalized since 1984, when the bilateral talks began, the ceilings on rates for demand deposits and smaller time deposits remain low. Time deposits account for about three-quarters of total bank deposits here, according to industry estimates. Utsumi said Japanese officials agreed on the need to completely liberalize interest rates, but disagreed on timing. He bluntly disagreed with U.S. charges that interest rate controls were being retained to give Japanese banks a source of artificially cheap capital for loans and other investments, enabling them to expand their presence overseas. ``To avoid foreign exchange exposure ... loans overseas are made with funds in the same currency the loans are denominated in,'' Utsumi said. Utsumi declined to explain why Japan would not specify a timetable for its plans and refused to comment on reports that interest rate ceilings would be lifted by 1993. Mulford said the failure to produce a timetable was likely to fuel protectionist moves in Congress. Foreign banks' share in total bank deposits in Japan has risen only from 0.9 percent in 1983 to 1.04 percent in 1988, while their share of loans has fallen from 3.57 percent to 1.88 percent, the Bank of Japan says. Japan's share in the U.S. lending market, meanwhile, has grown from 7.4 percent in 1983 to 14 percent in 1989. The Treasury Department is required by law to report to Congress by Dec. 1 on whether Japan and other countries have given U.S. banks and brokerages the same access they receive in American financial markets. The Fair Trade and Financial Services Act being considered in Congress calls for retaliatory action against foreign financial firms in the United States if their own governments do not give U.S. companies reciprocal treatment. ``As of today, it will not be possible for the U.S. Treasury to give a positive report on the Japanese market,'' Mulford said. Analysts say the Finance Ministry faces strong opposition to interest rate deregulation from small and medium-size banks already facing difficulties due to higher interest rates and limited liberalization. Japan's central bank has raised its key rate for loans to commercial banks from 2.5 percent to 5.25 percent in the past year. In turn, commercial banks' prime lending rates jumped from about 5.5 percent to 7.2 percent. Finance Ministry officials did promise to approve new foreign exchange-related and securitized financial products and allow foreign securities firms to establish banking facilities to handle foreign exchange services, Mulford said. The Japanese also pledged to approve the use of the Globex trading system by the end of June. Globex is a global electronic automated system for the trading of futures and futures options jointly operated by the Chicago Mercantile Exchange and Reuters Holdings PLC. ``But we still see most of these improvements as only intermediate steps which fail to lead to complete financial market liberalization,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Introduces New Line of Fax Machines
DOC.TEXT: Xerox Corp. on Tuesday introduced a line of facsimile machines that use plain paper and double as full-service copiers. John P. Lafferty of the company's Information Products Division, said many users prefer receiving facsimiles on plain paper. ``Our strategy is to lead the high-end, business and government segments of the facsimile marketplace,'' he said. The machines are all made in Japan by Fuji Xerox Corp., although they were developed by Xerox engineers in the United States. ``For some time, the office products industry has been anticipating a single, multi-functional machine that combines many functions that currently reside in separate machines,'' Lafferty said.

DOC.HEAD: Dayton Hudson Earnings Up 60 Percent
DOC.TEXT: Dayton Hudson Corp. reported Tuesday its first-quarter earnings rose 60 percent on higher revenue and a one-time gain from an accounting change. The Minneapolis-based retailer said it earned $64 million, or 81 cents per share, in the quarter ended May 5, compared with $40 million, or 51 cents per share, a year earlier. The results reflected a $54 million gain from an accounting change, and $48 million in costs for employee retirement health care benefits, Dayton Hudson said in a statement. Without the one-time items, Dayton Hudson said earnings would have risen 45 percent during the quarter. Revenue totaled $3.01 billion, up from $2.83 billion a year earlier. The company said all divisions had increased revenue and operating income. The company's businesses include Dayton Hudson Department Stores, Target discount stores and Mervyn's, a moderate-priced department store chain. Dayton Hudson is also planning to buy the Marshall Field's department store chain from BAT PLC, the British conglomerate.

DOC.HEAD: Crop Futures Close Mixed; Weather Boosts New-Crop Corn
DOC.TEXT: Grain and soybean futures prices closed mostly lower Tuesday on the Chicago Board of Trade although new-crop corn futures rose slightly amid persistent fears about rain-delayed corn planting in the Midwest. Wheat futures retreated modestly despite the Agriculture Department's announcement that China bought nearly 400,000 metric tons of U.S. wheat at subsidized prices, and despite a USDA offer to subsidize sales of 2 million metric tons of wheat to Algeria. Joel Karlin, an analyst with Research Department Inc. in Chicago, said wheat traders fear the Bush administration may not renew China's favorable trade status, which could result in fewer grain sales to China. He said the wheat offer to Algeria had little market impact because foreign buyers are likely to wait another month or two, if they can, for the cheaper prices that will accompany the U.S. winter wheat harthe remedies disabled workers could seek from employers who willfully discriminate. The White House supported that amendment. Among key provisions of the bill: _Discrimination in hiring and on the job would be prohibited. The requirement would be phased in over two to four years, depending on the size of the company. Companies with fewer than 15 employees would be exempt. _Hotels, restaurants, shopping malls, drug stores, and business and professional offices, along with any other ``public accommodation,'' would have to make themselves accessible to disabled people. Accessibility includes structural adjustments, such as wheelchair ramps and widened doors, and services. _Transportation, public and private, would have to be made accessible. Fixed-route bus systems would have to be accessible for people with wheelchairs. Special facilities would be available for people with other disabilities who cannot use regular transit. Amtrak, Greyhound, and commuter rail systems are covered. Timetables for implementation vary according to system. _ People with speech and hearing impairments would have access to telephone service by means of relay services. These services would have to be provided by phone companies within three years.

DOC.HEAD: Obstacles Remain For Investing in Soviet Union, U.S. Official Says
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet Union could become the hottest growth market of the 21st century, but serious impediments remain for exporters and investors, U.S. officials told hundreds of American and Soviet business leaders Tuesday. The leaders of the U.S.-U.S.S.R. Trade and Economic Council spoke optimistically at their 13th annual meeting that political barriers to better business relations between the two nations finally were being swept away. However, U.S. Ambassador Jack Matlock said the Kremlin's economic embargo of Lithuania will make it difficult to get the U.S. Congress to approve a bilateral commercial agreement. The failing Soviet economy and Mikhail S. Gorbachev's plans to introduce desperately needed market reforms kept surfacing at the session. ``We understand that political freedom must be accompanied by meat on the table,'' said Alaska Gov. Steve Cowper, addressing the meeting on his state's recent cooperation with the Soviet Union. ``For perestroika to work, the Soviet economic system has to work.'' Thomas J. Duesterburg, assistant secretary of commerce for International Economic Policy, told the 500 American members and like number of Soviets that Gorbachev and other Kremlin leaders ``have had the courage to face these facts and to begin a massive restructuring program in the Soviet Union to take it away from the policies that have brought it to the brink of economic ruin.'' ``If democratization and a movement toward a market economy continues, the U.S.S.R. could certainly be `the' growth market of the 21st century,'' he said. But he said key obstacles remain. The Soviet ruble is not convertible, and foreign enterprises have not been fully integrated into the economy. The Soviets still try to contain and control foreign investment as a compartmentalized part of the economy. Basic factors such as market information, advertising, the ability to hire and fire local staff and the ability to communicate with potential customers and partners are needed to overcome this obstacle, Duesterburg said. Of the more than 1,400 joint-venture agreements registered in the Soviet Union, 140 involve U.S. firms. Less than 15 percent of all foreign joint ventures are operational, with most being small, service-oriented enterprises rather than manufacturing concerns. The average capitalization of these is less than $2 million. Council Chairman John J. Murphy, the chairman, president and chief executive officer of Dresser Industries, Inc., was nevertheless upbeat about the Soviet market. He said the upcoming summit between Gorbachev and U.S. President George Bush was a cause for optimism. He also said he was confident of a waiver of the Jackson-Vanik Amendment, which for years has denied the Soviets most-favored-nation status, to punish them for preventing free emigration. ``This will provide Soviet manufacturers with the opportunity to test their competitors in the largest and toughest market in the world,'' he said, referring to the United States. ``We also anticipate signing of the bilateral trade agreement, providing the means for two-way trade to reach world-scale dimensions for the first time in a long time,'' Murphy added. Co-chairman Vladislav L. Malkevich, head of the Soviet Chamber of Commerce, expressed the hope that political motives won't hurt U.S.-Soviet business relations. ``I hope that a trade agreement will not become an instrument of any political gain, like what happened in the past,'' he said. But Matlock, while saying that the political climate was improving, could not ease Malkevich's fears. He mentioned the economic embargo imposed by Gorbachev to punish Lithuania for its independence moves and said that under those circumstances, ``whatever we do in our negotiations, it's going to be probably very difficult and maybe impossible to persuade the American Congress to let a commercial agreement go into effect.'' Also at the meeting, a several new joint ventures were signed between U.S. and Soviet companies. Among them: _The American Medical Consortium, consisting of Pfizer International Inc., Colgate Palmolive Inc., Hewlett-Packard Co., Hospital Corp. International, Medical Service Partners and Federal Express, signed a contract to develop joint ventures. Its first will be a factory, located in Kazan, to produce medical, surgical and dental instruments and disposable syringes. About 20 percent of its production is to be exported for hard currency. _Raddisson Hotels International and Americom International Corp. signed an agreement with Intourist and the Committee for Foreign Tourism to build and operate the first American hotel and the first American-managed business center in Moscow. _The Coca-Cola Co. formally received the right to open a permanent representation office in Moscow. _Federal Express announced the introduction of outbound air express service from Moscow. Service from the United States and Europe to Moscow began in April.

DOC.HEAD: Says Cable TV Must Have More Competition
DOC.TEXT: Federal Communications Commission Chairman Alfred Sikes told cable television executives Tuesday that an era of increased competition is imminent in their industry. The head of an industry association said, however, that he still believes Washington will avoid drastic regulatory changes. Sikes told a meeting of the National Cable Television Association that it should accept government action to open the marketplace. The cable industry has been deregulated since 1984, though both Congress and the FCC currently are considering steps to reimpose some regulation. ``You cannot expect government to continue sanctioning, indeed, protecting and promoting cable as a sole-source provider of video services while at the same time foregoing the regulation that historically has been placed on monopoly operations,'' Sikes said. ``The American people, in short, will not tolerate an unregulated monopoly indefinitely.'' Though cable TV has soared in popularity over the last decade _ it is now received in 57.1 percent of all U.S. homes with television _ the industry has been beset recently by complaints from consumers about poor service and rising rates. Sikes said that during a visit last week to his home state of Missouri, he was besieged by questions _ from people who usually care little about FCC issues _ regarding cable TV. The FCC is scheduled to take up cable issues at its July 26 meeting. NCTA President James P. Mooney, whose association is holding its annual convention this week in Atlanta, said following Sikes' speech that the FCC chairman shed little new light for him on the cable regulation issue. Mooney said he stood by his earlier assessment that he expects the FCC or Congress this year to modify regulatory policies for cable but that the changes will not be drastic. ``I think we can say today it looks highly likely that Congress will support a moderate cable policy,'' Mooney told the NCTA gathering Monday. Sikes said he is going into the July 26 meeting supporting regulatory approaches ``which foster growth and diversity and, as a result, far less need for potentially debilitating government intervention.'' If the cable industry resists opening the marketplace, it could finditself in a utility-style regulatory environment that would inhibit entrepreneurs, Sikes said. Sikes also told the group he would support allowing cable to compete in other communications markets, such as telephone and other carrier-related services. ``If video service markets were effectively competitive, I can see few compelling public policy reasons for placing constraints on any of the participants, including cable,'' he said.

The stock market continued its spring rally today, pushing its best known indicator toward another record. Five minutes before the close, the Dow Jones average of 30 industrials was up 7.31 at 2,851.99 after finishing at a closing record in the previous session. Advancing issues led losers by a margin of 8 to 7 among New York Stock Exchange-listed issues, with 817 up, 698 down and 483 unchanged.

DOC.HEAD: American To Take Over Latin Routes In Phases
DOC.TEXT: American Airlines will take over Eastern Airlines' Latin American routes in four phases beginning June 30, Eastern said Wednesday. ``It just provided for the smoothest transition possible,'' Eastern spokesman Robin Matell said of the agreement, under which both airlines will fly to some Latin countries _ not at the same time _ from June 30 until Aug. 14. Eastern and parent Texas Air Corp. dealt the Latin American routes to American as part of Eastern's effort to emerge from Chapter 11 bankruptcy reorganization. Matell said the $349 million amount Eastern would receive under the original agreement is down to $310 milliion. He said the initial transaction price was reduced by $14 million because the U.S. Department of Transportation expects a route hearing challenging the transfer of Eastern's Miami-Toronto and Tampa-Toronto authorities. Another $25 million involves Eastern's routes to Puerto Rico. Matell declined to elaborate on the status of the Puerto Rican routes. The first sale to close on June 30 will cover Brazil, Argentina, Chile, Guatemala and Costa Rica, followed July 20 with Panama, Peru, Bolivia and Paraguay. Colombia and Ecuador will follow July 31. The transfer of Latin routes will be completed Aug. 14 with Belize, Honduras, El Salvador and Venezuela. The schedule provides that Eastern will receive the bulk of the $310 million in July, and the balance Aug. 14, Eastern said.

DOC.HEAD: Continental El Paso-Mexico Flight Begins July 1
DOC.TEXT: Continental will start flying non-stop from El Paso to Mexico City on July 1, becoming the first major airline to fly directly from the border city into Mexico since the early 1980s. Travelers now have to go through Dallas, Houston or Los Angeles to get to Mexico City. Round-trip fares will range from $334 for a seven-day advance purchase for a weekday flight to $337 for a full-fare weekend flight.
