DOC.HEAD: Monsanto, Exxon in Joint Plastics Venture
DOC.TEXT: Monsanto Chemical Co. and Exxon Chemical Co. said Tuesday they would merge their businesses in industrial rubber products called TPEs. The enterprise would combine Monsanto's technical, manufacturing and marketing expertise with Exxon Chemical's expertise in olefin-based raw materials and fundamental polymer science, the companies said in a joint statement. The material, known as thermoplastic elastomers or TPEs, is a rubberlike substance that, unlike the conventional vulcanized rubber, can be easily processed and recycled. TPEs are used in engineered industrial rubber and soft plastic applications in the automotive, medical, food, electrical, construction, appliance and business machine industries. Monsanto spokesman Carl Moskowitz said no dollar value has yet been placed on the venture, but he said sales are expected to top $100 million in 1990. And he said he expected the 30 to 35 percent annual growth in TPEs sales experienced by Monsanto to continue with the new company. Moskowitz said the new company, which has not yet been given a name, is to be headquartered in St. Louis. He said it will be free standing and will have its own officers and board of directors.

DOC.HEAD: Shareholders Ask Vote on Poison Pill Plan
DOC.TEXT: K mart Corp. shareholders, seeking a greater role in the governance of the nation's second-largest retailer, asked Tuesday that management give them a chance to vote on the firm's ``poison pill'' anti-takeover defense. A request that the K mart board submit the pill to a shareholder ballot was approved by a vote of 83.6 million shares to 64.1 million at the company's annual meeting. One of K mart's biggest shareholders, the State of Wisconsin Investment Board, said it does not necessarily oppose the defensive measure adopted by the K mart board of directors in May 1988. But such moves have enough impact on shareholders' interests that they should be submitted to a shareholder vote, investment board spokeswoman Betty Kepley said at the meeting. K mart's by-laws do not require that the plan win shareholder approval. The pill makes the cost of a hostile takeover prohibitively expensive by allowing the board to issue extra stock at a steep discount. With their vote Tuesday, K mart shareholders joined stockholders in other companies who are seeking a greater voice in corporate governance. Institutional shareholders like the Wisconsin investment board, are among the leaders in the growing shareholder rights movement. K mart Chairman Joseph E. Antonini said he would take the proposal before the board, although he said the request was advisory and does not compel board action. The retailer has not encountered any hostile takeover bids but adopted the measure because ``that's the way the wind was blowing,'' Antonini said at a news conference after the meeting. At the meeting, shareholders elected a slate of board-backed directors including Antonini. They defeated two other stockholder proposals, for confidentiality and third-party tabulation of shareholder votes, and for the annual election of the entire board of directors. Antonini told shareholders K mart's 6.4 percent increase in first-quarter income and 16.1 percent increase in sales were ``slightly above plan.'' K mart, the nation's No. 2 retailer after Sears, Roebuck and Co., operates the K mart discount chain as well as Waldenbooks, Payless Drug, Builder's Square, PACE membership warehouse and Sports Authority stores.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar, Gold Up
DOC.TEXT: The dollar gained ground Tuesday against most other currencies, particularly the West German mark, which remained under pressure as a result of growing political discord over that country's plans to reunite with East Germany. Gold prices ended higher in New York and in Europe after falling in Asia. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold bullion for current delivery settled at $375.60 a troy ounce, up $2.30 from late Monday. Republic National Bank in New York quoted a late bid for gold at $374.50 an ounce, up $2.15. Currency dealers said the dollar benefited from continued weakness in the West German mark amid growing concern about the future of the reunification plan. On Tuesday, Chancellor Helmut Kohl's government turned down the opposition Social Democrats' demand for alterations in a newly signed treaty on economic unity with East Germany. The Social Democrats maintain the new treaty fails to provide enough protection for East German workers and businesses. The dollar rose in Europe to 1.6685 West German marks from 1.6630 marks Monday, and to 1.67315 marks in New York from 1.66245. The dollar's value declined against the yen. In Tokyo, where the global trading day begins, the dollar closed at 152.40 yen, down from 153.25 yen Monday. It traded lower at 151.55 yen in London, and 151.25 yen in New York, down from 153.73 yen. Dealers attributed the dollar's drop against the yen largely to comments from Treasury Undersecretary David Mulford indicating that a further weakening of the dollar would be acceptable, although not necessarily a remedy to the U.S. trade deficit. The dollar was mixed against the British pound compared with Monday. Sterling bought $1.6915 in London, down from $1.6917, and $1.6930 in New York, up from $1.6875. Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Monday's quotes, included: 1.41765 Swiss francs, down from 1.4217; 5.6300 French francs, up from 5.6020; 1,228.00 Italian lire, up from 1,222.50; and 1.18735 Canadian dollars, up from 1.17715. Late dollar rates in Europe compared with Monday: 1.4175 Swiss francs, down from 1.4225; 5.6175 French francs, up from 5.6060; 1.8760 Dutch guilders, up from 1.8692; 1,225.25 Italian lire, up from 1,222.75; and 1.1907 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1793. Gold rose in London to a late bid price of $375 an ounce from $373.25 late Monday. In Zurich, gold rose to $375.35 an ounce from $373.50. Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold closed at $373.58 an ounce, down from $374.08. Silver prices increased. On New York's Comex, silver bullion for current delivery settled at $5.283 a troy ounce, up from $5.131 Monday. Silver rose in London to $5.19 an ounce from $5.14 Monday.

DOC.HEAD: Energy Prices Close Mixed on Technical Factors
DOC.TEXT: Energy futures prices settled mixed Tuesday as the market was moved by largely technical factors. The June contract for West Texas Intermediate, the benchmark grade of U.S. crude oil, fell sharply in New York Mercantile Exchange trading because it was expiring at the end of the session. The contract tumbled 58 cents to close at $17.68 a 42-gallon barrel. The July contract for crude fell 12 cents, the August contract edged 1 cent lower but subsequent months advanced. Prices for refined products traded on the exchange also were mixed. Unleaded regular gasoline for delivery in June fell 0.31 cent to 63.04 cents a gallon. The July contract also slipped lower, but later months closed higher. The June contract for home heating oil was off 0.04 cent to 51.40 cents a gallon. The July and August contracts closed higher, but the following months settled lower. Analysts said there were no news developments to affect trading. ``The market is moving under its own steam,'' said Peter Beutel, assistant director of the energy group at Elders Futures Inc., referring to investors adjusting their positions ahead of the June WTI contract's expiration. However, Beutel said, traders also remained pessimistic about the chances for reducing the current oversupply of oil. ``The perceptions are that OPEC is not going to be able to live up to its agreement'' to cut production, he said. Members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries recently agreed to production cuts, but the cartel's output has not fallen enough to move oil prices higher. In natural gas trading, the July contract fell to $1.613 per 1,000 cubic feet from $1.620 on Monday.

DOC.HEAD: Late Rally Pushes Dow Industrials to Another Record
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates with closing prices throughout.
DOC.TEXT: Fresh declines in interest rates and a late buying surge helped the stock market extend its spring rally on Tuesday, propelling the Dow Jones industrial average to its fifth record high in seven sessions. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials, which climbed 24.77 points to an all-time high on Monday, gained 7.55 points to set another record at 2,852.23. Chances for another advance were in some doubt at midday as profit-taking eroded a strong early rally but buyers appeared in the last 30 minutes of trading to give the market a lift. Advancing issues outnumbered losers by about 8 to 7 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed stocks, with 816 up, 689 down and 501 unchanged. Volume on the floor of the Big Board came to 203.35 million shares, up from 166.28 million in the previous session. Nationwide, consolidated volume in NYSE-listed issues, including trades in those stocks on regional exchanges and in the over-the-counter market, totaled 242.36 million shares. The market got an early lift from declining interest rates and a strong performance on stock markets in Tokyo and London. After the market opened, the Dow Jones industrials surged nearly 26 points higher in the first half-hour of trading before the rally stalled. By noontime, the Dow Jones industrial average was slightly below Monday's closing level and it drifted in negative territory for most of the afternoon. ``There was probably a little too much exuberance at the beginning,'' said Newton D. Zinder, a market analyst for Shearson Lehman Hutton. Bill Raftery, vice president for technical research at Smith Barney & Co., added at midday, ``This is perfectly normal profit-taking.'' The stock market has rolled up some impressive gains over the past three weeks in a rally that has been attributed mainly to declines in interest rates. Declining rates help stocks by making the potential rewards on stocks more appealing than yields on fixed-income investments. Lower rates also can improve the profit outlook for some companies by cutting their borrowing costs. In the credit markets Tuesday, yields on 30-year Treasury bonds slipped toward 8.61 percent from 8.68 percent late Monday. Nonetheless, some market watchers expect a correction in the stock market that will drive prices lower. But even small declines in stock prices appeared to draw out buying interest in the last 30 minutes of the session, lifting the market higher. ``It shows that even modest price discounts are being met by anxious buyers who have missed this three-week old rally and short sellers,'' said Alfred E. Goldman, director of technical market analysis at A.G. Edwards & Sons Inc. in St. Louis. Short-sellers are traders who establish positions based on the presumption that prices will fall; they are often drawn into the market as buyers when it becomes clear they have bet wrong and have to settle their accounts. The most actively-traded issue on the NYSE was Nova Corp. of Alberta, Canada which fell ] to 7 following a {-point gain in similarly active dealings on Monday. The company had said Monday it was selling its rubber division. Computer Associates International fell ] to 15{ after reporting earnings results that disappointed some analysts. Among widely-held stocks, Philip Morris rose { to 45, American Telephone & Telegraph lost \ to 43[ and International Business Machines rose } to 117}. Federal Express tumbled 5[ to 47 amid some apparent disappointment over April volume figures released late Monday. As measured by Wilshire Associates' index of more than 5,000 actively traded stocks, the market rose $7.036 billion, or 0.21 percent, in value. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks rose 0.30 to 195.58. Standard & Poor's industrial index rose 0.97 to 418.20, and S&P's 500-stock composite index gained 0.43 to 358.43. The NASDAQ composite index for the over-the-counter market rose 1.00 to 453.89. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index closed at 359.85, up 0.49.

DOC.HEAD: Shopping Center Sales Hit $676.2 Billion in 1989
DOC.TEXT: Retail sales in America's shopping centers reached a record $676 billion in 1989, a 7.8 percent increase over 1988, according to an industry report released Tuesday. Figures from the International Council of Shopping Centers shows there were 34,683 shopping centers in the country at the end of the year, accounting for more than 55 percent of all non-automotive retailing. The number represents an increase of 2,120 centers in the past year. But shopping center construction starts were down in 1989, with 1,529 new centers started compared to 1,951 in 1988. Center construction amounted to $7.4 billion and generated 123,000 jobs in construction-related industries. Retail sales at the centers generated $25.9 billion in state sales taxes, the ICSC reported. The centers provided employment for 9.9 million Americans _ one out of every 10 non-agricultural jobs. California showed the greatest number of shopping centers, with a total of 4,246 centers. Florida ranked second with 2,715, followed by Texas with 2,683. California led in retail sales with $81.6 billion, and in sales tax revenue with $2.9 billion. The figures were released during the annual ICSC convention, being held this week in Las Vegas. The ICSC represents some 29,000 shopping center industry trade members in 42 countries.

DOC.HEAD: Kentucky Fried Chicken Announces Expansion to Chile
DOC.TEXT: Kentucky Fried Chicken announced Tuesday it is expanding into Chile _ the country _ with the first restaurants scheduled to open there later this year. The restaurants will be located near the Chile's capital of Santiago, according to Donald Pierce, president of KFC International. Pierce said a development agreement had been signed with Chilean entrepreneurs Enrique Umbert and Gonzalo Bedoya. The project will bring to 59 the number of countries in which KFC operates or franchises nearly 8,000 restaurants, the Louisville-based company said in a news release.

DOC.HEAD: Senate Approves Return to Private Banking
DOC.TEXT: The Senate on Monday approved a constitutional change that will allow the return of private commercial banking, the government news agency Notimex said. The reform repeals the 1982 nationalization of the banking system. It eliminates a paragraph in the Constitution that reserved ownership of banking and credit services for the government. Proposed May 2 by President Carlos Salinas de Gortari and passed earlier by the Chamber of Deputies, the legislation will be sent to the country's 31 states. Approval by 16 of the state legislatures is required. The reform passed the Senate on a 52-2 vote. In the 90-minute debate, two senators from the leftist Democratic Revolutionary Party opposed the bill, arguing that it runs counter to national interests and will concentrate economic power in the hands of a few. Sen. Alfonso Martinez Dominguez of the ruling Institutional Revolutionary Party, which holds all but four of the 64 Senate seats, responded that the reforms are in response to world changes. Under the change, up to 100 percent private ownership will be allowed in the 18 commercial banks affected, but Salinas has said the government would retain stock in some commercial banks. The government also will keep numerous banks and other institutions that provide farm and development loans and other specialized services. When then-President Jose Lopez Portillo nationalized the banking system in September 1982 as he neared the end of his term, he claimed the banks were helping Mexicans send money out of the country, sinking the economy deeper into recession. In proposing the return to private banking, Salinas said the country has made sweeping changes in development policies and economic structure to emerge from the economic crisis. Since Salinas took office in December 1988, hundreds of state-owned businesses and industries have been closed or put up for sale to private interests, the country's once-heavily protected domestic markets have been opened up to foreign competition and doors have been reopened to foreign investment. Also on Monday, a Senate report recommended Mexico negotiate a free trade agreement with the United States, its largest trading partner, give high priority to trade with the Pacific Basic countries and review agreements with Japan to include new forms of cooperation and investment.

DOC.HEAD: News Corp.'s Harper Collins Unit Agrees To Sell J.B. Lippincott
DOC.TEXT: One of the nation's leading medical publishers, J.B. Lippincott Co., is being sold by News Corp. Ltd.'s book publishing affiliate to a Dutch publisher for more than $250 million. News Corp.'s Harper Collins affiliate said Monday it reached a definitive agreement to sell the Philadelphia-based Lippincott in an effort to reduce its $800 million debt and to focus on educational, religious and general books. The buyer is Wolters Kluwer NV, a publisher of professional, scientific and educational materials that is based in Amsterdam. Harper Collins announced plans to sell Lippincott and some other assets mainly in Australia a month ago. It said it hoped to raise a total of $500 million from the sales. Lippincott had revenue of about $100 million last year, and company officials said the sale price amounted to about 20 times its operating earnings. ``We felt it was a good price,'' said Robert L. Biewen, group vice president for educational and professional publishing at Harper Collins. The sale agreement followed an auction involving six bidders over several days, Harper Collins said. It did not identify the other bidders. The sale is expected to be completed by June 29 subject to regulatory approval. Wolters Kluwer earned nearly $75 million on worldwide revenue of $1 billion in 1989. Bruce Lenz, senior vice president at Wolters Kluwer US, said Tuersaday that the acquisition of Lippincott should boost to 17 percent from 10 percent the share of the worldwide company's revenues derived from the U.S. operations. Wolters Kluwer already is a major publisher for the medical community through its Raven Press and Aspen Publishers companies. Lenz said the prospective new owners hope to increase Lippincott's international sales. He said there are no plans to change any of its operations and the company intends to maintain Lippincott's base of operations in Philadelphia. Lippincott, founded in 1792, publishes a variety of materials for students, doctors, nurses, dentists and other health care professionals. Its Drug Facts and Comparisons publication is widely used by American pharmacists. Its Gower Medical Publishing division produces illustrated books for the medical profession. News Corp. bought Harper & Row Publishers, which included Lippincott, for $293 million in 1987. It subsequently bought William Collins PLC of Great Britain for $700 million and last year merged the two operations to form Harper Collins. Harper acquired the Zondervan religious publisher several years ago and Harper Collins bought Scott Foresman & Co., educational publishers, last year. The sale of Lippincott comes as News Corp., which is headed by Rupert Murdoch, has shifted its sights toward improving profitability after a buying binge that has seen it accumulate an estimated $6 billion in debt. On Monday, Murdoch vehemently denied a report in the trade publictaion Advertising Age that said he was sounding out prospective buyers for TV Guide magazine. News Corp. also owns about a dozen other magazines, TV stations, the Fox TV network, the Twentieth Century Fox film company and several newspapers and is starting a satellite TV service in Great Britain.

DOC.HEAD: Tentative Agreement Sent to Union Members
DOC.TEXT: Cincinnati Bell Telephone Co. and the Communications Workers of America said they reached a tentative agreement on a contract affecting about 2,900 installers, linemen and information operators. The three-year agreement reached Monday is being offered for ratification by CWA locals 4400 and 4401. Cincinnati Bell spokeswoman Cyndy Cantoni said the contract provides for a 7 percent wage increase over the life of the pact, a profit-sharing plan that could add 9 percent in compensation during the contract period, improvements in dental and vision insurance, a savings plan and pension plan, and a basic prepaid legal plan. ``We think we have a `win-win' situation,'' said Charles Schultze, Cincinnati Bell labor relations vice president. ``I regret that we experienced a short work stoppage. I am pleased we have a new agreement that adequately balances employee and company concerns.'' ``We always regret having to call a strike, but in this case it worked the way it is supposed to,'' said CWA representative Dodie Ditmar. ``Together we forged some creative solutions to problems we were stuck on a week ago. All in all, we are pleased with the results.'' Members of the locals will conduct a joint meeting Tuesday and, if they approve the contract, would report for work Wednesday. The union staged a rally at the company's downtown headquarters Monday. Union leaders have said the strike was sparked by Cincinnati Bell's insistence that union employees begin paying a greater share of their health insurance costs, but the company had not made any public comment about the issues in the dispute. Contract talks broke off May 13 when the two sides reached an impasse. The workers' old contract expired that day. Cincinnati Bell serves about 580,000 customers in the Cincinnati area and neighboring parts of northern Kentucky and southeastern Indiana. About 1,000 Bell managers and administrators have been working 12-hour days and six-day weeks since the walkout began in an effort to fill in for the striking employees.

DOC.HEAD: Brokerage Reportedly Will Resume Index Arbitrage for Own Account
DOC.TEXT: Kidder, Peabody & Co. has announced it would resume for its own accounts a form of program trading blamed for worsening stock market volatility, a newspaper reported. Kidder said it believed it can avoid disrupting the market with safeguards it is adopting, The New York Times said in an early edition of Tuesday's newspaper. Kidder and other Wall Street brokerages stopped employing a type of program trading known as index arbitrage after the stock market plunged last October. The strategy seeks to profit from small differences in prices between the stock and futures markets by simultaneously buying and selling big baskets of stocks and stock index futures. Kidder, a subsidiary of General Electric Co., said it wouldn't use the strategy during times of high volatility. It also said it would require that stock sales would be made as part of program trades only if the last trade on the New York Stock Exchange took place at a higher price than the previous one, and purchases would be made only if the last Big Board trade was done at a lower price than previously. ``Whatever we do will be done more slowly and we will surely do less than we would have done without the restrictions,'' Thomas F. Ryan, executive managing director of Kidder, was quoted as saying. Although other brokerages have continued to conduct program trades for clients, the only Wall Street firm to do so for its own accounts has been Bear, Stearns & Co.

DOC.HEAD: Cocoa Futures Resume Climb On Ivory Coast Supply Fears
DOC.TEXT: Cocoa futures prices seesawed to new 14-month highs Tuesday on New York's Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange amid mounting fears of supply disruptions from the Ivory Coast, the world's largest cocoa producer. On other commodity markets, precious metal futures rose; copper advanced; grains and soybeans were mostly lower; energy futures were mixed; and livestock and meat futures were mixed. Cocoa futures settled $39 to $45 higher with the contract for delivery in July at $1,491 per ton, the highest settlement of a near-month cocoa contract since March 15, 1989. Prices surged late in the session after a day of erratic price movement that followed a drop of $31 in the July contract on Monday. Cocoa futures have soared more than $250 per ton in the last two weeks as government workers in the Ivory Coast have staged a variety of demonstrations, mainly protesting wages and living conditions in the West African nation, whose economy has been crippled by last year's collapse in cocoa and coffee prices. Protests Tuesday by firefighters in the capital city of Abidjian followed demonstrations by the city's police force on Monday and by elements of the army last week. Ivory Coast dockworkers have threatened to strike June 5. ``It continues to be a very worrisome situation,'' said Arthur Stevenson, an analyst with Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. Silver futures led the precious metals higher. Analysts said there was no news to account for the surge of buying, but silver has been underpinned recently by tightening supplies and stronger world demand. Stephen Platt of Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. cited plans by photographic-equipment giants Kodak and Fuji Photo Film to build or expand plants in Eastern Europe. Silver is used in photographic film and film processing. Gold futures settled $1.90 to $2.30 higher on New York's Commodity Exchange with June at $376.40 a troy ounce; silver was 15 cents to 15.2 cents higher with May at $5.283 a troy ounce. Platinum futures settled $3.20 to $3.80 higher on the New York Mercantile Exchange with July at $504.90 a troy ounce. Energy futures ended mixed on the New York Merc ahead of the American Petroleum Institute's weekly stocks report, which showed a sharp rise in U.S. crude oil supplies. The API reported crude stocks up 4.4 million barrels in the latest week compared with trade estimates of an increase of no more than 4 million barrels. Gasoline and distillate stocks were within expectations, as was a 0.8 percent increase in refinery activity. West Texas Intermediate crude oil settled 12 cents lower to 10 cents higher with July at $18.92 a barrel; heating oil futures finished .15 cent lower to .12 cent higher with June at 51.40 cents a gallon; unleaded gasoline was .31 cent lower to .65 cent higher with June at 63.04 cents a gallon. The June crude contract expired at $17.68 a barrel, off 58 cents. Grain and soybean futures settled mixed on the Chicago Board of Trade, with some new-crop corn and soybean contracts up slightly amid fears that planting will be further delayed by rains expected next week in the Midwest. Wheat futures settled 2\ cents to 3{ cents lower with July at $3.34} a bushel; corn was 2\ cents lower to 1} cents higher with July at $2.74} a bushel; oats were { cent lower across the board with July at $1.50} a bushel; soybeans were 1} cents lower to \ cent higher with July at $6.09 a bushel. Cattle and hog futures slipped on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, reflecting perceptions that those markets have peaked after strong rallies in recent weeks. Pork bellies advanced amid speculation that a weekly exchange report would show a continued decline in bellies stored in commercial freezers outside of Chicago. But the report showed a 630,000-pound increase, prompting predictions of a lower opening Wednesday. Live cattle settled .15 cent to .45 cent lower with June at 74.37 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .15 cent to .45 cent lower with May at 85.52 cents a pound; live hogs were .08 cent to .35 cent lower with June at 66.92 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were .25 cent lower to 1.15 cents higher with May at 69.40 cents a pound.

DOC.HEAD: Bush's Son Approved Loans to Partner Who Defaulted, Regulator Says
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 1 new graf after 3rd graf pvs to UPDATE with Bush's attorney not returning call; picks up 4th graf, `Hershkowitz and ...'; ADDS 2 grafs with plans to issue subpoenas to Mowbray, other witnesses. Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: President Bush's son Neil voted as a board member of a Colorado thrift to approve $106 million in loans to a business associate who defaulted on the entire amount, a federal regulator said Tuesday. Stephen Hershkowitz, deputy director of enforcement for the Office of Thrift Supervision, revealed the amount of the loss after a House Banking Committee member pressed him to testify on Neil Bush's role in the collapse of Silverado Banking, Savings and Loan Association of Denver. Bush, 34, was to testify Wednesday before the panel examining the $1 billion collapse of the thrift in December 1988. He was a director of Silverado from 1985 to August 1988, resigning two weeks after his father received the Republican presidential nomination. Bush's attorney, James Nesland, did not return a telephone call Tuesday seeking comment on Hershkowitz's testimony. Hershkowitz and other regulators testified Tuesday that Silverado made inflated loans to developers who had to reinvest part of the money in the thrift. Thrift regulators told the committee that under the ``quid pro quo'' lending program at Silverado, developers received loans to buy buildings at inflated values set by outside appraisers. The properties' values were inflated by $270 million to $300 million over market value, they said. In exchange, developers were required to use part of the loan money to buy preferred stock in Silverado's holding company to purchase an interest in a ``loan pool'' set up by the thrift. The pool, which contained both good and bad loans, totaled around $1 billion or roughly 60 percent of Silverado's total loan portfolio. Developers who bought shares in the loan pool received interest generated by the performing loans in the pool. Examiners said Monday they believed this arrangement, set up in August 1986, was unique in the S&L industry. The panel of regulators told the banking committee that Silverado's board of directors was a ``rubber stamp'' for management. They also said insider abuse occurred at the thrift. Neil Bush had oil and gas business deals with two of Silverado's major borrowers, developers Kenneth Good and Bill Walters. Regulators have alleged that loans by Silverado to the two men were a conflict of interest for Bush, who failed to disclose the relationship to the board. Hershkowitz said Bush voted to approve loans to Walters, but did not vote on loans to Good. Rep. Frank Annunzio, D-Ill., pressed Hershkowitz on the loans after the regulator testified that Bush's role was ``no different than other outside directors'' in the collapse, except that he voted on the Walter loans without the disclosure. ``Bush had information that would be relevant to other board members and did not disclose it,'' said Hershkowitz. Hershkowitz said the loans to Walters totaled $106 million. ``Were any in default?'' asked Annunzio. ``All of them,'' Hershkowitz said. Hershkowitz said he didn't know how much of the money had been recovered and that another agency, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp., would have to sue to recover any losses. The collapse of Silverado, now operating as part of Columbia Savings, the largest thrift in Colorado, is expected to cost U.S. taxpayers as much as $1 billion. Total losses from the nationwide savings and loan crisis, which has forced the government to take over more than 400 failed institutions, are estimated at around $250 billion. Rep. Henry B. Gonzalez, D-Texas, chairman of the banking committee, said he would ask the panel to subpoena Kermit Mowbray, a former president of the Federal Home Loan Bank of Topeka, Kan. Mowbray had been scheduled to testify at Tuesday's hearing but did not appear. The committee also plans to issue subpoenas to other requested witnesses who failed to show up, said a committee spokesman who spoke on condition of anonymity. They are Good; Walters; Thomas Thompson, former district director of OTS' Topeka office; Larry Mizel, chief executive of MDC Holdings; and John R. Sullivan, chief executive officer of SDC Land Partners.

DOC.HEAD: Moody's Downgrades Credit Rating Of Nation's Largest Bank
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf to CORRECT to debt sted credit downgraded.
DOC.TEXT: Citicorp's credit rating was lowered Tuesday by another major debt-rating service, which based its decision on concerns about the quality of real estate and takeover loans at the nation's largest bank. Moody's Investors Service Inc. said it downgraded a total of $37.4 billion in debt of Citicorp, some of its subsidiaries and debt that it guarantees. The announcement came nearly one month after rival Standard & Poor's Corp. took similar action. Both credit rating firms said they were largely concerned about the effects of escalating problem real estate loans, particularly in commerical developments, given what they called Citicorp's weak earnings position and low capital levels. They also cited worries about Citicorp's large Third World debt portfolio and loans to finance takeovers. Lower credit ratings for Citicorp is regarded as general sign of weakness in the banking sector and makes it more expensive for the bank to borrow money. Last month, Citicorp reported a 56 percent drop in first-quarter earnings, mainly because of domestic real estate loan difficulties in slumping regions that are expected to worsen this year. ``Although Citicorp's real estate portfolio is geographically diverse and its underwriting standards appear to be sound, Moody's believes that Citicorp is vulnerable to the deteriorating national real estate market,'' Moody's said in a statement. A number of major banking institutions have seen their debt ratings lowered recently by Moody's and S&P because of similar problems. Citicorp said it was disappointed by Moody's action but added that it didn't expect the downgradings to significantly increase overall funding costs. In a statement, Citicorp said it was confident ``the strength of its core businesses and well-positioned global franchises will continue to provide excellent returns and growth.'' Although Citicorp's credit remains investment-grade quality, a lower rating heightens a bank's borrowing costs by prompting investors to demand higher interest to compensate for increased risk. The ratings have no effect on customer deposits. The downgradings by Moody's included Citicorp's senior debt to single-A-three from single-A-one, commercial paper to prime-two from prime-one and Citibank's senior debt to single-A-one from double-A-two. In additon, it said it lowered about $6.2 billion in structured debt guaranteed by Citicorp and Citibank letters of credit.

DOC.HEAD: Pinnacle West Rejects Fourth Offer From PacifiCorp
DOC.TEXT: Pinnacle West Capital Corp. directors on Tuesday rejected a $1.82 billion cash offer from PacifiCorp, saying the Northwest utility giant didn't offer enough for the parent of Arizona Public Service Co. It was the fourth time Pinnacle West directors have rejected a PacifiCorp bid for the holding company itself or for its utility subsidiary. Pinacle West Chairman Richard Snell said the board also turned down a $500 million offer by the Salt River Project utility to buy part of Arizona Public Service's service territory in the Phoenix area. Snell said Salt River Project's offer, made Friday, was too low based on the annual revenues from the 166,000 customers involved. Arizona Public Service is the flagship subsidiary of Phoenix-based Pinnacle West and has been its only profitable operation for two years. PacifiCorp, based in Portland, Ore., said last week its fourth offer was its last. But in a statement after the rejection, Verl R. Topham, PacifiCorp's executive vice president, said the company may now make an offer to Pinnacle West's shareholders. ``Shareholders of Pinnacle West have been told by their management not to expect dividends for at least the next three years,'' Topham said. ``We believe shareholders ... see the significant value of our offer and support the merger proposal.'' PacifiCorp, which owns Pacific Power & Light and Utah Power & Light, has begun an advertising campaign here to solicit support from shareholders and Arizona Public Service ratepayers. Pinnacle West's annual meeting takes place here Wednesday. It was expected to be raucous even before the takeover rejection. After posting a $676 million loss from discontinued operations by its former MeraBank subsidiary, Pinnacle West reported a $551.4 million net loss in 1989. Its common stock dividend was eliminated in October. Snell said PacifiCorp's $21-per-share offer _ $8.25 higher than the stock price at the time _ did not ``reflect the value of this company.'' Pinnacle West shares fell 12{ cents to close at $15.87{ Tuesday in New York Stock Exchange trading. PacifiCorp shares fell 25 cents to close at $21.75. ``More importantly, this is not the time for us to sell this company,'' Snell added. He said it would take two to three years to win regulatory approval for the Oregon company to acquire Pinnacle West, which also owns the SunCor Development, El Dorado Investment and Malapai Resources companies. Shareholders would not receive their money until approval was won, Snell said, and by then, ``Pinnacle West's business strategies will have significantly increased both equity and the intrinsic value of the company.'' Snell said an attempt by PacifiCorp to take over Pinnacle West through stockholder proxies would lead to a long fight. He said his company's outlook has grown increasingly more positive. He said Pinnacle West was close to selling Malapai Resources, recently closed the sale of The Wigwam resort and anticipated a turnaround in the Arizona economy. But the major factors supporting a rosier outlook are the resolution of its ill-fated ownership of MeraBank, which lost more than $400 million in two years before the government took it over Jan. 31, and the prospect of better operations at the Palo Verde nuclear generating plant, Snell said. Malfunctions have kept most of the $9.3 billion, three-reactor power complex out of operation since March 1989.

DOC.HEAD: Senate Panel Votes for Product Liability Law Changes
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Recasts lead; SUBS 7th graf to CLARIFY breakdown of damages payments under proposed bill; UPDATES to include prospects in Judiciary Committee and companion House bill. Also moving on general news wire. ^By DENISE CABRERA
DOC.TEXT: Proponents of a federal law that might make it more difficult for victims of defective products to collect damages overcame a major obstacle Tuesday when a key committee voted to approve the proposal. Sen. Ernest Hollings, D-S.C., chairman of the Commerce, Science and Transportation Committee, and consumer subcommittee chairman Sen. Richard Bryan, D-Nev., both opposed the bill. But backers picked up support from other Democrats in the 13-7 vote. ``This is what we never had before. This is what is new,'' said Victor Schwartz, an attorney for business and industry supporters of the legislation, who said the support from Sen. Lloyd Bentsen was especially important. ``This is very bipartisan now,'' he said. Congress has tried to develop a federal product liability law since the 1970s, and President Bush made it an administration legislative priority in his State of the Union address. The bill would create a uniform standard for imposing punitive damages in product liability lawsuits and establish a two-year statute of limitations for most product liability claims. Claims by workers injured by durable goods such as factory machinery would have a 25-year statute of limitations. The measure would allow separate trials or settlements of punitive damages and compensatory damages and allow companies to pay some non-economic damages in proportion to their responsibility for harm. It would also exempt from punitive damage lawsuits products approved by the Food and Drug Administration and the Federal Aviation Administration. Opponents say the bill would needlessly pre-empt state law and would limit the ability to collect for deaths and injuries that result from industry negligence or irresponsibility. Backers of the legislation argue that variations in liability laws from state to state offer potentially limitless damages and hinder product development and American competitiveness. The bill will not go immediately go to the Senate because it has been referred to the Judiciary Committee. Proponents say the bill's prospects there are uncertain. However, there is a companion bill, HR-2700, in the House. Schwartz said some opponents may attempt a filibuster if the bill reaches the Senate floor for debate. Besides Bentsen, D-Texas, Democratic senators voting to report the bill favorably out of committee were: Daniel Inouye of Hawaii, Nebraska's James Exon, Jay Rockefeller of West Virginia and Charles S. Robb of Virginia. Republicans voting for the bill were: Wisconsin's Robert W. Kasten Jr., John Danforth of Missouri, Larry Pressler of South Dakota, Ted Stevens of Arkansas, John McCain of Arizona, Conrad Burns of Montana, Slade Gorton of Washington and Trent Lott of Mississippi. Joining Hollings and Bryan in voting against the bill were: Sens. Wendell Ford, D-Ky.; John Kerry, D-Mass.; Al Gore, D-Tenn.; John Breaux, D-La. and Robert Packwood, R-Ore.

DOC.HEAD: Canadian Family Pushes On In Quest For Armstrong
DOC.TEXT: A Canadian investor family said Tuesday it will continue to pursue its interests in Armstrong World Industries Inc. despite setbacks at last month's company meeting. The investment company owned by the Belzbergs filed notice with the Securities and Exchange Commission this week that it bought an additional 10,000 shares of Armstrong stock on May 15. The Belzbergs now own 11.69 percent of Armstrong's 47.15 million shares, said family spokesman Ned Scharff. ``It's really a small increment,'' he said. ``But it shows they are buying.'' The SEC filing did not describe the family's intentions for the company, Scharff said. ``In this latest filing, they say they might buy, they might sell, push for a merger, find a partner,'' he said. ``They just listed about anything possible.'' Armstrong spokesman John Scheldrup said, ``This filing isn't anything new. Everything they said today they've said before.'' The Belzbergs and Armstrong have been waging a bitter, protracted proxy fight in full-page newspaper ads and in the courts. The family wanted revisions in the company's articles of incorporation to be placed before the shareholders at the annual meeting April 30. The floor covering company refused, charging that the changes apparently were intended to smooth the way for a takeover by eroding the board of directors' authority. The Belzbergs were not able to gain a court order in time to force the revisions to be placed before the shareholders. The matter is still in litigation. The Belzbergs gained just one seat on the 13-member board at the April 30 meeting. The proxy fight prompted Pennsylvania to enact the nation's toughest anti-takeover law in April. The measure would garnish corporate raiders' short-term profits on takeover attempts, constrict their voting rights and preserving labor contracts if ownership changes hands.

DOC.HEAD: Automaker Says It Will Keep Aerospace-Defense Subsidiary
DOC.TEXT: Chrysler Corp. is dropping a plan to sell its remaining defense and aviation electronics business because it didn't receive high enough bids, company officials said Tuesday. The nation's third-largest automaker put Chrysler Technologies Corp. on the block in December and sold its largest operation, corporate jet manufacturer Gulfstream Aerospace Corp., in February for $825 million. Chrysler had said it also sought buyers for the remaining Chrysler Technologies units as part of a move to concentrate on making cars and trucks. Those units are Electrospace Systems Inc., a maker of defense and electronics products and systems bought in 1987 for $367 million, and Airborne Systems Inc., formed in January 1989 by combining military aviation operations of Gulfstream and Electrospace. The company received inquiries ``but the values didn't approximate what we felt these companies were worth to the shareholders,'' Chrysler Technologies spokesman John Stellman said. ``Chrysler had stated that if it couldn't get a good price, it wouldn't sell,'' said analyst Ron Glantz of Dean Witter Reynolds in San Francisco. Although changes in world politics may have created uncertainties about defense spending for tactical weapons, Chrysler Technologies Chairman Paul E. Wright said the company had a 12 percent increase in orders in 1989 for the electronics, surveillance and intelligence-oriented equipment in which it specializes. Chrysler Technologies employs about 3,500 people in Texas, Alabama and Virginia.

DOC.HEAD: United's Unions Seek Second Investment Banker for Buyout
DOC.TEXT: Unions at United Airlines are negotiating to hire a second investment banker to help secure financing for their planned buyout of parent company UAL Corp., a union representative said Tuesday. United Employee Acquisition Corp. wants to hire Goldman, Sachs & Co. to supplement work being done by Salomon Inc., one of the advisers to the pilots' union. The union group's contract to buy UAL will lapse if financing for the $4.38 billion deal is not obtained by Aug. 10. If the group obtains financing it would have until the end of the year to close the deal. ``This is a very large deal and there's a desire to get as much firepower as we can possibly muster,'' said Steven Matthews, a spokesman for the union group. ``It would be unusual for a deal of this size and complexity to go forward with only one investment bank,'' Matthews said in a telephone interview. The group includes the Air Line Pilots Association, the International Association of Machinists, the Association of Flight Attendants and non-contract workers. Under the deal approved April 6 by UAL's board, United's pilots would own 37.9 percent of the company's stock, Machinists would own 35.7 percent, non-contract employees would get 14.3 percent and flight attendants 12 percent. The union group has proposed overall employee wage and benefit cuts totaling $2 billion over five years to offset buyout costs. Investor skepticism about the ability of the union group to borrow the $4 billion needed to complete the buyout has contributed to a steady slide in UAL's stock price from $163.50 the day the deal was signed to as low as $150.37{. The stock fell $2.25 Tuesday to close at $151.50 on the New York Stock Exchange. Skepticism has been fueled in part by the union group's inability to find a new chief executive officer to replace UAL Chairman Stephen M. Wolf. Matthews refused to comment on the search for a CEO but said he is confident financing will be secured.

DOC.HEAD: VMS Funds Report First-Quarter Profits
DOC.TEXT: Eight investment funds spawned by troubled VMS Realty Partners said Tuesday they returned to profitablity in the first quarter after reporting net losses last year because of their former parent's problems. The funds also said they may try to take possession of some VMS properties. The five real-estate investment trusts and three publicly traded trusts made no additions to their loan-loss reserves in the first quarter, they said in separate statements. But each of the funds reported a decline in earnings compared with the first quarter of 1989, mainly because of provisions made to cover the possibility that they will be unable to collect accrued and unpaid interest from VMS. The funds have severed their ties to Chicago-based VMS, a limited partnership syndicator that disclosed a severe liquidity crisis last year. The funds had raised $1.1 billion from the public and lent it to VMS to invest in real-estate development. In February, VMS stopped making loan payments to the funds and four VMS officers resigned. VMS's troubles resulted partly from the softening real estate market and from changes in the federal tax law in 1986 that made real estate investments less attractive. Xerox Corp. holds a 25 percent interest in VMS. The eight funds said they were exploring the possibility of taking possession, through various means including foreclosure, of properties VMS put up as collateral. They said they have retained four firms _ Dean Witter Reynolds Inc., Cushman & Wakefield Inc., Draper & Kramer and Grubb & Ellis _ to provide real estate and financial advice. ``Representation by these well-regarded companies demonstrates faith in our efforts to enhance the value of the funds,'' said Leonard G. Levine, president of all eight funds and a former VMS vice president. VMS had no immediate comment on the funds' statement, said Kathy Zajicek, secretary to VMS Executive Vice President Scott Lager. The funds are VMS Mortgage Investment Fund; VMS Mortgage Investors Limited Partnership; VMS Mortgage Investors L.P. II; VMS Mortgage Investors L.P. III; VMS Short Term Income Trust; VMS Hotel Investment Fund; VMS Strategic Land Trust; and VMS Strategic Land Fund II.

DOC.HEAD: Soviets Predict Their Energy Exports Are Likely To Fall Behind
DOC.TEXT: Two Soviet officials predicted their nation's energy exports to Western and Eastern Europe would drop in the next few years because Soviet oil, natural gas and coal are becoming too expensive to produce. Petroleum and gas exports could drop to as little as one third of their 1988 levels, according to Alexander A. Arbatov, a member of the committee for natural resources of the Soviet Academy of Sciences, and Foreign Ministry official Eugene M. Khartukov. In that year, the Soviet Union exported the energy equivalent of 447 million tons of coal, the two officials said in a joint written presentation at the seventh Petroleum and Gas Conference here. ``Energy exports have ceased bringing in ... golden eggs'' for the Soviet economy, the paper said. The Soviets have earned a significant amount of hard currency by exporting energy to Western Europe, particularly West Germany, Italy and Austria. Eastern Europe relies almost exclusively on the Soviets for energy imports. The paper gave no specific reason for the rising cost of energy production. Western experts, however, have said that Moscow has failed to invest in modern equipment and is being forced to drill for oil and gas on remote Siberian locations as more easily accessible sources become depleted. In 1981, the Soviet Union made 7.1 times as much from the sale of a barrel of crude petroleum as it cost to produce the oil, the two officials' paper said. By next year, that ratio will have fallen to 1.8, the paper said, adding similar declines in profitability were expected for natural gas and coal.

DOC.HEAD: Amid Hype And Humor, Microsoft Unveils Its Newest Windows
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 1 graf after 16th graf pvs, `That strategy ...,' to CLARIFY which computers can use Windows. Picks up 17th graf pvs, `This is ...'.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto NY25
DOC.TEXT: With smoke, loud music and MTV-style videos, Microsoft Corp. Tuesday formally introduced its new version of Windows, a software product designed to make IBM personal computers and their clones as easy to use as Macintosh computers. Bill Gates, Microsoft's 34-year-old chairman, told hundreds of financial analysts, journalists and others at a New York theater that Windows is ``a major milestone in the history of the PC industry.'' Many analysts agree. They say Windows could provide the strongest challenge yet to Apple Computer Inc.'s popular Macintosh by grafting its user-friendly operations onto International Business Machines Corp. personal computers and compatible models _ machines that are notorious for their arcane commands. Gates told the standing-room-only crowd _ and, by satellite hookup, audiences in six other cities nationwide _ that his Redmond, Wash.-based software company will spend $10 million promoting Windows over the next six months. He called that a record for the software industry. Microsoft plans to mail 400,000 demonstration copies of the $149 software to personal computer users, Gates told the audience after a sound-and-light show that mixed hype, humor and product demonstrations. More than 30 personal computer companies have said they will include Windows with their machines, and dozens of software companies are making applications programs compatible with the new version of Windows. Windows could provide a major boost to Microsoft, which already dominates the personal computer software industry. Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. projects Windows and related products will reap nearly $500 million in revenues for Microsoft in the fiscal year that starts July 1. ``I think it's the most significant announcement since the introduction of DOS,'' said Rick Sherlund, an analyst at Goldman, Sachs & Co., referring to the operating system for IBM personal computers developed by Microsoft. ``This delivers a lot of the capabilities that normally have been associated with the Mac to the PC,'' he said, referring to IBM machines and their knockoffs. The loser, of course, could be Apple. A Windows-equipped IBM clone could sell for as little as half the price of a Macintosh. Apple's stock dropped a total of $2 a share Friday and Monday, after adjusting for a dividend, but rose $1.87{ a share Tuesday to close at $41.37{ in national over-the-counter trading. Microsoft shares jumped $1.25 Tuesday to close at $71.50 in over-the-counter trading, after rising a total of $5.50 Friday and Monday in anticipation of the announcement. Apple, based in Cupertino, Calif., is expected to announce a lower-priced Macintosh later this year and is working on a more powerful version of its operating system. Most computer experts also say the Macintosh retains some advantages over a Windows-equipped IBM machine, expecially for intensive graphics-based uses. Microsoft, for its part, says it will not target Macintosh users or potential users, instead pitching Windows to users of IBM machines and compatible models. That strategy is due in part to the fact that 85 percent of the computer market is composed of IBM machines or clones, compared with the Macintosh's 7 percent share. Windows works on computers using Intel Corp.'s 80286, 80386 or 80486 microprocessors. That encompasses about 20 million computers in use, out of about 50 million that use the DOS operating system, Microsoft says. This is Microsoft's third version of Windows. The first version, introduced in 1985, and a later enhancement both failed to impress computer experts. Windows is product known as a graphical user interface. It shields computer users from complex, typed commands by replacing them with on-screen pictures called icons and a hand-held control device called a mouse. Windows also expands a computer's useable memory capacity and allows users to keep several applications programs active at once by running them in sections of the screen called windows.

DOC.HEAD: FBI Agents Search Northrop Corp. Plants In California
rkdsm1rkdjsa2
DOC.TEXT: FBI agents on Tuesday searched two Northrop Corp. plants where fuselage parts are built for the Navy's FA-18 fighter-bomber. Neither Northrop nor the FBI would comment on the purpose of the raids. The government sued the company last month alleging fraudulent billing on the FA-18 program. The raids were the latest in a series of criminal and civil actions that have plagued the aerospace company over the past few years. Northrop spokesman Ron Owens confirmed the searches of plants in suburban Hawthorne and El Segundo. ``We are working with them in their search, and that is all that I can comment upon,'' Owens said. FBI Special Agent Fred Reagan said he could not comment on the raids, although he admitted, ``Everyone seems to know about them.'' McDonnell Douglas is the prime contractor for the carrier-based FA-18. Northrop assembles the center and aft sections of the plane as a subcontractor under what is known as a sole-source, fixed-price agreement. That means only one contractor is considered qualified to do the work and it is not subject to competitive bidding. In April the Justice Department sued Northrop, claiming the company had fraudulently fattened bills submitted to the Navy for work on the FA-18. Damages were estimated at $25 million by an attorney familiar with the case, and the recovery could be treble because the suit was originally filed by a former Northrop employee under the federal false claims act. The Justice Department intervened in the case and took over the litigation after apparently deciding not to file criminal charges as part of a deal with Northrop last February. Under that deal, Northrop pleaded guilty to 34 criminal fraud counts and agreed to pay a $17 million fine for alleged falsification of tests on a stabilization control for the Marine AV-8B Harrier jet fighter and for the MX missile guidance mechanism. The Justice Department lawsuit claimed Northrop failed to disclose savings it made from a new manufacturing method for the FA-18 parts. The parts are made from composite materials and formed in a process that requires high pressure, heat and vacuum. The original suit was filed in 1987 by former Northrop contract and pricing division manager Eldon L. Janssen, who claimed he learned of the alleged deceitful pricing in the course of his duties. Despite the February plea-bargain agreement, Northrop remains open to several investigations and lawsuits. The Justice Department sued Northrop for $5 million over the AV-8B tests despite the criminal pleading. Among Northrop's other legal problems: _Allegations of $20 billion in overcharges on the B-2 bomber. FBI agents in February raided Northrop's B-2 parts plant in Pico Rivera. _Grand juries in Los Angeles and Honolulu are looking at whether Northrop made political payoffs to South Korea. _A Texas grand jury is looking into allegations that Northrop cheated the government on a program auctioning property seized by the U.S. Customs Service. _Former Northrop employees are engaged in a ``whistleblower'' lawsuit that mirrors the government charges on the MX missile guidance system. Their attorney said he is seeking between $20 million and $30 million in damages.

DOC.HEAD: UAW Delegates Kill COLA for Retirees
DOC.NOTE: Eds: DELETES 16th graf pvs, `The COLA ...' to reflect convention has ended.
DOC.TEXT: Delegates to a United Auto Workers bargaining strategy convention Tuesday killed an effort that would have required bargainers to seek cost-of-living protection for the union's 446,000 retirees. By knocking down a procedural move to have the convention consider a resolution from a Flint, Mich., local, delegates supported UAW President Owen Bieber's plea to keep negotiating committees unfettered. After winning the vote Bieber engineered a quick end to the convention, which originally was scheduled to conclude Wednesday, with delegates adopting dozens of resolutions directing negotiators this summer. At a news conference later, Bieber said the union would seek inflation protection for its 446,000 retirees. ``We'll have the whole six miles out there,'' he said, meaning all options to protect the income of pensioners will be considered. The UAW isn't required to bargain for retirees. But in the past, the union has negotiated lump-sum payments for retirees to counter inflation. A COLA for retirees proposal could be extremely costly for the Big Three automakers, the companies and the union have said. The union estimates that such a provision could cost more than $1 billion a year for the Big Three. Contract talks open in July with each of the Big Three. Automakers and UAW executives alike have warned that the cost of a sliding inflation protection instead of a lump-sum payment could result in reductions in other benefits. Despite that, the COLA for retirees issue has been gaining steam in recent months. On Tuesday, after about an hour's debate, a move by delegate Alex Wassell to bring a resolution from Flint calling for COLA for retirees to the convention floor failed overwhelmingly in a show-of-hands vote. During the debate, Bieber repeatedly told delegates that although a separate resolution doesn't include specific references to COLA, negotiators would bring the matter to bargaining tables at General Motors Corp., Ford Motor Co. and Chrysler Corp. ``I do not believe that there is one single person in this convention hall, and certainly your president, who reads that language to preclude our attempting to get COLA,'' Bieber said. That wasn't good enough for Wassell of Local 1776 at GM's Willow Run, Mich., assembly plant. ``I was trying to shoehorn Bieber into getting the language,'' he said. ``I'm not satisfied because Bieber may indeed not make that a top priority.'' In his opening address on Monday, Bieber listed five major bargaining goals _ job security, pension improvements, higher wages, protection of health-care benefits and responsible management by the automakers. There was little debate during the first two days of the convention, with the exception of retirees' inflation protection. ``Brother Bieber said it does not preclude fighting for COLA on pensions. I believe that's not half strong enough,'' said Mike Nuckolls of Local 1999 in Oklahoma City. ``There is one issue we can't let them wimp out on,'' he said. ``We need COLA for pensions.'' Also Tuesday, UAW members voted overwhelmingly to combine three of the union's 15 U.S. regions into two. The merger would occur only when one of the three regional directors leaves office for any reason. The three regions _ 2, 2A and 2B in Ohio, West Virginia and parts of Pennsylvania _ have just under 113,000 members. The consolidation reflects the shrinking size of the union, which has dropped from a high of about 1.5 million members in the 1970s to about 1 million now.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Slips, Share Prices Advance Moderately in Early Trading
DOC.TEXT: The dollar slipped in early trading against the yen Wednesday and share prices rose strongly on the Tokyo Stock Exchange. The dollar started trading at 151.65 yen, down 0.75 yen from Tuesday's close of 152.40 yen. It finished at 152.25 yen in New York overnight, down from 153.73 yen on Monday. The yen's strength bolstered prices in Japan's stock and bond markets. The Nikkei Stock Average of 225 selected issues gained 241.56 points, or 0.75 percent, moving to 32,179.86 points in the first 15 minutes of trading. The index rose 173.25 points Tuesday. The benchmark No. 119 10-year Japanese government bond rose to 87.69 points from Tuesday's close at 87.45. That pushed the yield down to 7.025 percent from 7.075 percent. Currency dealers said the dollar's low opening followed its overnight decline against the yen in New York, even though the U.S. currency gained ground against most European currencies there. Kouhei Kuroda, a dealer with Fuji Bank, said the dollar was bought temporarily during early trading, but failed to rise as far as the 152-yen level. ``There's still a sentiment of yen strength against the dollar in the market,'' Kuroda said.

DOC.HEAD: Federal Grand Jury Charges Four Companies
DOC.TEXT: Justice Department prosecutors have charged that four companies conspired to fix prices nationwide on heavy-duty hinges. A federal grand jury indictment returned Tuesday in St. Louis said the companies and executives of three of the firms violated antitrust law, the St. Louis Post-Dispatch reported. The conspiracy began as early as April 1986 and lasted for at least two years, the indictment alleges. Companies indicted were Hager Hinge Co. of St. Louis, The Stanley Works of New Britain, Conn., McKinney Products Co. of Scranton, Pa., and Lawrence Brothers Inc. of Sterling, Ill. A Justice Department lawyer working on the case, P. Terry Lubeck, said Hager has agreed to plead guilty. Lubeck said Hager officials began cooperating with authorities soon after the investigation began two years ago. A Hager official declined to comment. Stanley said in a release it would plead not guilty. The one-count indictment said the defendants and others conspired to ``suppress competition by fixing prices'' on architectural hinges sold nationwide. Architectural hinges are used to hang heavy doors in offices and public buildings. The companies conspired to reduce list prices for architectural hinges but cut discounts to customers, the indictment said. ``They lowered their list prices and lowered their discounts so that the net effect was to increase prices,'' said Lubeck, adding that the scheme netted ``many, many, many millions of dollars.'' Also indicted were John A. Lawrence, chairman of Lawrence, and two Stanley officials _ Richard G. Martin, president of the Stanley Hardware Division and John F. Hollfelder, a vice president of sales who has since retired. ``The Stanley Works and Mr. Martin ... intend to plead not guilty,'' Stanley spokesman Ronald F. Gilrain said in a release. ``The company and Mr. Martin believe that they have meritorious defenses and they will defend themselves vigorously against the charges.'' Also charged was Robert A. Haversat, president of McKinney until September 1986, the indictment said. Haversat is now president of Esstar Holdings Inc., the parent of McKinney, Lubeck said. David B. Gibson, a marketing manager who reported to Haverset at McKinney and is now its president, also was indicted. No Hager officials were charged. Lubeck declined to specify what prompted the inquiry. If convicted, maximum penalties against each company would be a $1 million fine, twice the gain from the crime or twice the loss to victims _ whichever is greater. The company executives could be sentenced to three years in prison and fined $250,000.

DOC.HEAD: Australian Financier Bond Has 10 Weeks to Sell Brewery Assets
DOC.NOTE: Eds: All dollar figures are U.S.
DOC.TEXT: Financier Alan Bond's beleagured company said it still will face debts of about $4.03 billion even after its planned sale of its major cash producer, its Australian brewing operations. On Tuesday, the National Australia Bank gave Bond Corp. Holdings Ltd. 10 weeks to complete the sale of its local brewing assets or repay in full the brewery's debt of $608 million by the end of September. Bond Corp. director Peter Lucas said Wednesday that the expected sale of the breweries to Bell Resources Ltd. will not change the group's consolidated debt because it is an internal deal. Bell is owned 58 percent by Bond Corp. ``We've still got a big program in front of us, and a long way to go until we are in the clear,'' Lucas said. The National Australia Bank decision requires Bond Corp. to surrender control of Bond Brewing, the producer of Tooheys, Castlemaine XXXX and Swan beers. Bond Corp. and Bell Resources said in separate statements that Bell would buy the breweries in a deal valued at $1.40 billion. Bell will not pay for the breweries, instead receiving $243 million owed by Bond Corp. from inter-company debts. Published reports Wednesday in several Australian newspapers suggested that the deal will allow New Zealand brewer Lion Nathan Ltd. to re-open negotiations over buying a half share in the breweries as it originally planned to do last September. ``The latest delopment turns the focus back to Bell Resources, with whom we have maintained a strong dialogue,'' Lion Nathan chief executive Doug Myers said. Also Tuesday, Bond Corp. agreed to cut its voting rights in Bell Resources to 25 per cent _ ahead of reducing its stake to that level by next March _ and pass managerial control of the breweries to accountancy firm KPMG Peat Marwick in the interim. Under the terms of the agreement, Bond Brewing does not need to repay its loans from the bank syndicate until July 1, 1991 if the brewery sale is completed by this July 31. Otherwise, the National Australia Bank-led syndicate retains the right to liquidate Bond Brewing if the debts are not repaid by September 30.

DOC.HEAD: Hammer Defends Occidental Building Museum in His Name
DOC.TEXT: Occidental Petroleum Corp. Chairman Armand Hammer told skeptical shareholders Tuesday it was a legitimate corporate expense for Occidental to spend $98 million to set up a museum for his art collection. Hammer, 92, joking that his new heart pacemaker is guaranteed for eight years, said the museum will breed goodwill as displaying his collection around the world has done. That will help business, ultimately boosting profits and the stock price, he said at Occidental's annual meeting at the Santa Monica Civic Auditorium. The Armand Hammer Museum and Cultural Center is under construction beside the company's headquarters building in Los Angeles and is scheduled to open in November. Three groups of shareholders sued after learning that Occidental was funding the museum. Plans call for the company to donate $60 million to build the Armand Hammer Museum of Art and Cultural Center and $38 million to endow it. That doesn't sit well with shareholders such as Geneva Fulton, who stepped to the microphone and told the board of directors: ``I don't believe as a stockholder that we should have to pay for Dr. Hammer's museum.'' Hammer replied that his art collection was appraised recently at $400 million and included a van Gogh painting, ``Hospital at St. Remy,'' that he estimated might be worth more than $100 million at auction. ``I am surrendering this without any reward to myself or compensation,'' he said. ``For one reason, you can't take it with you,'' he said to laughter. ``The second reason is, I think it's good for Occidental and for you as shareholders.'' Hammer decided to build the museum after reneging on a promise to donate his collection to the Los Angeles County Museum of Art. He backed out of that deal after the museum refused some of his demands, including taking the names of other donors off the building. Not all shareholders were critical of the museum plan and Hammer. ``He's an older man ... let him live in peace and contentment, and the shareholders should mind their own business,'' a gray-haired woman said at the end of a rambling speech of praise. ``I love you dear, and you should live forever.'' Hammer, noting that he'd heard recently of a 90-year-old woman marrying a 93-year-old man, replied: ``Send me your name and telephone number.'' He met briefly with her after the meeting.
